Government of India in consultation with the Reserve Bank. Much of the routine work of exchange control is delegated to certain commercial banks, which act as authorized dealers permitted to buy and sell foreign exchange for specified purposes under regulations laid down by the Reserve Bank. With respect to direct investments in India, all collaboration proposals, with or without equity participation, are reviewed by the For- eign Investment Board. Under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, the general or specific approval of the Reserve Bank is necessary for the continuance of commercial, industrial, and trading activities in India of companies with more than 40 per cent nonresident inter- est or for the establishment by them in India of any branch, office, or other place of business for carrying out any such activity. The Reserve Bank's prior permis- sion is also required by nonresidents, noncitizens, non- banking companies not incorporated under Indian law, and Indian companies with more than 40 per cent nonresident interest for acting or accepting appointment as agents or technical advisers of any person or com- pany in India in the trading or commercial transactions of such persons or companies. Import and export licenses are issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Prescription of Currency India has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under cur- rent U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, countries are divided into two groups: Bilateral Account countries (see footnote 2) and External Account countries (all other countries); the former group is also referred to as the Rupee Payment Area and the latter as the Gen- eral Currency Area. Payments to and from Bilateral Account countries must be settled in Indian rupees through the appropriate clearing account. Payments to 14 External Account countries3 may be made in rupees to the credit of the account of a resident of any country in this group or in the currency of any country or territory in this subgroup. Payments to all other External Account countries may be made in (1) the currency of the country concerned; ( 2) the currency of any country of the subgroup men- tioned; or (3) rupees to the account of a resident of any 3 The countries listed are Austria, Belgium-Luxembourg, Canada, Denmark and the Faroe Islands, French Franc Area, Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands Monetary Area, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, United Kingdom, and United States and territories under U.S. sovereignty. 223 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA country in the External Account group.4 Receipts from 14 External Account countries (see footnote 3) may be obtained in rupees from the account of a bank in any External Account country, or in the currency of any territory in this subgroup. Receipts f rom all other Exter- nal Account countries may be obtained in (1) the cur- rency of the country concerned; ( 2) the currency of any territory in the subgroup mentioned; or (3) rupees f rom the account of a bank in any External Account country. Notwithstanding the foregoing, special rules may be applicable in respect of Afghanistan, Burma, Egypt, the Sudan, and exports under lines of credit extended by the Government of India to the governments of certain foreign countries. In addition, payments to, and receipts f rom, member countries of the Asian Clearing Union other than Nepal (i.e., Bangladesh, Iran, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their prod- ucts) may, but need not, be effected in Asian monetary units through the Asian Clearing Union. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of Indians (w i th the exception of cer- tain accounts held by persons of Indian nationality or origin who are or have been nonresidents) and of Nepa- lese and Bhutanese nationals resident in Nepal and Bhu tan, as well as the accounts of offices and branches of Indian, Nepalese, and Bhutanese firms, companies, or other organizations in Nepal and Bhu tan are treated as resident accounts.5 Accounts related to all other for- eign countries are treated as nonresident accounts. The treatment of these accounts distinguishes between those of banks and of others. The accounts of banks are classified in two groups corresponding to the division of countries for prescrip- tion of currency purposes, i.e., Bilateral Accounts and External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with payments for imports, interest, dividends, and other authorized purposes, with authorized transfers from the nonresident accounts of private firms (including banks) or persons, with proceeds f rom sales of the currency of the country or monetary area of the account holder, and with proceeds f rom sales of the currencies of External Account countries. They may be debited for payments for exports and for other payments to residents of India. These accounts may also be debited for transfers to nonresident accounts of persons and firms (including b ank s ), provided that both the transferor and transferee 4 All remittances by nationals of the People's Republic of China to any coun try outside India and all remittances to the People's Republic of China by any person resident in India, whether for personal or t r ade purposes, were stopped with effect f rom November 3, 1962. All pay- men ts due to the People's Republic of China are requ ired to be credited to blocked rupee accounts. The prior approval of the Reserve Bank is requ ired for all remittances to Pakistan and Rhodesia. Payments for transactions relating to t rade with Pakistan that is conducted on a government-to-government basis or through government-controlled trade corporations of the two countries are allowed under a special bank ing arrangement. 5 However, residents of Nepal have to obtain their fore ign exchange requirements f rom the Nepal Rastra Bank. 224 accounts are of External Account countries. Transfers may be made f rom External Accounts to other External Accounts. All other entries on Bilateral and External Accounts, with the exception of debits by way of pay- ments to residents, require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Ordinary nonresident accounts of private individuals or firms may be credited, without prior approval, for payment of dividends and interest on securities, shares, and deposits; refunds of amounts previously debited or overcharged; proceeds of remittances in appropriate for- eign currency or transfers f rom appropriate nonresident banks' rupee accounts (see section on Prescription of Currency, above); proceeds from checks issued by the Life Insurance Corporation in respect of maturity or death claims and surrender value of policies held by nonresidents, provided that the Corporation certifies that premiums had been received in India in an approved manner and that actuarial reserves are held in India; refunds permitted by the income tax authorities; pen- sions due from the Central Government or any State Government; withdrawals or loans f rom, and maturity proceeds of, the Public Provident Fund, where the account holder is an Indian national or a person of Indian origin; and proceeds of checks, provided that the aggregate of such credits during a month does not exceed Rs 2,000 and no individual credit is in excess of Rs 750. Where the nonresident account holder is an Indian na t iona l, ma tur i ty proceeds of all types of securities as well as sales proceeds of securities sold on stock exchanges in India and the repurchase price of units issued by the Unit Trust of India may be freely credited to his account. Where the account holder (in the case of a jo int account, any of the account holders) is a foreign national, authorized dealers may freely credit the sale and maturity proceeds of all types of securities and the repurchase price of units, provided that the securities had been originally purchased either out of funds held in the account or by remittance from abroad, and in the case of sales proceeds, that the sale was made on the stock exchange. Sales proceeds of shares owned by the nonresident account holder, whether he is an Indian or a foreign national, may be freely credited to his account if the shares had been sold with the approval of the Reserve Bank. Ordinary private nonresident accounts, as well as blocked accounts maintained by persons of Indian nationality or origin who are resident abroad, with a balance of Rs 50,000 or less may be freely debited for local payments. Other ordinary private nonresident accounts may be debited without prior approval for such items as payments for premiums on life insurance policies of the account holder or his dependents; all taxes due f rom the account holder in India; contribu- tions to the National Defence Fund, the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund, or any government-sponsored charity; allowances not exceeding Rs 1,000 a month to relatives and dependents in India; investments in Indian ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Government securities and in units issued by the Unit Trust of India; and for checks up to Rs 1,000 a week drawn in favor of beneficiaries resident in India or in favor of the account holder while temporarily resident in India. For ord inary nonresident accounts of Indian nationals or persons of Indian origin, as well as blocked accounts of such persons with balances in excess of Rs 50,000, the holders may draw up to Rs 2,000 a week dur ing their stay and, in addition, a lump sum of up to Rs 10,000 annually may be debited for any purpose dur ing an account holder's stay in India; either type of account, when held by a person of Indian nationality or origin, may also be debited freely for investment in the Public Provident Fund Scheme, 1968. Other credits and debits require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Transfers are not normally permitted from nonresident accounts of individuals or firms to nonresident accounts of banks, unless the amounts originally credited to such accounts could have been transferred abroad. Special regulations cover funds lodged in National Defence Remittance Scheme Special Accounts represent- ing rupee proceeds of inward remittances for the account of nonresidents and rupee proceeds f rom sales of certifi- cates issued under the Scheme, which expired on May 31, 1966. Balances in such accounts cannot be remitted abroad; they may, however, subject in some cases to prior approval by the Reserve Bank, be invested domestically or be used for other expenditures in India. Withdrawals from such accounts with balances of Rs 50,000 or less held by persons of Indian nationality or origin may be made freely for any payments in India. Nonresident (External) Accounts may freely be opened by authorized dealers in India for persons of Indian na t iona l i ty or origin resident outside India. They may be freely credited with new funds remitted through bank ing channels from the country of residence of the account holder. They may also be credited, after approval by the Reserve Bank, w i th funds from any other nonresident account of the holder, provided that such funds are eligible for remittance. The accounts may be freely debited for disbursements in India and for transfer abroad. Interest on monies s tand ing to the credit of such accounts is exempt from income tax and is freely transferable. The balances held in such accounts are exempt from wealth tax. Foreign Currency (Nonresident) Accounts denomi- nated in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars may be held by persons of Indian nationality or origin who are resident in External Account countries. These accounts may be credited with savings remitted through normal bank ing channels, and with interest on the balances, which is free of income tax. The balances in these accounts are free of wealth tax. Balances may be held only as term deposits but are repatriable at any time in the currency of denomination, without reference to the Reserve Bank. There are also blocked accounts, to which are credited capital proceeds and payments that are due to nonresi- INDIA dents and may not be remitted abroad. Assets in India of Indian emigrants in excess of the amount allowed to be remitted are also required to be credited to blocked accounts. Balances in blocked accounts may be placed on fixed deposit or invested in Indian rupee securities quoted on stock exchanges in India (other than bearer secur i t ies) or, if the holder is of Indian nationality or origin, in the Public Provident Fund Scheme, 1968; with the approval of the Reserve Bank, they may also be invested in shares of Indian companies quoted on stock exchanges in India. The income derived from such investments can be remitted to the owner's country of residence in accordance with the special instructions issued by the Reserve Bank at the time of opening a blocked account. For Indian nationals who were granted emigration facilities prior to January 1, 1963, net income f rom investments financed f rom blocked accounts is allowed to be remitted in fu l l. For those granted such facilities between January 1963 and April 1968, remit- tances of income from assets left behind are limited to Rs 20,000 a year. No income of any kind is remittable to persons who obtained emigration facilities after April 30, 1968. Imports and Import Payments Specified items may be freely imported under an open general license. Practically all other imports require individual licenses. Imports of specified raw materials, spare parts, and components required by "select" indus- tries, by small-scale industries, and by units in other indus tr ies that had an export performance of 20 per cent or more of their production during the previous year, are licensed liberally. Licenses for raw materials and components are issued on a con t inu ing basis generally by way of importers claiming replenishment of goods actually consumed during a period of not more than 12 months. As for spare parts, licenses are issued annu a l ly on the basis of prescribed percentages of the c.i.f. value of the imported machinery and of indigenous machinery having imported components. Licenses to actual users for imports of raw materials, components, and spare parts are not granted wholly against free foreign exchange, but partly against tied-aid credits from par t icu lar countries or against rupees in bilateral clearing accounts. However, a greater preference with respect to the permitted origin of imports is accorded to actual users with specified m in imum export performance. Indi- v idual licenses may be issued ( 1) ad hoc, (2) on the basis of quotas allocated to established importers in accordance with their imports in a base period, (3) to actual users on the basis of their requirements, and (4) to registered exporters in accordance with the import content of their exports. Generally, licenses may be used to import from any country except Namibia (South West A f r i c a ), Pakistan, Rhodesia, South A f r ica, and the Tibet region of the People's Republic of China; imports from these coun- 225 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA tries (except Pakistan) are prohibited.6 Such licenses are referred to as General Currency Area Licenses, as distinct from Specific Licenses, which are issued for capital goods and other supplies against tied aid and are valid only for imports from the country or countries providing the assistance. Single Country Licenses are issued for certain imports from countries with which bilateral trade or payments agreements are in force. Licensing policy generally accords priority to food- stuffs, fertilizers, capital goods, raw materials, and other industrial requirements, while the import of other items is restricted or prohibited. The import program for the period ending March 31, 1976 contains a list of 42 items, the import of which is not normally allowed,7 and a list of 68 items, the import of which is allowed on a restricted basis, i.e., only a part of the requirement is allowed to be imported because of partial domestic availability. Even nonpermissible items are allowed up to specified limits to actual users, against their licenses for raw materials, and under the import replenishment scheme. Licensing is in most cases on an annual basis. There are special procedures applicable to imports of capital goods, heavy electrical plant, and goods imported to fulfill government contracts and for irrigation projects. Favored treatment in allocating foreign exchange for imports of capital goods and equipment is given to "select" industries. An import replenishment scheme enables registered exporters to obtain specified raw materials and other items needed for their export pro- duction; these commodities include certain items whose import otherwise is banned. In licensing imports of a capital nature, their essentiality, their potential for earn- ing or saving foreign exchange, and the availability of medium-term or long-term credits for financing such imports are taken into account. Import licenses for machine tools and other capital goods valued at more than Rs 750,000 are not granted until Indian producers have been given an opportunity by public advertise- ment to supply them; licenses are only issued if offers by domestic producers are disproportionately expensive or unacceptable for other reasons, or when no offers are received within 45 days. For certain types of steel cast- ings and forgings, this policy applies to all orders of more than Rs 50,000. Where a valid import license is held, the required exchange is released by an authorized bank on presenta- tion of the exchange control copy of the license. License holders may make payments by opening letters of credit or by remitting against sight drafts. Advance remittances before shipping documents can be submitted are not normally allowed; but in special cases, e.g., imports of machinery and capital goods, where deposits have to be made with overseas manufacturers, the Reserve Bank grants special authorization for advance payment for a part of the value of the import. 8 The importation f rom Nepal of commodities originating in countries other than Nepal or India also is prohibited. 7 Imports of nonpermissible items are permitted to actual users and under the import replenishment scheme, up to the specified extent. 226 The import of certain commodities, including food- grains, certain oils and fats, a number of pharmaceutical products, corkwood, raw cotton, raw ju te, cashew nuts, most fertilizers, most nonferrous metals, and many cate- gories of steel is reserved for the Government or state trading enterprises, the most important of which are the State Trading Corporation (STC), the Jute Corporation of India, the Food Corporation of India, Sail Interna- tional Ltd., and the Minerals and Metals Trading Cor- poration. In addition, imports of natural rubber, sulfur products, vitamins, and antibiotics are normally arranged under the auspices of the STC. Bulk imports of certain raw materials that are not reserved for the public sector may also be arranged by state agencies, including the Industrial Raw Materials Assistance Centre ( IRMAC ). In addition to any applicable import duty, imports are subject to an auxiliary duty of 5, 15, or 20 per cent ad valorem. Among the exemptions are foodgrains, raw cotton, tallow, and books. Payments for Invisibles In general, payments abroad for invisibles require approval. Foreign exchange is granted freely for a few such payments, mainly for expenses incidental to trade transactions and transfers of recurring contractual obligations. Premiums on insurance policies issued in foreign cur- rency to foreign nationals temporarily resident in India may be paid in rupees or in the currency in which the policy is issued; Indian residents are prohibited from tak ing out life insurance policies in foreign currencies. Branches of foreign banks are not allowed to transfer abroad any profits arising f rom the sale of nonbanking assets. Profit remittances by branches of foreign firms, companies, and banks require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Remittances of dividends by Indian com- panies to their nonresident shareholders do not require prior Reserve Bank approval, provided that certain conditions are met. Remittances of dividends by entirely foreign-controlled companies are limited when reserves are drawn on to finance the dividends. Otherwise there are no restrictions on the remittance of profits, dividends, and interest to beneficiaries permanently resident outside India (except any income accruing to beneficiaries of the National Defence Remittance Scheme), provided that all current tax and other liabilities in India have been cleared, except where such repatriation rights have been voluntarily surrendered. However, remittances to Indian nationals who were granted exchange facilities for emigration on or after January 1, 1963 but before April 30, 1968, of pensions and dividends and interest on shares, securities, and deposits held in India are sub- ject to an overall limit of Rs 20,000 a year and to any special directions given to the person concerned when he was granted emigration facilities. For emigrants who have been granted lump sum exchange facilities after April 30, 1968 on grounds of hardship, no remittance of income is allowed. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Foreign nationals temporarily resident in India on account of their business, profession, or employment are permitted to make reasonable remittances to their own countries to pay insurance premiums, for the support of their families, and for other expenses. Authorized dealers may allow such remittances by foreign nationals, other than nationals of the People's Republic of China, Pakistan, and Rhodesia, to the extent of 50 per cent of net income, subject to a max imum of Rs 2,360 a month (Rs 1,500 a month for nationals of Bangladesh). Requests for the remittance of larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Applications for foreign exchange for travel or edu- cation abroad are considered on an individual basis and require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Under the Foreign Travel Scheme, 1970, residents are permitted to travel abroad without "P form" formalities provided they have not visited any place outside India, other than Bangladesh, Mauritius, Nepal, or Sri Lanka, du r ing the period of three years immed ia te ly preceding the date of the journey; if traveling by Indian carrier on a round-trip ticket, they are entitled to foreign exchange up to US$100 or its equivalent. The scheme is applica- ble to all destinations except Bangladesh, Mauritius, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. Under the Mauritius Travel Scheme, substantially the same facilities are available for travel to Mauritius, except that any visits to Mau r i t ius w i th either a grant of foreign exchange by the Reserve Bank or passage booked with the prior approval of the Reserve Bank, as well as visits to other countries under the Foreign Travel Scheme, are to be ignored for de term in ing the traveler's eligibility under the three-year rule. There are no restric- tions on travel to Bangladesh and Nepal, while passages may be booked freely for air travel f rom Madras, Tiruchirapalli, or Trivandrum to Colombo, Sri Lanka. The schemes mentioned do not preclude access to other travel facilities ( for purposes such as business travel or attendance at conferences or seminars, etc.) that may be approved under normal procedures. Foreign exchange for tourist travel, however, is not norma l ly granted except under the two schemes mentioned above. Travel agents and airlines and steamship companies are not permitted to book passage abroad for persons resident in India (other than foreign nationals temporarily resident in Ind ia) unless the traveler is eligible under the Foreign Travel Scheme or the Mauritius Travel Scheme, has been granted travel exchange by the Reserve Bank, or has been specifically granted permis- sion by the Reserve Bank to book his passage.8 Travel abroad to attend conferences is unrestricted provided INDIA expenses are covered by the host institution. Fares for nonresidents' journeys to and from India may be settled, without Reserve Bank approval, in rupees debited to Nonresident (External) Accounts. The export of Indian currency notes and coins, except to Nepal, is in general prohibited. The following is applicable to all Indian currency other than the develop- ment-oriented design coins of Rs 50, Rs 10, and 10 paise issued in 1974. The export to Nepal of Indian currency notes in denominations of Rs 100 or higher is also prohibited. Deck passengers to Burma, Malaysia, Singa- pore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa and passengers to Pakistan or Sri Lanka may take with them Rs 20 a person at any one time in Indian notes and coins (within the limit of Rs 30 for Indian and foreign currency notes combined). Residents proceeding to Bangladesh for business or private purposes may take with them Indian and foreign currency notes and coins up to a combined total of Rs 20 a person a trip. Residents may take out foreign notes and coins up to <£ stg. 3.50 or its equiva- lent a person; exchange bureaus of authorized dealers and authorized money changers at airports and seaports are permitted to sell foreign currency notes up to a value of <£ stg. 3.50 or its equivalent a person to all passengers, whether Indian or foreign, but not to deck passengers or travelers proceeding to Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan, or Sri Lanka, or to foreign nationals who are transit passengers or passengers holding open- dated tickets (including return tickets) issued outside India. Travelers to Pakistan may take Pakistan rupees in notes or coins up to the equivalent of Rs 30 a person; travelers to Sri Lanka and deck passengers to Burma Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, or East Africa may take <£ stg. 1.50 a person. Nonresidents may take out the foreign currency which they declared on entry, less the amoun ts sold to authorized dealers and author- ized money changers in India. A foreign travel tax, at a un i fo rm rate of 12^ per cent on first class and economy class fares, is payable where the fare for an international journey is paid in Indian currency; tickets paid for in foreign exchange are exempt f rom the levy. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are required for only a few items, and most commodities may be exported without a license. Most of the controlled commodities are licensed freely to all shippers; a few may be exported through estab- lished shippers; and a few commodities are subject to export quotas. Exports to Namibia (South West Africa), 8 Prior permission to book passages abroad is not necessary, however, for the following: deck passengers to or f rom Bu rma, Malaysia, Pakistan, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Persian Gulf ports, or East A f r ica; UN staff members and their fam i l ies whose tickets are purchased by or on instruction f rom UN agencies; staff of airline and steamer companies traveling on official duty, and families of such staff posted on du ty abroad on a long-term basis; foreign diplomatic personnel stationed in India; families of persons gainfully employed abroad proceeding to join the head of the fam i ly or persons ga in fu l ly employed abroad re turn ing to their country of employment after a visit to India, pro- v ided the fa res are paid abroad; employees of Indian insurance com- panies and banks posted on du ty with their branches abroad and their fam i l ies; persons employed by foreign governments provided the fares are paid abroad; travel between India and Pakistan by persons holding res t r ic ted travel documents issued by the High Commission for Paki- stan in India or India-Pakistan passports; air travel between Madras/ Tiruchirapalli/Trivandrum and Colombo, Sri Lanka; and travel between Ind ia and Nepal and between India and Bangladesh. 227 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA Rhodesia, South Africa, and the Tibet region of the People's Republic of China are prohibited. Exchange control is exercised over the proceeds of exports to countries other than Bhutan and Nepal. An exporter must declare that the full export proceeds will be received and dealt with in accordance with the pre- scription of currency regulations. Foreign exchange holdings, including the proceeds of exports, must be offered for sale against rupees to an authorized dealer, unless the holder has been authorized by the Reserve Bank to retain them, or he is a foreign national not permanently resident in India and the funds do not represent the proceeds of an export. Export pro- ceeds must be surrendered within six months of shipment or, if the goods are sold to Afghanistan or Pakistan, within three months of shipment. The Reserve Bank may allow an extension of the six-month period where exports of capital goods or engineering goods are concerned. Some major exports, including certain ju te manufac- tures and iron ore, are subject to export duties. Some exports, including engineering goods, mica, tobacco, handwoven woolen carpets, and lac are subject to mini- mum prices. Some exports, ma in ly new manufactures such as engineering goods, receive cash compensatory support in lieu of nonrefundable taxes and levies. Cer- tain cotton textile items also receive compensatory support. An import replenishment scheme provides preferential import licensing facilities for producers of manufactured goods for export. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. There are special facilities, however, which allow persons of Indian nationality or origin who are resident in External Account countries to ma in ta in certain foreign currency accounts and Nonresident (External) Accounts in India, balances in which are freely repatriable abroad without reference to the Reserve Bank. Schemes are in operation for the priority allotment of passenger automobiles, motor scooters, agricultural tractors, and cement against certain inward remittances of foreign exchange. All bills rendered by hotels to foreign tourists and to nonresident Indian nationals, other than bills rendered to nationals of Bilateral Account countries, Bhutan, and Nepal, and such other foreign nationals and nonresident Indians as are specifically exempted from compliance with this rule by the Indian Government, must be collected by the hotels in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars (or travelers checks expressed in those currencies), or in any other convertible currency. The import of Indian currency notes and coins is, in general, prohibited. However, deck passengers from Burma, Malaysia, Singapore, Persian Gulf ports, and East Africa, and travelers from Pakistan and Sri Lanka, may import into India Rs 20 a person against presenta- tion of evidence that they previously had exported this amount from India. Persons coming to India from 228 Burma, other than deck passengers, are allowed to bring in Indian currency notes up to a value of Rs 50 for an adult and Rs 25 for a child between the ages of 12 and 18. Travelers from Nepal may bring in up to Rs 75 a person. Foreign currency notes may be brought into India without limit, provided that a declaration of the total amount brought in is made to the customs authori- ties upon arrival if the value of foreign notes and coins together with the value of the travelers checks brought in exceeds US$1,000 or its equivalent. Persons holding foreign currency notes may sell them to any authorized dealer in foreign exchange or to any authorized money changer. Capital Inward capital transfers are, in general, unrestricted, but their subsequent utilization in India in most cases is subject to approval. Foreign investments, once admitted, are eligible for the same treatment that Indian enter- prises receive. Banks in India may borrow freely from their branches and correspondents abroad, provided that borrowings in excess of Rs 2 million are utilized for the purchase of rupees f rom the Reserve Bank or in the interbank market to finance their normal business operations in India; repayment of such borrowings requires the prior approval of the Reserve Bank and may be effected only when the debtor bank has no outstanding borrowings in India f rom the Reserve Bank or any other bank. Foreign borrowing by nonbank Indian companies is subject to Reserve Bank approval; only in exceptional cases is permission granted for any loan which has not been obtained as an official or officially guaranteed credit by the Central Government. Reserve Bank permission is required for initiating, expanding, or continuing in India any business activity or holding or acquiring shares of any company carrying on a trading, commercial, or industrial activity in India, by nonresidents, noncitizens, nonbank companies not incorporated under Indian law, and Indian companies with over 40 per cent nonresident interest.9 The Reserve Bank will allow the latter companies to continue their activities, provided Indian participation is not less than 26 per cent of the equity of the company and the com- pany is engaged in production in "core" industries, in predominantly export-oriented production (i.e., at least 60 per cent of output for exports), or in manufacturing activities which require sophisticated technology; tea plantations are included among companies benefiting from this provision. Companies engaged predominantly in trading activities or not meeting the other criteria listed will be required to reduce their foreign share- 9 Persons of Indian nationality or origin who are resident in External Account countries may invest freely in any public or private limited company and in any partnership or proprietorship concern, irrespective of the nature of its activities, provided that the funds required are either remitted f rom abroad through normal banking channels or are drawn f rom the Nonresident (External) Accounts, and provided that an unde r tak ing is given that repatriation of the capital invested or the profits and dividends arising therefrom will not be asked for. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution holding to 40 per cent within a specified period or con- vert their character to meet the above criteria or wind up their activities in India. In exceptional cases, companies not meeting the criteria but which have developed skills, expertise, or facilities, or use technologies not indige- nously available, may be permitted greater than 40 per cent foreign participation, provided that the latter does not exceed 76 per cent. Branches of foreign companies other than airlines and shipping companies must in all cases convert themselves into Indian companies. All companies are subject to "dilution" formulas, as follows: companies with foreign direct holdings exceed- ing 75 per cent must raise 40 per cent of the estimated cost of expansion through additional equity capital issued to Indians; for companies with foreign holdings above 60 per cent but below 75 per cent, and above 51 per cent but below 60 per cent, the corresponding proportions are 33Vs per cent and 25 per cent, respectively. No new foreign equity is permitted in companies engaged predominantly in internal trading and commercial activi- ties. Without the permission of the Reserve Bank, resi- dents are prohibited from lending to, or depositing money with, a nonbank firm or company in which the nonresident interest is more than 40 per cent. Nonciti- zens, non-Indian firms, and nonbank Indian firms with more than 40 per cent foreign participation must obtain Reserve Bank permission in order to acquire, hold, trans- fer, or dispose of immovable property within India (except when a lease for a period of not more than five years is involved). Nonresidents besides the above categories of persons and companies must obtain Reserve Bank permission to allow the use of their trademarks by others for any consideration, and to obtain or continue employment in India as agent or technical or manage- ment adviser of Indian persons or companies. The prior approval of the Reserve Bank is also required for all transfers of shares of Indian companies by nonresidents or foreign nationals to other persons, whether resident or nonresident. Residents are prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from engaging in any transaction which increases beyond 49 per cent the nonresident share of a business outside India in which the nonresident interest is 49 per cent or less, and they are also prohibited, except with Reserve Bank permission, from holding, acquiring, transferring, or disposing of immovable prop- erty outside India (except where a lease of not more than five years is involved). Residents also require Reserve Bank approval for transferring any interest in a business in India to a nonresident, a noncitizen, a nonbank com- pany not incorporated under Indian law, or an Indian company with over 40 per cent foreign participation. Furthermore, Reserve Bank approval is required for residents exporting Indian securities to any place out- side India and transferring Indian securities to nonresi- dents. Residents are prohibited —except with Central Government or Reserve Bank permission —from guaran- INDIA teeing the obligation of a nonresident or the obligation of a resident in favor of a nonresident, and are also prohibited, except with Central Government permission, from associating with or participating in any business concern outside India. Capital invested in approved projects after January 1, 1950 by residents of other countries, including capital appreciation on the original investment, may be repatri- ated at any time; the public has been advised, however, to obtain the Reserve Bank's prior approval before effecting a sale when repatriation of the assets may exceed Rs 1 million. The proceeds of approved sales are allowed to be remitted in installments, usually of Rs 1 million a year, when the amounts sought to be repatriated are significant. The proceeds from liquidated foreign investments not eligible for repatriation are blocked (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). Indian nationals (including persons permanently resi- dent in India) are not normally granted any foreign exchange facilities for emigration purposes. In excep- tional cases of hardship, foreign exchange may be released up to a limit of the equivalent of Rs 25,000 in one lump sum at the time of emigration; the remainder of the emigrant's assets and income are blocked and no fur ther remittances, including pensions, if any, are allowed. Foreign nationals who are temporarily resi- dent in India (other than Bangladesh, Chinese, Pakistani, and Rhodesian nationals) are permitted at the time of their retirement to transfer to their own countries the proceeds from the sale of their investments, subject to a limit of Rs 100,000 for each family at the time of retirement and the remainder in annual installments not exceeding Rs 30,000, provided that the shares and securities concerned are quoted on recognized stock exchanges in India; in addition, they may transfer all their current remittable assets in India. Bangladesh nationals temporarily resident in India are permitted to transfer, besides their current assets in full, the sale proceeds of their capital assets up to a limit of Rs 50,000 for each fam i ly at the time of their retirement, and the remainder in annual installments of Rs 20,000. There are no restrictions on the import into India of Indian or foreign securities. The acquisition, sale, trans- fer, export, or other disposal of foreign securities requires approval. Persons resident in India are per- mitted to hold foreign securities that have been acquired in a manner not involving a breach of the Indian exchange regulations; residents, other than foreign nationals not permanently resident in India, who are private persons are not normally permitted to purchase securities or personal real estate outside India. Indian nationals resident abroad and wishing to return to India to take up employment or to set up small indus- trial units are upon application exempted, for a period of three years, from the requirement that any foreign currency balances in their possession be surrendered within 30 days of arrival. As an alternative to holding 229 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDIA such balances in the form of foreign currency, the holder may use the funds for the import, subject to import license, of equipment and capital goods, or, in small amounts, for personal requirements. Furthermore, these persons have the option of surrendering their balances immediately, with the right to reacquire them within three years in the event of their deciding to go back to a foreign country. Balances held in Nonresident (External) Accounts or Foreign Currency (Nonresident) Accounts in India by such persons as on the date of their return to India are also eligible for similar retransfer or recon- version facilities. These various facilities are not avail- able in respect of earnings arising f rom employment abroad with any Indian-owned organization. Gold Detailed control is exercised over the manufacture, acquisition, possession, and disposal of gold in various forms through a Gold Control Administrator. There is a total ban on private possession of primary gold. Although there is no ban on possession of finished arti- cles of gold (including coins) previously declared, there is restriction on their manufac ture and fresh acquisition. There is no restriction on the acquisition, disposal, or possession of gold ornaments, except that holdings of such ornaments (which may be of any purity) above specified limits are subject to the requirement of declara- tion. The consumption of gold by industrial users is regulated through permits and authorizations. Control is exercised over dealers and goldsmiths through a sys- tem of licensing. Gold ref in ing is under state manage- ment. The Government Mint is licensed to accept tenders of gold for purposes of ref in ing and conversion in to standard gold bars, for which strict specifications as to fineness, weight, dimensions, and markings are pre- scribed. Forward trading in gold or silver is prohibited; exports of silver and products of silver are subject to licenses, which are granted freely. With the exception of jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler, imports of gold in any form by residents other than the monetary authorities require special authorization from the Reserve Bank and are not normally permitted; in certain cases, however, jewelers are permitted to manufac ture gold jewelry in bond from imported gold, for export purposes only. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry pro- duced in India for export and jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler are prohibited unless the export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authori- ties. The export of gold ornaments and jewelry to the Bilateral Account countries and Pakistan is prohibited. Changes during 1975 January 1. Following the expiration of the bilateral payments arrangements with Bangladesh, settlements with that country were placed on a convertible currency basis. 230 January 1. Exchange for private visits to Bangladesh was made available in pounds sterling, up to the equiva- lent of Rs 300 a person for one trip a year; the amount in Indian currency notes that could be taken out remained unchanged at Rs 20 a person at a time. January 1. The ban on trade with Portugal was lifted. The prohibition of payments to Portugal was terminated on May 6. January 1. Imports of steel items were channeled through Sail International Ltd. Previously, they were channeled through Hindustan Steel Ltd. January 7. A 5 per cent cash incentive was extended to exports of handloom fabrics (including made-up arti- cles and garments) and to exports of other cotton tex- tiles, excluding piece goods and yarn. January 9. The eligibility requirements for blanket exchange permits granted to exporters for travel abroad for export promotion and other approved purposes were tightened. The minimum annual export performance required was increased from Rs 2.5 million and Rs 500,000 for traditional and nontraditional exports, respectively, to Rs 7.5 million and Rs 1.5 million, respec- tively. On June 25, it was announced that a Rs 0.5 million annual m in imum, rather than that of Rs 1.5 million, was applicable to Indian consultancy organiza- tions of consultancy or design engineers. January 9. A new credit agreement with Mauritius was signed; the credit of 50 m i l l ion Indian rupees was intended to finance Ind ian exports. Implementing direc- tives to authorized dealers were issued on July 23. January 15. A protocol on the resumption of shipping services was signed with Pakistan. Carriage of cargo between the two countries was to be restricted to vessels sailing under the flag of either country. All payments and expenses relating to shipping services between the two countries were to be effected in freely convertible currencies. January 17. Procedures were announced to govern exports to Bangladesh under the Rs 100 million Emer- gency Relief Credit extended by India under a credit agreement which came into force on November 12, 1974. On April 9, procedures were announced for exports under the earlier Rs 100 million commodity credit and Rs 20 million commodity grant to Bangladesh. January 23. A one-year trade agreement was signed with Pakistan, permitting, initially, trade only on a government-to-government basis or through govern- ment-controlled trade corporations of the two countries. The goods to be exported f rom Pakistan and India under this agreement would be of Pakistani and Indian origin and for consumption in India and Pakistan, respectively. All trade-related payments were to be effected in con- vertible currencies through the State Bank of India and the National Bank of Pakistan. January 29. The export of coconut, dessicated coco- nu t, and copra was banned. January 30. The Reserve Bank granted general per- mission to the public for (1) sending out of India not ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution more than two pieces each of the development-oriented design coins of Rs 50, Rs 10, and 10 paise for the pur- pose of making noncommercial gifts of such coins to nonresidents, and (2) for taking out two pieces each of Rs 50 and Rs 10 by passengers going abroad, for pur- poses of presentation. February 1. A scheme for priority allotment of agri- cultural tractors against inward remittances of foreign exchange came into effect. It would be available to Indian nationals who have returned from abroad and to relatives of Indians who are residing abroad and who have remitted foreign exchange in favor of the relatives in India for the purchase of a tractor. The scheme was similar in operation to that introduced in September 1974 for priority allotment of passenger automobiles and motor scooters. On February 15, a similar scheme for priority allotment of cement came into effect. February 10. Exports of groundnut oil and refined groundnut oil were banned until September. February 13. The export of all types of cotton yarn, which (except for singles and folded) had been pro- hibited since April 25, 1974, was permitted up to December 31, 1975. February 15. Exports of molasses, ethyl alcohol, and rectified spirit of any proof or degree were banned until November. February 20. Contracts for imports of goods and services from Poland had to be expressed in U.S. dollars, while the clearing account was to be credited in Indian rupees. February 28. The auxiliary customs duty was extended until June 30, 1976. March 13. Debits for investment in the Public Provi- dent Fund Scheme, 1968 by Indians and persons of Indian origin were added to the permitted debits to nonresident accounts, National Defence Remittance Scheme Special Accounts, and blocked accounts. April 1. The import policy for 1975/76 came into effect. It involved some liberalization of imports, espe- cially with regard to entitlements for industries produc- ing nontraditional exports, and a simplification of import licensing procedures; export obligations were increased: (1) Licensing of imports used as inputs in industrial production was made "automatic," i.e., license applica- tions could be made directly to the licensing authority without authorizations from other agencies and would be granted on the basis of the value of the previous year's consumption of such inputs or licenses obtained, which- ever was less. The system of "repeat licenses" was abol- ished. (2) The list of "priority" industries was replaced by a list of "select" industries, including 29 categories and comprising 79 items. Such industries could receive, on providing justification to sponsoring authorities (not the import-licensing authority), "supplementary" licenses for imports over and above those obtained through the "automatic licensing" procedure. They would also be permitted to import "nonpermissible" spare parts against their licenses for raw materials and components up to INDIA 5 per cent of their face value. (3) Small-scale units were also permitted supplementary licenses, which could be obtained as part of the automatic licensing procedure. (4) All units exporting at least 20 per cent of their out- put could receive licenses on the basis of the value of consumption of imports, regardless of the value of licenses obtained during the previous year. Small-scale units exporting 20 per cent or more of their production would be eligible for licenses under free foreign exchange up to 75 per cent of their entitlement and for the balance under U.K. credit. (5) The compulsory export obliga- tion was increased from 5 per cent to 10 per cent for certain industries. (6) All industries were now eligible for separate licenses for import of spare parts, which would be allowed on the basis of 5 per cent of the value of imported machinery imported prior to 1970 and 3 per cent in respect of machinery imported during or after 1970. In the case of indigenous machinery with imported components, all units would be eligible for spare parts licenses on the basis of 0.5 per cent of the purchase value of machinery (1 per cent for small-scale un i t s ). Nonpermissible spare parts would be allowed for import up to 10 per cent of the face value of licenses for spare parts, but the value of no single such spare part could exceed Rs 50,000. (7) The value limit of emergency spare parts was raised from Rs 20,000 to Rs 25,000 for large-scale units (from Rs 8,000 to Rs 10,000 for small-scale un i ts ). (8) The system of bank guarantees which exporters had to execute for discharging their export obligation against advance and imprest licenses was considerably relaxed. (9) Twelve items were no longer required to be imported through specified channels. April 1. Exports of bananas were allowed freely until March 1976. April 1. Exports of basmati rice were allowed freely un t il March 1976, but only through the STC. April 3. It was agreed with Nepal that India would apply specified ceilings on exports to Nepal during 1975/76 of iron and steel products, cement, and gal- vanized iron pipes. April 7. Exports of benzene methanol and toluene were channeled through the STC. April 7. Exports of 30 chemical items were banned, and exports of 18 other such items were restricted. April 8. Exports of forging quality steel products were banned. April 10. Exports of beef and beef tallow were banned. April 18. The export of ivory and ivory products was banned. April 23. Silver products could henceforth be exported freely to External Account countries. The items covered were silver coin; silver bullion, sheets, and plates; silver chemicals and compounds with more than 50 per cent silver content; and other products with more than 50 per cent silver content. (Exports of silver coins and bullion had been licensed freely since Febru- ary 21, 1974.) August 23. Import duty on materials, components, and parts imported under the scheme of advance licenses issued to exporters was waived. This eliminated the wa i t ing period for receiving drawbacks. August 23. Fifteen export-oriented engineering indus- tries were given general permission to expand their capacity by 25 per cent over the next five years without going through the normal licensing procedures. September 1. The Reserve Bank was prepared to pur- chase deutsche mark and Japanese yen forward also for six months' delivery; previously, this facility was avail- able only for one, two, and three months' forward delivery. In addition, forward sales of sterling, U.S. dol- lars, deutsche mark, and Japanese yen by authorized dealers to the Reserve Bank against their spot purchases of these currencies became permissible. September 15. Indians resident abroad, who had opened a Nonresident (External) Account by remitting funds from abroad through banking channels and then returned to India, could, on the merits of the case, obtain permission from the Reserve Bank (1) to recon- vert the balance into foreign currency when leaving India within three years of their return; (2) to reconvert the resident account into a Nonresident (External) Account after departure from India within three years, provided no local rupee credits had been made into the account in the meantime; or (3) to open a new Nonresi- dent (External) Account, a f ter departure from India within three years (up to the value of the balance at the time of initial conversion of the account into a Resident Accoun t). The facilities were not available to Indians employed abroad with any Indian-owned organization. September 25. The currency was re pegged from the pound sterling to a weighted basket of currencies; mar- gins would be maintained within 2.25 per cent on either side. Previously, the central rate was Rs 18.9677 = <£ stg. 1. The intervention currency continued to be the pound sterling, and the Reserve Bank would fix the buying and selling rates for sterling, ad jus t ing these from time to time in conformity with the new policy. October 10. Nonresident Indian nationals and per- sons of Indian origin resident abroad were permitted to subscribe to the equity capital of new companies for setting up new projects in all industries (with some specified exceptions), subject to the condition that the total of such holdings by one or more nonresidents of the categories referred to would not exceed 20 per cent of the new capital to be issued by such companies. These investments, along with the income thereon, could be repatriated (subject to deduction of applicable Indian taxes), provided that such investments were made by remittances from abroad through normal banking chan- nels or out of funds held in Nonresident (External) Accounts. Investment under the scheme would be in addition to any foreign equity investment that might be permitted by the Government in the company concerned. October 28. Authorized dealers were required to obtain the prior approval of the Reserve Bank before granting loans or overdrafts to nonresident persons of Indian nationality or of Indian origin against the secur- ity of fixed deposits created solely out of remittances f rom abroad (including balances held in Nonresident (External) Accounts or Foreign Currency (Nonresi- den t) Accoun ts); the authority to grant such credit up to Rs 20,000, subject to certain conditions, was revoked. October 31. An Ordinance was issued to amend the Unit Trust of India Act, 1963. The Ordinance exempted from income tax and wealth tax income arising from investments in units of the Unit Trust of India and the value of the investments, respectively, by nonresident persons of Indian nationality or origin when financed f rom Nonresident (External) Accounts or through remittance of foreign exchange through normal banking channels. November 1. A new type of nonresident account, Foreign Currency (Nonresident) Accounts, was intro- duced. Nonresident persons of Indian nationality or origin could open accounts in designated foreign curren- cies (pounds sterling and U.S. dollars) for remittance of their savings from abroad. Interest was paid in the currencies in which the accounts were held and was free of Indian income tax. The balances, including interest, were repatriable at any time in the same currencies, without reference to the Reserve Bank. Balances could only be held as term deposits, for periods ranging from 91 days to 61 months. The exchange risk was borne 233 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA (Position on December 31,1975) Nonresident Accounts There are no restrictions on the opening by foreign nationals of accounts in Indonesia in rupiahs or foreign currencies with authorized foreign exchange banks. No distinction is made between resident and nonresident accounts. Imports and Import Payments There is a registry of authorized importers and an initial deposit is required for registration. Since Octo- ber 31, 1968, only Indonesian nationals may obtain an importer's license, but certain established foreign firms have been enabled to retain their licenses and new for- eign investors can obtain an importer's license restricted to the import of materials required for their own projects. Imports from Angola, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports f rom all sources of any secondhand goods and of specified commodities. The latter include built-up sedans and station wagon sedans; components for the assembly of luxury-type automo- biles; built-up commercial vehicles and motorcycles; radio and television sets in built-up or semi-knocked- down condition; built-up air conditioners, refrigerators, and electric sewing machines; sarongs; galvanized iron sheets; iron roofing sheets; mosquito sticks; matches; monosodium glutamate; mattresses; certain types of cotton ya rn; and specified types of textiles, car tires, batteries, printed matter, office supplies, animal traps, bottles, and lamps and bulbs. The importing of cloves, fertilizers, rice, refined sugar, and wheat and wheat flour is restricted to specified approved importers. Imports of certain commodities for the "national iron stock" are reserved for state enterprises; they include cement, news- print, certain types of paper and automobile tires, asphalt, cotton weaving yarn, sheet iron, raw materials for maritime industries, pharmaceutical raw materials, and certain other items. No licenses are required for imports. In principle, all permitted imports may be paid for either with general exchange (Devisa Umum) or aid exchange (Devisa Exchange Rate System No par value for the Indonesian Rupiah has been established with the Fund. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse, transactions in U.S. dollars have since August 23, 1971 been effected at rates within 1 per cent either side of Rp 415 per US$1; on December 31, 1975 the buying and selling rates were Rp 414 and Rp 416, respectively, per US$1. Exchange rates for other cur- rencies are determined on the basis of the Jakarta rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, and rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse three calls for exchange are conducted each week under the man- agement of Bank Indonesia. Bidding for exchange in the call is restricted to the authorized foreign exchange banks and licensed foreign exchange dealers. Bank Indonesia is committed to deal with any w i l l ing buyer or seller at the going rate. Representatives of the for- eign exchange banks no t i fy Bank Indonesia of their supply to the market and each presents a bid for the total of his bank's requirements at a particular rate. Bank Indonesia clears the market at the intervention rate. The Bank also offers authorized banks certain facilities for forward contracts in respect of aid exchange and for swap transactions in U.S. dollars. Sabang is entirely outside the Indonesian exchange and trade control system,1 but the Indonesian rupiah is legal tender there. Administration of Control The implementation of exchange and trade control is entrusted to Bank Indonesia, the Ministry of Trade, the Ministry of Finance, authorized foreign exchange banks, and the customs authorities. Exchange control is admin- istered by Bank Indonesia and the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks and are normally effected in converti- ble currencies. Export proceeds must be received in Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Malaysian dollars (also referred to as r ingg i t ), Nether- lands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Indonesia has no operative payments agreements.2 INDONESIA ers of a value not exceeding US$100, and imports spe- cifically authorized by the Ministry of Trade (such as goods constituting part of a foreign investment). A rupiah deposit of 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of credit must be lodged with Bank Indonesia when a letter of credit is opened in respect of imports financed with aid exchange; for imports financed with general exchange, importers are required to make an advance deposit of at least 40 per cent of the letter of credit value when they submit applications for letters of credit to authorized banks, and to settle the balance within 75 days of the opening of the letter of credit. Applications to foreign exchange banks for imports under merchant letters of credit must be accompanied by a deposit of 25 per cent of the value. The deposits are released to the importer only after the issuance by a foreign exchange bank of the KPP (certificate of import declaration) or when he presents correspondence from suppliers indicating that the merchant letter of credit has been canceled. The amount of the deposit against letters of credit for nongovernment imports financed with aid exchange is left to the discretion of the author- ized bank if the latter purchases aid exchange forward from Bank Indonesia. Import duties, which are almost without exception ad valorem, are imposed on the c.i.f. value of the com- modities converted at the customs valuation rate (Rp 415 per US$1 on December 31, 1975). Sales taxes of 5, 10, and 20 per cent are levied on most imports on their c. & f. value plus import duty. Items which are exempt from import duties are also exempt from sales taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted or subject to control. Pro- ceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Travel- ers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign banknotes but only Rp 2,500 in Indonesian notes and coins other than gold and silver commemorative coins; Indonesian commemorative gold and silver coins issued in August 1970 may be taken out freely up to Rp 65,000 a person, while the limit applicable to gold and silver coins issued in October 1974 is Rp 130,000. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Angola, the People's Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are exports to all countries of gold ore and pure gold; clove seeds; pepper seeds; fertilizers; rawhides of cattle; certain categories of unprocessed or low-quality rubber; certain logs and timber; all types of waste paper (from Java and Madu ra ); scrap of bronze and copper (except from Irian Jaya ); iron scrap; and scrap of steel (from Java, Madura, and Suma tra). The prior authorization of the Minister of Trade is required for the export of flat- bark crepe, cinchona bark, silver, and antiques of cul- tural value. Otherwise, all commodities may be freely exported by registered private firms and state trad- ing firms. 236 All exporters except certain mining companies and licensed "border-crossing" traders must require their buyers to open a bank letter of credit covering the value of the goods to be exported. For certain minor exports, including handicrafts, the exporter must surrender the full foreign exchange value prior to shipment if there is no banker's letter of credit.4 For the principal export commodities other than petroleum, the sales price must not be lower than "indication" prices ("check" prices) determined periodically by the Minister of Trade. The full proceeds from exports other than petroleum, prod- ucts of certain mining companies, and goods exported by licensed "border-crossing" traders are subject to sur- render (except in "border-crossing" trade, see below) and, except for finished goods, batik textiles and other handicrafts, plywood, fresh fish, and a number of other items, are subject to a 10 per cent export tax. Exports of petroleum and of products of certain mining compa- nies are also exempt from export tax. A specific cess is levied on exports of certain agricultural products and on inter-island trading in the same products. Certain commodities produced in border regions may be exported to Malaysia and the Philippines in exchange for certain eligible goods. In this "border-crossing" trade with Malaysia, the value of import or export shipments must not exceed M$600 a month, if transported over- land, and M$600 a shipment, if transported by sea; for the Philippines, the value of imports or exports must not exceed the rupiah or peso equivalent of US$150 for a single trip if transported by sea-going vessel or US$1,500 if transported by boat. Capital Foreign capital invested in Indonesia is governed pri- marily by the Foreign Capital Investment Law of Janu- ary 10, 1967, as amended in August 1970, and by Presi- dential Guidelines issued on January 22, 1974 and September 21, 1974. In principle, such investments may be undertaken only through a jo int venture with an Indonesian partner. All investments in Indonesia require the approval of the Investment Coordinating Board (BKPM ). Enterprises that are wholly or largely oper- ated in Indonesia as separate business units must be incorporated under Indonesian law and must have their domicile in Indonesia. The operating permit for foreign investment is usually valid for a maximum of 30 years. Among the inducemen ts offered are exemption f rom, or reduction in, corporate and dividend taxes for a certain number of years. Investors are granted the right to transfer profits (after settlement of taxes and financial obligations in Indonesia) and to make transfers relating to expenses connected with the employment of foreign nationals in Indonesia, and in respect of depreciation allowances after the expiration of the tax holiday from corporation tax. The law provides that no transfer per- mit shall be issued for capital repatriation as long as the 4 There are separate arrangements for exports of orchids. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution investments benefit from tax relief; at present, however, foreign payments do not require a transfer permit. The exploration and development of petroleum resources are governed by the Petroleum Law of 1960. A special regime applies to enterprises previously nationalized but now restored to the original owners. Such enterprises are allowed tax holidays for a period of three years on new capital in foreign currency brought in within the context of rehabilitation and expansion programs that have been approved by the Government. The transfer of proceeds f rom the sale of the assets of those restored enterprises which ceased operations could take place with effect from January 1, 1972 at the rate of one fifth of the proceeds each year, with a full guarantee as to their value in foreign cur- rency. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of assets of enterprises whose period of operation has expired or whose operations have been terminated by the Gov- ernment is allowed at the rate of one fifth a year effec- tive from the time of the sale of assets. This transfer is guaranteed as to its value in foreign currency. A Debt Investment Conversion Scheme (DIGS) exists for the benefit of foreign creditors holding nonguaran- teed claims against Indonesia. Rupiahs covered by the Scheme are administered in two kinds of DICS-Rupiah Accounts, A and B, the former relating only to claims of which the creditor is the first holder. Private creditors willing to accept the terms of the Scheme and prepared to make investments under the Foreign Capital Invest- ment Law of 1967 are paid in rupiahs in settlement of their claims. These claims are transferable to other potential investors in Indonesia, but only the original creditor's DIGS rupiahs may be used, in the creditor's own projects that have been approved under the Foreign Capital Investment Law of 1967, for the purchase of foreign exchange for the import of equipment and raw materials necessary for the establishment and operation of those projects. There are no limitations on the remittance to Indo- nesia of capital in the form of foreign exchange or in commodities. Both residents and nonresidents may hold foreign currency deposits with foreign exchange banks. However, foreign exchange banks, nonbank financial institutions, and private companies are subject to Bank Indonesia directives with respect to borrowing abroad, the acceptance of deposits from nonresidents, and the issuance of certificates of deposit to nonresidents. A 30 per cent reserve requirement is applicable to the foreign currency liabilities of foreign exchange banks; no deposit requirements are applicable to the foreign borrowings of nonbank financial institutions or private companies. Certain borrowing abroad is subject to clearance by Bank Indonesia, and all foreign borrowing is subject to reporting to Bank Indonesia and /or the Ministry of Finance. The prior approval of the Minister of Finance is required before any public enterprise or public sector body may accept a loan f rom abroad. INDONESIA Indonesian citizens and residents of foreign national- ity may freely transfer, negotiate, import, and export securities denominated in rupiahs or in foreign currency. Gold Indonesia has issued six commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold and gold coins in Indonesia. Exports of gold ore and pure gold, unless made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, are prohibited by virtue of Decision No. 68 /KP / IV /70 of April 17, 1970 of the Minister of Trade. Travelers may freely take out Indo- nesian commemorative gold and silver coins issued in August 1970 up to Rp 65,000 a person, and gold and silver coins issued as part of the "conservation coinage" in October 1974 up to Rp 130,000 a person; amounts in excess require the prior approval of Bank Indonesia. Imports of gold are free of license but require prior notification to the Ministry of Industry and are subject to an extra levy of Rp 25 per US$1. Changes during 1975 January 13.
