Not for Redistribution IRAN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0108055 gram of fine gold per Iranian Rial, corresponding to Rls 82.2425 = SDR 1. The exchange rate is maintained on the basis of this par value equivalent. Iran has availed itself of wider margins, and the intervention currency is the U.S. dol- lar. On December 31, 1975 the official rates of Bank Markazi Iran (the Central Bank) for the U.S. dollar, the only currency that is officially quoted, were Rls 69.15 buying, and Rls 69.40 selling, per US$1. The Central Bank also publishes daily exchange rates for 14 other currencies1 for purposes of the calculation of import registration fees and import duties; these rates are based on the official rates for the U.S. dollar and the London market rates for the currencies concerned. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market (or official rate market) with fixed U.S. dollar rates and a noncommercial market with fluctuating rates. Both markets operate w i th in the bank- ing system. The Central Bank stands ready to purchase from the commercial banks, at official rates, any foreign exchange proceeds from exports of goods and services. Import payments must in principle be settled in the offi- cial rate market. Also settled at official rates are basic allocations for certain authorized current payments (travel, study, and medical treatment abroad) and, on the supply side, any export proceeds and other current receipts converted by public sector agencies (including the National Iranian Oil Company). Proceeds from exports other than oil, oil products, and natural gas, as well as the proceeds from exports of services, may be sold either in the official or the noncommercial market. All other payments and receipts are settled at the noncommercial market rate. However, transactions over clearing accounts denominated in U.S. dollars are in all cases settled at the official buying and selling rates. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank. In principle, all foreign exchange transactions must take place through the Central Bank or authorized banks. The import and export of goods is governed by regulations issued annually by the Ministry of Com- merce and approved by the Council of Ministers. For- eign trade relations with Albania and the Republic of China are under the control of the Foreign Transactions Company within the Ministry of Commerce. 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds ster- ling, Swedish kronor, and Swiss francs. 238 Prescription of Currency Transactions with six of the nine countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements2 must be con- ducted through agreement accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, while those with the People's Republic of China, the German Democratic Republic, and North Korea must be conducted through accounts denominated in Iranian rials. Settlements with Mexico rnay optionally be made through a clearing account denom ina ted in U.S. dollars. Settlements with the other member coun- tries of the Asian Clearing Un ion (Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) may be effected in Asian mone tary un i ts or in the currency of one of the countries that are parties to the individual contract con- cerned. Payments to and from Pakistan and Turkey relating to visible trade (exc lud ing border trade, petro- leum and petroleum products, and defense materials) are settled over clearing accounts ma in ta ined by the respective central banks in U.S. dollars. Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Settlements with other coun- tries normally are settled in the quoted currencies (see footnote 1). Nonresident Accounts Foreign nationals are permitted to maintain accounts freely, in rials as well as in foreign currencies, with authorized banks; rial accounts may be used both for payments in Iran and for conversion into foreign curren- cies through the noncommercial market. Foreign nationals as well as Iranian physical or juridical persons may ma in ta in sight or time deposits in foreign curren- cies in Iran; these accounts may be used for transfers abroad or for sales to authorized banks. Imports and Import Payments All imports into Iran are subject to control by the Government. The import policy is re-examined annu- ally, and a new Import List, effective for the next Iranian year, is published by the Ministry of Commerce. The Import List distinguishes between "authorized," "unau- thorized," and "prohibited" goods. "Authorized" imports, consisting of goods whose importation is considered essential and including items which either are not produced in Iran or are produced in Iran but not in quantities sufficient to meet domestic require- ments, are divided into two main categories: (1) imports for which orders may be placed without prior approval 2 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hunga ry, No r th Korea, Poland, Roman ia, and U.S.S.R. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution by government agencies,3 and (2) imports that are sub- ject to prior approval by government agencies (gener- ally the Ministry of Commerce) before the import order is placed. "Unauthorized" imports are goods whose importation is not considered essential, inc lud ing goods whose local production is suff ic ient to meet domestic demand. Commodities may be shifted from the "autho- rized" list to the "unauthorized" list, and vice versa, as and when deemed necessary. For "prohibited" goods, no authorizations are given; these comprise only a few items such as opium and firearms. Imports without payment through the official exchange market of "authorized" goods require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce and the Central Bank. How- ever, imports of "authorized" goods without payment are permitted without any l im i ta t ion, provided that regis- tration is made before the order is placed. Such imports up to US$5,000 are permitted without prior registration but are subject to the registration deposit; payments may be made either through the commercial or the noncom- mercial exchange market. In addition, permission is given for the following: imports destined for official charitable ins t i tu t ions or government organizations; machinery; spare parts and raw or intermediate mate- rials for productive entities, up to US$1,000 a sh ipmen t; and all other imports of "authorized" goods up to US$300 a shipment. Imports on this basis are exempt from the import registration deposit. The import of gifts, whether "authorized" or "unauthorized" commodi- ties, is restricted to Rls 10,000 a person a year. Specified commodities, such as sugar, wheat, tobacco, and cigarette paper, are imported under state monopoly. Payments may be made either against bills for collec- tion or documentary letters of credit. Payments against bills for collection may be made without prior authoriza- tion for goods (ma in ly capital goods and raw materials) listed in the Schedule attached to Circular No. 116 of August 3, 1965 (Iranian date 12 /5 /1344 ). Payments for imports of other goods may also be made against bills for collection without prior permission from the Central Bank, provided that the bills are settled w i th in nine months. All orders for imports must be registered with the Central Bank through an authorized bank; registration is effected against a pro forma invoice. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited and special regulations apply to certain commodities when originat- ing in Hong Kong. At the time of registration of imports, an import regis- tration fee of 1 per cent of the amount of an import order, calculated on the basis of the official selling rate is collected by authorized banks. Imports brought in under the Law for the Attraction and Protection of For- eign Investment in Iran are exempt f rom the fee. For some goods, importers must at the t ime of registration 3 Exports and imports of goods that are not included in the bilateral expor t / import list for countries with which Tran has bilateral t rade and payments agreements require special approval by the Ministry of Commerce. IRAN lodge with the Central Bank, through an authorized bank, a deposit of 15 per cent of the invoiced value. Most food items are exempt from the registration deposit. The deposit is refundable upon presentation of the customs clearance certificate a f ter the respective goods have been cleared through customs, or if and when the order is canceled. The Central Bank may permit, when necessary, the sh if t ing of imports from the category in which an advance import deposit is required to the exempt category. Authorized banks make payments for permitted imports against the presentation of shipping documents. Approval of the sh ipp ing documents by the authorized banks represents approval of the foreign exchange t rans fe r. Almost all imports are subject to commercial benefit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are in addition to any applicable customs duty. The ad valorem commercial benefit tax ranges f rom 1 per cent to 200 per cent. Monopoly taxes are included in the commercial benefit taxes. The authorities specify in the Import List the commercial profit taxes for each year. These taxes are paid to the customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon the presentation of shipping documents endorsed by the authorized banks, specifying that payment has been made or will be made, and, when required, that the special import authorization has been received from government agencies prior to lading of goods in the country of origin. Payments for invisibles Payments for all current invisibles may be made freely through the noncommercial market. In addition, there are certain allocations at the official rate for travel, study, and medical treatment abroad. Payments for invisibles related to imports are made on the same basis as payments for the f.o.b. value of those imports. Official exchange is granted to importers for insurance of imports against bills for collection; for imports covered by documentary letters of credit, insur- ance must be taken out in Iran. Official exchange is not granted to exporters for insurance of Iran ian exports sold f.o.b. Official exchange also is not granted for the payment of other insurance prem iums, although reinsurance premium payments are permitted. Autho- rized banks are permitted to remit interest on importers' suppliers' credit not exceeding 8.5 per cent; higher inter- est rates require special permission from the Central Bank. Foreign nationals working in Iran as technical assis- tan ts whose employment has been recognized as neces- sary by the Government may remit at the official rate about 50 per cent of their net salaries; any additional amounts may be remitted through the noncommercial marke t. The basic travel allowance for Iran ian and for- eign nationals —the equivalent of Rls 50,000 a person 239 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN a trip —may be made available by authorized banks at the official rate upon presentation of a valid passport and exit permit; each accompanying member of the passport holder's family is entitled to the same allowance, and there is no limit on the number of times a person may avail himself of this facility. Additional funds in respect of personal or business travel may be purchased freely in the noncommercial market. Banks may sell, at the official rate, up to the equivalent of Rls 200,000 a person to Iranian nationals traveling or residing abroad, for medical treatment; additional foreign exchange at the official rate can be obtained against medical bills certified by an Iranian consulate abroad, and any fur- ther amounts may be purchased in the noncommercial market. Iranian physical and juridical persons may also freely make remittances abroad from domestic current accounts in which they retain foreign exchange received from sources abroad, including export proceeds; bal- ances in such accounts are freely transferable. Iranian nationals leaving the country are required to pay a travel tax of Rls 10,000 for each single-journey exit permit. The tax is imposed also for pilgrimage travel. Lower rates apply to fam i ly members traveling on the same passport (wife and children from 7 to 18 years of age), viz., Rls 750 a person. Iranians resident abroad and students studying abroad but visiting home temporarily are exempt from payment of the tax. Travelers leaving Iran may take with them Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes. Travelers of foreign nationality may not export foreign currency in excess of the amount they imported less the amounts they have sold to autho- rized banks, as recorded in their passports; they may, however, convert rials up to the equivalent of US$100 into other currencies at the official rate, upon presenta- tion of their visaed passport, and may freely convert any additional amount in the noncommercial market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of some commodities require licenses. The commercial benefit tax and customs duty charged at the time of import of raw materials contained in manufactured goods for export may be returned to the exporter after the export has taken place. Certain minor exports are granted incentive payments by the Center for the Promotion of Exports. The Central Bank offers preferential discount facilities for export bills. The foreign currency proceeds of commodities other than petroleum, petroleum products, and natural gas may be retained abroad; if they are repatriated, they may be kept as foreign currency deposits with domestic banks or sold to the banking system either in the offi- cial exchange market or in the noncommercial market. Authorized banks normally accept export proceeds only in U.S. dollars and other quoted currencies (see foot- note 1), but they are permitted to accept other curren- cies at their discretion. 240 Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained in a foreign currency account with an authorized bank, where they remain at the free disposal of the account holder. Travelers may freely bring in Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes; higher amounts require the prior approval of the Central Bank. The repatriation of Iranian banknotes through the mail is not permitted. Capital Iranian nationals may retain in domestic foreign cur- rency accounts any capital receipts accruing in foreign exchange; transfers abroad from such accounts may be made freely, as may domestic transfers to other Iranian nationals. Private outward transfers of capital may be made through the noncommercial market, irrespective of their purpose. The retransfer abroad at the official sell- ing rate is permitted, provided that the inflow had been specifically authorized by the Central Bank. Authorized banks may freely accept inflows of foreign exchange f rom abroad (both deposits and borrowings) and lend the foreign currency to residents or sell it in the non- commercial market for rials; the rial counterpart may be lent to residents, but such lending is subject to the applicable credit ceilings. In accordance with the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran (1955) and regulations implementing the law, foreign capital invested in approved development or productive activities in industry, mining, agriculture, or transport may be repatriated, together with net profits (in accordance with Article 1 of the law and the provisions contained in the implementing regulations), in the form of foreign exchange and /or goods. Transfers of exchange must be made at the official market selling rate prevailing at the date of transfer. However, the Central Bank has the option of buying the exchange or accepting it as a deposit to be converted into rials at a rate mutually agreed upon in a separate agreement, and this rate remains applicable to the funds when they are repatriated. Capital imported under this law in the form of foreign exchange must be in currencies acceptable to the Central Bank; the exchange is converted into rials at the buying rate prevailing on the date of application for conversion. All conversions must take place in the official market (capital, profits and dividends, amortization, and liquida- tion proceeds). The law does not set up any limit of participation with respect to the ratio of foreign to domestic investment, but the Supervisory Board encour- ages participation by Iranians in the proposed investment. Gold No Iranian gold coins are legal tender.4 Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell 4 Article 2 ( d) of the Monetary and Banking Act prohibits the use of gold coins as legal tender. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution gold and silver in any form in Iran, and there is a free market for both. Authorized banks may freely import and export gold and silver (bullion only, which for gold must be at least "%ooo fine), against settlement through the official rate market, and sell these metals to any person in Iran. The import and export of gold for monetary purposes or for international settlements is reserved for the Central Bank, while the import for industrial and dental use is effected by professional organizations, at the official rate and subject to super- vision by the Central Bank. The Central Bank accepts gold bullion on deposit f rom domestic banks as well as nonbank residents and issues gold certificates against such deposits. Travelers may freely import and export gold bullion and coins up to 1 kilogram a person a trip; the Central Bank is empowered to approve larger quan- tities. The export of Iranian gold coins for numismatic purposes requires prior approval by the Central Bank. Imports of gold are free from customs duty and com- mercial benefit tax but are subject to the 1 per cent import registration fee. Bank Melli Iran and other com- mercial banks give daily quotations for domestic sales. Changes during 1975 February 12. The currency was repegged from the U.S. dollar to the SDR. The exchange rate would be maintained on the basis of its par value equivalent, Rls 82.2425 = SDR 1, and Iran continued to avail itself of wider margins of 2.25 per cent on the special drawing right. The U.S. dollar rates would be changed when the degree of fluctuation either side of the middle rate had exceeded the 2.25 per cent margin on five consecutive business days. Not for Redistribution IRAQ (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Iraqi Dinar. The parity for the U.S. dollar, which is the inter- vention currency, is ID 1 = US$3.3778, and Iraq avails itself of wider margins. Transactions in the official mar- ket are carried out in any of the listed currencies 1 or in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts in Iraq. The Central Bank of Iraq quotes official rates for the listed currencies, other than the U.S. dollar, for its transac- tions with authorized dealers only. The Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were US$3.394678 and US$3.377778, respec- tively, per ID 1. Administration of Control The Board of Administration of the Central Bank of Iraq is entrusted with all powers and responsibilities in connection with exchange control; this authority is exe- cuted through the Foreign Exchange Committee (headed by the Governor of the Central Bank, his Deputy, or a member specified in advance by the Board of Adminis- tra t ion), which has delegated certain approval authority to the Department of Foreign Exchange of the Central Bank and to the licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a licensed dealer unless otherwise authorized by the Board of Adminis- tration. All branches of the Rafidain Bank, the sole commercial bank, are licensed dealers. Import policy is determined by the Council for the Regulation of Trade. The Directorate-General of Economics (Government and Private Import Section) in the Ministry of Econ- omy, two state organizations (dealing with trade in capital goods and consumer goods, respectively), the General Department for Industrial Promotion in the Ministry of Industry, and the Industrial Organization in the Ministry of Industry are the principal licensing authorities for imports and exports, but import licenses are also issued by certain other public organizations and government departments. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is established annually, and foreign exchange allocations under the import pro- gram are supervised by the Import Program Committee. Prescription of Currency Settlements must be made in any of the listed curren- cies l or, under the bilateral payments agreements with the People's Republic of China and Egypt, through the appropriate clearing account.2 Payments to and receipts from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 With effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1976, settlements with the People's Republic of China and Egypt were placed on a convertible currency basis. 242 Nonresident Accounts The opening of a nonresident account requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Transac- tions permitted in convertible currencies may alterna- tively be settled in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts. Nonresident accounts are divided into ordi- nary nonresident accounts, which arise f rom transac- tions in respect of current payments, and special non- resident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of capital transfers. Furthermore, Iraqi nationals who have been working abroad for at least a year or who become residents after having been nonresidents may open accounts in foreign currencies with banks in Iraq and credit these with up to 50 per cent of their foreign savings. Balances in such accounts may be used for a variety of purposes, including imports for the holder's personal use, imports of certain capital goods, or meeting expenditures abroad for travel, medical treat- ment, and study purposes; payments from these accounts up to the equivalent of ID 500 a year do not require Central Bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of many commodities, including jute, sugar, tea, edible oil, certain medical supplies, machine tools, and automobiles, are a government monopoly. All pri- vate imports except those of the private sector oil com- panies require licenses; in principle these are issued in accordance with an annual import program, but this program has been made increasingly flexible, also for imports of consumer goods. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and all imports f rom Hong Kong other than certain essential goods are prohibited. Imports of some commodities on a Protection List are in principle prohibited from all sources. A tax of up to 15 per cent is levied on the amount of any supplementary import licenses above a private importer's annual quota. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of l/2 of 1 per cent is levied on imports of capital goods and a tax of % of 1 per cent on imports of consumer goods. All imports subject to import duty are also subject to a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty. Licensed dealers make exchange available upon pres- entation of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments from foreign currency accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above), all payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports carried on a c. & f. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. Licensed dealers are'permitted to transfer up to 75 per cent of income accrued to Arab and foreign nationals resident in Iraq; for workers and technicians this limit is 50 per cent. There is a basic exchange allowance for tourist and business travel of ID 250 a trip for each person 12 years of age or over (ID 125 for children under 12) for trips of a month or less to Arab countries, socialist countries, Iran, and Turkey; for trips of over a month the allow- ance is increased to ID 300 (ID 150 for children under 12), and for subsequent trips in the same calendar year these allowances are reduced to 50 per cent of the basic allowance. For travel to other countries, the basic allow- ance is ID 400 a trip for each person 12 years of age or over for trips not exceeding one month, ID 500 for longer trips, and 50 per cent of the basic allocation for subsequent trips in the same calendar year. In addition, there are special allocations of up to ID 2,000 a person for medical treatment abroad, and of ID 800 for persons accompanying a patient. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, in addition to 50 per cent of the domestic currency equivalent of the foreign exchange allocated, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permitted to take out the equivalent of ID 200 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 100 for persons over 5 and under 18). On leaving the country, Iraqi nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 20, except when traveling to Gulf coun- tries or on an official mission the entire expense of which is borne by the Government. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Hong Kong, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and exports of certain goods to all other countries are prohibited. The Ministry of Economy has authority to prohibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The Council for the Regulation of Trade may also prohibit the export of certain commodities. The export of certain items is reserved for the Marketing and Services Corporation. All other exports are licensed freely. Exporters must generally undertake to repatriate their foreign exchange proceeds through a licensed dealer and to surrender them within 6-12 months after shipment. Proceeds from exports of dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding I r a n ), India, and Pakistan are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600 in value or 25 tons in weight. Some commodities may be exported on a com- pensation (bar ter) basis. This system links the export of certain "new" exports to the import of prohibited items. Exports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Subsidy Fund. IRAQ Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts in excess of ID 50 from invisibles must be surrendered within three months to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel currency), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Nonresidents who are engaged in border trade, however, may bring in ID 600 in Iraqi currency. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa, but they must deposit it with a licensed dealer; such deposits may be con- verted into local currency at the official rate, and repatri- ation to the country of origin is permitted. With minor exceptions, foreign companies starting operations in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits net of income tax from foreign investments is limited to 10 per cent per annum of the paid-up capital for trading companies, to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial companies, and to 50 per cent of total profit for service companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also apply to profits on capital resulting from the mandatory reinvestment of profits in excess of the transferable percentage. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limitations and entitled to preferential treatment in sev- eral other respects; interest payments are not subject to any ceilings. All transfers of capital abroad by resi- dents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, require exchange control approval; such transfers are severely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to bring in con- vertible currency freely through a licensed dealer for specified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be transferred abroad in convertible cur- rency. Similar facilities permit Iraqi nationals to bring in convertible currency through a licensed dealer and deposit the funds in foreign currency accounts, balances in which are freely transferable abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 22 of 1973), certain incentives and guarantees may be granted to approved investments of domestic or foreign capital in Iraq. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign-owned firms except banks 3 must have a majority of equity capital held by Iraqi nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requiring special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Since mid-1961, the Rafidain Bank has held a monopoly over the import and domestic distribu- tion of gold needed for industrial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota system based on their past turnover of gold. Travelers may freely bring gold into Iraq, provided that it is declared at the point of entry on a foreign exchange form. Changes during 1975 February 1. Not for Redistribution IRELAND (Position on December 37, 7975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Irish Pound. Since June 23, 1972, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the Irish pound within prescribed margins, except for sterling. The Cen- tral Bank of Ireland quotes the pound sterling at par with the Irish pound, and transactions in sterling are free of commission. The Bank also quotes buying and selling rates for other currencies, which are approximately equal to the rates quoted against sterling in London. As of December 31, 1975, the Central Bank's buying and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar were US$2.0236 and US$2.0230 per Irish pound. Certain capital transactions involving investment currency (see section on Capital, below) take place at d ifferent effective rates; on Decem- ber 31, 1975 the investment currency premium was 61.84 per cent (based on the spot exchange rate of US$2.0230 per Irish pound ). Forward transactions between authorized banks and their customers must have an underlying commercial transaction. On February 15, 1961, Ireland formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries if the goods are agricultural in character. Import licensing is not used for exchange control purposes. Import and export controls are admin- istered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency Irish exchange control regulations distinguish between (1) the Scheduled Territories, consisting of Ireland, Northern Ireland, Great Britain, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and Gibraltar, and (2) the rest of the world. The latter is subdivided into (1) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries which on June 23, 1972 ceased to be regarded as Scheduled Terri- tories;1 (2) EEC member countries other than the 1The Overseas Sterling Area thus comprises Australia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Bermuda, Botswana, British Indian Ocean Territory, Solomon Islands, British V irg in Islands, Brune i, Cayman Islands, Cyprus, Falkland Islands and Dependencies, Fiji, The Gambia, Ghana, Gilbert Islands, Grenada, Guyana, Hong Kong, Ice- land, India and Sikkim, Jamaica, Jordan, Kenya, Kuwa i t, Leeward Islands, Lesotho, Malawi, Malaysia, Maldive Islands, Malta, Mauritius and Dependency, Nau ru, New Zealand, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Pitcairn Islands, Qatar, St. Helena and Dependen- cies, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Singapore, South A f r ica, Namibia (South West A f r ica ), Sri Lanka, Swaziland, Tanzania, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks and Caicos Islands, Tuvalu (Ellice Islands), Uganda, United Arab Emirates, Western Samoa, Windward Islands, People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, and Zambia. United Kingdom and Ireland; (3) Rhodesia; and (4) the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST), which consist of all other countries. Payments to and from other Scheduled Territories may be made freely in Irish pounds or pounds sterling; certain insurance payments between Scheduled Territories, however, may be made in foreign currencies.2 Authorized payments to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may be made in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. The proceeds of exports to coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rho- desia must be received in Irish pounds or sterling through an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. The proceeds of permitted exports to Rhodesia must be received in foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency; payments to Rhodesia are subject to special regulations. Residents are defined as persons who are permanently resident, for exchange control purposes, in the Scheduled Territories. However, some Irish regulations are in terms of Irish residents (residents of Ireland) only. Ireland is a Scheduled Terri- tory for purposes of the exchange control regulations of the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts Accounts of persons resident in the Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as resident accounts. Accounts of per- sons resident in countries outside the Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as nonresident accounts and, with the exception of Rhodesian Accounts, are designated Exter- nal Accounts. These may be credited with payments authorized for transfer to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts in Irish pounds or sterling, with the proceeds in Irish pounds or sterling of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency sold by a resi- dent of a country outside the Scheduled Territories to an authorized bank in Ireland, and with the proceeds of Irish currency notes (the crediting of notes in denomina- tions exceeding <£Ir 10 requires specific approval) or sterling notes received from outside the Scheduled Terri- tories. Balances on these accounts may be transferred freely to other External Accounts in Irish pounds or in sterling, used for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, or converted through an authorized bank in Ireland into any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Accounts held by or on behalf of residents of Rho- desia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. The opening of such accounts, and all debits and credits thereto, require the prior approval of the Central Bank. 2 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than those of a Sched- uled Territory. 245 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia require a special license. With this exception, the import of goods into Ireland is subject to three types of admin- istrative control. Under one type, which covers only a limited range of commodities for protective and other nonbalance of payments purposes, imports of certain commodities are subject to quantitative restrictions, which, in most cases, are on a world-wide basis.3 Indi- vidual import licenses are required for these goods and are used to limit the quantity of goods imported. In addition, special quota restrictions apply to certain tex- tiles and yarns originating in any of 16 specified coun- tries or territories.4 Second, imports of certain goods from non-EEC sources may from time to time be subject to restriction or surveillance by virtue of EEC decisions, directives, or regulations. All other imports generally are free of quantitative restrictions. Under the third type of control, prior permission of the Central Bank is required before orders may be placed for goods originat- ing outside the Scheduled Territories, if they are not to be used in Ireland or are to be delivered more than nine months after the date of the order. In addition, Ireland has since June 1975 operated a system of surveillance licensing for imports from all sources of certain foot- wear, clothing, and other textiles, and for imports from non-EEC sources of specified other footwear; under this system, licenses generally are issued virtually automatically. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies which have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regula- tions are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For permitted imports, appropriate exchange or per- mission to credit Irish pounds or sterling to an External Account is granted automatically. Exchange control forms are required for import payments exceeding <£Ir 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control unless they are for transactions out- side the Scheduled Territories. Payments to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. Approval to make payments for most invisi- bles is delegated to the authorized banks; for other invisibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tourist travel outside the Scheduled Territories (other than to Rhodesia) there is a basic allowance for residents of the State of <£Ir 300 a person for each trip. 3 Most of the remaining quotas are being gradually increased in accordance with EEC commitments and with an obligation in the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement; the enlargements are made on a global basis, although the obligations relate only to goods origi- na t ing in the United Kingdom and the other EEC countries. 4 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Republic of China, Czechoslo- vakia, German Democratic Republic, Hong Kong, Hunga ry, India, Japan, Macao, Malaysia, Pakistan, Poland, Roman ia, U.S.S.R., and Yugoslavia. 246 For business travel, up to <£Ir 2,000, at a rate of <£Ir 40 a day, is allowed for each journey, or alternatively up to £Jr 300 for each trip. Limits are also established for allowances for education and other purposes. Applica- tions for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unauthorized export of capital is involved. Not more than <£Ir 300 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the fo rm of currency notes. Persons travel- ing to destinations outside the United Kingdom (other than to Rhodesia) may also take with them up to «£Ir 25 in Scheduled Territory currency notes. Travelers who are resident outside the Scheduled Territories (other than Rhodesia) may take with them any foreign cur- rency notes that they brought into Ireland. There is no restriction on the amount of Irish or other banknotes that may be taken to the United Kingdom. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a limited range of goods. There is a special restriction on exports to Rhodesia. Exporters of goods to countries outside the Scheduled Territories must obtain payment for the goods within six months of shipment, if their value exceeds <£ Ir 100. When payment is received in foreign curren- cies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an author- ized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceeding <£Ir 2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing exchange receipts f rom invisibles, but if foreign currencies are received they must be offered for sale to an authorized bank or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign currency held by a person after his return f rom a tr ip abroad may be retained for three months f rom the date he received the exchange, for use on a subsequent trip abroad. There are no limitations on the import of Irish or foreign banknotes. Capital Inward and outward movements of capital between Ireland and other Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control and take place at the official exchange rate. Exchange control approval is required for all transfers of capital to countries outside the Sched- uled Territories. Applications for transfer of capital at the official market rate of exchange by residents of the State emigrating to OSA countries, EEC member coun- tries other than the United Kingdom, or RNST countries are approved up to a limit of <£Ir 20,000 a family; there is no such allowance for emigration to Rhodesia. Where the total value of an emigrant's assets exceeds <£Ir 20,000, the transfer of the excess amount is restricted for a period of four years from the emigrant's redesignation as a nonresident, i.e., from the date of departure f rom Ireland. After the four-year period, the assets are to be treated in the same way as those of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution non-Scheduled Territory residents who have never been resident in Ireland. However, permission is given at any time after redesignation for the restricted funds to be transferred outside the Scheduled Territories through the investment currency market (see below) or invested in Irish registered securities or in sterling securities.5 For Irish residents taking up employment and resi- dence in an EEC country other than the United King- dom, applications are considered to transfer Irish or U.K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of «£Ir 20,000; the additional facilities are authorized at the official rate of exchange if they are shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to take up employment in the country concerned. Applications for the transfer of resident-owned capital for purposes other than emigration are considered on their merits, but there are special facilities for residents taking up employment in EEC countries other than the United Kingdom and for direct investment in such countries. There are no restrictions on the inflow of capital, but inward direct investment from outside the Scheduled Territories requires exchange control approval (which normally is granted) 6 and net inflows into the banks may be subject to guidelines set from time to time by the Central Bank. Since January 16, 1973, banks have been requested to deposit with the Central Bank 50 per cent of any net capital inf lows ;7 however, subject to prior consultation with the Central Bank, the deposit require- ment may be waived for capital inflows that assist in the financing of major industrial development projects. Purchases of unquoted Irish securities by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories require exchange control approval, and the purchase of nonurban land by foreign nationals in most cases requires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in foreign cur- rencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. However, investment currency, i.e., the foreign currency proceeds f rom the sale mainly of foreign currency securi- ties 8 sold outside the Scheduled Territories, may be fully reinvested in foreign currency securities, provided that the securities sold were held prior to April 7, 1965, or acquired by "switches" from securities so held, and that the investment is carried out within six months from the date of sale through a bank, a stockbroker, or a solicitor. Where the securities sold were purchased with investment currency on or after April 7, 1965, 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be surrendered at the official rate. Investment currency may be invested temporarily in foreign currency certificates of deposit and similar paper 5 Securities solely payable in pounds sterling and quoted on a recog- nized security market within the Scheduled Territories. 6 On January 1, 1976 the exchange control regulations governing direct investment in Ireland were reissued. No policy changes were involved but existing policy and procedures were clarified and a sec- tion on intercompany accounts was introduced. 7 At present the base date by reference to which inflows are measured is February 18, 1975. 8 Foreign currency securities are all securities on which capital monies and dividends are payable or optionally payable in a foreign currency and that are quoted on a recognized security market. IRELAND with up to six months to run to final maturity, without incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on maturity or resale, provided that the limit of six months for the holding of investment cur- rency is not exceeded. The entire foreign currency pro- ceeds from the sale outside the Scheduled Territories of property for personal use owned by residents are nor- mally regarded as investment currency where the whole of the property is sold; where part of such a property is sold, the full foreign currency proceeds must be sold in the official exchange market. Residents may obtain, sub- ject to individual permission, reasonable amounts of investment currency to purchase from non-Scheduled Territory residents property outside the Scheduled Terri- tories for personal use; payments for attendant expenses and improvements must also be made with investment currency. Approval is normally limited to one property a fam i ly. Purchases from residents of the Scheduled Territories must be settled in sterling. Transactions in securities are controlled to ensure that capital is not transferred outside the Scheduled Territories. Direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories requires prior approval and may normally be financed with investment currency or by borrowing foreign cur- rency; in certain cases the use of official exchange may be approved, depending on the merits of the project. Use of official exchange is allowed, however, for all approved new direct investments by Irish residents in EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom. The foreign currency proceeds of the sale or liquidation of direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories are not normally eligible for sale in the investment cur- rency market. Dealings in Irish registered securities are permitted freely between residents of the Scheduled Territories. Specific approval is required for all dealings by Irish residents in securities payable in Rhodesian currency. Remittances of cash gifts or personal loans to OSA countries are normally permitted up to <£Ir 1,000 a donor a calendar year; the corresponding limit for other non-Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia is «£Ir 300 a donor a year. For dependents, an additional amount of up to <£Ir 2,000 a donor a year in cash gifts or personal loans may be remitted to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. Authorized banks may freely accept deposits in for- eign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories and lend such deposits on to other nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Application must be made to the Central Bank for nonbank private sector borrowing from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories; such applications are considered on their merits and, except as regards borrowing for the acquisition of property for personal use, on the benefit likely to accrue to the econ- omy. Public sector borrowing outside the Scheduled Territories is undertaken following consultation with the Central Bank. Lending of Irish currency to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories is not normally permitted, 247 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND except to the extent that overdraft facilities may be pro- vided by the banks to members of non-Scheduled Terri- tories' diplomatic and consular missions in Ireland, and except that banks may freely make available loan and overdraft facilities in Irish pounds or sterling to residents of OSA countries, provided that the underlying transac- tion is a trade transaction or one associated with the movement of goods. Provided that the company is not a medium for portfolio investment, a subsidiary or branch of an EEC-controlled company can, subject to exchange control approval, obtain from Irish banks all the finance it requires for its operation in Ireland. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coins in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Although there are no import restrictions, residents require specific exchange control permission to purchase gold coins or bullion outside Ireland. Specific exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coins and bullion outside Ireland. Specific permis- sion to buy or export gold coins or bullion normally is given only for bona fide numismatic or industrial pur- poses, respectively. Residents of Ireland are not per- mitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1975 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative import regulations were made in accord- ance with EEC decisions and directives; most of these related to textiles, beef and veal, or electronic calculators. January 1. A revised customs tariff schedule took effect. The changes included (1) a further reduction of 20 per cent in duties on imports f rom EEC member states other than the United Kingdom; (2) a 20 per cent reduction in duties on imports of U.K. and Northern Irish origin of those goods not subject to tar iff reduc- tions under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement; and (3) a fur ther move toward alignment of the full and the preferential rates of customs duties with the rates in the common customs tariff of the EEC. January 1. Direct investment by Irish residents in EEC countries was formally liberalized, the use of offi- cial exchange being allowed for all approved new direct investments by Irish residents in EEC member countries other than the United Kingdom. Previously, the use of official exchange for this purpose was subject in principle to a limit of £Ir 250,000 a project a year, while appli- cations to transfer larger amounts at the official exchange rate were considered on their merits. January 1. New import quotas came into effect for superphosphates (not of U.K. origin) and for miscel- laneous textiles and textile piece goods (when originat- ing in countries specified in footnote 4, above). 248 January 15. The 1975 budget provided for govern- ment borrowing abroad of <£Ir 225 million and foreign borrowing by public enterprises of <£Ir 50 million. April 16. Following the imposition of restrictions on imports of gold coins by the United Kingdom on April 15, specific exchange control permission was again required for the purchase of gold coins outside Ireland. Specific permission to buy or export gold coins or bul- lion outside Ireland henceforth was normally given only for numismatic or industrial purposes, respectively. Pre- viously, specific permission was not required to import gold coins from elsewhere in the Scheduled Territories, and permission to export gold coins to elsewhere in the Scheduled Territories was given for all bona fide transactions. May 29. The OECD Declaration of May 30, 1974 on Imports, Exports, and Other Current Account Transac- tions was renewed for one year. June 12. Ireland unilaterally introduced a system of surveillance over imports f rom all sources of certain footwear, clothing, and other textiles and over imports f rom non-EEC sources of specified footwear under tariff heading 64.02A. Licenses would generally be issued virtually automatically. July 1. A revised customs tariff schedule took effect. The main changes were (1) the tenth and final annual reduction in duties on imports of U.K. or Northern Irish origin under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Agreement took place, involving the abolition of customs duties on virtually all industrial products originating in the United Kingdom or Northern Ireland; and (2) import quota restrictions on several items were abolished, including superphosphates. July 1. The global import quotas for specified indus- trial items lapsed; these items then were fully liberalized f rom all sources. July 1. Improved market access was granted to many imports from specified developing countries, under the terms of the Lome Convention between the EEC and certain developing countries of Africa, the Caribbean area, and the Pacific region (the ACP countries). July 1. Personal clothing and footwear, whether domestically produced or imported, were completely relieved of value-added tax. July 10. The Commission of the EEC authorized Ire- land to apply un t il December 31, 1975, a 10 per cent import duty on leather footwear originating in the United Kingdom. On December 23, the Commission authorized the application of this duty in 1976 to imports f rom all sources, inside or outside the EEC. August 4. A National Foreign Trading Company, with 20 per cent Irish Government participation, was established. It was to purchase commodities from devel- oping countries in order to ensure stable supplies to Irish trade and industry. It also was to endeavor to improve export opportunities of small and medium enterprises in Ireland. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution August 4. The EEC informed the GATT that the European Communities were withdrawing the invoca- tion of Article XXXV of the General Agreement with respect to Japan, insofar as this concerned Ireland. The relevant decision by the Council of the European Com- munities took effect 30 days after this notification. August 18. The amount in foreign currency notes which may be exported by travelers, in their baggage or on their person, was increased from <£Ir 250 to <£Ir 300. The limit of ,£25 in Irish or British notes continued to apply. September 16. The Government raised a US$250 million medium-term Euro-dollar bank loan, September. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System1 The par value is 0.120370 gram of fine gold per Israel Pound. On August 5, 1975, however, the authorities ceased to ensure that the exchange rate for the Israel pound would be based on its par value. They establish from time to t ime the buying rate of the Israel pound in terms of the U.S. dollar; on December 31, 1975 this rate was I .£7.10 = US$1. The Bank of Israel estab- lishes buying and selling rates for certain other curren- cies, based on the rate for the U.S. dollar. Authorized banks are permitted to buy and sell foreign currencies at spot rates d ifferent from those officially quoted by the Bank of Israel, but they may quote rates only within the range established by the quotations of the latter. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Foreign Exchange Control of the Ministry of Finance, under the responsibility of the Controller of Foreign Exchange and in cooperation w i th other government agencies and is carried out through authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected in the cur- rency and manner prescribed by the exchange control authorities. Settlements with countries w i th which pay- ments agreements are in force 2 are usually made in U.S. dollars as an accounting un i t. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either on foreign cur- rency accounts or on local currency accounts. The open- ing of nonresident foreign currency accounts does not require prior approval. The principal type of nonresi- dent foreign currency account is the PATACH account. The holder may freely effect transfers from his foreign currency account; he may also convert funds held in the account into local currency at the official rate of exchange. Local currency accounts of nonresidents are of the following types: (1) Registered Accounts —for payments to and hold- ings of foreign aviation, shipping, insurance, and film companies and for nontransferable holdings of former residents —may be established only with special approval. Funds acquired from the sale of real estate and awaiting repatriation must also be held in Registered Accounts. Aviation, shipping, and insurance companies may freely convert at the official rate of exchange any amounts held on these accounts which are surplus to local requirements; film companies may do so under indi- 1W i th effect from February 16, 1976 a surcharge of 15 per cent was applied to purchases of fore ign exchange for payments in respect of certain invisibles, including foreign travel. 2 Brazil and Portugal. 250 vidual arrangements made with each company. Regis- tered Account funds held by former residents may be used for investment in listed Israeli securities, for pur- chase of real estate, for tourist expenses in Israel up to an amount of I <£ 250 a day 3 for the account holder and for each member of his fam i ly, for remittances of up to I £15,000 a year in support of relatives who are resi- dents of Israel, for the settlement of taxes payable in Israel by the owner of the account, arid for donations to public and charitable institutions. Funds representing the sales proceeds of certain real estate become transfer- able a f ter five years, in equal installments over the following five-year period. Ownership of Registered Accounts may not be transferred. ( 2) Tourist Demand Deposit Accounts —to hold the proceeds from the conversion by tourists or travel agents of any kind of foreign currency and of Development Loan bonds. (3) Other nonresident accounts in local currency may be used to hold funds derived from former investments that are eligible for transfer at the official exchange rate. Balances may be transferred freely between nonresi- dents. The accounts may be liquidated at any time by the purchase of foreign exchange at the official rate; such fore ign exchange may be freely transferred abroad or credited to a PATACH account. Funds in these accounts may also be used within Israel by conversion into Israel pounds, and no limit is placed on the amount that may be withdrawn. Israeli residents who are temporarily living and earn- ing abroad may maintain foreign currency in temporary PAMAZ accounts in Israel. Balances in such accounts may be freely used abroad when the holder is abroad; when he is in Israel he may only convert these funds into local currency at the official exchange rate. Immi- grants and temporary residents have the right to maintain foreign currency deposits in PAMAZ accounts for the first ten years after arrival in Israel. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may maintain foreign currency deposits with authorized banks in Israel on either PAZAK accounts, which may be held by all recipients of foreign exchange other than those to whom exchange has been allocated f rom domestic sources, or TAMAM accounts, which may be held by recipients of restitution payments and disability pensions. PAZAK accounts are demand or time deposit accounts denominated in convertible currencies. All foreign exchange receipts, except those derived from exchange allocations by the Ministry of Finance but including export proceeds, may be placed in PAZAK accounts with authorized dealers, who must redeposit the foreign cur- 3 Increased to I £400 a day in February 1976. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution rency funds with the Bank of Israel. Account holders may retain foreign exchange in this manner or may exchange it into local currency. Account holders may use foreign exchange balances in PAZAK accounts to make any authorized foreign payments. Balances in PAZAK accounts are not negotiable between residents, but only among members of the immediate fam i ly of the account holder. TAMAM accounts also are demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies with authorized deal- ers, who must redeposit the foreign currency funds with the Bank of Israel. One third of convertible exchange receipts derived from personal restitution payments and from pensions, etc., of disabled soldiers who served dur- ing World War II may be credited to TAMAM accounts. The permitted uses of TAMAM accounts include the following: (1) the purchase through the medium of the authorized bank holding the account of foreign securities denominated in convertible foreign currency that are registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries; (2) payment of premiums on existing life insurance policies denominated in foreign currency; (3) payment of expenses in connection with travel and subsistence abroad in excess of the basic travel exchange allocation of the equ iva lent of US$450 a trip, provided that not more than the equivalent of US$1,800 a trip is drawn by the account holder and for each member of his fam i ly; 4 and (4) payment of legal expenses resulting from restitution claims. NATAD accounts are t rans fer accounts in foreign exchange that are used ma in ly for transactions in foreign securities. As stated above, holders of TAMAM accounts may purchase abroad foreign securities denominated in convertible foreign currency and registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries. Foreign securi- ties thus acquired may be traded freely between resi- dents, through the intermediary of the authorized bank that is the depository, against payment either with NATAD or TAMAM funds or in Israel pounds. If the origi- nal buyer resells securities bought with TAMAM account funds for foreign currency he may deposit the proceeds in TAMAM accounts. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign exchange pro- ceeds from the sale of foreign securities in NATAD accounts. Balances in NATAD accounts may be used to purchase further foreign securities but are not negotiable between residents. If foreign securities are sold between residents against Israel pounds, the conversion factor used to establish their domestic currency value is the so-called NATAD rate. On December 31, 1975, it stood at I£8.70 per U.S. dollar. Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited f rom all sources and all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of goods * US$3,000 a tr ip if no TAMAM funds have been used for this pur- pose for three years. ISRAEL listed in the Free Import Orders are free of all licensing and administrative or quantitative restrictions. Other imports are subject to licensing. For commodities on the Automatic Approval List, licenses are issued auto- matically upon application. Other permissible imports constitute the Restricted List. All commodities whose importation is not liberalized are listed in a Negative List. Six basic food products (frozen meat, milk powder, wheat, oilseeds, edible fats, and sugar) are imported exclusively by or for account of the Government. Exchange to pay for items listed in the Free Import Orders or to pay for licensed imports is granted auto- matically. All individual import licenses must be coun- tersigned by the Department of Foreign Exchange Con- trol of the Ministry of Finance. The currency and method of payment are prescribed in each license; if a convertible currency is prescribed, payment may be made in any convertible currency. If payment is to be made by documentary credit, the foreign currency required may be purchased at the time of opening the credit. Funds not transferred abroad immediately must be deposited in a special account with the Bank of Israel un t il transfer is made. Licenses are not issued for imports of goods on consignment unless the recipient of the license imports goods valued at US$100,000 or more within three months. Each license is valid only for a single commodity, and an importer cannot receive more than two such licenses a year. The approval of the Department of Foreign Exchange Control is required for all imports effected under foreign credits; foreign currency financing is not normally permitted except for raw materials or capital goods. Virtually all imports are subject to an import sur- charge of 15 per cent of the c.i.f. value. The main exemptions are for newsprint and uncut diamonds. A purchase tax is levied on almost all imported and domes- tically produced goods, other than capital goods. Payments for Invisibles 5 Most payments abroad for invisibles require individ- ual licenses. Each resident is allowed exchange equiva- lent to US$10-250, which is obtainable on demand, for certain purposes such as the purchase of books, mem- bership dues, and registration in a university. For tour- ist travel abroad, there is an exchange allowance equiva- lent to US$450 a traveler for each journey (US$350 for children under 12).6 For travel for business reasons, the allowance is US$50 a d a y7 for the first 21 days. Exporters are not subject to these limits and may use additional funds resulting from export proceeds. Not more than I £200 in Israel banknotes may be taken out by travelers. Foreign tourists leaving Israel are permitted to repurchase through authorized dealers foreign cur- rency up to US$30. Adult residents traveling abroad 5 See also footnote 1. 8 With effect f rom February 16, 1976 the children's allowance was reduced to US$150. 7 Increased to US$60 a day in February 1976. 251 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL must pay a travel tax of I £750 plus 15 per cent of the price of the ticket.8 Travelers to specified countries are taxed at a lower rate; these include Cyprus, Ethiopia, and Romania. Immigrants and their families are exempt from travel tax for three years from the date of immi- gration or of entry as temporary residents. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses if paid for in freely convertible currencies. For some commodities, however, export licensing is retained for the purpose of quality control. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry maintains a check on export transactions with a low value-added content which are made with bilateral partners; this is done to discourage switch transactions. Export pro- ceeds in foreign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PAZAK account. Exports of most commodities are eligible for incentive payments calculated on the gross value of exports and based on domestic value added; they are designed to rebate estimated internal indirect taxes and the import surcharge. At the end of 1975, the payment for diamonds was I<£1.80 per US$1 of domestic value added, and for other commodities the payment ranged from I<£1 .32 to I<£1.85 per US$19 of gross export value, with the higher rates applicable to commodities with a higher proportion of domestic value added. For inputs directly imported by an exporter there is a system of rebate of customs duties, wharf charges, etc. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds f rom invisibles must, in general, be surrendered. Alternatively, they may be kept in for- eign exchange on PAZAK accounts, balances on which may be exchanged into Israel currency at any time or used to make authorized payments abroad. Any resident is free to accept specified convertible currencies from tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real estate; such receipts must be surrendered within a few days. Hotels are eligible for indirect tax rebates based on the length of stay of foreign tourists; on December 31, 1975 the rebate was I £0.55 per US$1. One third of the foreign exchange received by resi- dents of Israel as restitution payments, and as pensions by disabled soldiers who served in World War II, may be retained in TAMAM accounts and the other two thirds may be held in PAZAK accounts. For ten years after entering Israel, new immigrants are exempt from surrendering their foreign exchange to the Treasury, and they may keep these foreign currencies with authorized banks in Israel or with banks abroad. 8 With effect from February 16, 1976 the travel tax was increased to I£1,000 plus 15 per cent of the price of the ticket for adults; for children the tax was levied at I £500 plus 15 per cent of the price of the ticket. 9 Increased to a range of up to I£2.03 per US$1 with effect from March 1, 1976. 252 Tourists visiting Israel are expected to bring with them the amounts of foreign currency that they will need during their stay. Not more than I <£ 200 in Israel bank- notes may be brought in by travelers. Tourists and others visiting Israel who are holders of Registered Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above) may draw upon such accounts to the extent of I £250 a day for themselves and the same amount for each mem- ber of their families; if they are holders of other non- resident local currency accounts, they may draw on them without limit. Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and belonging to a resident must be surrendered at the offi- cial rate or held in a PAZAK account. Capital brought into Israel for the purpose of investment may, subject to approval, be granted preferential treatment in accord- ance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments of August 16, 1959, which, inter alia, per- mits a nonresident who has made an "approved" invest- ment in foreign currency to transfer all his profits abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Current policy is to grant "approved" status only to enterprises in selected fields of production that fulfill one of the fol- lowing conditions: (1) that they are established either in "priority areas" or in less developed areas; (2) that they are export-oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of output is exported or existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent while at least 50 per cent of the additional output is exported; (3) that, although for economic reasons the enterprise cannot be established in a priority area or in a less developed area, its production is of the import-substitution type; or (4) that the project aims at facilitating the absorption of imm igran ts. There is no longer any difference between an "approved investment" and any other investment made by a nonresident in foreign currency insofar as his rights to transfer abroad the principal or the interest or profits on his investment are concerned, and repayments and amo r t iza t ion of capital may also be transferred (for real estate, the transfer is subject to "five-year" and "ten- year" res tr ic t ions). However, the difference does still exist as regards other benefits, such as income tax, con- cessions, and grants. The principal of foreign investments made prior to January 1, 1958, or made af ter that date in foreign exchange, can be transferred abroad. The proceeds of investments in real estate, however, can only be trans- ferred five years a f ter its purchase, in five equal annual installments over the following five-year period. Proceeds accruing from the repatriation or liquidation of foreign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds from invisibles. Any resident may retain real estate abroad, but not money, securities, or the income f rom such assets; in addition, new immi- grants may retain their liquid assets for ten years. Trans- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution fers abroad of a capital na ture by residents other than new immigrants are generally not permitted. Owners of TAMAM deposits are entitled to purchase foreign securities registered at stock exchanges in speci- fied foreign countries. Foreign securities purchased to the debit of a TAMAM deposit can be sold abroad by their owners, or in Israel either against foreign currency to owners of other TAMAM or NATAD deposits or against Israel pounds. The proceeds of the sale may be credited to the TAMAM account previously debited for the pur- chase. The owner of foreign securities bought through TAMAM or NATAD accounts is also allowed to sell them to residents against Israel pounds, and the purchaser in his turn may sell them either against Israel pounds or against foreign currency (abroad or to holders of TAMAM or NATAD deposits); he is entitled to deposit the foreign currency proceeds in a NATAD account. This is the only manner in which NATAD accounts can be established. The holder of a NATAD account may draw on it to purchase foreign securities abroad, or to pay to a holder of a TAMAM or NATAD account foreign currency for foreign securities. It is also permissible to purchase gold from monies in TAMAM and NATAD accounts, the pro- cedure being the same. A general license allows authorized dealers to pur- chase real estate in Israel for nonresidents. Nonresi- dents may freely purchase shares, provided that pur- chases are financed with converted foreign currency; debentures, however, may be purchased by nonresidents only if they are quoted on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. Direct loans in any form to or from nonresidents are subject to licensing. Gold Residents, including private persons, may freely hold gold in any form either in Israel or abroad; purchases by private persons must be financed out of TAMAM or NATAD accounts, except for purchases of jewelry and of articles containing a minor quantity of gold, such as watches. Gold can be sold only to an authorized dealer and can be bought only from an authorized dealer. Other residents are forbidden to trade in gold, to trans- fer it from place to place, or to take it out of Israel. Imports of gold are permissible only if an import license is obtained. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are transacted by five importing wholesalers. These whole- salers may sell the gold only to purchasers registered with the Purchase Tax Administration. The latter checks these purchases by each manufac turer against the gold content of products marked as "purchase tax paid" in order to eliminate the possibility of sales of these quantities of gold on the market as bullion. Authorized banks converting foreign currency of any k ind for tourists, or converting Devel- opment Loan bonds, were advised to credit the proceeds to Tourist Demand Deposit Accounts, which could be used by tourists to obtain exemption f rom local taxes. Funds held in tourists' nonresident or blocked accounts could be transferred for this purpose to the credit of Tourist Demand Deposit Accounts. In addition, travel agents could establish Tourist Demand Deposit Accounts; such accounts could be credited with the proceeds from the conversion of foreign currency debited to PAZAK accounts and received by travel agents as advances for tourists' reservations. Banks were also instructed to open for each hotel an account denominated in Israel pounds to which its proceeds from tourism must be credited, so that banks could issue hotels a monthly certification, expressed in U.S. dollars and calculated at the official exchange rate, of a hotel's foreign currency receipts f rom tourists as reflected in these accounts. 254 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Kate System The par value is 0.00142187 gram of fine gold per Italian Lira. A central rate of Lit 581.500 = US$1 has been established. On February 13, 1973, however, Italy notified the Fund that for the time being the exchange rate for the lira on the official market for current trans- actions would not necessarily be confined within the announced limits either in respect of the U.S. dollar or in respect of EEC currencies. The rate for the U.S. dol- lar on December 31, 1975 was about Lit 684 per US$1.1 The monetary authorities do not in principle intervene in the forward exchange market; forward premiums and discounts are normally left to the interplay of market forces, although the Bank of Italy (the central bank) may from time to time offer the commercial banks cer- tain swap facilities. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot exchange transactions in any currency, and in forward exchange transactions up to 360 days in major convertible and externally convertible curren- cies,2 when dealing with other banks, or up to 180 days when dealing with nonbanks. The permissible amount of forward transactions against lire is subject to a limit on net transactions set individually for each bank. For- ward cover is freely permitted only for commercial transactions; cover in respect of financial transactions requires authorization. Public corporations which have been instructed to borrow abroad on behalf of the Bank of Italy receive full forward cover for their debt service payments. Italy formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Italian Exchange Office (Ufficio Italiano dei Cambi or UIC) on the basis of instructions issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. All sales and purchases of exchange must be effected through banks authorized for this pur- pose. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Certain imports and exports require the prior visa of the National Foreign Trade Institute. Issues of securities by nonresidents require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and are subject in addition to the rules governing the issuing in Italy of Italian securities.
