These currencies are referred to in the Italian regulations as convertible cur- rencies or conto valutario currencies. Republic of San Marino or Vatican City are not subject to exchange control. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries must normally be made in convertible currencies or in lire on Foreign Accounts. For settlements with Egypt, special arrange- ments are applicable under a debt liquidation agreement with that country. Nonresident Accounts The main types of accounts in Italian lire which nonresidents are allowed to maintain with authorized banks in Italy are Foreign Accounts and Capital Accounts.3 The use of these accounts, and of Special Accounts for certain investments, is described below. 1. Foreign Accounts may be credited with transfers from other Foreign Accounts, from Capital Accounts, and from Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, with lire from authorized current and capital payments, and with the proceeds from sales of convertible currencies.4 They may be debited for purchases of any of these currencies in the ordinary market, for transfers to any other For- eign Account, Capital Account, or Special Account Under Law No. 43, for payments to residents of Italy for current and capital transactions, for payments due to residents on account of their disinvestments abroad, and for drawings in cash by the holder of the account or his delegates. 2. Capital Accounts may be credited with transfers from Foreign Accounts, from Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, and from other Capital Accounts, and with the proceeds from the liquidation of foreign invest- ments in Italy not made under the provisions of Law No. 211 of March 2, 1948 or Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 (see below). Capital Accounts may be debited for transfers to any other Capital Account or to Foreign Accounts, and for the purchase of investments not made under Law No. 43, including purchases of personal prop- erty or real estate in Italy. 3. Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 of Febru- ary 7', 1956 are accounts in the names of nonresidents 3 A Ministerial Decree of February 4, 1976 provided for the estab- lishment of Emigrants' Foreign Currency Accounts. Implementing regulations were issued by the UIC on March 26 (Circular No. A328). Such accounts had to be denominated in conto valutario currencies. They could be credited with remittances (including banknotes) effected direct to the bank from abroad (up to 80 per cent of the holder's wage or salary earnings if credits were to exceed Lit 150,000 a month) and with interest on the balances; they could be debited freely for conver- sion into lire, for withdrawals in foreign banknotes (up to Lit 100,000, for re turn trips abroad), and for transfers abroad (except for accounts held by "border-area workers"). These accounts could not be held by Italian representatives abroad or by Italian staff employed by interna- tional organizations. 4 With effect from February 26, 1976 the banks' power to credit for- eign banknotes and credit instruments expressed in foreign currency without prior authorization was limited to Lit 1 million in a calendar year for banknotes and credit instruments not remitted to the banks direct from abroad. 255 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY who have invested in Italy convertible currencies or externally convertible European currencies in accor- dance with the above-mentioned law. These accounts may be credited with the countervalue of convertible currencies sold in Italy, with transfers f rom Foreign Accounts, or f rom other Special Accounts, and with the proceeds f rom sales of investments that have been made in accordance with Law No. 43. They may be debited for purchases of the same currency that was originally sold and for investments in Italy, and balances on them may be transferred to Foreign Accounts, Capital Accounts, or any other Special Account Under Law No. 43. Imports and Import Payments All imports of Rhodesian origin are prohibited. Practically all imports from other countries except the People's Republic of China, Japan, North Viet-Nam, and the CMEA countries are free of quan t i ta t ive restric- tions; all goods, however, require a bank certificate (benestare bancario) for submission to the customs authorities and sometimes also a license issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the M in is try of Foreign Trade. Commodities that still require individual licenses when imported f rom these other countries are included in a negative list (Tabella A Import)? Some items in the list require an import license only when o r ig ina t ing in Israel or Yugoslavia. The general permission to import goods not included in the Tabella A Import applies to Egypt and Yugoslavia only if the goods both originate in and are shipped direct f rom the country concerned; in addition, in respect of imports of raw cotton, rice, and crude petro- leum from Egypt, the payee must reside in that country or in one of the European OECD countries. (Seventy per cent of the value of other imports f rom Egypt must be paid to creditors residing either in that country or in any OECD country, and 30 per cent must be paid in lire to Egypt's lira account with the UIC.) A more extensive negative list (Tabella B Import) contains those commodities which require an individual license when originating in and imported f rom Albania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslo- vakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Roman ia, the U.S.S.R., or North Viet-Nam. There is a special list of commodi- ties, also included in Tabella B Import, whose importa- tion is unilaterally and de facto liberalized when they both originate in and are shipped from Albania, Bul- garia, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, or the U.S.S.R. These goods may be admitted by the customs without a license, although some require a visa issued by the Institute of Foreign Trade. A separate negative list applies to Japan indicating the 5 Tabella A Import applies to all countries except Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Iran, Israel, Japan, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. 256 goods that are subject to restrictive import licensing when imported f rom that country; some other items are included in a special list of commodities for which import licenses are issued freely. All other goods of Japanese o r ig in6 may be imported freely without an individual license, irrespective of the country f rom which they are shipped. Imports f rom non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regula- tions are also applied to imports from non-EEC coun- tries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For imports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no exchange control form is required; for imports from Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the importer is required; for imports over Lit 2 mil- lion in value, an import document completed by an authorized bank is required. The importer must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, through which he must carry out all payments operations related to his import transactions if settlement takes place more than 360 days af ter impor ta t ion. Advance payments for imports require special approval when they are to take place more than 30 days before importation.7 For all authorized imports, the authorized banks pro- vide exchange or permit payment in Italian lire to a Foreign Account, provided that appropriate payment terms are observed (see section on Capital, below). International postal money orders may be used for import payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. Payments for Invisibles In principle, payments abroad for invisibles require licenses issued by the exchange control authorities. Under general authorization, however, the authorized banks may sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the necessary documents are submitted, except for tour- ist travel and travel for business, study, or health rea- sons; their authority to sell exchange for family remit- tances is limited to Lit 35,000 a transfer. Exchange is granted freely for remittances of earnings or investments. Residents may use in terna t ional postal money orders for payments, subject in the case of payments to Switzerland to a limit of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and foreign beneficiary. Certain transactions (but not the related payments) in respect of services are subject to approval by the M in is try of Foreign Trade or the Ministry of Industry. Residents traveling to foreign countries may obtain from the banks exchange equivalent to Lit 500,000 a person a year for tourism, business, medical treat- ment, and education (the corresponding amount for group travel also is Lit 500,000);10 the UIC grants foreign exchange above these allowances (except for tourism), provided that it is satisfied that this is jus t i- fied in the light of the duration and purpose of the trip. Repayment of such loans may be made freely. A deposit requirement is applicable to outward trans- fers of resident-owned capital for direct investments, portfolio investments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and personal capital movements. The transferor must lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for investment fund securities, but mu tual funds investing entirely in I ta l ian securities are exempt) in a noninterest-bearing account with the bank effecting the transfer. In addi- tion, when foreign investments are transferred between residents against lire, the transferee is subject to the deposit requirement, regardless of the date when the investment was made. The deposits are released only when, and to the extent that, disinvestment operations occur, and their release requires the prior approval of the local Bank of Italy office. Purchases by residents of certain bonds issued by specified EEC institutions are exempt. Outward direct investment transactions have from time to time been given an ad hoc exemption. Foreign investment in Italy is, in principle, gov- erned by Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 and sub- sequent implementing regulations. Foreign investments of any kind in Italy, including both direct and port- folio investment and the purchase of real estate, are permitted freely, and no restrictions are applied to their repatriation. Direct investment in OECD countries by physical or juridical persons (other than participation by a financial institution that has its main office in Italy in a foreign company not having the same corporate purpose), is permitted in any form and w i thout any limit.14 Direct investment in other countries may be made only (under the supervision of the UIC) by jur id ical persons in firms that are in the same line of business as that of the Italian firm mak ing the investment; other types of direct investment in such countries require special authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade. The general license to make these investments also covers the reinvestment of earnings and the use for this purpose of the liquidation proceeds of previous investments (a f ter crediting the proceeds of the disinvestment to 14 Financial investment, i.e., investment not intended to establish per- manent relations, is not considered direct investment. The regulations governing direct investment are also not applicable to participations in "holdings" abroad of any kind. 258 bank accounts similar to those established for proceeds from exports and invisibles; see section on Proceeds f rom Invisibles, above). Residents of Italy are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of Italy or the authorized banks, any fore ign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on for- eign stock exchanges, and to deal in such securities among themselves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securities of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited w i th an Italian bank or w i th a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by residents of shares of foreign financial institutions of any k ind ( inc lud ing mu tual f u n d s ), as well as con- vertible bonds issued by such ins t i tu t ions, requires prior approval by the UIC. In practice, however, a resident is able to purchase freely shares of foreign funds that have received authorization f rom the M in is try of For- eign Trade to sell their shares in Italy, since that authori- zation is in fact valid also for the individual resident subscriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, including that of invest- ing at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and that of setting up a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require au thor iza t ion to purchase real estate in EEC countries. All issues of securities by nonresidents on the Italian capital market require the prior approval of the Min- istry of Foreign Trade, and are subject to the rules govern ing the issue in Italy of domestic securities. These rules include the prior approval of the Bank of Italy, and, for issues beyond Lit 500 m i l l ion, that of the M in is try of Treasury, the M in is t ry of Industry, and the In te rm in is te r ial Credit Committee. Issues are normally restricted to in te rna t ional ins t i tu t ions. Transfers in connection with donations, inheritances, and dowries may be made freely. The transfer of prop- erty of residents leaving Italy permanently is allowed in two stages: up to the equivalent of Lit 5 million a person upon presentation of specified documents to an authorized bank at the t ime of leaving Italy, and the rema inder subject to examination of the documents by the UIC, when residence has been established abroad. Banks' authority to sell foreign exchange for cash gifts is limited to Lit 35,000 a remittance. Special regulations apply to commercial credits and credits related to the performance of services. Advance payments for imports may be made freely if importation is to take place within 30 days (but see footnote 7 ); in all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required. When prepayments for imports exceed Lit 5 million,15 an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. Deferred payments for imports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cent, w i th in 360 days after importation, and the balance within 24 months after impor ta t ion; such payments require the prior approval of the UIC if the settlement is to take place between 15 Increased to Lit 10 million on Janua ry 2, 1976. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution 12 months and 24 months a f ter impo r ta t ion. In all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of For- eign Trade is required; where, according to the contract, settlement is to take place more than 360 days a f ter the date of impor ta t ion, the approval of the UIC (in some cases the M in is try of Foreign Trade) is required to make the payment prior to the due date set in the contract. Advance payments for exports may be received freely if exportation is to take place w i th in 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the UIC. Deferred paymen ts for exports are per- mitted if settlement is to take place to the extent of at least 90 per cent within 90 days after exportation, and the balance within 24 mon ths af ter exportation (but see footnote 12 ). For settlement between 90 and 360 days after exportation, the approval of the UIC is required; in all other cases such receipts requ ire the prior approval of the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade. V ir tua l ly identical regulations are in force for the per- mitted credit terms for impor ts and exports of services. In relations with EEC countries, the reciprocal grant- ing of credits for commercial transactions or the per- formance of services, w i th a m a tu r i ty longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to five years, may be effected a f ter exam ina t ion of the documents by the UIC. This applies also in relations with Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland. Loans and credits (the latter only beyond a certain dura t ion, generally 180-360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or with the performance of services require the approval of the M in i s t ry of Foreign Trade. However, financial loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC countries as ind ica ted above. The export of I ta l ian and fore ign securities is per- mitted only when they are owned by nonres iden ts and have been purchased against U.S. dollars, Canad ian dollars, Japanese yen, or externally convertible Euro- pean currencies, or against funds on a Foreign Account or a Capital Account. The net external position of the banks is subject to control by the UIC. This control encompasses ( 1) the spot position vis-a-vis nonresidents in foreign currencies and lire together; and (2) the overall position, spot and forward combined, in all foreign currencies; a balanced foreign currency position on a daily basis is required separately in (a) U.S. dollars, (b) EEC currencies, and (c) all other conto valutario currencies combined. Authorized banks are not subject to any ceiling on their net foreign liability position but are prohibited from m a in t a in ing a net foreign asset position. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Ivory Coast has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transac- tions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de PAfrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place on the basis of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a commission of 2.50 per mill for transfers to countries outside the West African Monetary Union, while trans- fers within the Union are exempt. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Ivory Coast's exchange control measures do not apply in finan- cial relations with (1) France (and its Overseas Depart- ments and Territories, except the French territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Repub- lic of the Congo, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these coun- tries may be made freely. All other countries, except Ivory Coast itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign coun- tries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of External Finance and Credit in the Ministry of Econ- omy and Finance, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast, foreign inward direct investment, and all outward investment in foreign coun- tries. The BCEAO is authorized to collect any informa- tion necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, other financial institutions, the Postal Adminis- tration, and notaries public. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of For- eign Trade in the Ministry of Commerce. iThe CFA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. Prescription of Currency Ivory Coast is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Rhode- sia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Abidjan by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of such banknotes is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports from the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the U.S.S.R. are subject to special provisions. Certain imports are prohibited (e.g., a speci- fied type of coffee-husking machine and wheat flour) or subject to import license (paints, matches, and deter- gen ts ). Imports of rice are related to domestic pro- duction in such a manner that imports are made complementary to purchases of domestically produced rice. All other imports from countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Virtually all imports o r ig ina t ing in EEC countries other than France also are free f rom quan t i ta t ive restrictions and free of license. As a rule, nonliberalized imports from non-EEC coun- tries outside the French Franc Area require import licenses and may be made in accordance with an import program, which is determined annually by the Ministry of Commerce. Under this program, annual global quotas are established for imports f rom such countries and spe- cial quotas for imports from countries with which Ivory Coast ma in ta ins bilateral trade agreements.2 The pro- gram also includes indicative quotas for the EEC coun- tries and a quota for Hong Kong and Eastern European countries. With minor exceptions, imports by sea or air, when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more, are subject to preship- 2 These include Republic of China, Denmark, Egypt, Hungary, Israel, Japan, Norway, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland. 261 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST ment inspection, in order to control their price, quantity, and quality. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000; transactions of lower value must be domiciled if a financial transaction is to be undertaken before customs clearance. The import licenses or import attestations entitle importers to pur- chase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than one month before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresi- dents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Any resident may freely and at any time make remittances abroad up to the equivalent of CFAF 50,000 without indicating their purpose. Resi- dents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism of an amount equiva- lent to CFAF 175,000 a person a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under t e n ); any foreign exchange remain- ing in excess of CFAF 5,000 after return to Ivory Coast must be surrendered. The transfer of the full basic salary of a foreigner working in Ivory Coast is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, pro- vided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out BCEAO bank- notes up to CFAF 25,000. Travelers to other Franc Area countries may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a mem- ber of the West Afr ican Monetary Un ion, the amount taken out must be declared to the customs if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may freely take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000, as well as any travelers checks, etc., issued abroad. Subject to documentation, they may also take out any amount of travelers checks, etc., in foreign currency established in their name after conversion of foreign currency into CFA francs or drawn against a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency in Ivory Coast. Nonresidents who have made a currency declaration upon entry or are able to show the proper banking notices may take out higher amounts. 262 Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Most exports are free of license and require a declaration only. Exports of agricultural commodities, however, require the visa of the Direc- torate of Foreign Trade, also when processed. The due date for payments in respect of exports to foreign countries must not be later than 180 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. The proceeds must be collected and, if the contract is invoiced in a currency other than that of a country of the Franc Area, surrendered on the exchange market, within two months of the due date. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other coun- tries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may br ing in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign bank- notes or other foreign means of payment must sell any amount in excess of CFAF 5,000 to an authorized bank within eight days and must declare them to the customs upon entry. Capital All capital movements between Ivory Coast and Rhodesia are prohibited. Capital movements between Ivory Coast and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital trans- fers to all other countries require exchange control approval, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over foreign inward direct investment, over all outward investment in foreign coun- tries, and over the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those relating to foreign securities, these control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Mone- tary Union, and those other countries whose bank of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate bqilding operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Ivory Coast require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance.3 Foreign direct investments in Ivory Coast,4 must be declared to the Minister of Economy and Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The liquidation of invest- ments, whether direct investments or not, in Ivory Coast or abroad must similarly be declared in advance to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of invest- ments, whether these are Ivory Coast investments abroad or foreign investments in Ivory Coast, must be reported to the Minister within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance, as do issues by Ivory Coast companies. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Ivory Coast Govern- ment and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Ivory Coast has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indi- cated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Ivory Coast, or by approved international trading houses to finance inter- national merchanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 50 million for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed 3 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Ivory Coast and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Ivory Coast. 4 Including those made by companies in Ivory Coast that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Ivory Coast of foreign companies. IVORY COAST the normal market rate. The repayment of loans consti- tuting a direct investment is subject to the formalities prescribed for the liquidation of direct investments. The repayment of other loans requires authorization only if the loan itself was subject to prior approval. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control autho- rization. Law No. 59-134 of September 3, 1959 provides tax and customs duty benefits and other special privileges for new enterprises recognized as having priority status. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Ivory Coast. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance, which is rarely granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured arti- cles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold- filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a weight of 250 grams. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.900364 gram of fine gold per Jamaica Dollar. On February 20, 1973, a central rate of J$l = US$1.10 was established, corresponding at the time to J$ 1.09668 = SDR 1 or 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar and Jamaica avails itself of wider margins. In practice, the Bank of Jamaica's dealings against Jamaica dollars are confined to transactions in Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, to purchases of Canadian, U.K., and U.S. banknotes, and to purchases of certain Caribbean and European banknotes (see below). It deals in other currencies only against sterling and U.S. dollars. The Bank buys and sells U.S. dollars at par, plus a commission of %e of 1 per cent on the selling side. Exchange rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar (except the East Caribbean dollar and the Trinidad and Tobago dollar) are based on the Bank of Jamaica's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the rates against the U.S. dollar for the currencies concerned in international markets. The Bank of Jamaica sets daily official buying and selling rates for dealing with the banks in sterling and Canadian dollars on the basis of the previous day's closing quotations in New York. On the basis of these rates, the Bank also fixes daily rates at which commercial banks must deal with their customers in transactions involving Jamaica dollars against Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, or U.S. dollars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to fix its buying and selling rates of exchange. On December 31, 1975 these rates relating to spot dealings with the com- mercial banks reflected no commission charge on pur- chases but a charge of %6 of 1 per cent on sales. The commercial banks applied a commission charge (pre- mium) of % of 1 per cent on sales of foreign exchange to customers and a commission charge (discount) of Vs of 1 per cent on purchases. For purchases equivalent to J$l,000 or more, the commission charge (discount) was waived. The Bank of Jamaica's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were US$1 = J$0.9075 and US$1 = J$0.9125, respectively. Under an arrangement with the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago and with the East Caribbean Cur- rency Authority, the Bank of Jamaica purchases bank- notes issued by these monetary authorities and repatriates them in return for reciprocity of treatment with respect to collections of Jamaica dollars. The Bank's purchases are made at the middle rate determined on the basis of the prevailing sterling-U.S. dollar rate; for transactions in these currencies, the commercial banks charge a com- mission of 1A of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate, buying and selling. There is a "bourse" (interbank exchange market) in which all commercial banks participate and in which only Canadian dollars and pounds sterling are traded against U.S. dollars. The Bank of Jamaica does not provide forward cover to banks. Capital transactions between nonresidents and non- bank residents are in principle channeled through an investment currency market, which, however, is inopera- tive. Transactions are subject on the buying side to a premium of 10 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buying rate and on the selling side to a premium of 20 per cent on the Bank of Jamaica's buying rate (plus the normal commission charged on sales of exchange). Jamaica formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 22, 1963. Administration of Control The Bank of Jamaica administers exchange control on behalf of the Minister of Finance, subject to certain limitations in respect of which the approval of the Minister is required. The commercial banks are desig- nated as authorized dealers and have authority to pro- vide exchange for imports valued at less than J$10,000, and for basic travel allowances and certain other pay- ments up to specified lesser amounts. Import licenses are issued by the Trade Administrator, who is respon- sible to the Minister of Marketing and Commerce. Prescription of Currency Jamaica has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to all countries may be made by crediting Jamaica dollars to an External Account or in any foreign currency.1 Receipts from all countries must be received by debit of an External Account or in any foreign cur- rency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia, and all payments to Rhodesia require specific authorization. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Jamaica dollars may be held by persons who are regarded for exchange control pur- poses as normally permanently resident outside Jamaica. These accounts are further designated External Accounts or Blocked Accounts. The commercial banks are empowered to open External Accounts in Jamaica dollars for nonresidents 1 All currencies other than the Jamaica dollar are considered foreign currencies. All foreign currencies have been designated as specified currencies. 265 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA except residents of Rhodesia, provided that no credit of Jamaica dollars is made to the accounts without the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica. The funds on these accounts may be transferred freely between nonresidents. External Accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Jamaica approved by the exchange control authorities, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from the sale to an authorized dealer of gold or foreign curren- cies. They may be debited for payments to residents of Jamaica, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for the purchase of foreign currencies. Accounts which are credited with funds that may not be placed at the free disposal of nonresidents of Jamaica (including the proceeds from the sale of undeveloped land) are designated Blocked Accounts. Blocked funds may be invested in local mortgages and in Jamaica dollar securities; the income from such securities is nor- mally available for credit to an External Account. Applications for the release of funds in Blocked Accounts for use in Jamaica by the nonresident owner must be referred to the Bank of Jamaica. The assets of residents emigrating to countries outside Jamaica in excess of the prescribed settling-in allowance of J$ 10,000 are restricted under Section 43 of the Exchange Control Act (see section on Capital, below). Imports and Import Payments A small number of goods may be imported freely from virtually all sources under an open general license.2 All other imports require specific licenses, irrespective of origin. For some goods, licenses are not normally issued unless they originate in member countries of the Caribbean Common Market (CARICOM ).3 Imports are subject, in principle, to a global annual ceiling. Licenses for some items, however, are issued freely; these include raw materials, fuel, and certain capital goods. Imports originating in Rhodesia or South Africa are prohibited, and all imports originating in the People's Republic of China or Cuba require individual import licenses. Cer- tain food items may be imported only by a public sector agency, the Jamaica Nutritional Holdings Limited. Payments for imports equivalent to J$ 10,000 or more are subject to prior registration with the Bank of Jamaica and all payments for imports are subject to the licensing requirements, if any, being met, and the importer presenting a copy of the settlement invoice or other evidence of purchase and value, together with documentary evidence that the goods either have been shipped or are about to be shipped, or that the importer is under contract to make prepayment up to six months 2 For these goods, the open general license applies to all countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. Goods imported under the license must be consigned from one of the permitted countries and must also originate in a permitted country. 3 The CARICOM countries are Antigua, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Jamaica, Montserrat, St. Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, and Trinidad and Tobago. For import licensing purposes, the Bahamas are also treated as a CARICOM country. 266 prior to shipment; specific exchange control approval is required for advance payments. Certain goods are subject to a consumption tax, whether they are imported or manufactured domesti- cally. Where such goods are imported, the tax is col- lected at the port of entry and is calculated on the sum of the value accepted for customs and the customs duty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require the approval of the exchange control authorities. Except for transactions involving residents of Rhodesia, the following applies. With the exception of payments in respect of foreign travel, bona fide current payments are not restricted. Approval is granted freely for payments for all com- mercial transactions, when the application is supported by the appropriate documentary evidence. A basic exchange allocation of J$500 a person for each 12-month period for foreign travel other than for busi- ness and professional reasons is made available auto- matically to residents by the authorized dealers; this allowance may be accumulated for up to two years. Additional amounts are granted in cases of hardship. Facilities for travel for business and professional reasons may be provided by authorized banks at the rate of J$60 a day for up to ten days while applications for higher amounts are dealt with by the Bank of Jamaica.4 Expenses for hotel accommodations, meals en route, etc., that are settled in Jamaica in domestic currency must be deducted from the travel allocations. Authorized dealers may, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence, approve payments for the fol- lowing: consular fees without limit, as well as transfers from the Ministry of External Affairs to accounts in the names of embassies and their established staffs, High Commissioners, and diplomats; and up to a limit of J$100 for subscriptions to trade organizations and professional organizations, and for membership dues, registration fees, correspondence courses, examination fees, and imports of books, magazines, periodicals, and other publications. Requests for additional amounts (except for travel) or for purposes for which there are no standard limits (e.g., remittances by charitable institutions) are approved if the authorities are satisfied that no capital flight is involved. Non-Jamaicans work- ing in Jamaica with the Government or a statutory body, under a work permit, as a rule are allowed to remit abroad only 40 per cent of their gross salary. Residents going abroad may take with them Jamaica banknotes not exceeding J$20 and other banknotes not exceeding J$100. Nonresidents may take out the foreign currency notes they brought in. 4 On February 26, 1976 business firms were asked to limit their requests for foreign exchange for business travel in 1976 to 75 per cent of their actual purchases of foreign exchange in 1975; this guide- line would be applied flexibly. With effect from March 16, 1976, all applications for business travel had to be submitted to the Bank of Jamaica. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds All goods valued at not more than J$200 (f.o.b.) may be freely exported by post or air express to any country not on the prohibited list.5 Where the value exceeds this amount the goods may be exported to all countries except those on the prohibited list, but a specific license is required for the export of certain agricultural products, ammunition, explosives, firearms, antique fu rn i tu re, ready-made garments, gold bullion, mineral and metal ores, and antique paintings. Export- ers are required to surrender their exchange proceeds to authorized dealers within three months from the date of shipment. However, certain exporters may retain, with the approval of the exchange control authorities, an agreed portion of their settlement of overseas com- mitments necessary for their operations; such retained export proceeds must not be sold to other nonbank residents. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized dealer. Residents returning to Jamaica may bring in Jamaica banknotes up to J$20 a traveler, provided this amount was declared on leaving the country, and all travelers may bring in any amount of other banknotes; resident travelers are required to sell their holdings of foreign currencies to a local authorized dealer upon return.6 Capital Outflows of resident-owned capital are restricted, irrespective of their destination. Investments abroad by residents require the approval of the exchange control authorities and are not approved unless they result in tangible benefits for Jamaica. Residents must obtain prior approval from the Bank of Jamaica to make cash gifts, which are normally limited to J$100 in any 12-month period from each adult donor, to nonresidents of Jamaica. With the exception of certain types of investment in real estate, all direct investments in Jamaica by non- residents are granted "approved status," under which the investor is given written assurance that he will be able to repatriate at any time his original investment plus any capital gain. In order to obtain approved status, the investor must register his investment with the Bank of Jamaica. Remittances of current items, such as profits and dividends, are permitted in full when the application is supported by the appropriate set of accounts. 6 The list comprises Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, South Africa, and U.S.S.R. Exports to these countries require specific licenses. In practice, no licenses are issued for exports to South Africa, and exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. 6 With effect from February 26, 1976, tourists were required to settle their hotel bills in foreign currencies unless they could prove that they had purchased an equivalent amount of Jamaica dollars from an authorized bank in Jamaica. JAMAICA Payments for amortization of, and interest on, foreign loans approved by the Bank of Jamaica are permitted upon application to the exchange control authorities. However, nonresidents are not normally permitted to take security in respect of loans made to Jamaican com- panies owned or controlled by them. Domestic bank credit to nonresidents of Jamaica and to nonresident- controlled companies is subject to selective credit con- trols; for this purpose, firms are considered to be nonresident-controlled when the controlling interest is held beneficially, either directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside the CARICOM area. Such lending is subject to approval by the Bank of Jamaica; authorized dealers may, however, without reference to the exchange control authorities, make loans or overdrafts to non- residents of Jamaica up to J$2,000 for certain specified purposes. Authorized dealers may also without refer- ence to the exchange control authorities make loans or overdrafts to resident companies or branches controlled by nonresidents up to J$20,OGO, provided that the bor- rower is not specifically precluded under some prior conditional permission from the exchange control authorities. Other requests are referred to the Bank of Jamaica. In general, foreign nonresidents are not permitted to raise local mortgages. However, nonresidents working in Jamaica under a work permit may acquire a house to live in, with the permissible amount of mortgage restricted to 50 per cent; the transfer of capital gains made from real estate transactions by such persons is restricted on their emigration to J$l 0,000 a year. Foreign sellers of land whose funds are blocked under the regulations of January 1974 and persons whose funds are restricted under Section 43 of the Exchange Control Act can invest the blocked or restricted funds in Jamaica in stocks registered locally and in mortgages, and income therefrom can be remitted, subject to a maximum of J$50,000 annually. Foreign nonresident owners of real property in Jamaica, when selling it to residents of Jamaica, are allowed to remit from Jamaica, in the first instance, the amount they paid originally from funds brought into Jamaica; the balance of the sale price can be remitted in ten equal installments, subject to a m in imum remittance in any one year of J$ 10,000, except where the owner had received a previ- ous undertaking that the investment in land carried "approved status." Foreign nonresident owners of houses built on residential lots are dealt with in the same manner, provided that the nonresident seller can satisfy the Bank of Jamaica as to the amount spent in Jamaica in acquiring the lot and constructing the build- ing thereon. Jamaican nationals emigrating are granted a settling-in allowance of the equivalent of J$ 10,000 at the official market rate of exchange (up to J$20,000 on a basis of need where the emigrant is 60 years of age or over and has retired f rom w o r k ); any assets in excess of the 267 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA allowance are restricted for four years. On the fourth anniversary of the emigrant's departure from Jamaica, the emigrant may normally remit up to J$50,000 a family unit; in the fifth year after emigration he may remit J$25,000, and similar amounts annually there- after.7 Emigrants in possession of overseas assets at the time of emigration are entitled to remittances only when the accumulated remittance entitlements, referred to above, plus the settling-in allowance for an emigrant family unit of J$ 10,000, exceed the value of his prop- erty abroad, valued on the basis of their current value at the time of emigration; however, if the emigrant can prove that the assets held abroad by him were not transferred directly or indirectly from Jamaica, such assets are not taken into account in the calculation of the amounts released. Moreover, the amounts of per- mitted releases are increased to the extent that property owned by the emigrant in Jamaica at the time of emigra- tion was acquired from the proceeds of the emigrant's own funds brought in from outside Jamaica. These arrangements are applicable also to naturalized Jamaican citizens, and to nonnationals resident in Jamaica who are not subject to the provisions of the Work Permit Law. For income arising to emigrants from property in Jamaica or any other source in Jamaica, whether by way of salaries, commissions, fees, shares of profits, or of any other kind whatsoever, remittances are restricted to the lowest of the following limits: (1) J$50,000 per annum after tax; (2) 10 per cent per annum of the value of the property in Jamaica; or (3) actual income arising each year in Jamaica. Where the emigrant owned property abroad at the time of emigration, the amounts under ( 1 ), ( 2 ), and (3) are reduced by a sum equivalent to 10 per cent of the foreign property value, such value being reduced each year by the amount of J$25,000. However, the reductions do not apply where the property owned abroad was not transferred from Jamaica or out of the proceeds of such transfer, or was transferred abroad with the permission of the authori- ties. Remittances to beneficiaries under wills or intestacies are limited to J$ 10,000 divided among them in the first instance; J$50,000 for all beneficiaries at the end of the fourth year after first approval of a distribution in cash or kind; and J$25,000 among them a year thereafter.8 Gold Two commemorative gold coins of J$20 and J$100 are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Jamaica for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the 7 On February 26, 1976 the limits on remittances to emigrants were reduced to J$10,000 a family unit on the fourth and subsequent anniver- saries of the emigrant's departure from Jamaica. The initial settling-in allowance of J$ 10,000 remained unchanged. 8 These amounts were reduced in February 1976 to J$10,000 on the fourth anniversary and J$10,000 annually thereafter. 268 monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. All commercial imports of jewelry are prohibited. Changes during 1975 January 1. On June 28, Notice No. 2935 removed the People's Republic of China, Cuba, North Korea, and North Viet-Nam from the list. March 25. An export levy on sugar was introduced of J$100 a long ton. New exchange control guidelines came into force, providing, inter alia, for the following changes: (1) Releases of proceeds from property in Jamaica owned by Jamaican emigrants were reduced from J$ 100,000 in the fourth and J$50,000 in the fifth and subsequent years after emigration to J $50,000 and J$25,000, respectively. Different provisions applied to emigrants who owned property abroad at the time of emigration and to emigrants who initially acquired the property in Jamaica from the proceeds of funds brought in from own resources outside Jamaica. (2) Remittances of income accruing to emigrants from property in Jamaica or from any other source in Jamaica, whether by way of salaries, commissions, fees, shares of profits, or of any other kind whatsoever, were restricted to the lowest of the following limits: (a) J$50,000 per annum after tax; (b) 10 per cent per annum of the value of the property in Jamaica; or (c) actual income arising each year in Jamaica. Where the emigrant owned property abroad at the time of emigration, the amounts under ( a ), ( b ), and (c) were reduced by a sum equivalent to 10 per cent of the foreign property's value, this value being reduced each year by J$25,000. (3) Remittances to nonresident beneficiaries under wills or intestacies were limited to amounts, for all ©International Monetary Fund. Thus, they were reduced from J$ 100,000 in the fourth year after the first approval of a distribution to J$50,000, and from J$50,000 in the fifth and subse- quent years to J$25,000. Special provision would be made to permit traders normally importing only from CARICOM countries, and thus not holding current importers' quotas, to continue their normal level of importation. Not for Redistribution JAPAN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00246853 gram of fine gold per Japanese Yen. A central rate of ¥ 308.00 = US$1 has been established, and Japan avails itself of wider mar- gins. Since February 14, 1973, however, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the yen within any announced margins. The interbank selling rate for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 was about ¥ 305 per US$1. Authorized banks may freely carry out spot and forward exchange transactions with nonresident banks and among themselves; their forward transactions with resident customers must have a permitted underly- ing transaction. Japan formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from April 1, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Min- istry of Finance, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI), and the Bank of Japan as the Govern- ment's agent. However, most of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to authorized banks referred to as foreign exchange banks. Import and export licensing is handled by MITI. Inward direct investments of a long-term character require the approval of the Minister of Finance and other competent minis- ters. (Most industries have already been liberalized, see section on Capital, below.) Outward direct investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance in exceptional cases only. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made in any cur- rency, including yen, and receipts also may be obtained in any currency. Settlements in yen with foreign coun- tries must be made through a Nonresident Free Yen Account. All payments to Rhodesia require prior approval by the Minister of Finance or the Minister of International Trade and Industry; in many cases such payments are prohibited or restricted for security reasons. Nonresident Accounts There are two main nonresident accounts, as described below. 1. Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. These accounts may be opened by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan and may be credited with the yen pro- ceeds from exports of goods to Japan and from other authorized transactions, with yen proceeds from sales of all foreign currencies, with transfers from other Free 270 Yen Accounts, with interest accrued on balances in these accounts, and with the countervalue in yen of authorized ou tward payments. There are no restrictions on payments from these accounts, and balances may be converted freely into any foreign currency. 2. Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan. They may be credited with yen proceeds f rom transactions other than those which are authorized to be credited to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Permitted credits to Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts are limited mainly to proceeds from the sales of debentures and beneficiary certificates sold within six months from the date of validated acquisition. Balances ou ts tand ing on December 31, 1970 were per- mitted to be transferred to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts or to be remitted abroad. Balances accrued after that date are not convertible into foreign curren- cies, although remittances are permitted each year up to 30 per cent of the balance at the end of the previous year or the equivalent of ¥ 720,000, whichever is higher. Withdrawals from these accounts are authorized for certain purposes, such as meeting the outlays involved in managing investments in Japan and the expenses of non- residents s tay ing in Japan. Transfers to other Nonresi- dent Yen Deposit Accounts may be made freely, thus en ab l ing the ind iv idual account holder to repatriate his funds by selling them to another nonresident in return for foreign currency, but there is no market for such funds in Japan. Imports and Import Payments With the exception of books and periodicals, imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Other imports are subject either to individual licensing by the authorized banks or, if liberalized, to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liberalized. There are two procedures for imports requiring payment in foreign currencies: ( 1) Under the Import Quota System (covering imports of goods on the "negative list," which comprises 82 items, in terms of the four-digit Brussels nomenclature; 27 of the 82 items on the "negative list" have been notified to the GATT as residual restrictions while the other 55 items have been notified as falling under the national security, public health, and moral protection provisions of the GATT), the importer must first obtain from MITI an import quota, which is based on the quantitative principle. If the quota is granted, the importer receives an import quota certificate which entitles him to receive an import license from an author- ized bank automatically upon application. Practically ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution all import quota certificates are issued on a global basis, without regard to the country of origin or the currency of settlement, by MITI. (2) Under the Declaration Sys- tem, imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing and require only a declaration by the importer to a foreign exchange bank. All items subject to the Declaration System may be imported from any country except Rhodesia. Items under state trading include cer- tain dairy products, certain cereals, salt, raw silk, and raw and manufactured tobacco. Payment for imported goods must be made under one of the "standard" methods of settlement for imports. When the settlement proposal is not in accordance with one of the "standard" methods (i.e., when certain advance payment is proposed or payment is to be made more than four months after customs clearance), prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance or the Minister of Interna- tional Trade and Industry. Payments to other countries for invisibles also require approval, but current payments are not restricted and most such payments are approved freely by foreign exchange banks without any limitation or within certain established limits. Payments for cer- tain invisibles, including payments that exceed the established limits, are referred to the Bank of Japan for the purpose of capital control; upon verification of the authenticity of the current transaction, they are auto- matically approved without undue delay. Residents may purchase foreign currencies for payments in connection with travel abroad up to US$ 1,500 a person a trip, sub- ject to validation by a foreign exchange bank; applica- tions in excess of US$1,500 a person a trip require the approval of the Bank of Japan. A traveler is permitted to pay in yen or in foreign currency, before departure, the cost of transportation to and f rom his destination and for all side trips. Residents may freely and at any time make payments abroad up to US$200 a remittance, for virtually any purpose other than import payments, repayments on loans, and technical assistance payments, etc.; the cor- responding amount for current invisibles related to trade is US$1,000 for each remittance. Certain insurance and technical assistance contracts require approval; but when a license for a contract has been granted, any payment resulting from the contract may be made freely. Settle- ments which are not made under a "standard" method require, in principle, individual approval; without such approval, payments for services, etc., may not be made more than three months before or later than six months after receipt of the services, etc. Both residents and nonresidents may take out freely up to ¥ 30,000 in Japanese currency. Subject to verifi- cation, i.e., upon presentation of documentation showing any prior conversion of foreign currency, a nonresident may freely purchase foreign currencies up to the amount JAPAN which he brought into Japan; without verification the conversion into foreign currencies is limited to the equivalent of US$1,000. Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. All exports to Iran, Iraq, and Nigeria require special authorization. All exports (except exports with- out exchange) must be registered with a foreign exchange bank ("bank certification"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods subject to the following restrictions: restrictions on cer- ta in goods to control their export to specified communist countries; restrictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., some staple foods); and restric- tions designed to forestall the imposition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain textiles). Exports under processing and con- signment sale contracts and exports for which settlement is not under the "standard" method also require indi- vidual licenses. Under the "standard" method of settlement for exports, the value of the exported goods must, in gen- eral, be settled by drawing a bill of exchange payable within five months after sight or within six months after shipment. There are no surrender requirements for for- eign currency earnings. The conversion into yen of advance receipts in respect of exports, i.e., proceeds received before shipment, requires an individual license when they exceed the equivalent of US$500,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts under the "standard" method of settlement may be accepted without a license. Under this method, receipts for the value of services, etc., must be obtained within one year before, or within six months after, rendering the service, etc. Contracts for services per- formed for nonresidents when payment is to be received by a nonstandard method are subject to individual licens- ing. Receipts from invisibles need not be surrendered. Both residents and nonresidents may bring in freely any amount in foreign or Japanese currency. Capital Foreign investments in Japan are generally subject to approval, mainly in accordance with the Law Concern- ing Foreign Investment (Law No. 163 of May 10, 1950) or the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law (Law No. 228 of December 1, 1949). All acquisitions of stocks, bonds, debentures, beneficiary certificates, and claims in the form of loans by foreign investors are, in principle, subject to validation or license. However, acquisitions of stocks for portfolio investment are auto- matically approved by the Bank of Japan. All these acquisitions must be made against yen proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange or its equivalent, if the investor wishes to obtain remittance rights upon validation. Stocks in the form of stock dividends from earned sur- 271 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAPAN plus or revaluation of assets may be acquired freely, but application for remittance rights must be made within three months from the date of acquisition. At present, the acquisition of Japanese securities by nonresidents is not restricted, although subject in the case of shares to the foreign ownership limits. The following are deemed to be the same as yen pro- ceeds from the sale of foreign exchange, if they are reinvested in Japan and if approval had been obtained for their acquisition: proceeds from the redemption after ma tur i ty of debentures, beneficiary certificates, or claims in the form of loans; dividends on stocks, interest on debentures or on claims in the form of loans; distributed profits from beneficiary certificates; receipts from tech- nological assistance contracts; and proceeds from sales of stocks, debentures, and beneficiary certificates. In the event of expropriation or compulsory sale of a foreign investment, the amount paid because of expro- priation may be repatriated freely. The remittance of the proceeds from the sale of validated stocks (shares), as well as the transfer abroad of earnings on foreign investments acquired with foreign currency, is permitted. Proceeds from the sale of stocks may be deposited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Proceeds from the sale of bonds, debentures, and bene- ficiary certificates normally may be deposited in Non- resident Free Yen Accounts, if the securities have been held for six months from the date of acquisition. Pro- ceeds from the sale of stocks, bonds, debentures, bene- ficiary certificates, etc., acquired with yen w i thdrawn from Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts may be depos- ited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, provided that the securities have been held for at least three years from the date of acquisition. There are no special rules pre- scribing that the yen proceeds from sales of securities by nonresidents must within any specified period be either reinvested in securities or converted into foreign cur- rency for transfer abroad. Repayments of loans extended to residents from Non- resident Yen Deposit Accounts become remittable, sub- ject to licensing by the Bank of Japan, beginning three years from the date of the loan. When foreign companies desire to establish a branch or a plant in Japan, they are required to inform the Ministry of Finance and MITI in advance through the Bank of Japan. When branches or plants established by foreign companies wish to bring in funds from their main offices abroad, they are required to obtain licenses. The branches established in accordance with approved procedures are permitted to remit their profits and prin- cipal abroad. Foreign direct investment in Japan generally requires approval by the Minister of Finance and other compe- tent ministers after deliberation (in certain important cases) by the Foreign Investment Council. Foreign ownership up to 100 per cent is permitted in new or existing enterprises in all but seven industries. Among these seven, foreign ownership in three industries, which 272 are 50 per cent liberalized, is to be fu l ly liberalized by May 1, 1976, from which time 100 per cent foreign ownership will be permitted in all but four industries. In three of these four industries, investment will be subject to case-by-case screening and in one, foreign ownership will be permitted automatically up to 50 per cent. The present liberalization applies both to the establishment of new firms and (provided in all cases that the firm concerned consents) to take-overs of exist- ing firms or participation in existing firms. Purchases by nonresidents of real estate in Japan for residential or other nonprofit purposes and of offices require approval by the Bank of Japan, and those of real estate for other purposes require approval by the Minis- ter of Finance. The approval of the Bank is given automatically. The transfer abroad of capital by residents and the mak ing of investments abroad are subject to approval, but approval generally is either automatic or freely given for outward direct investment (with the exception of certain projects which are not u rgen t ), purchases of real estate abroad, and outward portfolio investment. How- ever, the acquisition by residents of foreign short-term securities w i th maturities of one year or less is not permitted. Furthermore, for residents other than insti- tu t ional investors, there are certain restrictions on purchases of unlisted securities. In addition, foreign exchange banks and securities firms were informed in J anu a ry 1974 that the public should not be encouraged to buy foreign securities, but the request was withdrawn in 1975. Foreign borrowers are from time to time per- mitted to issue yen bonds on the Japanese capital market. Japanese emigrants may remit any amount from their assets to any country subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Emigrants of foreign nationality leaving Japan also may remit to any country any amount of personal assets, subject to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Certain types of outflows of long-term capital are facilitated by a foreign currency lending system under which government institutions and foreign exchange banks are authorized to make foreign currency loans to residents for 50 per cent of their direct invest- ment operations abroad and for advance payments in respect of imports. Outward financial credits and loans are subject to licensing. The issuing of bonds abroad, including issues for conversion into yen for domestic use, also is subject to licensing; dur ing 1975 such issues were permitted liberally. Securities acquired w i th approval under the Law Concerning Foreign Investment may be imported and exported freely. Foreign exchange banks are subject to controls over their overall net position in foreign currency (spot and forward comb ined). The switching of spot foreign cur- rency into yen by foreign exchange banks is also subject to regulation; their interoffice liabilities on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts are regarded as foreign currency liabilities for the application of this regulation. The inter- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution est rates on Nonresident Free Yen Accounts must not exceed those on resident-owned deposits, but otherwise are not subject to control. Deposits in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts are not subject to reserve requirements. Gold Residents, including domestic producers of gold, may freely hold gold and purchase and sell it in domestic transactions. The import of gold bullion containing more than 45 per cent of gold in weight normally is permitted, provided a payments license is obtained from the Bank of Japan; the volume of gold bullion imports may, however, be restricted at the discretion of the authorities if it reaches a level that would result in a disruptive influence on international gold markets. Imports of other gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold are freely permitted, subject only to verification by a for- eign exchange bank. Travelers (resident or nonresident) are freely permitted to bring in up to one kilogram of gold bullion a person a trip and up to the equivalent of US$200 in articles of gold and gold coins. Gold bullion, gold coins, and gold articles acquired by donation or inheritance may be imported freely, subject only to veri- fication by the customs authorities. Exports of gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold by residents require licenses from the Minister of Finance; exports of gold bullion are not norma l ly permitted.
