Not for Redistribution JORDAN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.29184 grams of fine gold per Jordan Dinar, and Jordan avails itself of wider margins. Since February 1975, the exchange rate for the dinar has been maintained on the basis of JD 0.387 = SDR 1. On December 31, 1975, the Central Bank of Jordan's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$3.04 and US$3.02 per JD 1, and those for sterling were £ stg. 1.50 and <£ stg. 1.48 per JD I.1 The buying and selling rates quoted by the commercial banks for these and other currencies must be based on the spot rates quoted by the Central Bank; as a result, no forward exchange transactions take place. A fee of 4 per cent is levied on the issue of import licenses. A fee of Mo of 1 per cent is levied on exchange permits approved by the Central Bank for sales of exchange for imports, except imports of government departments and certain other approved institutions. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Foreign Relations Department of the Central Bank of Jordan, which also issues exchange permits; the Central Bank has, however, delegated to authorized banks the issu- ance of exchange permits for import payments and, up to a permitted annual limit, for payments for educa- tional expenses of Jordanians studying abroad and for various other purposes. An Import Committee com- prising representatives of the Ministries of Industry and Trade and of Finance and Customs and the Central Bank presents from time to time suggestions and recom- mendations concerning changes in import policy to the Minister of Industry and Trade. In addition, an Eco- nomic Security Committee is empowered to amend exist- ing regulations or issue new ones concerning any aspect of Jordan's economic policies when this is considered necessary to the national interest. Prescription of Currency All settlements in respect of trade with Egypt must be made in pounds sterling through clearing accounts under a special bilateral payments arrangement with that country. Payments to other countries may be made in any currency. Proceeds from exports (except those of perishable goods and those of Jordanian goods up to JD 5,000 per transaction to neighboring Arab countries or up to JD 500 to other countries) and invisibles must be collected, and surrendered where required, in any convertible currency through an authorized bank in Jordan or in Jordan dinars from a nonresident account with an authorized bank in Jordan. Jordan has ceased 1 In addition to U.S. dollars and pounds sterling, the Central Bank maintains official quotations for Belgian francs, deutsche m a rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Ne the r lands gu i lders, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Nonresident Accounts Subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, authorized banks may open nonresident accounts in domestic currency. These accounts must be fed with approved funds; the approval of the Central Bank is necessary for transfers from resident to nonresident accounts, but transfers between nonresident accounts are permitted freely. In addition, nonresidents, including Jordanians working abroad, may freely open interest- bearing foreign currency accounts with authorized banks; balances on these accounts may be withdrawn freely in convertible currency, while the interest rate is fixed in accordance with rates prevailing in international markets. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain i tem s2 from any source, some imports from Roman ia, and all imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. All other imports, unless cov- ered by an agreement between Jordan and the exporting countries (i.e., agricultural products from neighboring coun t r ie s ), require import licenses if their c. & f. value is JD 50 or more. These are granted freely by the Min- istry of Industry and Trade except for certain items 3 which are subject to scrutiny by the Minister of Industry and Trade (whose prior approval is also required for imports of industrial machinery and of all materials needed for the establishment or expansion of an indus- trial firm) or scrutiny by the competent ministry. Importers of tea and certain other goods must obtain a specified m in imum proportion of their requirements from Indian sources. Imports shipped by sea should, in principle, enter the country through the port of Aqaba; goods that do not meet this requirement are subject to a penalty of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value (7 per cent for industrial raw materials and Brazilian coffee; foodstuffs, pharmaceu- ticals, and a few other items are exemp t). The Council of Ministers may grant exemptions f rom these rules on a case-by-case basis upon special recommendations by the Ministries of Industry and Trade and Transport. Bank guarantees in favor of the Ministry of Finance and Customs are required on most imports shipped 2 These include carbonic acid; arak; alcohol; nonalcoholic beverages; diesel-engined cars, trucks, and buses; and military uniforms. Certain of these commodities may be imported, however, f rom Arab Common Market countries and f rom countries with which trade agreements are in force. Imports of barley, lentils, olives, olive oil, and some other ag r icu l tu ral commodities are prohibited in good crop years. 3 These items on the "restricted list" include ghee, margarine, and other vegetable fats; tomato juice; saccharin; Dulcin; pectin; petroleum products (except aviation f u e l ); detergents; superphosphates; cement; tanned lea ther; amusement machines; blankets; woolen rugs; dry bat- teries; shaving lotion; and toothpaste. 275 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JORDAN through ports other than Aqaba, to ensure their impor- tation into Jordan. Imports that require an import license also require an exchange permit which is granted automatically when an import license has been obtained; the importer hold- ing an exchange permit may either open a letter of credit or pay against documents. A fee of VIQ of 1 per cent is levied on exchange permits for imports, except those made by government departments and certain approved institutions. The use of suppliers' credit is subject to prior Central Bank approval, which normally is given for essential imports only. Most imported commodities are subject to an import duty of 4 per cent of the c. & f. value, payable on the issue of the import license. Payments for Invisibles Remittances by postal order do not require exchange control approval, provided that they do not exceed JD 10 a person a month. With this exception, all pay- ments for invisibles are subject to exchange control approval. Payments for the following types of invisibles are generally permitted up to certain limits: income of nonresidents; savings of foreign nationals who intend to return to their own countries; remittances to residents' dependents; reasonable living expenses of Jordanian nationals abroad; expenses of Jordanian residents travel- ing abroad; expenses for education; expenses for medical treatment; business expenses abroad; and insurance payments in accordance with special regulations.4 The exchange allowance for business and tourist travel is the equivalent of JD 5,000 a person (JD 500 for children under 18). These allowances are granted for one or more trips once a year. For family support, an annual allowance of JD 5,000 for each beneficiary is permitted, once a year; however, remittances by postal order may be made for amounts not exceeding the equivalent of JD 10 a month to any one person resident abroad and are not subject to this ceiling. The policy in respect of payments for invisibles is, in general, liberal and nondiscriminatory. In practice, the Central Bank does not restrict remittances of income accruing to non- residents or of savings of foreign nationals returning to their own country. In addition to any travel allocation, residents traveling abroad make take out up to JD 300 in any combination of Jordanian and foreign notes and coins. Furthermore, all travelers may take out checks, travelers checks, or letters of credit issued by authorized banks in Jordan in accordance with exchange permits authorized by the Central Bank. Tourists and other nonresidents may also take out foreign currency notes and coins and any other foreign means of payment that they had previously brought in and declared upon entry to the customs authorities and that had been entered in their passports by the latter. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds exceeding JD 50 must be collected and the foreign exchange surrendered within six months of ship- ment. Exempt are the proceeds from perishable vege- tables and fruits, and proceeds up to JD 5,000 from exports of Jordanian products to neighboring Arab countries or up to JD 500 from such exports to other countries. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to an authorized bank or, if banknotes and travelers checks are received, to an authorized exchange dealer. Travelers entering Jordan may bring in any amount in Jordanian and foreign notes and coins.5 Any person regarded for exchange control purposes as resident in Jordan may be required by the Central Bank to surrender to an authorized bank any foreign currency at his disposal. Capital Capital may be imported freely, but exports of capi- tal require approval and are not normally allowed, with the following exception. The Central Bank is prepared to exam ine applications by banks, insurance companies, industrial or trading firms, and contractors for permis- sion to t rans fer funds abroad for specified investment or operating purposes. Current income resulting from non- resident investments in Jordan may be transferred abroad. Under the Law for the Encouragement of Investment, which took effect on October 16, 1972, profits f rom approved foreign investments may be remitted, without limitation, in the currency of the origi- nal investment or in any other convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. After two years, repatri- ation of the capital is permitted in three equal annual installments in the same foreign currency in which the original investment was made or in any other convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. The Investment Committee may approve more liberal provisions, and exchange permits are granted accordingly. Gold The Central Bank has issued four gold coins under the Gold and Silver Coins Regulation No. 61 of 1968; these coins, although legal tender, do not circulate and are available only to nonresidents and domestic numis- matists. Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Jordan for numismatic or investment purposes. Profits derived from such investments and the proceeds upon liquidation had to be transferred to Jordan. Not for Redistribution KENYA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Kenya Shilling. A central rate of K Sh 9.66000 = SDR 1 has been established, and Kenya avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kenya deals with the Government and with authorized banks in Tanzania shillings and Uganda shillings against Kenya shillings at par; in principle, the authorized banks also deal with the public in these currencies at par.1 In transactions w i th authorized banks, the Central Bank stands ready to issue Kenya shillings in exchange for U.S. dollars and to supply U.S. dollars in exchange for Kenya shil- lings, at rates based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U.S. dollar/SDR rate. The Central Bank deals w i th the Government and commercial banks, on the basis of the daily closing rates in New York, in deutsche ma rk, French francs, Japa- nese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, and, on the basis, of their U.S. dollar cross rates, in Bu rundi francs and Zambian kwacha. The Central Bank does not deal in other foreign currencies,2 except occasionally on behalf of the Government. The Central Bank deals up to six months forward in sterling and U.S. dollars with commercial banks, to cover their contracts with exporters and importers; commercial banks may cover their forward exchange contracts in other foreign currencies against U.S. dollars or pounds sterling in outside markets. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance and Economic P l a n n i ng has delegated the administration of exchange control to the Central Bank. Authority for approving payments for imports of goods not listed in Import Schedules I-IV with an invoiced value not exceeding K Sh 4,000, many payments in respect of current invisibles, and some capi- tal payments to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda is delegated to the authorized banks. Import and export controls are administered by the Director of Trade and Supplies in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. The responsibility for issuing import and export licenses rests with the Director, to whom applications must be submitted by the importer and exporter in Kenya before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Applications for foreign exchange allocation permits for imports also must be submitted to the Director of Trade and Supplies, who forwards these to the Central Bank; applications are screened by the Foreign Exchange Allocation Commit- tee, composed of representatives of the Central Bank, the Treasury, and the Director of Trade and Supplies. Orders for imports of goods on open general license must be preregistered with the Director of Trade and Sup- plies before shipment. The government-owned Kenya National Trading Corporation, Ltd. has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities, and the export of certain agricultural commodities is controlled by State Marke t ing Boards. Together with Tanzania and Uganda, Kenya is part of the East African currency area. Payments from Kenya to Tanzania and Uganda are free of restric- tions, but the export or import of Kenya banknotes is prohibited. Prescription of Currency Kenya has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Settlements with Tanzania and Uganda no rma l ly are effected in East A f r ican currency.3 Pay- ments to residents of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda (except Rhodesia and South A f r ica) may be made in Kenya shillings to the credit of an External Account in Kenya or in any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency. Receipts f rom countries other than Tanzania, Uganda, and Rhodesia may be obtained in Kenya shillings f rom an External Account in Kenya or in any marketable foreign currency. All payments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Remittances to South A f r i ca also are prohibited, with the exception of those of pensions payable by the Government of Kenya or by the East A f r ican Commun i ty organizations. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Kenya shillings held by residents of countries other than Rhodesia, South Afr ica, Tanza- nia, or Uganda with authorized banks in Kenya are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Kenya, with transfers f rom other External Accounts, and with the proceeds f rom sales of any currency (other than East A f r ican, Rhodesian, or South Afr ican currency) and gold by nonresidents to authorized dealers. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to resi- dents and nonresidents. Non t rans fe rab le funds of residents of countries other than Tanzan ia and Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prescribed procedures, balances on Blocked Accounts (other than those in the beneficial ownersh ip of residents of South Africa or Rhodesia) may be used for approved domestic expenditures and 1 All dealings in Tanzania and Uganda banknotes are suspended. 2 All currencies other than the Kenya shilling, the Tanzania shilling, and the Uganda shilling are considered fore ign currencies. 3 East A f r ican cu r rency comprises Kenya shillings, Tanzan ia shillings, and Uganda shillings. 278 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution for the purchase in Kenya of specified bonds issued by the Kenyan Government or by local authorities and officially quoted in Kenya;4 the redemption proceeds of these securities, which must have a life of five years at the time of acquisition, are transferable, arid interest is freely transferable to nonresidents as and when it accrues. Imports and Import Payments Some imports f rom all sources are prohibited for rea- sons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports from Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. With certain exceptions, imports from Tanzania and Uganda are unrestricted, but many goods imported from these countries require a specific license unless they are of Tanzanian or Ugan- dan origin. Many goods may be freely imported from other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. Certain items are imported only by the Kenya National Trading Corporation, Ltd. These include sugar, salt, rice, edible oils, fertilizers, blankets, and cotton piece goods. In addition to the open general import license, there are four commodity schedules for imports. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports of commodities in Schedules I, II, III, and IV from countries other than Tanzania and Uganda require a foreign exchange alloca- tion license issued by the Director of Trade and Sup- plies; applications must be submitted before firm orders are placed. Imports of goods on open general license do not require an exchange allocation license but must be preregistered with the Director of Trade and Supplies before firm orders are placed. All goods in the first three schedules require a specific import license from the Director of Trade and Supplies. Once the specific import license has been obtained, for- eign exchange is granted freely for goods in Schedule I and on the basis of quotas reflecting past imports for goods in Schedule II. No foreign exchange is granted for Schedule III items. For items in Schedule IV, a specific import license is not required but foreign exchange is allocated on a quota basis. From time to time, exemptions may be granted from the quotas estab- lished under Schedules II and IV and from the prohi- bitions of Schedule III. Applications for foreign exchange allocation licenses for imports are subject to a charge of 1 per cent of the amount of the application. When an exchange allocation license has been obtained from the Central Bank or when such a license is not required, authorized banks are permitted to pro- vide exchange automatically, but not normally prior to customs entry. Prior exchange control approval must be obtained for imports of capital goods on deferred payment terms, and for imports of machinery and 4 Such securities must be payable in East A f r ican currency and they must not be redeemable earlier than five years f rom the da te of acquisition. KENYA equipment when the value is required to be regarded as a contribution toward capital or to be accounted for on a loan basis. Most imports with a pro forma invoice value in excess of K Sh 20,000 are also subject to preshipment inspec- tion as to quality, quantity, and price by the General Superintendence Company acting for the Central Bank. A "Clean Report of Findings" must be obtained before shipment, and authorized banks in Kenya may not issue shipping guarantees for the clearance of imports un t il this "Clean Report" has been received. The buying and conf irm ing commission with respect to imports into Kenya may not exceed 3 per cent of the value of the import. The interest rate on suppliers' credit normally is limited to 11 per cent per annum. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of cur- rent payments without limitation or up to established limits; amoun ts above these limits as well as other cur- rent payments may be approved administratively, and most current payments are in fact unrestricted. Fees for education up to the equivalent of K Sh 14,000 a person for a fu ll scholastic yea r5 and fees for other specified purposes may be approved by an authorized bank upon production of evidence of debt. Facilities exist whereby nationals of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda who come to work in Kenya as employed persons (as well as certain categories of the self- employed, such as doctors and dentists) for not more than four years may remit abroad as savings up to 33!/3 per cent of their monthly salaries but not more than K Sh 3,000 a month; in addition, they may remit funds to cover maintenance, education expenses, etc., provided that their total remittances including savings do not exceed 50 per cent of their monthly salaries. Expatriates who have stayed for over four years in the Scheduled Territories6 may continue to effect remit- tances f rom salaries as above, but those who avail them- selves of the facilities for remittance of savings from salaries are not entitled to exchange facilities upon emigration. Remittances to South Afr ica, other than those of certain pensions, are prohibited. Nonresident individual property owners may remit up to K Sh 20,000 of net rental income in each 12- month period. Any excess of net rent over the permit- ted transfer is placed in a Blocked Account and may be invested in approved securities with at least five years to ma tur i ty, af ter which period the redemption proceeds may be remitted to the nonresident beneficiary. The basic allowance for travel outside the Sched- uled Territories by adults holding round-trip tickets is K Sh 4,000 a person (K Sh 2,000 for children between 3 and 12 years of age) every two years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes.7 Holders of one-way tickets are entitled to a basic travel allowance of K Sh 2,000 for adults and K Sh 1,000 for children. The basic allowance is not available for travel to Rhodesia or South Africa. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Residents of Kenya traveling abroad on international flights and holding return tickets may carry up to K Sh 100 with them for local expenses on return, but otherwise the export of Kenya bank- notes is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Export transactions must be registered with the Cen- tral Bank. Exports of certain foodstuffs and agricul- tural products require licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Kenya. Exports of tea, certain minerals, precious stones, and strategic materials are also subject to licensing. Export licenses for some commodities are required only for destinations other than Tanzania or Uganda. Other goods may be exported without licenses. Exports of coffee are made through the intermediary of the Coffee Marketing Board. All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be col- lected within three months of exportation and offered to an authorized bank in Kenya for conversion into Kenya shillings.8 Exports of manufac tured goods to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are eligible for special incentives. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in freely foreign currency notes. The import of domestic banknotes is prohibited, with the exception that residents returning to Kenya may bring in up to K Sh 100 previ- ously taken out by themselves. The import of East African shilling notes also is prohibited. 7 Banks are not permitted, w i thout specific approval, to sell exchange in excess of K Sh 200 a day (subject to a max imum of K Sh 3,000 for a stay of not less than 15 days) for travel to Bu rund i, Ethiopia, Malawi, Mozambique, Rwanda, Somalia, Sudan, People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, Zaire, and Zambia. 8 There are minor exemptions with respect to Ethiopian dollars and Somali shillings for persons resident in specified border areas. 280 Capital Capital transfers to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are restricted. Transfers to Rhodesia or South Afr ica are not allowed. With the exception of expatriate employees who have opted for remittance of savings f rom salaries, persons leaving Kenya perma- nently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of K Sh 50,000 for each fam i ly un it if they take up resi- dence in a country outside the Scheduled Territories; they may additionally every 12 months thereafter, dur- ing a period of five years, apply for the release of K Sh 20,000 f rom their Blocked Accounts. All remain- ing funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; they may then be invested in approved securities, and redemption proceeds become transferable, provided that redemption does not take place earlier than five years f rom the date of purchase. If an emigrating or repatriat- ing person's assets in Kenya are valued at K Sh 1 million or more, the total assets must be liquidated before any exchange control approvals are sought and the pro- ceeds must be invested in prescribed securities. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Kenya, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is necessary to obtain from the Treasury a "certificate of approved enterprise" for the investment. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production requires approval under the East African Licensing Ordinance. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled companies requires exchange con- trol approval and is restricted. The same is true of borrowing by residents from nonresidents. Except in respect of Tanzania and Uganda, all imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresi- dents of Kenyan securities on a recognized stock exchange, provided that payment is received in an appro- priate manne r. The income f rom such securities is remittable, but the proceeds on resale must normally be credited to a Blocked Account. Purchases of securi- ties outside Tanzania and Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Kenya may not send as a cash gift to a country other than Tanzania or Uganda more than K Sh 200 a year without specific exchange control approval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Kenya for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require exchange control approval. The import of the following f rom all sources other than Tanzania and Uganda, and f rom Tanzania and Uganda when originating in other countries, is subject to individual ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; gold- smiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bul- lion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Imports of gold jewelry require specific import licenses as Schedule III items and no foreign exchange is allocated for them; import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets) are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restrictively, while imports of gold coins are not being licensed. Changes during 1975 January 1. The exchange rates for the currencies of Tanzania and Uganda remained unchanged. The initial middle rate for the U.S. dollar was K Sh 8.16. October. Re-exports of fertilizers were prohibited. Tariff preferences to members of the EEC would no longer be granted and the existing three-column ta r i ff would be reduced to a single column. 281 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KOREA (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Korean Won has been estab- lished with the Fund. The exchange rate in the exchange certificate market is maintained around W 484 per US$1. On December 31, 1975 the buying and selling rates of the Bank of Korea for the U.S. dollar were W 483.40 and W 484.60, respectively, per US$1, and the telegraphic transfer buying and selling rates of the foreign exchange banks were W 483 and W 485, re- spectively, per US$1. Exchange certificates valid for 30 days may be issued by the foreign exchange banks against all foreign ex- change earnings in prescribed currencies surrendered by residents. In practice, most foreign exchange proceeds are exchanged for won at the buying rate posted by the foreign exchange banks. Exchange certificates may be changed into equivalent foreign means of payment. There ,is a limited forward exchange market restricted to exporters covering their export earnings. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance is in charge of exchange control. It carries out policy with respect to prescription of currency and method of settlement, foreign exchange operations, payments for nonmerchandise transactions, and capital transactions and transfers. The Bank of Korea, as the Government's agent, executes the above functions in large part; it regulates operations in the exchange market and is authorized to intervene in it. The Bank has also been delegated authority to control payments related to invisibles and certain capital trans- actions. The foreign exchange banks, as well as the branch offices in Korea of foreign banks, are authorized to engage in commercial international banking and in specified foreign exchange dealings. The trade program for imports financed f rom Korea's own foreign exchange resources (KFX) is prepared by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Imports financed by foreign loans are programmed separately by the Economic Planning Board in consultation with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Import licenses are issued by the foreign exchange banks. Prescription of Currency All settlements between Korea and other countries are made in convertible currencies. The proceeds of exports must be obtained in prescribed currencies.1 The methods of payment on account of other settlements require the approval of the Bank of Korea. 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 282 Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents, including Korean workers abroad, may maintain foreign currency deposit accounts with foreign exchange banks. Remittances from such accounts and withdrawals in the form of currency notes upon depar- ture f rom Korea may, in general, be made freely. The approval of the bank where the account is held is required for remittances from balances that have ac- crued from remuneration for services in Korea, fares paid for travel by air or ship, or insurance premiums received in Korea, or from exchange deposited in accord- ance with a decision of the Ministry of Finance (except exchange registered at the customs on entry or remitted f rom ab road ). The deposits may be disposed of by sale to a foreign exchange bank at the prevailing ex- change rate, and they may be debited for salary pay- ments to foreign employees. Foreign residents and nonresidents (including Korean workers abroad) are permitted to hold demand, notice, and time deposit accounts in prescribed currencies with foreign exchange banks. Certain residents of Korean nationality, such as the airline and some insurance companies, as well as enter- prises in which foreign capital is invested, may maintain demand deposit accounts in foreign currencies with foreign exchange banks. Companies registered to oper- ate in the Masan Free Export Zone also may maintain demand deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange bank within the zone. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports require licenses; for certain imports (see below) licenses are issued upon application. No licenses are issued for any goods originating in the People's Republic of China, Cuba, North Korea, or North Viet-Nam and for certain imports f rom all other countries. Imports are divided into two categories: those paid for with Korean foreign exchange (KFX imports) and those paid for with foreign loan funds. KFX imports are classified as automatic approval, restricted, or pro- hibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., applications for import licenses are automatically approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or pro- hibited commodities. Automatic approval items (on December 31, 1975 these were 644 out of 1,312 basic items in the Standard International Trade Classifica- tion—SITC) consist mainly of essential consumer goods not domestically produced and certain raw materials and capital goods. Restricted items (602) in a negative list are subject to individual licenses. Prohibited items (66) are mainly luxury goods, items prohibited for rea- sons of public health or morals, and some domestically produced goods. Imports of raw materials for the pro- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution duction of exports are normally approved automatically, irrespective of their classification. Import licenses are granted only to registered traders; to maintain the status of a registered trader, a minimum value of US$1 million of exports is required each year for ordinary exporters. The commercial terms of payment on which imports may be contracted are regulated, and advance import deposits are required for most types of goods imported by the private sector; these are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of local currency at the time of applying for import licenses (or, for raw materials for export pro- duction, when the letter of credit is opened). Advance deposits are retained un t il the bill of lading is released, subject to a minimum retention period which for most goods is 90 days. Advance deposits for KFX imports range between zero per cent and 200 per cent according to the nature of the import and the commercial terms of payment (sight letter of credit (L /C), documents against accept- ance (D /A), documents against payment (D /P ), or bonded warehouse transaction (BWT) terms). The customs tariff is a "flexible" tariff. Furthermore, the Government may alter import duty rates adminis- tratively by up to 50 percentage points. The Govern- ment also has authority to impose import surcharges of up to 30 per cent on all dutiable imports, but by the end of 1975 had not invoked this authority. A defense surcharge of 2.5 per cent ad valorem is levied on most goods, whether locally produced or imported. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require individual licenses. Payments for invisibles connected with foreign trade transactions and for certain other items such as banking charges, insurance premiums, communication fees, and periodicals are licensed automatically. There are cer- tain standard allocations for business travel. In addition, exporters are authorized to use certain exchange earn- ings for the expenses of their overseas branches. Resi- dents departing for travel abroad may purchase foreign exchange up to the equivalent of US$90 a day or up to US$700 as a monthly allowance for living expenses; they may purchase additional foreign exchange for each trip for extra expenses. Korean currency notes in excess of W 100,000 and foreign currency notes may not be exported without special permission. Nonresident for- eigners need not register foreign exchange in specified currencies that they bring into Korea and, when depart- ing, may reconvert unused won notes into U.S. dollars up to US$300, subject to confirmation of the original sale of exchange (up to US$50 without such conf irma t ion). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to certain specified countries designated by the Government are prohibited, as are exports of certain goods (such as raw cotton, platinum ores, wood KOREA charcoal, pulp, and waste paper) to all other countries. Certain exports on a restricted list require individual licenses. All other exports may be made freely under an automatic approval procedure. The export proceeds in foreign exchange must either be surrendered to a for- eign exchange bank at its posted customer rate or be exchanged into equivalent foreign exchange certificates. Exporters are not permitted to retain their export pro- ceeds as foreign currency demand or time deposits with foreign exchange banks. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds derived from invisibles must either be sold to a foreign exchange bank for won or be ex- changed for equivalent exchange certificates. Travelers may bring with them any amount of foreign exchange, but the import of Korean currency by travelers is restricted. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Foreign capital investment, loans from abroad, and imports of capital goods on a long-term basis can secure a guar- antee of repayment and repatriation under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law. No limits are placed on the conversion and remittance of legitimate profits and divi- dends, or on the repatriation of the original capital invested, but proposed remittances must be notified to the Economic Planning Board 90 days prior to the end of the fiscal year. Gold Certain commemorative gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely buy, hold, and sell gold in any form in Korea. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Bank of Korea; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users. Domestically produced gold may be disposed of in the free market. The free market price at public gold auctions was about W 2,976 a gram at the end of 1975. Changes during 1975 January 1. With effect from March 1, the system of foreign currency deposits was revised. These could now be held by nonresidents (including Koreans employed abroad) and foreign residents as demand deposits, notice deposits, or time deposits, and could bear interest up to 2 percentage points above the corresponding rate in the Euro-dollar market; previously only time deposits could be held by foreign residents and by nonresidents. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Hate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Kuwaiti Dinar, corresponding to KD 1 = US$3.37778, and Kuwait avails itself of wider margins. Since March 18, 1975 the exchange rate for the Kuwaiti dinar has been maintained on the basis of its value in terms of a weighted average of currencies. The Central Bank of Kuwait quotes daily buying and selling rates for ster- ling and U.S. dollars; on December 31, 1975, these were KD 0.59492 buying, and KD 0.59566 selling, respec- tively, per £ stg. 1, and KD 0.29397 buying, and KD 0.29433 selling, respectively, per US$1. On April 5, 1963, Kuwait notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control There is no exchange control and residents and non- residents may freely purchase and sell foreign currencies in Kuwait. Dealings in the currencies of Israel, Rho- desia, and South Afr ica, however, are prohibited. Gen- eral and individual import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The limited con- trol over exports is administered by the Customs and Ports Adm in is tra t ion of the Ministry of Communications. Prescription of Currency Kuwait has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. There are no prescription of currency requirements. All settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open accounts in Kuwaiti dinars and foreign currencies. The use of such accounts is not restricted. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all private imports other than foodstuffs; licenses are issued freely, except for wheat, flour, and asbestos pipe. Registered import- ers handling a variety of commodities may obtain a general license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for ind iv idual commodities, which are also valid for one year. All imports f rom Israel, including imports of Israeli manufacture and those that contain Israeli materials or are manu fac tu red by com- panies financed by Israeli capital, and all imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Imports of a few items (ma in ly oxygen, certain steel pipes, alco- holic beverages, and used trucks and buses not using 286 gasoline for fuel and over ten years old) are prohibited from all sources. To be registered, the importer must be either a Kuwa i ti citizen or a firm in which all partners are Kuwaiti nationals or a shareholding or limited liability company in which Kuwaiti nationals own at least 51 per cent of all stock. Commercial imports normally are limited to registered importers. Imports from any permitted source may be paid for freely. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica. There are no limi- tations on the export of domestic or foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of live sheep and poultry and of certain other items (such as sugar, fa ts, rice, meat, eggs, fish, milk, cheese, butter, olive oil, fresh f ru i t s, vegetables in any fo rm, beans, lentils, chick-peas, jams, and cement) are prohibited in t ime of emergency or shortage in Kuwait. These items may be exported in limited quantities only, under a special license issued by the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. Exports of arms, ammunition, and scrap metal require licenses. Licenses are not required for other exports or re-exports. All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports, except that these must not accrue in Israel pounds, Rhodesian dollars, or South African rand; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surren- dered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles No requirements are attached to the use or disposal of receipts in any currency other than Israel pounds, Rhodesian dollars, or South Afr ican rand. Travelers entering Kuwait may bring with them any amount in Kuwaiti or other banknotes except Israel, Rhodesian, or South Afr ican currency. Capital There are no exchange control obligations on the transfer to Kuwait of resident or nonresident capital in any currency. Government agreement is necessary for the participation of nonresident capital in corporations in Kuwait, and a license is required for the establish- ment and operation of industries in Kuwait; at least 51 per cent of ownership of new Kuwaiti companies must be held by Kuwaiti nationals. No restrictions are imposed on outward capital pay- ments by residents or nonresidents to other countries except Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Gold The monetary authorities and merchants registered with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry may import and export gold in any form, provided that such gold is not less than 18-karat fine; gold jewelry, how- ever, cannot be imported or sold unless it is properly hallmarked. Kuwaiti nationals may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Other residents may, on arrival or departure, bring in and take out their holdings of gold in any form, without restriction or license. Jewelry and precious metals in any form, manufactured or non- manufactured, are subject to import duty at 4 per cent. Changes during 1975 February 9. The Kuwaiti dinar was unpegged from the U.S. dollar. Kuwait ceased to observe the margin of 2.25 per cent either side of parity in its daily quotations for the U.S. dollar; the exchange rates for the Kuwaiti dinar henceforth were maintained on the basis of its value in terms of a weighted average of currencies. The spread between buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged at Vs of 1 per cent. Not for Redistribution LAO PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC * (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Lao Kip has been established with the Fund. On December 31, 1975, the official exchange rate was K 750 = US$1. This rate applied to a few specified imports, to government payments covered by the foreign exchange budget for official trans- actions, to a few types of private sector payments in respect of current invisibles, and to proceeds f rom invisi- bles or capital sold to the banking system. All other per- mitted exchange transactions took place at an exchange rate of K 1,200 per US$1 resulting f rom the application of an exchange tax or exchange subsidy of K 450 per US$1 to the official rate. Transactions in the unoff ic ial free market, which in the second half of 1975 was very narrow, were illegal; on December 31, 1975, the exchange rate in that market was about K 5,000 = US$1. The official exchange market was supplied mainly by the Foreign Exchange Operations Fund (FEOF), which sold foreign exchange to banks at the official rate.2 Administration of Control FEOF sells and buys foreign exchange only in trans- actions with the four commercial banks and the Devel- opment Bank of Laos, which act for the account of their customers. The National Bank of Laos (the central bank) conducts foreign exchange transactions only with exporters making the obligatory surrender of export proceeds, with Lao public agencies selling their exchange receipts, and with foreign embassies and international organizations; receipts f rom these sources are used to meet the foreign exchange expenditures of the Lao Gov- ernment, including its contributions to FEOF. The approval of the Exchange Control Commission (Com- mission d'Octroi des Devises Etrangeres or CODE) in the Ministry of Finance is required for purchases of exchange by the public at the rates of K 750 = US$1 and K 1,200 = US$1. Exchange authorization for cer- tain invisibles eligible for the K 750 rate is granted, how- ever, by the National Exchange Office in the Ministry of Finance, acting on behalf of CODE. The Commission for the Coordination of Foreign Finance is empowered to modify the lists of imports eligible for official exchange. The Foreign Trade Department of the Min- istry of Economy issues export licenses and keeps an annual register of importers and exporters. 1 Since the end of 1975, the economy has been progressively adapted to a centrally planned system. The banks have been nationalized. The Lao authorities are in the process of mod i fy ing the ex is t ing t rade and payments system in accordance w i th the new economic f r am ew o r k. 2 FEOF, which received most of its resources f r om fore ign donor countries, ceased operations on March 27, 1976. 288 Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are imposed on receipts or payments, but the National Bank provides and accepts only U.S. dollars, French francs, and pounds sterling. There is a bilateral payments agreement with the U.S.S.R. providing for payments to be made through a clearing account ma in ta ined in French francs as the un it of account. Imports and Import Payments Importers must be listed on the annual register of importers, for which a yearly registration fee has to be paid to the Government. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited. Financing at the official rate is permitted only for certain commodities deemed most essential (List B ); other essential imports are settled at the effec- tive exchange rate of K 1,200 per US$1, i.e., the official rate plus the exchange tax of K 450 per US$1 (List C). Imports of all other goods are effectively prohibited, since imports may not be financed in the parallel market. An official agency, the Societe Nationale d'Exportation et d'Importation, acts as sole importer for the Govern- ment. Import transactions at the official rate are subject to exchange control approval. On being notified that exchange approval will be granted, the importer must make an advance import deposit in kip at the Treasury. The advance deposit requirement is 40 per cent of the c.i.f. value for imports from all sources. Payments for Invisibles Private sector payments for the few current invisibles eligible for the official rate are subject to exchange con- trol approval by the CODE and most are restricted. There is a foreign exchange budget detailing the Gov- ernment's payments in foreign exchange dur ing the fiscal year; for such payments the National Bank makes exchange available at the official rate. Payments for all other invisibles, with the exception of freight and insur- ance on imports and exports, are effectively prohibited, since access to the parallel market is restricted. There are no regulations limiting the export of domestic or foreign banknotes by travelers. Exports and Export Proceeds Exporters must pay an annual registration fee to the Government. Exports of gold and silver are prohibited, except when made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. All other exports are subject to authoriza- tion. The fu ll proceeds f rom all exports must be sur- rendered to the National Bank in U.S. dollars, French francs, or pounds sterling at the official rate and receive ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the exchange subsidy of K 450 per US$1. An official agency, the Societe Nationale d'Exportation et d'lmpor- tation, is the sole exporter of timber and other forest products and of coffee. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange converted by foreign embassies, missions, representatives, and institutions to cover their official expenses in the Lao People's Democratic Repub- lic must be surrendered at the official rate. All other receipts from invisibles may be retained by the recipient. There are no regulations limiting the import of foreign or domestic banknotes by travelers. Capital Under the Investment Law of February 1970, various incentives are available to foreign investors. Capital inflow is free from exchange control regulations and the foreign exchange need not be surrendered. No official exchange is granted for outward capital transfers other than debt repayments approved by CODE. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form within the country. Any imports of gold are subject, in principle, to payment of a tax of K 42,000 a kilogram and an import duty of 3.5 per cent. Exports of gold by or on behalf of physical or jur id ical persons other than the monetary authorities are not officially approved. Exports of gold coins issued under Decree No. 784/PC of June 26, 1969, however, are permitted in principle. Changes during 1975 March 26. The official exchange market was closed. It reopened on March 31. March 31. The official exchange rate was changed from K 600 to K 750 per US$1. Not for Redistribution LEBANON (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System All exchange transactions, including those in clearing dollars, take place at the free market rate, which for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 was Lebanese Pounds 2.42 per US$1. There also exists a "moving parity" used for the calculation of duties and taxes levied on amounts invoiced or expressed in foreign cur- rency, particularly customs duties; for December 1975 the "moving parity" was LL 2.38 per US$1. There are no restrictions on foreign payments. Prescription of Currency In general, no requirements are imposed on exchange payments abroad or receipts in Lebanon. Some trans- actions with certain countries with which Lebanon has payments agreements1 specifying the method or chan- nel of payment may be made through specific accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few goods (mainly arms and ammun i- tion, narcotics, and similar products) are either pro- hibited or reserved for the Government. All imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of certain other commodities (including wheat, barley, beet and cane sugar, olive oil, poultry, gasoline, kerosene, and liquid gas) that are for the most part produced locally are subject to prior licensing. Import licenses are also required for all machinery for the installation or expansion of manufacturing plants. All other commodities may be imported freely without license. Exchange to pay for imports may be obtained freely through the free market, but a cash deposit of 15 per cent must be made in foreign currency against import letters of credit. A municipalities tax of 3.5 per cent is levied on the value of all goods imported, except those of Arab origin, and a stamp tax of 1.2 per cent is applicable to all imports except gold and banknotes. A surcharge of 10 per cent of the applicable import duty is levied on specified textiles and garments. Payments for Invisibles No restrictions are placed on payments for invisibles. Exchange may be obtained freely through the free market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain goods (such as arms and ammuni- tion and narcotics and similar products) to any destina- tion, and all exports to Israel and Rhodesia are pro- hibited. Exports of certain metals and a few other items 1 Czechoslovakia, Egypt, German Democratic Republic, Poland, and Romania. There is also an inoperative payments agreement with Guinea. 290 and exports valued at over LL 200 of certain other items —mainly livestock, wheat and wheat products, bar- ley, rice, sugar, edible oils, dairy products, canned or frozen meat, newsprint, petroleum and petroleum prod- ucts, and industrial and agricultural machinery and equipment —to any country and all products intended for export to North Korea require export licenses. Exchange receipts f rom exports may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Capital There are no limitations on capital payments or receipts. Exchange may be obtained or sold freely through the free market. Banks are prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held deposits denomi- nated in Lebanese pounds. They have been requested not to extend credit in Lebanese pounds to nonresidents unless this serves to finance foreign trade transactions. Banks' foreign currency credits to residents and non- residents are subject to deposit requirements, and their net foreign currency positions (claims and liabilities separately) are subject to l im i ta t ion. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form w i th residents and nonresidents at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are freely per- mitted and do not require a license but must be offi- cially recorded. The import, export, and domestic sale of foreign gold coins must be covered by a certificate indicating the gold content and weight and issued by the Office for the Protection of the Consumer. Not for Redistribution LESOTHO (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System Lesotho's currency is the South African Rand. The par value of the rand is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per rand. The South African Reserve Bank on Decem- ber 31, 1975 quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the South Afr ican Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against the rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. Lesotho forms part of the Rand Monetary Area, which is a single exchange control territory comprising Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland. The Registrar of Financial Institutions in the Ministry of Finance controls all external currency transactions. Lesotho has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary Area. These are uncontrolled and unrecorded. In relation to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, Lesotho applies exchange controls that are in all material aspects similar to those of South Afr ica and Swaziland. Payments to nonresidents for current transactions, while subject to control, are not normally restricted, but applications for outward trans- fers of capital are considered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Authority to approve some types of current payments is delegated to authorized dealers up to estab- lished limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Lesotho is a member of a customs un ion with Bo- tswana, South Africa, and Swaziland, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South Afr ica do not require licenses and include an unknown quantity of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Lesotho imports goods direct from countries outside the customs union, such imports are usually licensed in conformity with South Africa's import regulations. Import licenses are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment. Lesotho's trade licensing arrange- ments, however, are designed mainly to raise revenue and to prevent tax evasion and are confined in practice to exports of diamonds; permits are issued by the 292 Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Licenses for finan- cial institutions are issued by the Registrar of Financial Institutions. Certain tax incentives for inward direct investment are provided by the Pioneer Industries Encouragement Act, 1969 to manufac tur ing activities approved by a Pioneer Industries Board. Residents may freely pur- chase, hold, and sell certain Lesotho gold coins that are legal tender. Changes during 1975 April 17. Exchange Control Circular No. 2 provided that authorized dealers could allow temporary residents domiciled outside the Rand Monetary Area to transfer outside that Area savings up to one third of gross local monthly income or local annual taxable earned income, or, if such persons were maintaining their families out- side the Area, up to half the gross local monthly income. April 18. Circular No. 3 confirmed that dividends and profits were freely transferable to nonresidents of the Rand Monetary Area. Where the remittance of profits earned or dividends declared by local subsidiaries of non -Rand Monetary Area companies involved the use of local credit facilities, applications had to be referred to the Registrar of Financial Institutions. May 23. The Exchange Control Act (Act No. 2 of 1975) was gazetted. It came into effect on July 1. The Consolidated Exchange Control Regulations (High Commissioner's Notice No. 98 of 1949) were repealed. June 20. The Minister of Finance was authorized to issue certain gold and silver coins that would be legal tender. June 27. It was announced that the South African Reserve Bank was discontinuing the practice of making small and frequent adjustments to its buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars. In fu tu re these rates would be kept constant for longer periods at a time and would only be adjusted upward or downward if considered essential in the event of any basic change in domestic or international economic circumstances. The new pol- icy would be based on a middle rate of R 1 = US$1.40 with the same total spread of ¥2 of 1 per cent as before. The Reserve Bank quoted public buying and selling rates of US$1.4035 and US$1.3965 per rand. The previous middle rate had been R 1 = US$1.47. August 29. The Exchange Control Regulations, 1975 (Legal Notice No. 36 of 1975) were gazetted. They came into force immediately. September 22. The Reserve Bank's middle rate for the U.S. dollar was changed from R 1 = US$1.40 to R 1 = US$1.15. The Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates were adjusted to R 1 = US$1.1529 and R 1 = US$1.1471, respectively. No change was made in the exchange rate policy introduced on June 27. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBERIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Liberian Dollar, and the parity rate for the U.S. dollar is $1 = US$1. U.S. currency is legal tender in Liberia and circulates along with Liberian coinage. Official accounts are kept in U.S. dollars and cents. There is no exchange control and there are no restrictions on foreign exchange transactions. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments There is no general system of import control. A few items (e.g., arms and ammunition, explosives, used clothing, and Pharmaceuticals) require prior licenses; imports of cement are not being licensed. Also, imports of certain goods (e.g., obscene literature, narcotics other than for medicinal purposes) and all imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. In practice, meat is imported only by the Liberian Sup- ply Corporation and petroleum only by the Liberian Refining Company. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Export licenses are required for precious metals, precious stones, ivory, agricultural products other than rubber, and certain other items, such as arms and ammunition and explosives. Licenses are generally issued freely and no licenses are required for direct exports by foreign concession holders; licenses serve mainly to enforce taxation or, for agricultural products, to assure certification of quality and origin and to safeguard the export monopoly of the Liberian Produce Marketing Corporation. The surrender of export proceeds is not required, and exchange receipts are freely disposable. An export tax is levied on diamonds. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Under an Investment Incentive Code of 1966 (as amended in 1973), enterprises undertaking new invest- ment projects may be granted a five-year 90 per cent du ty exemption on imports of raw materials and machin- ery, total tax exemption on reinvested profits, a 50 per cent exemption on distributable profits, and a protective tariff on competing imported products. The five-year incentive is eligible for a two-year renewal if extenuating circumstances warrant it. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are subject to licenses issued by the Minister of Finance; import licenses are issued freely but export licenses are granted restrictively. Changes during 1975 No significant changes took place. 293 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Libyan Dinar. The parity for the U.S. dollar, the inter- vention currency, is LD 0.296053 = US$1, and the Libyan Arab Republic avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Libya publishes daily buying and selling rates for 15 currencies.1 It deals with commer- cial banks only in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars, at rates fixed daily. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were LD 0.29531 buying, and LD 0.29679 selling, per US$1; for the pound ster- ling the rates were LD 0.59776 buying, and LD 0.60076 selling, per <£ stg. 1. The commercial banks are permitted to buy or sell other currencies against pounds sterling and U.S. dollars through their foreign correspondents. The commercial banks' buying and selling rates for currencies other than sterling and U.S. dollars are based on quotations in London, New York, and other centers abroad. They may not deal among themselves in foreign currencies. Neither authorized banks nor importers or exporters are allowed to enter into forward commitments in for- eign currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, which has delegated some of its powers to the author- ized banks. Policy relating to import and export licens- ing is determined by the Ministry of Economy. Import and export licenses generally are issued by the Ministry of Economy; for certain imports the approval of an- other Ministry (Interior, Health, or Agriculture and Agrarian R e fo rm) is required. Certain imports are con- fined to public sector companies and institutions (see section on Imports and Import Payments, below). Im- ports of unprocessed gold are confined to the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Settlements with other countries are made in con- vertible currencies, usually U.S. dollars or pounds ster- ling. All settlements with Israel, Mozambique, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts A nonresident, as defined by the Central Bank, who is gainfully employed in the Libyan Arab Republic is permitted under the existing exchange control regula- 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Tunisian dinars, and U.S. dollars. 294 tions to open and maintain a nonresident account in Libyan dinars with any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Legitimate earnings from employers of such nonresidents, including overtime payments, can be credited to their nonresident accounts. Similarly, au- thorized banks have authority to credit interest earned on balances in these nonresident accounts. All other credits to nonresident accounts require the prior ap- proval of the Central Bank. Remittances abroad from such accounts ma in ta ined by nonresident laborers and technicians can be allowed by banks up to 60 per cent of net salary each mon th; for those whose contracts specify that lodging and /or board will be made avail- able free of charge by the employer, remittances up to 90 per cent of net salary are permitted. Banks may issue travelers checks and foreign currency notes to nonresi- dent laborers and technicians within the limits men- tioned. Applications for amounts in excess of these limits must be submitted to the Central Bank. Such nonresidents may take with them when going abroad on vacation or on final departure certain goods whose value is not deducted from the balances in their non- resident accounts; a nonresident may also export one automobile during his period of service in the Libyan Arab Republic. Funds brought into the Libyan Arab Republic by nonresident contractors undertaking contracts in their own names are required to be kept in "special resident accounts" with a bank in the Republic. Payments re- ceived in the Libyan Arab Republic by such contractors in respect of their contracts may also be credited to these accounts. Remittances from the Libyan Arab Republic to the debit of these accounts are subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank af ter submission of all the prescribed evidence. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts. With the approval of the Central Bank, funds in blocked accounts (with certain exceptions) may be used for expenditures in the Libyan Arab Republic up to LD 500 a year to cover the cost of current visits to the Libyan Arab Republic by the owner of the funds or a close relative; for payments in the Libyan Arab Republic of legal fees, taxes, etc.; for remittances to the owner of the funds in his country of permanent residence, up to LD 1,000 in a calendar year; and for remittances in cases of hardship. When the funds have been in a blocked account for five years, they qua l ify for remit- tance in full to the owner in his country of permanent residence. The blocked accounts of persons (with cer- tain exceptions) who have left the Libyan Arab Re- public permanently are being released in installments; balances credited prior to March 31, 1966 have been released. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments Import transactions are governed by Law No. 64 of 1971, which, among other things, stipulates that import and export activities for trading purposes shall be con- fined to Libyans and to Libyan companies whose capital is wholly owned by Libyan nationals. Certain imports may be made under open general license. The import of some items, including alcoholic beverages and narcotics, is prohibited. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, motor vehicles, sugar, salt, tea, rice, barley, wheat, flour, vegetable oils, tomato paste, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, and Pharmaceuticals are confined to public sector companies and institutions and may be imported only by the National Oil Corpo- ration, the National Supplies Corporation, the Tobacco General Company, or the National Company for Medi- cines. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. All imports from Israel, Mozambique, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. The Government exercises direct control over certain imports from various countries. Exchange permits required for imports are readily granted by the authorized banks, provided that there is a firm contract and any necessary import license has been obtained and, if the import is to be made on a letter of credit basis, that a marine insurance policy from an insurance company in the Libyan Arab Repub- lic is submitted before the letter of credit is established. However, no letter of credit in respect of the import of consumer durable goods may be opened by an author- ized bank without obtaining a cash margin of 25 per cent of the import price. Importers must submit to the bank granting the exchange permit, within two months of customs clearance, a customs declaration confirming clearance and stating the valuation. The approval of the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank is required for advance payments. De- ferred payments (for up to 90 days after customs clearance) and payments for consignment shipments may be approved by the authorized banks. Imports are subject to customs duty and to customs surcharges totaling 15 per cent of the applicable cus- toms duty. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks are empowered to approve ap- plications by residents to remit foreign exchange up to LD 100 in a calendar year for meeting genuine personal commitments abroad of a noncommercial nature, in- cluding family assistance and gifts. They may also approve allocations for travel as indicated below, as well as transfers abroad to residents of the Libyan Arab Republic undertaking studies abroad, of foreign ex- change for maintenance, up to limits prescribed for various countries, plus tuition fees, an allowance for books, etc. Remittances from nonresident accounts may be approved by authorized banks up to certain limits LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). All other payments for invisibles, as well as payments in excess of the approval authority delegated to the banks, require licenses from the Central Bank. Applications are considered on their merits. Persons leaving the country may take with them Libyan currency notes not exceeding a total of LD 20 (LD 10 for children under 12); these may not be spent or exchanged outside the Libyan Arab Republic, but are intended for immediate expenses in the Libyan Arab Republic upon return to the country. Residents leaving for personal travel abroad, including tourist travel may, in addition, take out foreign exchange in the form of foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit not exceeding a total value of LD 300 in a calendar year as a basic travel allowance; the exchange may be obtained from any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Children under 12 years of age are allowed half of this amount. Amounts in excess of the above may be granted in special cir- cumstances. Pilgrims were entitled during 1975 to a special quota of LD 400 in addition to the basic travel allowance. For business travel, residents may take out the equivalent of LD 1,000 a trip, subject to a maximum of LD 2,500 in any calendar year. All fares may be settled in Libyan dinars in the Libyan Arab Republic. Temporary residents may take out any travelers checks or foreign currency notes which they had previously brought in and declared to the customs. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are only required for fish and for commodities which are not of Libyan origin. Export proceeds must be received through an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Exports of nonmone- tary gold (other than for processing ab road ), vegetable oils, and scrap metals are prohibited; the export or re- export of wheat, wheat flour, crushed wheat, barley, rice, tea, sugar, and macaroni, which are subsidized commodities, is also prohibited. All exports to Israel, Mozambique, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers checks or foreign currency notes may be cashed only at an authorized bank or at an exchange office licensed by the Central Bank. Travelers entering the Libyan Arab Republic may bring with them Libyan currency notes, not exceeding a total of LD 20, and other currency notes, travelers checks, letters of credit, securities, coupons, and other negotiable instruments in unlimited amounts. Capital Many aspects of the activities of oil companies operat- ing in the Libyan Arab Republic are governed by Pe- troleum Law No. 25 of 1955, as amended. However, 295 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC 51 per cent or more of the Libyan interests of most international oil companies has been nationalized. Un- der the provisions of the Foreign Capital Investment Law No. 37 of July 31, 1968, foreign capital invested in projects deemed to contribute to the economic devel- opment of the country, as well as profits thereon, and salaries of foreign staff employed on such projects may be transferred freely to the country of origin, provided that the paid-up capital is not less than LD 200,000 and that at least 51 per cent of the shares is held by foreign nationals. Foreign participation in new industrial ven- tures (i.e., those set up after March 20, 1970) is per- mitted only on a minority basis, and only if it leads to increased production in excess of local requirements, introduction of the latest technology, and cooperation with foreign firms in exporting the surplus production. Insurance companies and foreign shareholdings in banks have been nationalized. Commercial firms have been Libyanized in varying degrees. Real estate in the Libyan Arab Republic may be sold only to Libyans, other than in exceptional circumstances specified in a law of May 24, 1960 governing this sub- ject. The net sales proceeds af ter tax of real estate belonging to foreign nationals are transferable, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident- owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). Residents require the prior approval of the Central Bank to borrow funds abroad. As a rule, residents require prior permission to purchase real estate situated outside the Libyan Arab Republic or to invest abroad in securities. Residents of the Libyan Arab Republic taking up permanent resi- dence abroad are permitted to transfer up to LD 5,000 for a fam i ly; applications may be submitted for the release of the balance of their assets over a number of years. The investment of national capital abroad is governed by Law No. 25 of April 20, 1973. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form other than bars in the Libyan Arab Republic. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. It sells bars to domestic goldsmiths in limited quantities, to meet genuine commercial needs, at prices announced f rom time to time; at the end of 1975 this price was LD 1,602 a kilogram. Provided that a license is obtained f rom the Ministry of Economy, goldsmiths may have such gold processed abroad, after which it must be reimported. Bars purchased from the Central Bank must be melted and processed before they can be sold to the public. Exports of unworked gold not for processing are not permitted unless made by or on behalf of the Government. Unworked gold is subject to an import du ty of 15 per cent. Changes during 1975 May 15.
