Not for Redistribution MADAGASCAR (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Madagascar has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the Malagasy Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of FMG 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Central Bank and commercial banks take place at the rates of FMG 50.25 selling, and FMG 49.75 buying, per F 1. The Central Bank quotes seven other currencies.1 Its buying and selling rates for the U.S. dol- lar on December 31, 1975 were FMG 223.15 and FMG 225.40, respectively, per US$1. The authorized banks are not permitted to ma in ta in an exchange posi- tion in any foreign currency. All countries other than Madagascar itself are considered foreign countries, and financial relations w i th all foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Office of External Finance of the Directorate of the Treasury in the Ministry of Finance and Planning, which also supervises borrowing and lending abroad by residents, the issue, sale, or introduction of foreign securities in Madagascar, all outward investments, and inward direct investment. Some of the exchange control approval authority has been delegated to the authorized banks. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized inter- mediaries. Import licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Directorate in the Ministry of Economy and Commerce, including those for gold. Export authoriza- tions are issued either by the Foreign Trade Directorate or by other specified public agencies, mainly stabilization funds or marketing offices for agricultural products. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized intermediaries, which may deal with the Central Bank only in the currencies quoted by the latter. Nonresident Accounts The principal type of nonresident account is Foreign Accounts in Malagasy Francs; these accounts may be debited and credited only for transactions between nonresidents and for explicitly authorized transactions between residents and nonresidents. When Malagasy francs accruing to a nonresident are not eligible for credit to a Foreign Account for lack of sufficient docu- mentation, they must be credited to a Special Account, balances in which may be used by the holder for per- 1 These currencies are listed as Belgian francs, deutsche ma rk, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. sonal expenses in Madagascar, subject to a limit of FMG 20,000 a day. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to import licensing; the import of certain other items is prohibited or suspended until fu r ther notice. Imports of fruit juices are conditional on purchases of domestic fru it juices (jumelage). Imports are effected within the framework of an annual import program. The import program is based on the estab- lishment of global quotas that set the limits up to which specified commodities may be imported. For certain goods automatic licenses are issued. The import of cer- tain items is reserved for the Regie Malgache des Monopoles Fiscaux and the Societe Nationale de Com- merce (SONACO) ; these include alcoholic beverages, rice, wheat flour, vegetable oils, and cement. All import transactions valued at FMG 10,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized bank. The import license entitles importers to purchase the neces- sary exchange (not earlier than eight days before ship- ment when a documentary credit is opened); where documentary drafts are used, the payment can be made when the shipping documents are submitted to the authorized intermediary. Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance and Planning. For some types of transactions the approval authority has been delegated to authorized banks, either up to specified l im i ts or for any amount that is properly documented. Residents may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism equivalent to FMG 75,000 a person a trip, for up to two trips a year (FMG 35,000 for children under t e n ); any foreign exchange remaining after return to Madagascar must be surrendered. There also is an exchange allocation for business travel up to the equivalent of FMG 10,000 a person a day, subject to a max imum of FMG 200,000 a person a trip, for any number of trips a year. Authorized banks may not make available foreign banknotes in excess of the equiv- alent of FMG 20,000 a person a trip for tourist or business travel. Applications for amounts in excess of the basic tourist and business travel allocations, and applications for exchange for any other type of travel, must be submitted to the Ministry of Finance and Plan- ning. Allocations for different types of travel may not be combined without the prior approval of the Direc- torate of the Treasury. There are basic allocations for study expenses and certain other current invisibles. Dividends are trans- ferable in full when distributed by industrial firms and up to 75 per cent in other cases; they may only be 297 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MADAGASCAR transferred to nonresident physical or juridical persons of foreign nationality. The transfer of savings from wages and salaries earned by a foreigner working in Madagascar is permitted, upon presentation of his work contract and employment permit, and provided that the transfer takes place w i th in three months of the pay period. The amounts allowed are up to 25 per cent of the net salary for bachelors and persons having their family in Madagascar, and up to 45 per cent for those whose family lives outside Madagascar (100 per cent for all concerned during leave spent outside Madagas- car) ; in no event, however, may the transferab le amount exceed FMG 300,000 a person a month. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to FMG 5,000 in Malagasy banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any rema in ing foreign banknotes and coins and other foreign means of payment declared by them on entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to all destinations of products under quota and of so-called controlled products require an exit permit (autorisation de sortie) issued by the Foreign Trade Directorate or the appropriate commodity stabili- zation office; these products include coffee, vanilla, cloves, pepper, sugar, rice, and petroleum and petroleum products. SON AGO has a monopoly over exports of beans and live cattle. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered; such export proceeds normally must become due not later than one month af ter arrival of the goods at their destination. All export transactions valued at FMG 50,000 or more must be domiciled with an authorized intermediary and the exporter must sign a commitment to repatriate the foreign currency pro- ceeds. Proceeds from Invisibles All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income or proceeds accru- ing in those countries or from nonresidents, must be repatriated and, when received in foreign currency, sur- rendered within one month of the due date. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of means of payment denominated in a foreign cur- rency. The import of Malagasy banknotes in excess of FMG 5,000 is prohibited. Capital Capital movements between Madagascar and foreign countries and between residents and nonresidents are subject to prior authorization by the M in is try of Finance and Planning; capital receipts from foreign countries normally are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver- 298 tising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Madagascar. Foreign direct investments in Madagascar,2 and Mala- gasy direct investments abroad,3 require prior approval of the Minister of Finance and Planning (i.e., the Directorate of the Treasury). The total or partial liqui- dation of such investments must be declared to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of direct investments, whether these are Malagasy investments abroad or foreign investments in Madagascar, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and P lann ing within 20 days following each operation. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company, but such participation is subject to prior declaration to the M in is try of Finance and Planning. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Madagascar requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance and Planning. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in con- nection w i th shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Madagascar has previously been authorized. Borrowing abroad by physical or juridical persons, whether public or private persons, requires prior autho- rization by the Minister of Finance and Planning. How- ever, loans contracted by authorized banks or credit in s t i tu t ions w i th special legal status are exempt from approval. Lending abroad is subject to authorization by the Ministry of Finance and Planning. In accordance with the Investment Code of Septem- ber 19, 1973, foreign or domestic enterprises of special interest for the economy may be granted preferential treatment in accordance with an "order of approval" (arrete d'agrement). Such enterprises may benefit from specified advantages relating to import and export duties, income taxes, import licenses, the introduction of quotas for competing imports, etc. The same benefits may be granted temporarily to investments not qualifying for an "order of approval." Exceptional treatment beyond the benefits provided for by the Investment Code and other existing legislation may be granted in a participa- tion contract (contrat de participation). Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Madagascar. Imports and exports of gold require prior authorization by the Ministry of Finance and Planning. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Central Bank; (2) imports and exports of manu- 2 Including those made by companies in Madagascar that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Madagascar of foreign companies. 3 Inc lud ing those made through the in te rmed ia ry of fore ign compa- nies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Madagas- car and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Madagascar. ©International Monetary Fund. Imports of gold, whether licensed or exempt from license, are subject to customs declaration. Newly mined gold must be surren- dered to the Directorate of Industry and Mines, which, in principle, must deliver it to the Central Bank after processing. Changes during 1975 February 8. Not for Redistribution MALAWI (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Malawi Kwacha. Since June 7, 1975 the currency has been pegged to the SDR, at MK 1 = SDR 0.9487. The middle rate for the U.S. dollar is determined on the basis of the Fund's daily calculations of the U.S. dollar/ SDR rate; rates for other currencies are determined on the basis of cross rates in the London market. On December 31, 1975, the Reserve Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were MK 1 = US$1.1142, and MK 1 = US$1.1086, respectively. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of Malawi under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the authority for approving nor- mal current payments is in tu rn delegated to commer- cial banks designated as authorized dealers. Import policy is formulated by the Minister of Trade and Industry, subject to the approval of the Cabinet. The Minister is also responsible for the issue of import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Malawi has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. For prescription of currency purposes, a distinction is made between the rest of the Sterling Area (the Nonresident Scheduled Area) and all other coun- tries except Rhodesia (the External Account Area).1 Settlements with residents of other countries in the Ster- ling Area may be made in Malawi kwacha through a Nonresident Scheduled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Payments to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhode- sia may be made in sterling or in Malawi kwacha to the credit of an External Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhodesian currency. Pay- ments from residents of countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Malawi kwacha from an External Account, or in any non-Sterling Area currency freely exchangeable for ster- ling. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Malawi kwacha held by residents of other parts of the Sterling Area are designated Nonresi- 1 Under Malawi's exchange control regulations, all currencies other than the Malawi kwacha (or any other currency that may be legal tender in Ma law i) are considered fore ign currencies. 300 dent Scheduled Area Accounts. These accounts may be credited with the proceeds from sales of any Sterling Area currency, with authorized payments to Sterling Area countries by residents, and with transfers from other Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts. Balances on these accounts may be used to make payments to residents of Malawi for any purpose and may be trans- ferred freely to other Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts; these accounts may also be debited for pay- ments to the account holder while temporarily resident in Malawi. Transfers to External Accounts require specific approval. Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with authorized banks by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized pay- ments by residents to countries outside the Sterling Area except Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, with individually approved transfers from Nonres ident Scheduled Area Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any non-Sterling Area currency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to autho- rized dealers. They may be debited for payments for any purpose to residents of Malawi and of any other country of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts held in Malawi or any other Sterling Area territory, or to Nonresident Scheduled Area Accounts in Malawi, and for purchases of any Sterling Area or non-Sterling Area currency other than Rhode- sian currency from authorized dealers; they may also be debited for withdrawals by the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi. External Accounts —Rhodesia are accounts in Malawi kwacha that are held by persons regarded as residents of Rhodesia. They may only be credited with (1) the proceeds from the sale of Rhodesian currency to an authorized dealer in Malawi, and (2) transfers from another Rhodesian External Account. The accounts may be debited with (1) payments to residents of Malawi for any purpose; (2) payments to the account holder while temporarily staying in Malawi; (3) trans- fers to another Rhodesian External Account; end (4) transfers to the account holders in Rhodesia. Blocked Accounts in Malawi kwacha held with autho- rized banks by residents of any country other than Malawi are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Malawi currency which have accrued to nonresidents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Normally, approval is given for the investment of balances of Blocked Accounts in Malawian securities, provided that these are held in Malawi to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on' Blocked Account balances is ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution freely transferable to the account holder's country of residence. Imports and Import Payments The statutory basis of the principal import restrictions is the Control of Goods Act, which authorizes the Minister of Trade and Industry to control and regulate the import, export, distribution, disposal, purchase, sale, wholesale price, and retail price of any goods. It also has provisions which, when brought in to operation, will require all importers and exporters to be registered. The import from Rhodesia of asbestos, iron ore, pig iron, chrome, tobacco, copper, and hides and skins is prohibited. For a number of items,2 import licenses are required regardless of the country of origin. All other goods may be imported under an open general license when or ig ina t ing in Commonwealth countries or in non- Commonwealth countries that are members of the GATT. Imports or ig ina t ing in the Republic of China are treated similarly but require an ind iv idual license. With respect to other countries, an import license is required for all commodities except certain items such as petroleum products, exposed cinematographic films, bona fide unsolicited gifts not exceeding MK 50 in value, samples, and advertising materials. Payments for imports f rom all countries must be made after customs entry and w i th in six months after the date of import, except with the express permission of the exchange control authorities. Foreign exchange for these payments is automatically granted by the authorized dealers, subject only to the presentation of relevant documents ( inc lud ing the customs entry certifi- cate) and compliance with import licensing require- ments. Any transfer of funds in anticipation of imports is prohibited, except with the permission of the exchange control authorities. Advance payments may, however, be made for imports valued at up to MK 100 on presen- tation of an invoice or other evidence ind ica t ing that the seller requires payment in advance. Imports from any Sterling Area country may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local Nonresident Scheduled Area Account, in sterling, or in any other Sterling Area currency. Imports from other areas, except Rhodesia, may be paid for in Malawi currency to a local External Account, in sterling to an External Account held else- where in the Sterling Area, or in any non-Sterling Area currency. A surtax of 10 per cent is levied on most goods imported into Malawi, irrespective of their origin; the surtax is calculated on 120 per cent of the sum of the value for customs duty purposes and any customs duty payable. 2 Certain agricultural and food products, new (m i l i tary type) and used clothing, gold, sugar, wheat flour, cement, fertilizers, newsprint and certain paper products, pencils, ball-point pens, office stapling machines and staples, pr in t ing inks, erasers, hand-operated number ing stamps, flick knives, explosives, arms and ammunition, game traps, mist nets, wild animals, live fish, cassava, and copyright articles. MALAWI Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes such as travel, is provided by the authorized dealers without prior reference to the exchange control authorities. The basic exchange allowance for private travel is MK 20 a day for an adult, with a maximum of MK 600 a calen- dar year, and MK 10 a day for each child under 18 years of age, with a max imum of MK 300 a calendar year for children between 10 and 18, and MK 200 a year for children under 10. The annual allowance is not cumulative but may be increased by up to 50 per cent if the traveler has not applied for a travel allowance dur ing the preceding three years. These allocations are subject to a combined maximum of MK 2,000 a year for a fam i ly traveling together. The basic exchange allowance for business travel is MK 40 a day, up to MK 400 a tr ip for any number of trips a year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as education, medical treatment, and family remit- tances. Applications for amounts exceeding the stan- dard allocations may be submitted to the exchange con- trol authorities. Foreign nationals employed in Malawi on contracts or holding a temporary employment permit are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their current net earnings to their country of normal residence. Travelers may take out up to MK 20 in Malawi cur- rency and the equivalent of MK 20 in foreign currency in addition to their basic travel allowance. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of goods of any description that exceed MK 100 in va lue are prohibited, unless the Controller of Customs and Excise is satisfied that payment has been made or will be made in an appropriate manner to a resident of Malawi not later than six months after the date of exportation. Certain commodities3 are sub- ject to export licensing, mainly to ensure the adequacy of their domestic supplies. Export proceeds in foreign currency must be sold to an authorized dealer. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any foreign currency must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. There is no l im i ta t ion on the amount of foreign currency notes and coins that may be imported by travelers, but not more than MK 20 in Malawi currency notes and coins may be imported. The import of currency notes and coins of the former Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is prohibited. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted, with the exception that the taking up of loans from abroad by residents requires prior exchange control approval. 3 Implements of war, petroleum products, nickel, atomic energy materials, and certain agricultural and animal products. 301 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAWI This is normally granted, provided that the terms of repayment are realistic. Outward transfers of capital, including those to other parts of the Sterling Area, are controlled, but nonresidents are permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country f rom sources outside Malawi; there are no restrictions on the transfer abroad of divi- dends and profits of foreign-owned companies, provided that no recourse is being made to local borrowing. In general, residents are not permitted to transfer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized dealer any foreign exchange which accrues to them. However, residents may purchase foreign securities (except bearer securi- ties) quoted on recognized stock exchanges in the Ster- ling Area, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and held to the order of an authorized dealer, and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are permitted to be repatriated by the exchange control authorities of the coun try concerned. All income earned from these investments must be repatriated, and the corresponding foreign exchange must be sold to an authorized dealer. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed exchange up to MK 15,000 whether single or married. (2) Married persons who have not reached the age of 50 are allowed MK 6,000 on departure, together with MK 500 for each child, up to a max imum of MK 8,000 for a fam i ly. (3) Unmarried persons who have not reached 50 years of age are allowed MK 3,000 on departure. (4) The balance of the emigrant's funds is blocked, but he is permitted to transfer to his new country of residence a sum equal to the original emigration allowance on each anniversary of his departure from Malawi, up to a maximum of MK 8,000. Applications for emigrants' allowances, whether initial or subsequent, must be sub- mitted to the exchange control authorities for approval. Residents require prior approval to lend to nonresi- dents or to resident firms controlled directly or indirectly f rom outside Malawi. Approval to lend to nonresident-controlled firms may be withheld if it is felt that excessive recourse is being had to local borrowing, and that the firms have brought in insufficient working capital from abroad; the permissible ratio between nonresident-controlled firms' domestic borrowing and their externally obtained funds is subject to change. Gold Residents of Malawi may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Malawi for num isma t ic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authori- ties and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Minister of Trade and Industry in consultation with the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1975 June 9. The currency was pegged to the SDR at a rate of MK 1 = SDR 0.9487, corresponding to the rate applicable at close of business on June 6. Previously, the rate of the kwacha had been based on a weighted average of the rates for the U.S. dollar and the pound sterling. As before, rates for other currencies traded by the Reserve Bank continued to be determined by the appropriate cross rates prevailing in exchange markets abroad, ma in ly the London market. June 9. Henceforth, no foreign exchange was released to pay for imports until documentary evidence of impor- tation into the Malawian customs territory was pro- duced; payment against sight letters of credit and sight bills of exchange was no longer permitted. July 1. Malawi's Commonwealth tariff preferences were abolished. 302 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Malaysian Ringgit, and Malaysia avails itself of wider margins. On June 21, 1973 the authorities ceased to ma in ta in the exchange rate within announced margins, and since September 27, 1975 the ringgit has been pegged to a composite of the currencies of Malaysia's major trad ing partners. The closing buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the Malaysian foreign exchange market on December 31, 1975 were M$2.5870 and M$2.5875 per US$1, respectively. The commercial banks are free to determine and quote exchange rates for all currencies to customers and are permitted to deal forward in all currencies. Malaysia formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom November 11, 1968. Administration of Control The Central Bank of Malaysia administers exchange control on behalf of the Malaysian Government through- out Malaysia, the Governor of the Bank being the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Most of the authority for approving payments abroad is delegated to commer- cial banks authorized for this purpose; no delegation has been granted for the repayment of foreign loans or the payment of interest on such loans. The au thor i ty for import control rests with the Central Government. The day-to-day administration of import control throughout Malaysia is carried out jo in t ly by the Minis- try of Trade and Industry and the Royal Customs and Excise.1 Prescription of Currency Malaysia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. All payments to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa may be made either in ringgit through an External Account, or in any currency other than Israel, Rhodesian, and South Afr ican curren- cies. Receipts from exports to countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa must be obtained, within the time of payment specified in the commercial contract but subject to a maximum period of six months from the date of exportation, either in ringgit obtained from the sale of a specified currency to a bank in Malay- sia, or in any specified currency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. xThe three territories of Malaysia are Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, and Sarawak. Labuan is a free port. Nonresident Accounts The accounts in ringgit of residents of countries other than Malaysia are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless specially restricted, are designated External Accounts. There are no restrictions on debits to Exter- nal Accounts. Credits to these accounts for whatever purpose are freely permitted subject only to the comple- tion of exchange control forms for amounts above M$ 1,000; the proceeds from the sale of any foreign currency may be credited to External Accounts. For amoun ts exceeding M$ 1,000 and up to M$l million, permission may be given by commercial banks; above M$l million, permission is given by the Controller of Foreign Exchange. Balances on External Accounts may be t rans fe r red to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any currency except Israel, Rhodesian, and South Afr ican currencies. Accounts of residents of Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are designated as Israel Accounts, Rhodesian Accounts, and South Afr ican Accounts, respectively. All debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments Ta r i f fs and import controls of the various parts of Malaysia have not yet been fu l ly unified, although steps toward un i f ica t ion are being taken. Some internal tar iffs and other trade restrictions still exist between the terri- tories of Malaysia. Most imports are permitted freely. Depending on the na tu re and origin of the goods, spe- c if ic licenses are required for certain imports for health, security, or moral reasons; various conditions must be satisfied before licenses for such goods are issued. Cer- ta in other imports are subject to quantitative restrictions as a temporary measure to protect local industries; these restrictions are reviewed from time to time. Imports into all parts of Malaysia of all commodities f rom Israel, South A f r ica, Rhodesia, or any territory administered by any one of these are prohibited. Imports in to all parts of Malaysia of all commodities from the People's Republic of China are subject to specific license, and applications to import must be submitted through PERNAS, except those for items subject to quan t i ta t ive restriction. Imports into all parts of Malay- sia of all commodities f rom the German Democratic Republic and North Korea also require specific licenses. Imports into Peninsular Malaysia of primates from all sources, including Sabah and Sarawak, are prohibited except under specific license; imports of other live ani- mals (except sheep and goats), bones, and bone meal from Brunei, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Thai- land, and Viet-Nam also require a specific license. Imports into Sarawak of sulfur, certain chemicals, and live sheep and goats f rom all sources, including Peninsu- lar Malaysia and Sabah, are prohibited, except under 303 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALAYSIA specific license. Imports of motor vehicles and certain types of textiles into all parts of Malaysia are also subject to specific import licensing; however, imports of textiles into Sabah and Sarawak are allowed freely. Imports of wheat flour, bran, and most types of sugar from all sources are subject to quan t i ta t ive restrictions for protec- tive reasons; licenses for wheat flour and refined sugar are not being issued. Other goods subject to quan t i ta t ive restriction in Peninsular Malaysia include rolled oats, certain cotton fabrics, certain fabrics of synthetic fibers, jute, and fully assembled or completely built-up motor vehicles. Payment for permitted imports is freely allowed after exchange control requirements have been met. Virtually all imports into Malaysia ( inc lud ing Penang but excluding Labuan) are subject to a surtax of 5 per cent ad valorem. Some essential goods, such as rice, common salt, and kerosene, are exempt, and a draw- back may be granted on goods intended for re-export or for export af ter processing. In addition, most imports into Malaysia (excluding Labuan) are subject to a sales tax; the standard rate of tax is 5 per cent ad valorem, but certain luxury goods are subject to a rate of 10 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa may be made freely after exchange control requ iremen ts have been met. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad. Remittances to nonresidents of dividends, interest, and profits on all bona fide investments are freely permitted, subject only to the completion of exchange control forms for amoun ts in excess of M$ 1,000. Unless special permission is obtained, not more than M$ 1,000 in Malaysian notes and the equivalent of M$ 1,000 in fore ign notes may be taken out of Malaysia by travelers. Nonresident travel- ers are allowed to take out foreign currency notes up to the amount declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds The three territories of Malaysia at present maintain separate export control systems, although the Federal Government retains the right to legislate in respect of exports from any Malaysian territory. Exchange con- trol forms have to be completed and authorized by banks in Malaysia for exports valued at M$5,000 f.o.b. or more.2 Proceeds from exports must be received within the time of payment specified in the commercial con- tract but subject to a max imum period of six months f rom the date of export, either in a specified currency or in ringgit obtained from the sale of a specified cur- rency to a bank in Malaysia. Exports of rubber from Peninsular Malaysia require a certificate issued by the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board. 2 In the case of exports to Indonesia, in excess of M$100,000. 304 Exports of rubber and tin to South Afr ica and any terri- tory administered by South Afr ica are prohibited. All exports to Israel and Rhodesia and any territory adminis- tered by either are also prohibited. Exports of cement, scrap iron, steel bars, form ic acid, wheat flour, rice bran, and sugar are subject to licensing, and licenses for these and a few other items (such as fertilizers and pig iron) are administratively denied. Also subject to licensing are exports of all textiles, certain confectionery items, tiles, fish meal, bricks, "dollar area goods," all commo- dities used in barter trade, and all exports to the Peo- ple's Republic of China, the Republic of China, Hong Kong, North Korea, the Republic of Korea, Macao, and North Viet-Nam. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange control requ iremen ts governing exchange receipts f rom invisibles are, in principle, simi- lar to those for export proceeds. Travelers may bring in up to M$ l ,000 in Malaysian currency notes; other- wise, permission is required for the import of Malaysian notes. No l im i ta t ions are imposed on the import by travelers of currency notes of other countries. Capital Inward investment covered by the guidelines issued on February 20, 1974 (regarding the acquisition of assets, mergers, and take-overs) or by those issued on October 29, 1975 (regarding foreign equity participa- t ion) requires prior approval by the Foreign Investment Committee. The proceeds of investments may be repa- tr ia ted freely on resale, subject to the completion of exchange control fo rms for amounts above M$ 1,000. Malaysian residents require approval for borrowings f rom nonresidents in either ringgit or in foreign curren- cies. Companies in Malaysia controlled by nonresidents are permitted to borrow in Malaysia up to M$500,000 without exchange control approval. The permission of the Controller of Foreign Exchange is freely given for direct and portfolio investment by Malaysian residents in countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Gold Residents other than authorized dealers in gold are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any fo rm other than gold that has been materially increased in value by skilled craftsmanship. The manufac ture, import, or export of gold coins is prohibited, as is domestic trad ing in gold coins other than the M$100 gold coin of Malaysian currency and the S$150 gold coin of Singapore currency. Resident and nonresident travelers, however, may freely bring in or take out, on their person, one M$100 gold coin. In addition, each traveler is allowed to bring in f rom any country outside Malaysia one S$150 gold coin issued by the Singapore Board of Commissioners of Currency, and each traveler may take out one such coin, but only to Singapore. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Licensed goldsmiths are permitted by the exchange con- trol authorities to purchase certain quantities of gold from an authorized dealer at local free market prices for the manufacture of bona fide jewelry and ornaments. Furthermore, producers of gold are permitted to sell their output at local free market prices to authorized dealers in gold. Imports of gold are restricted under the Customs Act, 1967, and require licenses from the M in is try of Trade and Industry. Permission for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler is not normally given except for imports by authorized dealers in gold to meet the genuine requirements of goldsmiths for manu fac tu r ing jewelry and ornaments and for industrial use. Imports are allo- cated to authorized dealers in gold by means of a tender system; successful tenderers must pay a premium to the Government. Since 1973, however, no imports have taken place. Imports are subject to a 7 per cent import duty and a 5 per cent surtax (suspended un t il Decem- ber 31, 1975), as well as a sales tax of 10 per cent ad valorem. The sale of gold by domestic producers is subject only to the sales tax, at 10 per cent ad valorem. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry consti- tu t ing the personal effects of a traveler are prohibited under the exchange control regulations; any export licenses that might be issued for gold or gold coins would require in addition the approval of the exchange control authorities. Changes during 1975 January 9. Imports into Peninsular Malaysia of cer- tain shirting materials and su i t ing materials made entirely of either cotton or synthetic fibers required a specific license. Most of the items concerned became subject to quota. January 20. Exports of sugar f rom Sabah and Sara- wak required a specific license. Licenses were not nor- mally issued. April 9. Exports of many vegetables required a spe- cific license. April 25. The Petroleum Development Act of July 30, 1974 was amended. The amendment provided that any company processing or ref in ing petroleum or marke t ing or distributing petroleum and petrochemical products in Malaysia could be required to issue management shares to PETRONAS. May 15. The Industrial Coordination Act was enacted. The Act required all m anu f a c tu r ing companies in Malaysia, including those already established, to obtain a license from the Government, which could impose conditions as it deemed appropriate. June 5. A medium-term Euro-currency loan of US$150 million to the Government of Malaysia was signed. June 16. Imports of rice vermicelli required an indi- vidual license and became subject to quota. MALAYSIA August 21. The Malaysian Currency (Ringgit) Act, 1975 amended the Central Bank of Malaysia Ordinance, 1958 and substituted the term ringgit for that of Malay- sian dollar. August 28. Imports of additional types of sugar into Peninsular Malaysia, Sabah, and Sarawak required an individual license. September 11. Imports of certain bars and rods into Peninsular Malaysia and Penang required an individual license and became subject to quota. September 27. The Minister of Finance announced that it had no longer been desirable for the Central Bank to determine the exchange rate of the ringgit in terms of the U.S. dollar alone and to buy or sell the U.S. dollar in order to ma in ta in an exchange rate so deter- mined. Instead, the value of the ringgit would be deter- mined in terms of the currencies of those countries which are s ign if icant trad ing partners of Malaysia. October 27. The Prime Minister announced that the Government accepted the need for participation of for- eign private investment in the petroleum industry. October 28. The Minister of Trade and Industry announced certain changes in the guidelines for foreign investment in Malaysia. Only companies using imported components and producing almost entirely for export would be allowed to remain under foreign control. Com- panies already in Malaysia also would have to conform w i th the guidelines. The general aim was that foreign investment would be allowed in the proportion of 30 per cent foreign equity and 70 per cent Malaysian, of which 30 per cent was to be burntputra (indigenous Ma lay ). New import substitution projects must have 100 per cent Malaysian ownership. Industries exporting more than 80 per cent of their production and using mainly imported materials could be considered for majority foreign ownership, ranging f rom 51 to 70 per cent, but in exceptional cases 100 per cent foreign ownership might be considered. Export-oriented industries using nondepleting local raw materials must have Malaysian ownership ranging between 45 and 70 per cent; export- oriented industries using depleting local raw materials would be allowed a maximum of 30 per cent foreign ownership, although such companies might initially be allowed 35-45 per cent foreign ownership. The Minis- ter gave an assurance that the Government would not take over or nationalize foreign manufacturing companies. The statement also set out the equity conditions for existing manu fac tu r ing companies; a distinction was made between companies set up without approval, those approved before January 1, 1972, and those approved a f t er that date. November 6. Import duties were increased on a wide range of goods, including certain luxury foodstuffs, motor vehicles, refrigerators, and other consumer dur- ables. 305 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALI (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Kate System No par value for the currency of Mali has been established with the Fund. The official unit of currency is the Mali Franc, which is officially maintained at the rate of MF = 0.01 French franc. There is also a fixed rate for CFA francs of MF 2 = CFAF 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned. With the exception of those relating to gold, Mali's exchange control measures do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Mali itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to ex- change control. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance has sole authority in ex- change control matters; certain exchange control powers have been delegated to authorized banks. The bilateral payments agreements are operated by the Development Bank of Mali. Licenses for imports and exports are issued by the Directorate-General of Economic Affa irs in the Ministry of Commerce. Exchange control is applicable only to foreign countries. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of transactions covered by bilateral payments agreements are made in curren- cies and through accounts established under such agree- ments. Bilateral accounts are maintained with the People's Republic of China, the German Democratic Republic, Egypt, Hungary, Morocco, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam.1 Mali is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since its Central Bank maintains an Opera- tions Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in Mali francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries with which no payments agree- ment is in force are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those coun- tries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are, in principle, based on those applied in France. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited for health, safety, and similar reasons, and licenses are not normally issued for certain other goods. Imports of all other goods, irrespective of origin, require individual licenses, and imports from foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank. Imports are licensed in accordance with an annual import program. The program consists of two parts: an allocation for clearing countries and one for the convertible area (defined as comprising all other coun- tries, including the French Franc A rea ). Certain aid- financed imports are not included in the import program and do not require an import license. Imports may be made either by private importers or by state enterprises, among which the Societe Malienne de PImport-Export (SOMIEX) is by far the most important, having a monopoly over the import of a number of items.2 All imports from and exports to countries that have payments agreements with Mali are made by SOMIEX or UNICOOP. The Office des Produits Agricoles du Mali (OPAM) has a monopoly over the import of cereals. An allocation commission establishes quotas for each private importer on the basis of his turnover. Import licenses are issued to the private importer up to the limit of the quota accorded to him. In addition, importers may with an import license import any goods under the EXIC (Exportation et Importation Concomi- tante) procedure. The authorized banks are permitted to make foreign exchange available for all licensed imports. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above) and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other coun- tries are subject to approval. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresi- dents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely. Not for Redistribution MALI Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equiva- lent to MF 150,000 a person, which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange remaining after return to Mali must be surrendered. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of MF 40,000 a day, subject to a maximum of MF 400,000 a trip.3 The transfer of the entire salary of a foreigner working in Mali is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident travelers, irrespective of destination, may take out up to a max imum of MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Opera- tions Account countries (MF 5,000 for trips of less than 24 hours). Nonresident travelers may freely take out foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of MF 150,000; higher amounts may be taken out only if declared upon entry. They may also take out MF 50,000 in Mali banknotes and any payments instruments drawn up abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank, and export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Opera- tions Account country must be surrendered; export proceeds must normally be collected and repatriated within 90 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. Exports require individual licenses in order to ensure the repatriation of export proceeds. The export of cotton, groundnuts, meat, and hides and skins is reserved in principle for SOMIEX and the Societe Malienne du Betail et des Peaux et Cuirs (SOMBEPEC ); in practice, hides and skins may also be exported by private firms and individuals. Under the EXIC procedure, exporters may retain 75 per cent of proceeds from exports of commodities of the traditional sector except those covered by the monop- oly of state trad ing companies, for payment for their own imports that are made through regular official channels. Balances on EXIC accounts and import rights under the EXIC procedure are not transferable. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above) and other Operations Account coun- tries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the Central 3 Exchange for tourist travel purposes is made available only to persons submitting an exit permit (autorisation de sortie) issued by the Security Services. 308 Bank of Mali, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Capital Capital movements between Mali, France (as defined above), and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (in addition to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad; the Development Bank of Mali is exempt. The special control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above) or to coun- tries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Under an Investment Code of May 23, 1969 and Law No. 62 of January 15, 1962, the Government may grant special privileged status, providing for transfer, tax, and other preferential treatment to foreign invest- ments that would be of special interest to the Malian economy and that are compatible with the goals of the Economic Plan. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Mali for num isma t ic purposes and for ornaments. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authori- ties and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted. Changes during 1975 January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1974 of the bilateral payments agreement with Czecho- slovakia, settlements with that country were placed on a convertible currency basis. March 6. Ordinance No. 23/CMLN abolished the statistical tax of 2 per cent ad valorem on imports and exports. March 17. Instruction No. 6/MF-CAB re-established with minor changes the regime of import taxation of the West African Customs Union, which had been suspended since July 1, 1974. March 28. Ordinance No. 30/CMLN introduced a new tax of 3 per cent ad valorem on imports and exports. July 10. France resumed its participation in the Euro- pean common margins arrangement; the parity between the Mali f ranc and the French f ranc remained unchanged. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALTA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Kate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Malta Pound. In December 1971 a central rate of 2.18613 grams of fine gold per Malta pound was estab- lished, corresponding at the time to <£M 0.374412 = US$1, or £M 0.406504 = SDR 1, and Malta avails itself of wider margins. However, since March 20, 1973 the Malta pound has been pegged to a basket of cur- rencies. The Central Bank of Malta quotes daily rates for deutsche mark, Italian lire, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars based on developments in the principal exchange markets abroad. The Central Bank's basic rate (middle rate) for the pound sterling on December 31, 1975 was <£ stg. 122.38 per £M 100, and its basic rate for the U.S. dollar was US$2.4772 per <£M 1. The commercial banks' rates for currencies not quoted by the Central Bank are based on market rates in London and New York. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Central Bank as agent for the Minister of Finance and Customs; trade controls are administered by the Director of Trade in the Ministry of Trade, Industry, and Tourism. A large number of authorities to approve applications for the allocation of foreign exchange have been delegated to the authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Malta has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under cur- rent U.K. exchange control regulations Malta continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Authorized payments to all countries may be made by crediting Malta pounds to an External Account or in any foreign currency;1 the proceeds of exports to all countries may be received in Malta pounds from an External Account or in any foreign currency. Nonresident Accounts Residents of all countries outside Malta may maintain with authorized banks nonresident accounts in Malta pounds, designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments by nonresidents, with transfers from other External Accounts, with the proceeds f rom sales of gold or any foreign currency (including bankno tes ), and with Malta banknotes mailed from outside Malta. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to resi- dents, for transfers to other External Accounts, for pay- ments in cash in Malta, and for purchases of any foreign currency (including banknotes). 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the Malta pound. Authorized dealers may also freely open and maintain foreign currency accounts for nonresidents. These accounts may be credited with payments in foreign cur- rency to the account holder, with transfers from another foreign currency account belonging to a nonresident, and with interest payable on foreign currency accounts. They may be debited for payments by the account holder to residents, for transfers to other foreign currency accounts, and for transfers abroad. Blocked Accounts in Malta pounds are maintained for nonresidents of Malta for certain funds of a capital nature which, under the existing exchange control regu- lations, may not be transferred outside Malta. The principal type of funds that must be credited to a Blocked Account are assets of emigrants in excess of the amount ( < £M 7,500) that may be transferred to the new country of residence; the remaining funds are normally released three years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain commodities manufactured in Malta are either prohibited or restricted. All imports from Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam are subject to specific licensing, as are imports of certain items f rom any country of origin. Imports from coun- tries other than those mentioned that are not prohibited and do not require a specific license may be made freely under open general license. Imports subject to state trad ing include wheat and cement. Payments for all authorized imports may be made freely, provided that the prescription of currency regulations are complied with and that supporting documents, including the cus- toms entry form, are submitted to the intermediary bank. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles in excess of £M 50 require the approval of the exchange control authorities; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized banks for most types of payment. There is a standard exchange allocation for tourist travel of the equivalent of <£M 250 a person a trip; a business travel allowance of £M 250 a trip or £M 30 a day ( for up to 30 days a t r ip ), whichever is the larger; and an allowance for educational expenses abroad of <£M 2,000 a person for an academic year.2 Applications for allowances in excess of these amounts are approved by the Central Bank if the latter is satisfied that there is no illicit capital out- flow involved. 2 For purposes of exchange allocations for travel and study, residents are defined as physical persons who are at the time living in Malta in the normal course and either have so lived for at least three years or in tend to continue so living for at least three years. 309 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MALTA The transfer of genuine profits, dividends, and interest for approved foreign investments requires Central Bank permission, which is normally given, after compliance with certain formalities. Life insurance expressed in Malta currency may be contracted with nonresidents lawfully engaged in insurance business in Malta, pro- vided the policy is made for a term exceeding five years and is not linked to equity or property units. Mainte- nance remittances to beneficiaries abroad are allowed on application accompanied by documentary evidence of hardship. Travelers may export Malta banknotes and coins up to <£M 25 for each person. Exports of foreign currencies may be made by resident travelers up to <£M 250 for each person and by nonresident travelers up to the amount brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of works of art and strategic war materials are prohibited and, with the exception of some 80 items that may be exported freely, all other exports are sub- ject to specific licensing. The proceeds of exports are subject to surrender within six months of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in any amount in Malta and other currency notes. Capital No control is exercised over receipts. Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an autho- rized bank, and payments of a capital na ture in such currencies require prior approval. Applications for out- ward direct investment by residents of Malta and for direct investment in Malta by nonresidents are con- sidered on their merits. The purchase of real estate in Malta is controlled by the Immovable Property (Acqui- sition by Non-Residents) Act, 1974. This Act, which is administered by the Ministry of Finance, prohibits the acquisition of immovable property in Malta by nonresi- dents, with the exception of certain special cases which would be mainly related to the economic development of Malta. The Central Bank has delegated to authorized dealers the authority to approve the acquisition of for- eign investments up to the equivalent of <£M 500 a person a calendar year by resident persons over 18. Purchases of securities issued outside Malta in excess of the <£M 500 limit require prior permission f rom the authorities. Purchases of personal real estate situated outside Malta in excess of the same limit require prior exchange control approval. Foreign nationals who repatriate or take up residence outside Malta normally are allowed to transfer all their 310 assets to their new country of residence. Maltese nationals who emigrate may transfer abroad up to <£M 5,000 for each f am i ly ;3 any excess amount is nor- mally released four years after the date of departure on application to the Central Bank.4 Banks, other than those licensed to borrow and lend outside Malta only, are restricted in the acquisition of net foreign assets. Gold Malta has issued 16 gold coins which are legal tender. Residents other than authorized banks and registered jewelers are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than coins and jewelry, at home or abroad. Residents may freely purchase, sell, and hold any gold coins. The import of gold coins for numismatic pur- poses is controlled to ensure that such coins are genuinely for numismatic purposes. A specific import license is required for imports of gold coins, gold bullion, and manufactured or sem imanufac tured articles of gold; imports of filigree work of gold or silver are prohibited. Authorized importers are permitted to import gold (bul- lion and coins) only for the purpose of disposing of it to jewelers and other industrial users. The export of gold by residents other than the monetary authorities requires the permission of the exchange control authorities. Gold bullion and gold coins are free of import duty. Changes during 1975 Dur ing the year, additional items were brought under specific import license. Only the principal ones are listed below. Six legal tender gold coins were issued. January 7. The Central Bank began to quote daily rates for the deutsche mark, the Italian lira, and the U.S. dollar. Previously, it provided daily quotations for sterling only. February 4. Most footwear became subject to specific import license. February 28. Table wines required a specific import license. March 7. Passenger automobiles required a specific import license. July 17. New regulations regarding payments between Malta and the People's Republic of China came into effect. Import payments had to be made to the suppliers, whereas previously they had to be credited to a domestic currency account at the Central Bank of Malta. October 14.
