They may be debited for payments to residents for exports and services rendered to any country and for other permitted transactions, including purchases of foreign currencies. Balances may be transferred to any other nonresident account. However, Convertible Guilder Accounts may not be debited for the purchase of Netherlands treasury paper or guilder bank acceptances; they may not be credited with interest on guilder demand deposits, and, with minor exemptions for physical persons, no guilder time or savings deposits may be established.4 If held by residents of Rhodesia, Convertible Guilder Accounts may not be debited or credited w i thout special licenses, which are granted only for the exceptional cases referred to in the relevant UN Resolution.5 Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. Virtually all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of unknown origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products, mainly from the agricultural and textile sectors, when not of EEC origin. Except for imports f rom Rhodesia, prac- tically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most imports from Eastern European countries are forma l ly liberalized. Commodities corresponding to some 19 tariff headings or subheadings are subject to quan t i ta t ive restriction when originating in Japan. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previ- ous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports f rom non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products, some of which are subject to variable import levies. Imports of cattle and beef from "third" countries (i.e., countries that are neither members of, nor associated with, the EEC) are suspended. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the general prescription of currency regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodi- ties,6 but they require prior approval from the Nether- 4 With effect from January 1, 1976 the prohibitions on the crediting of interest and on the establishment of time and savings deposits were revoked. 5 With effect from January 6, 1976, accounts held by Rhodesians were separated into R Accounts (for payments within the Netherlands, which were freely perm i t ted) and Special Accounts ( th rough which external payments had to be made, subject to special license). 6 Commodities are so defined as to exclude gold. NETHERLANDS lands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those traditional in the trade concerned; such permis- sion is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Exchange for travel is provided in any currency and up to any amount, and the entire amount may be taken, if the traveler wishes, in Netherlands banknotes. A resident traveling abroad may in addition have any fur- ther amoun ts remitted to him through banking channels. Exchange purchased for travel purposes must not be spent for other purposes; it may be used for purchases for personal use, however. Payments for interest, divi- dends, and contractual amortization due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the appropriate non- resident account. The export of domestic or foreign banknotes by resi- dent travelers is not subject to limitation. Nonresidents may export all unutilized negotiable instruments and foreign and Netherlands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by d raw ing on their accounts or exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds V ir tua l ly all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are required only for a few commodities, mostly of a strategic char- acter, and for some agricultural products, scrap of iron and steel, and certain nonferrous metals. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of exports of commodities,6 but they require prior permission from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery where such advance payments are not tradi- tional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory, but any surrender that is made must be at the official rate. The collection of export proceeds through an authorized bank is obligatory. A license may be obtained, however, to hold a bank account abroad, to which export proceeds may be credited and import payments debited; in most cases, balances in excess of a stipulated maximum amount must be transferred peri- odically to the Netherlands. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles must be collected through an authorized bank but need not be surrendered and may instead be credited to foreign currency accounts. A license may be obtained on application to hold a foreign currency account with a bank abroad, to which account proceeds f rom invisibles may be credited. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands unlim- ited amounts in Netherlands banknotes, foreign bank- notes, and negotiable instruments. These may be sold 327 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS only to an authorized bank, to an authorized exchange office, or, in the case of foreign banknotes, to an author- ized depository, or they may be used to pay tourist expenses in the Netherlands. Residents are obliged to bring back to the Netherlands any unutilized portion of the banknotes and coins that they took with them on their outward journey; there is no limitation on the amount in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and coins that they may bring in. Capital Most external capital transactions by nonbank resi- dents, whether involving foreign or domestic capital, require a specific license f rom the Netherlands Bank. The main transactions permitted by general licenses are (1) purchases and sales (except issues) of officially listed stocks and bonds, (2) loans granted or received that do not exceed f. 100,000, provided that the resident does not lend or borrow more than f. 100,000 a year to or f rom the same nonresident, and (3) suppliers' and customers' credits granted or received, subject to certain limitations (see sections on Imports and Import Pay- ments and Exports and Export Proceeds, above). At present, borrowing abroad by nonbank residents is restricted for reasons of monetary, credit, or exchange rate policy. In general, the inward transfer of foreign capital (other than for portfolio investment or the pur- chase of real estate, see below) is permitted only if the capital constitutes a direct investment. In addition to foreign participation in the capital of newly founded or existing companies, direct investment is considered to include financial loans with a fixed term of at least five years f rom the foreign parent company. Under certain conditions, loans from other affiliated fore ign companies (i.e., sister companies or subsidiaries) are being licensed. Other financial borrowing —whether by way of issuing bonds and notes abroad or by way of borrowing f rom foreign banks —is, in principle, not allowed unless the proceeds are kept abroad and used for investments abroad (which are considered to include purchases of ships and a i rc ra f t ). However, companies working on the Netherlands' part of the Continental Shelf, whether foreign owned or resident owned, are allowed to take up foreign bank loans (with a fixed term of at least five years) up to two thirds of their financing requirements. Resident units of international companies are permitted upon request to maintain current accounts with their head offices or subsidiaries abroad, mainly for the stipu- lated purpose of intercompany commercial credit, which is subject to the same rules as suppliers' and customers' credits. Short-term foreign bank credit for the financing of imports is licensed (when there is no domestic credit restriction in force) if it is directly connected with a particular import transaction; for long-term financing, importers are referred to the domestic credit market. Sales to nonresidents, including central banks, of Nether- lands treasury paper and bank acceptances denominated in guilders are prohibited. 328 Most lending by nonbank residents to nonresidents (whether affiliated companies or others) is liberally per- mitted on application. Requested public issues on the domestic capital market on behalf of nonresidents are scheduled, and if necessary limited, by the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the market's capacity to absorb issues. In the debt certificate sector of the capital mar- ket (the market for onderhandse leningen), nonresi- dents are allowed to take up loans from institutional investors. Nonbank residents are not normally allowed to purchase foreign treasury bills or other foreign short- term negotiable instruments. Outward direct investment by residents is authorized on application. The inward or outward transfer of proceeds f rom the sale or liquidation of direct investments is free under general license. Repayment of licensed loans may be made or received freely, provided that any relevant stipulations in the license are complied with. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in all stocks and bonds listed on the Amsterdam stock exchange take place at official market exchange rates and are unrestricted. Residents may freely purchase officially listed securities abroad. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in unlisted stocks are gov- erned by the rules applicable to direct investment and require a special license. Residents are not allowed to purchase unlisted fixed-interest securities (such as notes) on the Euro-market if issued by nonresidents. Nonbank residents are licensed to issue bonds and notes abroad only if the proceeds are not brought into the Nether- lands (see above). The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by nonresidents (except Rhodesians) are transferab le in any currency, irrespective of the seller's coun try of domicile or residence. Nonresidents may have their securities, domestic or foreign, exported to them; for the exportation of listed guilder bonds, residents need a license, which is granted upon applica- tion. Domestic and foreign securities held abroad by a resident are subject to a deposit requirement, but the Netherlands Bank grants exemptions on application; securities held in the Netherlands are not subject to deposit. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment, and resi- dents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Mortgage loans between residents and nonresidents in connection with these real estate transactions are mostly free under general license or licensed on application. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free.7 Emi- grants may export any amount in foreign and domestic currency. They acquire the status of nonresidents upon leaving the Netherlands, provided that they have declared their intention to settle abroad for more than three years, and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. Nonresidents 7 Charitable g i f ts and donations for religious purposes are included in the Netherlands definition of current payments. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution inheriting from estates in the Netherlands may have the proceeds transferred to them freely. The curtailment of external borrowing is also applied to the authorized banks. Any net foreign indebtedness on their part is restricted by the "five million regula- tion," which prescribes that the total of each bank's spot foreign liabilities (regardless of denomination or te rm) must not at any time exceed its total spot foreign assets by more than f. 5 million. Banks are required to report to the Netherlands Bank twice a month the totals of their spot assets and liabilities, broken down into guilders and all foreign currencies combined. In addi- tion, banks must maintain a balanced total position (i.e., spot plus forward position) in each foreign cur- rency. They are required to report their spot position, as well as their forward position with residents and nonresidents, respectively, in each foreign currency at the end of each month; for deutsche mark, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars, the same data must also be reported at mid-month. Moreover, copies of all forward exchange contracts with nonresidents are forwarded to the Netherlands Bank. Banks are free, under general licenses, in their lending to foreign banks and, for maturities up to one year, to foreign nonbanks. Longer-term lending is usually permitted on request. Up to December 31, 1975, banks were prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits, from keeping guilder time deposits on their books in the names of nonresidents (w i th minor exemp- tions for physical persons), and from borrowing guilders abroad (see footnote 4). Otherwise, their freedom to accept deposits from nonresidents and to borrow abroad was not restricted, provided the limit set by the "five million regulation" was observed. All capital transfers in excess of f. 3,000 by nonbank residents, whether permitted under general license or specific license, must be notified to the Balance of Pay- ments Department of the Netherlands Bank. This includes suppliers' credits granted or received for peri- ods in excess of one year; prepayments exceeding f. 250,000 received for exports must be reported as such. Totals of security transactions must be reported periodically by securities brokers and authorized banks or by the resident parties concerned (if transactions take place through a foreign bank account). Authorized banks must report their own investments and loans; the resulting totals of foreign exchange dealings and deposit transactions are reported periodically. Gold Certain prewar gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. The Netherlands Bank engages in gold trans- actions only with monetary authorities and international financial institutions. Neither the Bank nor any gov- ernment agency imports or markets gold for industrial use. Authorized banks and other residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold ( f ine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad; gold held NETHERLANDS abroad, however, must be kept on deposit with the for- eign correspondent of an authorized depository. Imports and exports of gold require neither exchange licenses nor import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coins, if legal tender in the country of issue, are free of value- added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value-added tax at 4 per cent. The value-added tax on medallions and commemorative coins is 16 per cent; sales of gold bars and nuggets are exempt. Commercial imports of gold jewelry and of articles containing minor quantities of gold, such as watches, require import licenses only when originating in Hong Kong, Japan, or state trading countries. Changes during 1975 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative import regulations were made in accordance with EEC decisions and directives; most of these related to textiles, beef and veal, or electronic calculators. January 1. Banks were permitted to pay interest on guilder demand accounts held by nonresident banks, where these accounts served to provide required cover for documentary credits. January 2. The amount of payments to, or receipts f rom, nonresidents for which nonbank residents have to submit an exchange control fo rm was increased from f. 1,000 to f. 3,000. January 20. The coverage of the export financing arrangement between the Netherlands Bank and the authorized banks for credits with a maturity of at least five years was increased f rom f. 800 million to f. 1 bil- lion. On May 15 the ceiling was raised to f. 1,250 million and on September 1 to f. 1.5 billion. On Decem- ber 30, the Netherlands Bank informed the banks that f rom Janua ry 2, 1976, total commitments would be allowed to exceed the ceiling by 45 per cent, rather than the previous 25 per cent; on April 1, 1976 the permitted excess would rise to 65 per cent, and on September 1, 1976 to 80 per cent. April 24. In view of the substantial private place- ments of Euro-guilder notes in the first four months of 1975, the ceiling for the year as a whole was raised by 50 per cent to f. 1,350 million. The number of place- ments, which had been at a rate of one a week during 1974 and the early months of 1975, was restricted to one a month. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.471230 gram of fine gold per Netherlands Antilles Guilder.1 The gold content of the currency has been established at 0.411543 gram of fine gold. The central rate is Ant. f. 1.7900 per US$1, and the Netherlands Antilles avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. Exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at Ant. f. 1.79 buying, and Ant. f. 1.81 selling, per US$1, plus a tax of %o of 1 per cent on sales of exchange, making the effective selling rate for the U.S. dollar Ant. f. 1.8245 per US$1.2 The official buying and selling rates for certain other curren- cies are set daily on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar abroad. The Bank of the Netherlands Antilles (the central bank) deals with commercial banks at interbank rates. It does not normally deal with the public. Commercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances.3 Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Depart- ment of Economic Affairs. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign exchange for most current transactions without prior approval. The central bank may grant an exemption from the obligation of surrendering foreign exchange, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were acquired from nonresidents and are not being held in favor of, or on behalf of, or for the account of, third parties who are residents; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until fur ther notice or until revocation by the central bank. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. For statistical purposes, all payments made by residents through the authorized banks in foreign exchange as well as all receipts through the authorized banks, must be reported to the central bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open nonresident accounts in any foreign currency. Nonresidents (including for- eign investment fund s, etc., with nonresident status) are 1 In the islands of Saba, St. Eustatius, and St. Maarten, the Nether- lands Antilles guilder and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. 2 Foreign exchange purchased by resident companies with nonresi- dent status for exchange control purposes is exempt from the ex- change tax. 3 All currencies other than the Netherlands Antilles guilder are con- sidered foreign currencies. permitted to hold nonresident accounts in Netherlands Antilles guilders only if the authorized bank concerned considers that they have certain interests in the Nether- lands Antilles which render such an account desirable; balances in such accounts may not without central bank approval exceed Ant. f. 10,000. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain items, such as narcotics and explo- sives, are subject to license for public policy reasons. Imports into the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curacao of a number of commodities, including edible oils and certain domestic appliances, are subject to licensing by the Department of Economic Affairs, while commercial imports of passenger automobiles more than four years old are prohibited. Payments for permitted imports may be made freely. Companies with nonresident status normally finance their imports with their own foreign exchange. Certain commodities are subject to import surcharges in Aruba, Bonaire, and Curasao. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Licenses are required ma in ly for the purchase of travel exchange in excess of Ant. f. 180 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal remittances in excess of Ant. f. 5,000 each or in excess of Ant. f. 25,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no illegal capital transfer seems to be involved. Nonresidents may take with them on departure any foreign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to Ant. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which are usually granted. Exchange proceeds must be surrendered to an authorized bank within six months of shipment, with the exception of export proceeds received by companies with nonresi- dent status. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles (except those of firms with nonresident status) must in prin- ciple be surrendered to an authorized bank within eight days of receipt, but in practice the public is allowed to hold foreign banknotes and coins, since the domestic currency and the U.S. dollar circulate concurrently. Travelers may bring with them checks, travelers checks, or banknotes in foreign currency in unlimited amounts. Each traveler may also bring in Ant. f. 200 in Nether- lands Antilles banknotes. 331 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES Capital Foreign investment in the Netherlands Antilles requires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Investment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for duty-free entry of many commodities as well as tax facilities. New industrial companies primar- ily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the com- pany concerned exemption f rom exchange control (except in its transactions with residents), including exemption from the requirement of surrendering their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to investment companies, patent holding com- panies, shipping companies, and insurance companies. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance con- tracts between residents and foreign insurance com- panies for a m in imum term of ten years are licensed free ly up to an amount which is fixed annua l ly, depend- ing on the foreign exchange position, but outward trans- fers of capital by life insurance companies are not restricted. Investment by residents in real estate situ- ated abroad requires a license. Investment in officially listed foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally pay- able in the currency of a country other than the Nether- lands Antilles) is freely allowed by a general permission; purchases of mutual fund shares are prohibited. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign currency abroad f rom nonresidents ( inc lud ing residents with nonresident s ta tus), or accept foreign currency deposits from nonresidents, for relending to nonresidents or rede- posit abroad; their borrowing from nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Nether- lands Antilles guilders. Local borrowing in domestic currency by nonresidents (including resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold* Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Netherlands Antilles for num isma t ic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and autho- rized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Changes during 1975 April 1. Exchange Control Notice 75/1 of the same date came into effect. It liberalized residents' purchases of foreign securities. It contained a general permission allowing residents to acquire, dispose of, borrow against, and sell or donate foreign securities, provided that these are listed on a stock exchange, that they have been or will be deposited abroad in the name of an authorized bank, and that payment at the current stock exchange price is made or received through an authorized bank. All other capital transactions required a prior individual license; such licenses normally were granted on applica- tion, provided the transaction was considered to be in the interest of the Netherlands Antilles. April 1. Exchange Control Notice 75/2 of the same date came in to effect. It contained a general permission allowing residents (1) to enter into contracts with nonresidents f rom which receipts in respect of current transactions were to accrue; and (2) to receive the corresponding payments through an authorized bank. The Notice also defined current payments for this pur- pose; they included charitable donations and payments relating to l i fe insurance contracts. Licenses for current transactions not covered by this Notice were granted on application. June 1. In Aruba, Bonaire, and Curasao imports of edible oils became subject to license. Licenses would be limited in 1975 to 110 per cent of the volume imported by the applicant in 1974. June 16. Exchange Control Notice 75/3 of June 13 came into effect. It contained a general permission allowing residents (1) to enter into contracts with nonresidents from which payments obligations for the resident party would result up to the equivalent of Ant. f. 5,000 per payment, subject to a max imum of An t. f. 25,000 a resident a year; and (2) to make the corresponding payments through an authorized bank. The Notice also defined current transactions for this purpose; the definition was narrower than that in Notice 75 /2 but it included charitable donations and payments relating to life insurance contracts. Licenses for current transactions not covered by the new Notice were granted on application. July 1. Exchange Control Notice 75/4 contained a general permission allowing resident physical persons to hold a foreign currency account abroad, provided that the balance did not exceed the equivalent of Ant. f. 10,000, that funds remitted for credit from the Netherlands Antilles did not exceed Ant. f. 5,000 a quarter, and that the account was used exclusively for private expenditures. Such accounts could not be over- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES drawn and remittances had to be effected through an authorized bank. Licenses to exceed the limits men- tioned were granted on application. August 11. Not for Redistribution NEW ZEALAND (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.99531 gram of fine gold per New Zealand Dollar, corresponding to $NZ 0.892857 = SDR 1, and New Zealand avails itself of wider margins. Since July 9, 1973 no announced margins have been observed. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand adjusts the exchange rate for the U.S. dollar daily so as to maintain the effective relationship between the New Zealand dollar and the currencies of the main trading partners as at August 10, 1975. Except for the Aus- tralian dollar and the pound sterling, the rates for spot transactions in currencies quoted by the New Zealand trading (commercial) banks are based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. The rate for the pound sterling is derived by crossing the U.S./London rate quoted in New York with the New Zealand/U.S. rate. The outer limits for the banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on Decem- ber 31, 1975 were US$1.0437 and US$1.0387, respec- tively, per $NZ 1. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts for up to 6 months to cover import transactions and for up to 12 months to cover export transactions. Forward trans- actions in Canadian dollars and pounds sterling take place at rates of exchange determined daily by the Reserve Bank and based on the closing buy ing and sell- ing forward quotations of the previous day in London. Forward exchange contracts written in U.S. dollars are concluded at the relative spot rates, adjusted in the case of contracts covering imports with a loading of US$0.0050 a month on the spot rate. The Reserve Bank provides a fac i l i ty whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, spot and forward. Contracts in other currencies may be covered through the London or New York foreign exchange markets, against sterling or U.S. dollars. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand. The Reserve Bank has given discre- tionary authority to the trading banks in New Zealand to approve applications for certain remittances of funds overseas. The Overseas Investment Commission ad- ministers the regulations governing foreign direct invest- ment in New Zealand. Export and import licensing is the responsibility of the Customs Department and the Department of Trade and Industry, respectively. Prescription of Currency New Zealand has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- 334 tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Payments to and from residents of countries other than New Zealand may generally be made or received in any foreign currency.1 Payment to and from the accounts in New Zealand currency held with banks in New Zealand by banks not domiciled in New Zealand or Rhodesia also is a generally acceptable form of pay- ment. Nonresident Accounts The Reserve Bank supervises certain specified accounts in New Zealand of residents of other coun- tries ("controlled accounts"). The accounts in New Zealand dollars of overseas banks may be used for the settlement of transactions w i th other countries, but they may only be funded f rom overseas or by amounts which would otherwise be remittable from New Zealand. Imports and Import Payments 2 Imports are controlled through an annual Import Licensing Schedule, which groups imports into different categories to which various import procedures are applied. On a value basis, about 70 per cent of all private imports are exempt f rom licensing. The import categories included in the Schedule for July 1, 1975- June 30, 1976 are as follows: Category "E" (exempt) includes petroleum, lubr ica t ing oils, certain other raw materials, green coffee, cocoa beans, ju te, many textiles, specified spor t ing goods, tires, and printed books which may be imported w i thout license. In addition, certain imports of Aus tra l ian origin are exempt f rom licensing, irrespective of the licensing category to which they belong.3 A "Basic" category comprises items for which licenses are granted by reference to qua l i fy ing licenses issued or actual imports in a previous licensing period. Category "C" licenses are granted on an individual basis on such criteria as essentiality, availability, and price; for some "C" items, however, an initial allocation based on a previous period is provided, while applica- tions for fu r ther licenses are considered individually. "Administrative basic licenses" are issued automatically to ensure continuity of importation for certain regularly required goods that correspond to only part of an item code. Imports of completely knocked-down automo- biles are subject to special arrangements. In order to assure continuity of imports of specific items (mainly raw materials and consumer goods) in the 1974/75 program, the Government undertook that over a three- year period importers would receive licenses at least 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than New Zealand currency. 2 On February 2, 1976, the import of a selected list of goods, mainly consumer goods and representing about 7 per cent of imports, became subject to a deposit of 33Vs per cent of the customs value. 3 Under the terms of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agree- ment that came into force on Janua ry 1, 1966. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution equal in value to the basic allocation for 1974/75; existing commitments are honored but the scheme will be allowed to lapse at the end of the initial three-year period. All licenses issued may be used for imports from any source at the applicant's discretion, except Rhodesia. Imports from Rhodesia require the consent of the Minister of Foreign Affairs. A degree of flexibility in the application of the Licensing Schedule is achieved through the use of Group Schemes ( for Industry and Interchangeability Groups) that enable importers to transfer individual entitlements to a composite license, instead of holding licenses for separate items, and to import, up to the total amoun t, any item or combina- tion of items in the group. "No-remittance licenses" for imports outside the Im- port Licensing Schedule may be issued in special cir- cumstances, viz., for advertising material supplied free of charge; g i f ts, passengers' baggage, replacement of faulty or damaged goods; trade samples supplied free of charge; and temporary imports. The trading banks have authority to make foreign exchange in an appropriate currency available for pay- ments in respect of all licensed imports and all imports that do not require a license. Payments for Invisibles The trading banks are permitted to sell exchange for overseas payments up to established limits for many categories of invisibles, subject in appropriate cases to the submission of ju s t i fy ing documents. Payments be- yond the established limits, and for categories not included in the commercial banks' permitted list, require the specific approval of the Reserve Bank; applications must be supported, where appropriate, by ju s t i fy ing documents. Banks are authorized to sell foreign ex- change for genuine foreign travel purposes without prior reference to the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 1,000 a person a mon th or part thereof, with a max imum of $NZ 4,000 a person in any 12-month period. Requests for amounts in excess of $NZ 1,000 a month or for a total of more than $NZ 4,000 in any 12-month period must be re- ferred to the Reserve Bank. Larger amoun ts of ex- change for any type of travel are authorized at the discretion of the Reserve Bank, which meets all reason- able requests for genuine travel purposes. In addition to the above allocations, banks in New Zealand and their branches or agents in London and Australia may sell foreign currencies, w i thout limit as to amount, to New Zealand travelers against these persons' privately held foreign funds. The remittance abroad of dividends, interest, and profits due to nonresidents is approved, subject to formal authentication; for dividends and interest, the approval authority up to $NZ 1,500 in any 12-month period to any one remittee has been delegated to the authorized banks. Most contractual obligations incurred in the NEW ZEALAND ordinary course of business also are norma l ly approved, but each remittance requires approval and new com- mitments such as royalty agreements with overseas licensors or overseas borrowing require the prior con- sent of the Reserve Bank. Allocations for remittances on account of mainte- nance and /or gifts are made on a yearly basis without discrimination. Remittances by recognized New Zea- land religious and charitable organizations or individu- als operating as members of such an organization are not subject to any l im i ta t ion. Allocations to individuals for religious and charitable remittances, other than of the type specified above, are approved by the Reserve Bank up to $NZ 500 a remitter, and applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits. Any resident may freely make personal remittances up to a total of $NZ 100 a year to any destination overseas except Rhodesia, for any purpose except gambling or bu i ld ing up assets in the remitter's name, provided that no individual remittance exceeds $NZ 20. Travelers may take w i th them up to $NZ 50 in New Zealand currency, regardless of destination. Banknotes taken out may not be in denominations larger than $NZ 5. Up to $NZ 4 of the permitted total may be in coins. Exports and Export Proceeds With m inor exceptions, all exports require export li- censes. These are issued by the Customs Department and carry the condition that the net export proceeds must be surrendered to a trad ing bank in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations. General export licenses valid un t il December 31, 1976 are issued to regular exporters. Payments for exports must, unless prior consent is obtained, be received w i th in six months f rom the date of shipment. Exports to Rhodesia require the consent of the Minister of Foreign Affa irs. Certain items classified as strategic goods may only be exported when particular requirements have been met and sub- sequent to the issue of a permit to export. Temporary restrictions have been imposed on exports of tallow and specified types of mutton and on exports and re-exports of sugar. Exports of beef and veal to the United States and cheddar-type cheese to the United Kingdom are subject to annual quan t i ta t ive res tra in t. Under an export bonus scheme, manu fac tu re rs sub- mitting evidence of exportation may receive a replace- ment import license of the same value as the imported raw material or components still subject to import con- trol that are incorporated in the exported goods, as well as, subject to certain conditions being met, an additional bonus license; goods imported against the bonus license may be used for the manufac ture of goods for the home market or for export. Proceeds from Invisibles When remuneration for services provided or to be provided in New Zealand for overseas residents by New Zealand residents ( inc lud ing corporate bodies ordinarily resident in New Zea land) is paid in the fo rm of foreign assets,4 their foreign currency proceeds must be sold to the New Zealand bank ing system; interest and dividends earned overseas f rom portfolio inves tment are excluded from this surrender requirement. If the remuneration is in a form other than a foreign currency or a balance w i th an overseas bank, it must be converted in to for- eign currency before the surrender takes place. The disposal overseas by New Zealand residents of fore ign income from other invisibles such as interest and dividends is permitted, but such income is not eligible for sale in exchange for New Zealand currency, except that the foreign currency proceeds may be sold to a New Zealand bank. Travelers may br ing into the coun try un l im i ted amounts of foreign and domestic banknotes and coins, provided that any New Zealand banknotes brought in are in denominations not exceeding $NZ 5. Capital With the exception of certain capital issues outside New Zealand and certain overseas borrowings by cor- porate bodies, consents are not required in respect of capital receipts. Applications for consent to borrow abroad by companies operating in the property sector are not normally approved, unless the project involved is consistent w i th the Government's housing policy. While overseas borrowing by f inanc ial ins t i tu t ions is controlled, consents are usually granted where the funds are required for industrial development purposes. To be eligible for repatriation, capital must have been initially transferred to New Zealand through normal bank ing channels or in some other way approved by the authori- ties, e.g., as imports of plant or machinery. Capital so transferred, including capital gains and capitalized prof- its, may be repatriated, af ter the fo rmal approval of the Reserve Bank has been obtained. In the case of overseas borrowing, repayments are not permitted un t il the ex- piry of the term for which the funds were borrowed and in any case not within 12 months of the receipt of the proceeds. Overseas companies seeking to commence business in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission, under the terms of the Overseas Investment Regulations, 1974. *The kinds of remuneration that are involved are (1) the payment or provision of any money; (2) the crediting of any sum in any account at any bank or with any person; (3) the acquisition or provi- sion of any securities, or any real or personal proper ty, or of any right thereto or interest therein (whether actual or con t ing en t ); and (4) any benefit, whether by way of doing work or the pe r fo rmance of services, or otherwise, under any contract agreemen t, scheme, or trans- action of any kind (whether or not it is enforceable or intended to be enforceable by legal proceedings). 336 Capital issues outside New Zealand by companies incorporated in New Zealand require the approval of the Overseas Investment Commission; overseas borrow- ing by such companies also requires prior approval. Forward exchange facilities are available to cover borrowings abroad by New Zealand companies in cases where the borrowings relate to specific approved projects which w i ll develop industries based on the extraction or processing of indigenous raw materials. Any such forward exchange cover would be for the amount of the capital sum only and is norma l ly limited to not less than $NZ 50,000 and not more than $NZ 1 million for each project. New Zealand subsidiaries and branches of overseas companies must obtain the consent of the Overseas In- vestment Commission if they wish to borrow in New Zealand, whether for long-term or short-term finance. Local borrowing by companies which are more than 75 per cent overseas owned is normally restricted to 10 per cent of the tu rnover in the previous financial year, w i th a special allowance in respect of any export turnover. Companies which are predominantly but less than 75 per cent overseas owned may borrow locally, in add i t ion, an amount in proportion to the level of the ir borrowing f rom overseas based on the ratio of New Zealand and overseas equity holdings. Nonresident per- sons or companies desiring to make a direct investment in a New Zealand company through the purchase or exchange of shares are required to give notice to, and seek the consent of, the Overseas Investment Commis- sion in respect of any proposed offer for such shares whenever the inves tment would result in the control by the offerer of 25 per cent or more of the New Zealand company's voting capital. Emigrants to any destination other than Rhodesia may upon designation as nonresidents t rans fer the whole of their assets to their new coun try of residence. App l ica t ions for the remittance abroad of legacies from the estate of a New Zealand resident are normally approved in fu l l. The au thor i t ies do not norma l ly make exchange avail- able to private persons or firms for the purchase of overseas securities for portfolio investment. New Zea- land Government bonds purchased overseas by New Zea- land residents a f ter September 5, 1969 may not be t rans fe r red f rom the United Kingdom to the New Zea- land register. A New Zealand resident owning overseas securities is free to sell them to overseas residents for any foreign currency, which may be reinvested in other overseas securities, surrendered, or retained at the dis- posal of the New Zealand resident. With limited excep- tions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resident to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any overseas currency. The only overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in exchange for New Zealand currency are those of any overseas country which were ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents evidencing title were issued; the purchaser must lodge the share scrip w i th an approved depository (i.e., the Reserve Bank of New Zea land ). These securities may also be sold for any overseas currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the bank ing system or reinvested in other overseas securities within three months and the resulting scrip deposited. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in New Zealand for num isma t ic purposes. Since the revocation in 1954 of the Gold Acquisition Notice, 1948, it is no longer necessary to offer gold to the Reserve Bank, and sales w i th in New Zealand do not require Reserve Bank approval. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry cons t i tu t ing the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Customs Depart- ment; such licenses are not no rma l ly granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and indus t r ial users. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are licensed restrictively, but the importa- tion of gold coins is exempt from license. Changes during 1975 January 24. The 1975/76 Import Licensing Schedule was issued, to become effective on July 1. The schedule generally provided for a basic allocation equivalent to 100 per cent of the value of the 1974/75 basic licenses. This percentage was not applied uniformly to all imports subject to license, the percentage allocation being 75 per cent of the value of 1974/75 licenses for tires and tubes, Manchester goods, grinding wheels, glassware, and cer- tain toys and ceramic articles; and 50 per cent for com- pletely built-up vehicles. In addition, a number of items previously covered by basic allocations were shifted to the "C" category; they included barley and rice flour, wines, certain textile fabrics, and cutlery. Some 70 per cent of imports would be exempt from license, as previously. The replacement scheme for completely knocked-down automobiles would continue unchanged; built-up licenses to assemblers would be restricted to NEW ZEALAND 3 per cent of the value of the basic license issued for completely knocked-down packs f rom July 1, 1974 to March 31, 1975. No additional items were listed in the exempt category. Licenses issued under the three-year license assurance scheme would be honored but it was not intended to add to the scheme or to extend the assurance beyond the initial three-year period. April 4. Not for Redistribution NICARAGUA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.105237 gram of fine gold per Nicaraguan Cordoba. The parity for the U.S. dollar is C$7.00 = US$1. The Central Bank of Nicaragua deals with the commercial banks in U.S. dollars, the inter- vention currency, at C$7.00 per US$1, buying and sell- ing, and sells exchange to the Government at C$7.0525 per US$1. All exchange transactions between commer- cial banks and the public take place at the official rates of C$7.00 buying, and C$7.0525 selling, per US$1. Nicaragua accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from July 20, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank, which by law has the sole authority to buy and sell foreign exchange. This authority has been delegated to the commercial banks, and the Central Bank deals with the public only to the extent that it accepts deposits in foreign currency, and for purposes of monetary control. Certain agencies are also author- ized to buy and sell foreign exchange, but they may sell exchange only for payments for invisibles. The Central Bank is responsible for classifying imports and deter- mining any advance deposits required; no advance de- posit requirements are in force at present. Prescription of Currency There is no prescription of currency, but the customs authorities have the power to prohibit an export if the currency stipulated for payment is not readily convert- ible into U.S. dollars in international markets. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the Camara de Compen- sation Centroamericana, a clearinghouse established by the central banks of Central America to foster the process of economic integration of their countries. Pay- ments to Mexico may also be settled in Nicaraguan cordobas through the clearinghouse. The Central Bank does not accept banknotes of El Salvador for compen- sation through the clearinghouse in excess of 400,000 Salvadoran colones a month. Imports and Import Payments All importers are required to be registered. There are two categories of registered importers: those who are permitted to import any kind of merchandise and those who may import only for their own industrial needs. Imports from all countries, except the other Central American countries, must be consigned to persons or firms holding a commercial license from the Ministry of Economy. Import licenses are not required, but 338 import transactions must be registered with the Central Bank by means of import declarations. All imports on credit and all prepayments for imports require approval by the Central Bank, which is normally granted only for capital goods, industrial materials, and other essen- tial goods; when payment is not being made on sight of documents, an application for registration of the order must be submitted to the Central Bank. Imports of certain types of footwear and some pharmaceutical and veterinary supplies are prohibited, except when produced in countries signatory to the General Treaty for Central American Economic Integration. Payments for imports must be made with exchange purchased f rom banks.1 Payments are usually made by sight draf ts. Letters of credit are mostly confined to imports f rom Japan. Central Bank approval is not required to open an import letter of credit. The banks are not permitted to sell exchange for import payments in advance of the arrival of the documents. The Cen- tral Bank may authorize deferred payment or payment with funds derived from properly authenticated credits obtained abroad, provided that the imports are capital goods intended for development or production or for basic works complementary to production; such per- mission is at present limited mainly to industrial and agricultural machinery and, for certain industries, raw materials. Imports are not released f rom customs unless evidence is submitted either that payment has been made through a bank (constancia de pago) or that acceptance has been made through a bank (constancia de acepta- cion). In the latter case, the Central Bank must also approve the importation on credit terms; this require- ment does not apply to duty-free imports from member countries of the Central American Common Market. Most imports originating outside the Central Ameri- can Common Market are subject to an import surcharge of 30 per cent of the applicable import duty. Certain commodities are subject to a compensatory (selective) consumption tax irrespective of their origin. Further- more, most commodities are subject to a 6 per cent general sales tax, whether they are imported or domesti- cally produced. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not subject to license and may be made freely. Persons purchasing foreign cur- rency to make payments for invisibles are required, for statistical purposes, to complete a declaration specifying the purpose for which the foreign currency obtained will 1 However, by virtue of Decree No. 1-L (effective March 1, 1963) the exchange proceeds from bananas, coconuts, copra, and coconut by-products exported through the ports of the region of El Cabo and the department of Zelaya may be used by the exporters to pay for commodities not produced in Nicaragua which they themselves import for the exclusive use of or consumption by the inhabitants of those areas. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution be used. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be exported freely. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, but a declaration to the customs authorities must be completed for statistical purposes. The exchange proceeds of exports do not have to be surrendered; however, they may not be used to pay for imports (exchange for which must be pur- chased from a bank, with the exception stated in foot- note 1). For certain agricultural exports (live cattle, beans, rice, corn, and co t tonseed), the Ministry of Econ- omy can fix m in imum export prices or temporarily pro- hibit their export in order to avoid domestic shortages. Proceeds from Invisibles The surrender of foreign exchange derived from invisibles is not required. Domestic and foreign currency notes may be imported freely. Capital Remittances on account of foreign capital and capital transfers by residents and nonresidents may be made freely under the general provisions of the Exchange Law of March 1, 1963 or under the Law on Foreign Invest- ments of February 26, 1955 (effective March 11, 1955). Under the 1955 law, foreign investments approved by NICARAGUA the Central Bank and registered are guaranteed the following privileges, provided that the foreign currency is converted in the banking system: repatriation of the registered capital; transfer of earnings, profits, or interest on the capital; and re-exportation of goods imported for investment. Commercial banks and private investment companies require the prior approval of the Central Bank for all borrowing abroad. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nicaragua. Producers of gold sell their newly mined gold at free market prices to buyers abroad. The Central Bank purchases gold abroad for resale to domestic industrial and other users. Nonmonetary imports and exports of gold do not require import or export licenses but must be registered with the Central Bank and require prior government authori- zation. Commemorative gold coins were issued in 1967. Changes during 1975 May 17. Decree No. 148/MEIC prohibited the im- portation of iron rods from outside Central America for a period of 12 months. July 22. A law went into effect which created spe- cial incentives for investments to promote tourism and valued at over US$1 million. 339 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGER (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Niger has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc l which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, subject to a commission f rom which transactions for the account of the public Treasury and transactions in banknotes and travelers checks are exempt; the commission is Mo of 1 per mill for transfers to other countries of the West Afr ican Monetary Union and 2.50 per mill for transfers to countries outside the Union. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange market rate for the cur- rency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Niger's exchange control measures do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central Afr ican Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta ). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Niger itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle finan- cial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Office in the Ministry of Finance which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Niger, and inward and outward investment. The BCEAO is author- ized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Adm in is tra- tion, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through the BCEAO or authorized banks. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of External Trade in the Presidential Secretariat of State in charge of Economic A f fa i rs, Commerce, and Indus- 1The CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Ben in, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 340 try, subject to the visa of the External Finance Office in the Ministry of Finance, except those for gold, which are granted by the Ministry of Finance. Import certifi- cates for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself and, when imports are payable prior to importation, are first approved by the External Finance Office. Prescription of Currency Niger is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through cor- respondent banks in France in foreign currencies or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Certain settlements with Nigeria, however, are made through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in N iamey by authorized banks' foreign cor- respondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia or South Africa are prohibited. Imports of soap and certain printed cotton fabrics are prohibited irrespective of origin. The import from any source of rice, paddy, hulled rice, wheat flour, butane gas, many types of fabr ic, certain footwear, and certain plastic goods requires prior authorization, irrespective of whether an import license or import certificate is also required. A similar regime applies to imports of sugar, except from member countries of the Common Organization of Afri- can and Maur i t ian States, and to imports of matches, except from countries of the West A f r ican Customs Union. Imports f rom France and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area of all goods other than those mentioned above may be made freely without a license or certificate. Imports from other countries require either a license or an import certificate. Imports of virtually all goods f rom Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, and the six original member states ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of the EEC, many goods from other former OEEC countries and their past or present dependent territories, and a smaller number of items from the United States and Canada are liberalized and require only an import certificate. Imports of nonliberalized goods from non- EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are made under global quotas in accordance with an annual pro- gram that is determined each year by the Presidential Secretariat of State in charge of Economic Affa irs, Commerce, and Industry. Licenses for certain cotton fabrics are conditional upon purchases of the corre- sponding domestic product. Goods not subject to quan- titative restriction may be imported on an import cer- tificate, i.e., a declaration made out by the importer. The Societe Nationale de Commerce et de Production du Niger (COPRONIGER) has a monopoly over the import of specified commodities. These include wheat, wheat flour, green tea, and certain textiles. All import transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when valued at more than CFAF 25,000 c.i.f. Nigerien border. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, provided that the authorized bank is satisfied that the import transaction is genuine and in accordance with the import title. Import certificates require the visa of the External Finance Office if the goods are payable before importation. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to the approval of the External Finance Office, which for certain transactions has delegated its powers to the authorized banks. Pay- ments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, divi- dends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Residents travel- ing on tourist trips to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 100,000 a person a t r ip (CFAF 50,000 for chil- dren under t e n ), which may be taken up twice a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remain- ing af ter return to Niger must be surrendered within eight days by sale to an authorized bank. The t rans fer of salaries of foreigners wo rk ing in Niger is subject to prior approval by the External Finance Office and is normally limited to 50 per cent of net pay. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a max imum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, in addition to their travel allocation. Resident travelers to other countries NIGER of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes but, when traveling to a French Franc Area country outside the West African Monetary Union, must declare these if they exceed CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries, and foreign notes up to the amount declared upon entry,2 or, if no declaration was made, up to CFAF 25,000; they may also take out freely any amount of foreign currency travelers checks, etc., issued abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports of rice and paddy require the prior authorization of the Presidential Secretariat of State in charge of Economic A f fa i rs, Commerce, and Industry. Exports of millet and sorghum are prohibited unless covered by a shipping document in the name of the Office des Produits Vivriers du Niger (OPVN ). Gum arabic may be exported only by COPRONIGER. With the exception of peanuts, peanut oil, peanut cakes, sisal, cotton, cottonseed, and certain imported commodities, all of which require a license, all other exports to France (as defined above) and the Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely. Exports to all other countries of domestic products and imported commodities require a license and an exchange commitment. The due date of payments for exports to foreign countries must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their destination. The proceeds must be col- lected and, if the contract is denominated in a non- Franc Area currency, surrendered by sale on the exchange marke t, within two months after the due date. All export transactions with foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their total value exceeds CFAF 100,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due f rom residents of other coun- tries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries f rom foreign assets, must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or a bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold co ins). Residents must surrender 2 This amount is reduced, when appropriate, by the amount sold for CFA francs and increased by the amount of foreign notes acquired in Niger by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency account, by exchange for other foreign means of payment brought in, or by repurchase with CFA f rancs (such repurchase being limited to the equivalent of CFAF 25,000). 341 ©International Monetary Fund. Capital Capital movements between Niger and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts f rom such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are ma in ta ined over borrowing abroad, over inward and outward invest- ment, and over the issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Niger; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those over foreign securities in Niger, these control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West Afr ican Mone- tary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account. Special controls are ma in ta ined also over the soliciting of f u n d s, for deposit w i th fore ign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate bu i ld ing operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Niger require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.3 For- eign direct investments in Niger 4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the post- ponement of the projects submitted to h im. The fu ll or partial liquidation of investments, whether direct or not, also requires prior declaration. Both the mak ing and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Nigerien investments abroad or foreign investments in Niger, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO w i th in 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Niger requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, how- ever, are operations in connection with ( 1) loans backed 3 Inc lud ing those made through the in te rmed ia ry of fore ign com- panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Niger and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Niger. * Including those made by companies in Niger that are directly or ind irec t ly under foreign control and those made by branches or sub- sidiaries in Niger of fore ign companies. 342 by a guarantee from the Nigerien Government, and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issuing or offering for sale in Niger has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The fo l low ing are, however, exempt f rom this authorization: ( 1) loans cons t i tu t ing a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (3) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount out- s tand ing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 2 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual rate does not exceed the "nor- mal" market rate and that the proceeds of the loan are immediately sold on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of a for- eign borrow ing constituting a direct investment is sub- ject to the same formalities as the l iqu ida t ion of a direct investment; the repayment of other borrowings requires authorization only to the extent that the borrowing itself was subject to prior authorization. Lending abroad is subject to prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. Foreign investments in Niger may be granted certain guarantees and facilities under the Investment Code of July 31, 1968 (Law No. 68-24), as amended by Law No. 71-2 of January 29, 1971 and Law No. 74-18 of March 11, 1974. Existing benefits accorded under the previous Investment Code (Law No. 61-21 of July 12, 1961) have been ma in ta ined. The new Investment Code provides for privileged or regular trea tmen t. The latter provides assurances, for both new and existing enterprises, with respect to indemnities in the event of nationalization and con- cerning nondiscrimination between Nigerien nationals and foreign nationals; tax exemptions may be granted to new investments. Privileged treatment is reserved for enterprises deemed to be of special importance to national economic development and fa l l ing within speci- fied categories of industrial activities. Such treatment may be accorded under two d ifferent regimes, the approval regime and the agreement regime. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any fo rm in Niger. Imports and exports of gold f rom or to any other country require prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance, which is seldom granted. Exempt f rom this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and ( 3) articles of gold up to a combined weight of 500 grams when car- ried by a traveler. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. ©International Monetary Fund.
