Not for Redistribution NIGERIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The currency of Nigeria is the Naira. On April 17, 1963 an initial par value of 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Nigerian pound was established. On February 14, 1973 a central rate of 1.11973 grams of fine gold per naira was established, corresponding at the time to N 0.793648 = SDR 1 or N 0.657893 = US$1. Nigeria avails itself of wider margins and the intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. On April 1, 1974, however, Nigeria ceased to observe any specified margins. The Central Bank of Nigeria quotes daily rates at which it is prepared to deal in U.S. dollars and sterling with author- ized dealers and the public; such dealings are for approved transactions and are on a spot basis only. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar are set at VA of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate, and those for sterling are determined on the basis of the prevailing U.S. dollar rate and the previous day's U.S. dollar/ sterling middle rate quoted in London. The Central Bank does not normally publish rates for other foreign curren- cies.1 On December 31, 1975, the Central Bank's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.6020 and US$1.5940, respectively, per N 1, and its buying and selling rates for sterling were £ stg. 0.7789 and <£ stg. 0.7751, respectively, per N 1. For approved transactions authorized dealers may deal at market rates, spot or forward, between them- selves and with resident and nonresident customers. Authorized dealers may enter freely into contracts with residents of Nigeria for the purchase or sale of any for- eign currency except Rhodesian currency for delivery at a fu tu re date, provided that the transaction is one that would be acceptable on a spot basis and relates to a firm commercial contract for the import or export of goods or to freight charges on a specific shipment of goods, and is expressed as payable in a foreign currency. Forward contracts related to imports must not extend more than six months beyond the expiration date of the import license, or beyond the date of import when the license has no expiration date or when no license is required. Forward contracts related to exports may cover any necessary period, provided that payment for the goods is to be received within three months of ship- ment, or within such longer period as may have been authorized. Administration of Control The Federal Ministry of Finance is responsible for basic exchange control policy and, in principle, for 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the naira. Currencies designated as specified currencies are Aus t r ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish k rone r, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. 344 approving applications for the following: copyrights; the payment of shipping and marine insurance dues; the repatriation of capital and t rans fer of profits to any country outside N iger ia; the raising of external loans, including repayment of such loans; borrowing in Nigeria by companies controlled directly or indirectly from out- side Nigeria (other than local bank overdrafts to pay for impor ts); the granting of "approved status" to non- resident investments in Nigeria (other than investments in fishing, shipping, and insurance); and any dealings in foreign securities. The Central Bank of Nigeria is the principal administrator of exchange control. Most commercial banks and acceptance houses have been appointed as authorized dealers by the Ministry of Finance and thus are empowered to deal in foreign cur- rencies and to approve applications in accordance with instructions issued by the Central Bank. Any applica- tion that does not fall within the scope of the authority of these authorized dealers must be submitted to the Central Bank, or, for the transactions mentioned above, to the Ministry of Finance. Certain hotels and rest houses have also been appointed authorized buyers for the purchase of foreign currency and travelers checks f rom foreign visitors and Nigerians newly arrived in the country. All export proceeds and other proceeds in foreign cur- rencies (except the proceeds of oil exports) are cen- tralized w i th the Central Bank, which supplies the authorized banks with foreign exchange for approved payments. The Central Bank allocates foreign exchange da i ly to authorized dealers. Allocations are determined w i th in the framework of a foreign exchange budget, which, however, is essentially an indicative management tool rather than an allocation device. The administration of trade controls is carried out by the Federal Ministry of Trade and the Import Quota Allocation Committee, comprising officials of the Min- istries of Trade, Finance, Industry, and Economic Devel- opment, as well as representatives of the Central Bank and the customs administration. Import licenses for petroleum products, however, are issued by the Federal Commissioner of Mines and Power. Prescription of Currency Nigeria has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- l ing Area. Authorized payments to countries other than Rhodesia may be made in naira to an External Account in Nigeria or in any foreign currency. The proceeds of exports to foreign countries except Rhodesia may be received in naira f rom an External Account, in any foreign currency which is freely exchangeable for naira, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution or in any specified currency. However, settlements with Niger are channeled through special accounts. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia; most payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in naira of persons resident outside Nigeria are divided into three categories: External Accounts, Rhodesia Accounts, and Blocked Accounts. External Accounts, which are maintained for residents of all countries other than Rhodesia, may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Nigeria to residents of foreign countries other than Rhodesia, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with pro- ceeds from sales of foreign currencies other than Rho- desian currency. They may be debited for payments to residents of Nigeria, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency. Rhodesia Accounts are maintained for residents of Rhodesia and have been blocked since July 3, 1969. Blocked Accounts are accounts to which are credited funds that are blocked by directives given under Sec- tion 27 of the Exchange Control Act. Imports and Import Payments Importers must be registered if they wish to obtain individual import licenses. All imports from Namibia (South West A f r ica ), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, and the import from any country of certain specified commodities is banned, mostly for health, safety, moral, or religious reasons; the import of a few other commodities is also prohibited unless specific con- ditions have been complied with that are specified in the license authorizing such imports. Individual import licenses are required for a small number of items from all sources, including raw or manu fac tu red tobacco, cer- tain types of paper, and passenger automobiles w i th an engine capacity under 2,000 cubic centimeters. Imports which are neither prohibited nor subject to specific licensing may be imported under open general license from any country other than Namibia (South West A f r ica ), Rhodesia, or South Afr ica. Some imports are effected by an autonomous public agency, the Nigeria National Supply Company Ltd. Authorized dealers may grant foreign exchange for authorized imports at sight of shipping documents or in accordance with such credit terms as may be arranged between importer and exporter (subject to the approval of the Central Bank for the private sector or the Minis- try of Finance for the public sector). Payment in advance of shipment requires the approval of the Cen- tral Bank, except where prepayment is made against a letter of credit. For sight transactions, the importer must present the customs bill of entry within 90 days after the allocation of foreign exchange. NIGERIA Payments for Invisibles Most payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to residents of other countries are subject to individual approval; for some categories of invisibles this is granted by authorized dealers, either up to specified limits or up to the amount of the bill or invoice. Appli- cations for payments that cannot be approved by author- ized dealers and are not among those (such as profits and dividends) 2 that require approval by the Ministry of Finance are forwarded to the Central Bank for deci- sion. All insurance other than that for which facilities do not exist in Nigeria must be taken out with a com- pany in Nigeria and all insurance companies operating in the country must reinsure with the National Insur- ance Corporation. Residents are entitled to a basic tourist travel allow- ance of N 1,000 a person a year (N 500 a year for children under 1 2 ). Foreign exchange for this purpose may be sold to residents by authorized dealers. In addi- tion, travel agents and shipping and airline companies in Nigeria may sell transportation tickets for any destina- t ion, except Rhodesia, against payment in Nigerian cur- rency. The cost of services rendered by travel agents in respect of hotel accommodation, meals en route, etc., must be covered f rom the basic travel allowance. There is a separate travel allowance for pilgrimages, which for 1975 was the same as the tourist allocation but could not be combined w i th it. Business travel allowances are l im i ted to N 80 a day, up to 30 days a trip, for any number of trips. Allocations also are available for medi- cal care and study abroad; foreign exchange is granted for all bona fide educational expenses. Exchange appli- cations for most non tour ist travel must be submitted to the Central Bank. Foreign nationals residing in Nigeria may purchase annua l ly foreign currency up to 50 per cent of their gross annual taxable income for all personal remittances for any purpose (including insurance, educa- tion, medical expenses, provident fund contributions, sundry payments, and the basic travel allowance); appli- cations in excess of this limit are examined on their merits by the Central Bank. When taking overseas leave, they may also convert up to three months' leave pay into foreign exchange. Residents are permitted to take out the equivalent of their basic travel allowance in foreign currency notes and travelers checks; nonresident visitors may take out any foreign currency notes and travelers checks that were declared upon entry, minus the amount converted locally into Nigerian currency. Travelers may take out N 20 a New profits and dividends may be remitted as soon as they are declared. Remittances of technical fees, management fees, and royalties are permitted where it can be shown that these are related to the import of modern technology. Payments for technical and management fees requ i re approval by the Ministry of Finance. A fixed fee is nor- mally pe rm i t ted for the first five years a f t er the establishment of a new company, and thereafter a percentage of gross profit not exceeding 5 per cent. Each application is treated on its merits w i th in these broad guidelines. Similar policies are applicable to other service paymen ts, such as those relating to copyrights and trademarks. 345 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NIGERIA in domestic notes and coins; all other export of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most locally pro- duced goods may be exported freely, under open general license, to any country except South A f r ica and Namibia (South West A f r i c a ), exports to which require individual licenses. Individual export licenses are required for cigarettes and tobacco, columbite, tin and by-products of tin, tantalite, unrefined gold, petroleum products, goods made wholly or partly of imported components, and products subject to control by Marketing Boards (mainly cocoa, cotton, cottonseed, benniseed, ground- nuts, groundnut oil, palm oil, and palm ke rne ls ) .3 The selling abroad of all export crops purchased by the Mar- keting Boards is the responsibility of the Nigerian Pro- duce Marketing Company. The export of certain goods (A f r ican antiquities or works of art and objects that are being used or have been used in A f r ican ceremonies) is prohibited, except under prescribed conditions. The export of explosives, other than industrial explosives, and of certain foodstuffs is prohibited, and exports of cattle and groundnuts have been suspended. Exports of petroleum and petroleum products are subject to special arrangements. Export proceeds must be surrendered, through a com- mercial bank, to the Central Bank within three months of shipment. Exports of petroleum and petroleum prod- ucts, however, are exempt f rom the surrender require- ments. For all exports, the exporter is required to sub- mit an exchange control declaration at the time of shipment. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer, who is required to surrender them to the Central Bank. Persons entering Nigeria may freely br ing in foreign banknotes. Travelers may br ing in N 20 in domestic currency; all other import of Nigerian currency notes and coins is prohibited. Capital Except for the purpose of financing imports or exports, permission from the Ministry of Finance is required for any individual, firm, company, or branch resident in Nigeria to borrow abroad. In addition, offi- cial agencies and state-controlled corporations require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for any foreign borrowing. The taking up of suppliers' credit abroad also is subject to approval by the Ministry of Finance. The permission of the Ministry of Finance is also required for borrowing in Nigeria (1) by any non- resident individual or company, and (2) by any com- pany registered in Nigeria (other than a b ank) which is 3 On February 4, 1976 exports of timber and of edible g roundnut oil and palm oil were suspended. 346 controlled directly or indirectly from outside Nigeria. However, to enable entities mentioned under (2) to meet temporary shortages of funds, licensed banks in Nigeria may grant loans or overdrafts for periods not exceeding 14 days, or may increase the amount of any advance or overdraft by the amount of loan interest or bank charges payable thereon. General permission is also given for any loan, bank overdraft, or other credit facil- ity to be arranged to finance Nigerian imports or exports of goods. Banks have been directed to allocate 40 per cent of their total loans and advances to Nigerian per- sons and firms. Residents of Nigeria may not deal in foreign currency securities nor may they buy from or sell to nonresidents of Nigeria any security payable in Nigerian pounds or naira without the permission of the Ministry of Finance. The capital proceeds of securities registered in Nigeria and owned by nonresidents may be collected and negoti- ated through authorized dealers, provided that the prior permission of the Ministry of Finance is obtained. Remittances of cash gifts to nonresidents normally are restricted to the equivalent in any one fiscal year of N 1,000 for each transferor in favor of charitable orga- nizations outside Nigeria, and of N 300 per transferor for gifts to individuals. Exchange for the transfer of certain assets by emigrants or repatriates is granted on final depar ture f rom the country, but the transfer of the proceeds of assets realized in order to comply with the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972 may take place upon receipt. Nonresidents in tend ing to make direct investments in Nigeria are invited to apply to the Ministry of Finance for "approved status," the granting of which means that sympathetic consideration will be given to fu ture requests to repatriate the capital. The granting of "approved status" is not applicable to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange in Nigeria unless this fo rms an integral part of the approved investment project. Furthermore, this status is not normally granted when internally gener- ated funds from profits, dividends, rents, or locally raised loans or bank credit are invested in local enter- prises. With m inor exceptions, foreign-owned compa- nies and commercial banks operating in Nigeria must be incorporated in Nigeria. The repatriation of foreign capital requires approval f rom the Ministry of Finance. Gold With the express permission of the Federal Commis- sioner for Finance, residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Nigeria for numismatic purposes. Residents other than the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized industrial users are not allowed with- out special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require specific licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution monetary authorities, producers of gold, and industrial users. Furthermore, the import of gold coins current in the United Kingdom requires a license from the Com- missioner of Customs and Excise, and the import of other gold coins requires a specific import license. Imports of gold coins and of gold and silver bullion are free of duty when made by the Central Bank for mone- tary purposes; otherwise, such imports are subject to customs duty at 100 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1975 March 21. The issue of negotiable and nonnegotiable certificates of deposit was permitted; they could only be denominated in naira. The first issue took place in September. April 1. It was announced that the Federal Govern- ment had authorized a foreign exchange budget for 1975/76 involving an inflow of about N 6.48 billion and a foreign exchange outflow of about N 5 billion. April 1. The requirement that a customs bill of entry be presented before foreign exchange could be allocated for imports was eliminated. Imports could again be made on sight terms, either under letter of credit or on a collection basis. April 1. The compulsory credit terms for imports of capital goods and equipment valued at more than N 100,000 were abolished. April 1. Commercial banks were authorized to keep working balances abroad to facilitate payments for imports under documentary letters of credit. April 1. Stockfish was removed from the list of imports subject to license, but passenger automobiles with an engine capacity under 2,000 cubic centimeters were added to the list. Import licenses for small cars would be allocated so as to ensure that 60 per cent of all cars under 2,000 cubic centimeters sold in Nigeria (imported or domestically produced) would be of two specified makes. The import ban on corned beef, edible nuts, margarine, imitation lard, other edible fats, and waste material from textile fabrics was lifted. April 1. Substantial tariff reductions were introduced, including reductions of 10 per cent in duties on food items, 5 to 40 per cent for other imported consumer goods, and almost 70 per cent for building materials in short supply. Relief from import duty was granted for the soap, detergent, confectionery, and candle industries, and excise duties were abolished for a wide range of goods. April 1. The basic travel allowance was increased from N 400 to N 1,000 a person a year, and the daily business travel allowance was raised from N 40 to N 80 a day for up to 30 days a trip, for any number of trips a year. NIGERIA April 1. The separate, lower travel allowance for travel w i th in Africa was abolished; the new tourist travel allowance became applicable. April 1. Travelers to and from Nigeria were author- ized to import or export up to N 20 in currency notes or coins. Previously, all export and import of naira was prohibited. Arrangements were made for ships and air- lines operating to and from Nigeria to exchange accumu- lated naira balances with the Central Bank. The latter was not obliged to exchange naira for nonresident hold- ers such as foreign banks. April 1. Authorization was granted for the immediate transfer abroad of proceeds of sales of businesses sold to comply with the Nigerian Enterprises Promotion Decree, 1972. Previously, such proceeds had to be remitted according to a predetermined schedule. April 1. The ceiling of N 9,000 a person a financial year on personal remittances by expatriates was removed. Such remittances were subject, however, to a limit of 50 per cent of gross annual taxable income of the person concerned. April 1. The exchange allowance for cash gifts to nonresidents was increased. April 1. The ceiling of N 2,000 on fees which could be paid to nonresident directors of Nigerian companies was abolished. April 1. Payments in foreign exchange by post office money order for subscriptions, memberships, and sundry items were again permitted. April 1. It was announced that five foreign merchant banks had been granted approval to operate in Nigeria and that legislation would be introduced to provide for the operation of such banks. July 4. The Government assumed a 49 per cent inter- est in the 15 foreign insurance companies operating in Nigeria and announced the intention to establish its own reinsurance company. August 9. All shipping companies and agents operat- ing in Nigeria were required to register with the Nigerian Ports Authority and give at least two months' detailed notice of proposed sailings to Nigeria. In December, statutory force was given to these and related regulations by the Ports (Emergency Provisions) Decree No. 40 of 1975. August 18. Legal Notice No. 62 suspended import duty on cement. September 26. Legal Notice No. 92 suspended import duty on meat imported by the Nigerian Livestock and Meat Authority. October 10. Nigeria advised the GATT that it had decided to disinvoke Article XXXV of the General Agreement with respect to Japan. December 5. It was announced that a special com- mittee would negotiate demurrage and other outstanding claims of overseas cement suppliers. 347 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NORWAY (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.124414 gram of fine gold per Norwegian Krone. In 1973 a central rate was estab- lished of NKr 1 = SDR 0.145530 or NKr 6.87145 = SDR 1, corresponding at the time to 0.129328 gram of fine gold per NKr 1, and Norway avails itself of wider margins. Margins of 21A per cent are maintained for spot rates in the official exchange market between the Norwegian krone and the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Luxem- bourg franc, the Netherlands guilder, and the Swedish krona. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies. On December 31, 1975 the buying and sell- ing rates of the authorized banks for the U.S. dollar were NKr 5.5725 and NKr 5.5975, respectively. For- ward premiums and discounts are left to the interplay of market forces. Authorized banks' forward transac- tions with nonbank residents must have a commer- cial basis. Norway formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom May 11, 1967. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the M in is try of Commerce and Shipping in cooperation with the Bank of Norway. The authority to approve most current pay- ments has been delegated to authorized banks. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Shipping and, in certain cases, by the Ministry of Agriculture or the Ministry of Fisheries. Imports and exports of precious metals, and of semimanufactured articles thereof, are licensed by the Bank of Norway. Prescription of Currency Payments between Norway and Rhodesia are pro- hibited when they relate to imports, exports, or transit trade, and in all other cases are subject to special license issued by the Bank of Norway. Settlements with all other countries may be made in any convertible cur- rency, including Norwegian kroner on Convertible Krone Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below). Nonresident Accounts The main type of nonresident account is the Con- vertible Krone Account. Such accounts may be held by residents of all countries, subject to the proviso that without special permission f rom the Bank of Norway the total balance held by a nonbank nonresident must at no time exceed NKr 100,000. They may be credited with authorized payments to any country, with transfers from other Convertible Krone Accounts, and with pro- ceeds from the sale in Norway of convertible currencies. 348 They may be debited for authorized payments from any country to residents of Norway, for transfers to other Convertible Krone Accounts, and for purchases in Norway of any foreign currency. Imports and Import Payments Most commodities do not require an import license. Certain textiles and garments are subject to import licensing for surveillance purposes, irrespective of coun- try of origin. With this exception, industrial goods may be imported freely f rom the import free list area l upon presentation of the original invoice. Imports of certain agricultural products are restricted, irrespective of origin. There are two restricted lists for industrial goods for specified countries —one applicable to imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R., and the other applicable to imports from Japan and the Republic of Korea; many of the goods on these lists are licensed automatically. Imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. A global quota list contains a few quotas for agricul- tural products for which imports are permitted up to fixed limits; these quotas apply to all countries. New and secondhand ships built abroad, other than ships that are 20 years old or older and certain categories of fish- ing vessels, may be imported freely,2 but special permis- sion is required in order to supervise compliance with certain regulations regarding payments in advance of delivery. The import of a small number of commodities is prohibited for health and similar reasons, and certain goods (some grains, alcoholic beverages, equipment and materials for the fishing industry, pharmaceutical products, and drugs) are imported by government monopolies. If no license is required or when an import license has been obtained, payment may be made without delay, provided that the method of payment is in conformity with the general rules (see section on Prescription of Currency, above). Payments for Invisibles Payments to any country except Rhodesia for all cur- rent invisibles, including income from capital and con- tractual amortization, may be made freely. Payments for any purpose to any country other than Rhodesia do not require verification by authorized banks, provided that these payments do not exceed the equivalent of NKr 500. 1 All countries except Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hunga ry, Japan, Nor th Korea, Republic of Korea, Macao, Mongolia, Poland, Rhodesia, Roman ia, U.S.S.R., and Nor th Viet-Nam. 2 Au toma t ic au thor iza t ion is not gran ted for imports f rom Albania, People's Republic of China, Republic of China, Nor th Korea, Macao, Mongolia, Rhodesia, and No r th Viet-Nam. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution The granting of exchange for travel purposes is not restricted. The basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad is equivalent to NKr 5,000 a trip for each person. For business travel, the banks may sell reason- able amounts. Each person leaving Norway may take with him up to NKr 800 in Norwegian banknotes, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100. Nonresidents leaving Norway may, in addition, export any foreign banknotes brought into the country by them. Exports and Export Proceeds Most goods may be exported freely to countries in the export free list area,3 against a declaration or a license, which is granted automatically. Exports subject to regulation are listed and require export licenses. All exports to countries outside the export free list area require an export license. Exports valued at not more than NKr 500 to any country are exempt from export license. Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, with the exception of shipments for medical, humanitarian, or educational purposes. Payments must be received within 12 months of ship- ment and in conformity with the regulations (see sec- tion on Prescription of Currency, above). In principle, all exchange from exports must be surrendered. Proceeds from Invisibles In principle, receipts from invisibles must be sur- rendered. Each person entering Norway may bring in any amount in Norwegian currency, in denominations not exceeding NKr 100, and in other means of payment. Capital Inward transfers of capital and investments in Nor- way by nonresidents must be approved by the Bank of Norway. Outward transfers of capital require individual licenses; the granting of these licenses depends on the merits of the case. Licenses for outward transfers of proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments made in Norway by nonresidents are granted freely, and nonresident capital may be repatriated automatically. Payments for contractual amortization are also permit- ted freely. Most transactions in securities involving non- resident interests are subject to approval. Norwegian securities denominated in Norwegian kroner and pur- chased by nonresidents from Norwegian residents by special permission may be resold to Norwegian residents who will be granted licenses for the transfer of the pro- ceeds from the sale; the purchase of shares of Nor- wegian bank ing and industrial firms by nonresidents is licensed restrictively on a case-by-case basis. Personal capital transfers, such as transfers relating to family loans, gifts, inheritances, legacies, dowries, emigrants' assets, savings of nonresident workers, and NORWAY amounts in settlement of immigrants' debts, may be made freely. In general, resident-owned capital assets abroad, other than securities, real estate, and other authorized invest- ments, have to be surrendered. Applications for capital transfers to make direct investments abroad are treated liberally but portfolio investment abroad is approved only exceptionally. Resident-owned foreign securities quoted on a recognized stock exchange, with the excep- tion of securities issued by foreign investment companies or mutual funds, are freely negotiable between residents, provided that the securities originally were acquired by a resident before October 1, 1966, or that they were bought with the proceeds of foreign securities acquired before that date. Transactions in foreign securities between residents against settlement in kroner require a license from the Bank of Norway if the securities were not included in an authorized broker's safe deposit for customers on May 31, 1969. Residents may upon appli- cation transfer capital abroad to purchase, for recrea- tional purposes, real estate valued at up to NKr 80,000 a family; such purchases by business firms, staff associa- tions, etc., are approved liberally, also for higher amounts. In accordance with guidelines of December 13, 1971, the aggregate net foreign liability position of the banks may not deviate by more than NKr 260 million from the position at the end of October 1971, i.e., it must not be less than NKr 555 million or more than NKr 1,075 mil- lion. On May 23, 1972, however, these guidelines were modified slightly to allow the banks some additional flexibility in determining their net liability position. There are limits on the commercial banks' borrowing abroad. Thus, they may borrow funds or accept depos- its in foreign currency from foreign banks within a ceiling fixed at 20 per cent above their total foreign borrowing at the end of December 1970. Residents other than banks require the prior approval of the Bank of Norway before raising loans, accepting other forms of capital, or incurring or providing guaran- tee obligations abroad. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Norway. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Bank of Norway; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. No customs duties or other charges or fees are payable on imports or exports of gold bullion and gold coins not contained in jewelry. Domestic sales of gold coins are subject to sales tax at a rate of 20 per cent. A self-financing exchange risk cover scheme for export transactions came into effect. Cover could be extended by the Export Credit Guarantee Institute where it was not available on reasonable terms in the forward exchange market operated by the author- ized banks. In general, cover would only apply to the effects of exchange rate movements occurring within ten years f rom the conclusion of a contract. The pre- miums were stipulated as between 0.5 per cent and 2.5 per cent per annum, depending, inter alia, on factors such as the calculable risk and the period for which cover was required; for "snake" currencies and the U.S. dollar, however, a standard premium of 0.75 per cent was set provisionally. The cover commitment per con- tract could not as a rule exceed 35 per cent of the amount of the contract. Premiums and any exchange rate profits on covered contracts were to be channeled into a risk fund; shortfalls in this fund would be met by the Government, up to NKr 3 billion. August 25. The arrangement was intended for surveillance only, licenses being granted automatically for imports f rom countries from which imports of these items previously were unrestricted. The ma in purpose was to prevent circumvention of bilateral agreements imposing restrictions on the impor- tation of these products and to provide early data on imports of the same items f rom other sources. Not for Redistribution OMAN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System On July 4, 1974, Oman established an initial par value of 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Rial Omani, corresponding at the time to RO 0.416667 = SDR 1. The effective parity relationship for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, is RO 1 = US$2.89524. Oman avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Oman maintains fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar, while the commercial banks' rates for other currencies are based on market rates in London. On December 31, 1975, the official buy ing rate for the U.S. dollar was RO 0.3450 per US$1, and the official selling rate was RO 0.3457 per US$1. Oman informed the Fund on June 19, 1974 that it formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank, but there is no exchange control legislation in Oman. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and Rhodesia are prohib- ited. The use of the currencies of Israel and Rhodesia also is prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force.1 Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by resi- dents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for reasons of health, morals, or security. Imports of Maria Theresa dollars also are prohibited. Import licenses are not required and exchange for pay- ments abroad may be obtained freely. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited and exports or re-exports of live animals and foods tuffs may 1 Prior to June 23, 1972 Oman was administratively treated as a Scheduled Territory for purposes of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. Under current U.K. exchange control regulations, Oman is regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. be prohibited in times of shortage in Oman. All other commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re- exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surren- dered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for and proceeds from invisibles are not restricted. Payments must not, however, be made to or received from Israel or Rhodesia. Travelers may br ing in or take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, except that no payments must be made to or received f rom Israel or Rhodesia. Investment in business firms in Oman by foreign physical or juridical persons requires prior approval. Such investment is regulated by a for- eign investment law enacted in 1973. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of any customs duties or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel and Rhodesia, however, are prohibited. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0744103 gram of fine gold per Pakistan Rupee. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and Pakistan avails itself of wider margins. The State Bank of Pakistan (the central bank) main- tains official rates of PRs 9.8844 buy ing, and PRs 9.9312 selling, per US$1 for dealings of banks with the public. All transactions in foreign exchange must be conducted through authorized dealers, whose transactions with the general public must be effected at rates authorized by the State Bank. Authorized dealers in Pakistan are permit- ted to cover their requirements of specified currencies in foreign exchange markets abroad. They may also cover their permitted transactions in specified currencies against U.S. dollars or Pakistan rupees, either spot or forward for a limited period, with their agents in the countries concerned. Administration of Control The State Bank has delegated to a number of banks and financial ins t i tu t ions authority to deal in all foreign currencies, to supervise surrender requirements, and to sell exchange for specified purposes w i th in limits pre- scribed by the State Bank. The Chief Controller of Imports and Exports is responsible for the issue of licenses and the implementation of import and export policies. Certain foreign trade transac t ions are con- ducted through the Trading Corporation of Pakistan, Ltd. (TCP), a state trad ing agency. Prescription of Currency Exchange receipts and payments abroad must be effected through an authorized foreign exchange dealer, in principle in any convertible currency or in Pak is tan rupees from or to nonresident rupee bank accounts. Certain settlements with specified countries, however, are channeled through special accounts. Letters of credit for imports f rom all other countries must be established in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, the domestic currency of the beneficiary, or in the currency of the country of origin or shipment. No exchange control is exercised over transactions with A fghan is tan, and settlements are made freely in Pakistan rupees or in Afghan currency. Trade transac- tions under "barter" agreements are settled through special accounts in inconvertible currencies. Trade in specified commodities with Bulgaria, the People's Repub- lic of China, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Roman ia, Sweden, the U.S.S.R., and Yugoslavia is settled through clearing accounts.1 There is a special trade and payments arrangement with the German Democratic Republic, w i th an indicative commodity list 1 The bilateral payments a r rangemen ts with "Hungary, Roman ia, and Yugoslavia expired on December 31, 1975. 352 only. The clearing accounts with Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, and Hungary are maintained in nonconvertible Pakistan rupees; those with the German Democratic Republic, Poland, Romania, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. are in U.S. dollars; and the clearing account w i th North Korea is denominated in deutsche mark. Payments to and f rom Iran and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, Iranian oil, and defense ma ter ia ls) are settled through clearing accounts ma in ta ined by the respective central banks in U.S. dol- lars. Under a credit arrangement with the Central Bank of Ceylon, all trade with Sri Lanka is settled through a special U.S. dollar account. Payments to, and receipts f rom, member countries of the Asian Clearing Union other than Bangladesh, India, and Iran (i.e., Nepal and Sri Lanka) in respect of cur- rent transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, na tu ral gas, and their products) may be effected in Asian monetary un i ts through the Asian Clearing Union; for settlements w i th Sri Lanka, this is applicable to invisi- bles only. Payments between Pakistan and the Republic of Ch ina, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are suspended. No bank ing transac t ions are permitted between Pakistan and Bangladesh. Restrictions on payments between Pakistan and India have been lifted insofar as they relate to trade transactions in terms of the trade protocol with India of November 30, 1974 or the trade agreement of Janua ry 23, 1975. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of individuals, firms, or companies resi- dent in countries outside Pakistan are designated as non- resident accounts.2 Authorized banks are permitted to open nonresident accounts for nonbank nonresidents w i thout the prior approval of the State Bank where the accounts are to be opened with funds received from abroad through bank ing channels or with rupee funds which have been accepted for remittance abroad. Debits and credits to nonresident accounts for specified pur- poses can be made by authorized banks without the prior approval of the State Bank. Accounts of residents of India, other than the accounts of the Indian High Commission and its personnel, are blocked. Pakistani nationals residing abroad and foreign na t iona ls, whether resident abroad or in Pakistan, may open fore ign currency accounts w i th banks in Pakistan without prior approval of the exchange control authori- ties. There are no restrictions on the currencies in which the accounts may be denominated, credit balances may be freely transferred abroad, and interest on such 2 D i f fe rent rules apply to nonresident rupee accounts of individuals, firms, or companies, on the one hand, and to nonresident rupee accounts of banks, on the other hand. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution accounts is exempt from income tax. A deposit holder wishing to make payments in Pakistan must first convert the foreign exchange drawn from his account into Paki- stan rupees. If a Pakistani national holding such an account returns to Pakistan, he may retain the account unless his stay exceeds six months; thereafter the account must be closed and the exchange surrendered. Banks in Pakistan receiving such deposits must sell the foreign exchange to the State Bank. Imports and Import Payments Permitted imports are classified in two lists: a free list and a tied list. Items on the free list may, in principle, be procured without restriction while items on the tied list may be procured only from tied sources under credits, barter trade, loans, or the U.S. P.L. 480 pro- gram. Items not on either list are effectively prohibited for import except under certain circumstances by export industries, as mentioned below. All imports require licenses, except goods imported by the Central Govern- ment for defense or other purposes, goods in transit, per- sonal baggage, certain imports over the land routes from Afghanistan and Iran, and certain other items permitted under a Ministry of Commerce Notification (No. 3357 260/24 of June 12, 1951). Licenses for imports of a value up to PRs 500 incur no fee, but licenses above that amount up to PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 1 per cent of the value of the license and licenses above PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 2 per cent payable at the time of the issue of the license. The basic two-list import regime is subject to certain supplementary qualifications, the most impor tant of which are as follows: ( 1) Imports from the Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited, as are imports of goods originating in these countries but shipped from third countries. Imports from India are only permitted in accordance with the trade protocol of November 30, 1974. (2) In order to facilitate barter trading and aid utilization and to secure economies through bulk imports, the import of specified items is restricted to the TCP, unless the items are procured with U.S. aid. (3) The import of certain other items is restricted to the public sector or to industrial consumers. (4) In conformity with Regional Cooperation for Devel- opment arrangements between Iran, Pakistan, and Tur- key governing procurements from joint industrial ven- tures, the import of ten items, including six chemical items, is restricted to procurement f rom Turkey. Also, dates may be imported only from Iraq. (5) Special provisions exist for the import for export industries of tied list items from nontied sources and items not on either import list. (6) Private sector importers, other than those importing goods for personal use, who apply for import licenses for goods valued at PRs 20,000 or more, must be members of approved trade organizations. (7) Licenses for permissible imports of industrial plant and equipment are restricted to a c. & f. value of PRs 750,000 for imports against cash and PRs 1.5 mil- PAKISTAN lion for imports under tied credit and under bilateral payments arrangements (larger plant and equipment are to be procured under the auspices of the financing institutions and with the approval of the Ministry of Indu s t ry ). Except for imports of books, periodicals, and news- papers, irrevocable letters of credit must be opened for all commercial imports. Remittances are not normally permitted before shipping documents are received, but in special cases, e.g., machinery and other capital goods for which deposits have to be made with foreign manu- fac turers, the State Bank may authorize advance pay- ments for a part of the value of the goods. No import payments are permitted to be made for goods originating in or consigned f rom the Republic of China, India (other than imports covered by the trade protocol of Novem- ber 30, 1974), Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Except for specified items, including items on the tied import list, the State Bank requires banks to take a minimum margin of 25 per cent against import letters of credit. Certain goods are subject, irrespective of origin, to an import surcharge of 25 per cent ad valorem. These include cocoa, coffee, many domestic appliances, and passenger automobiles. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled by the State Bank and in many cases require its prior approval. No remittances are permitted to be made to Bangladesh, the Republic of China, India, Israel, South Africa, or Rho- desia. Under au thor i ty delegated to them, authorized dealers may sell exchange or make remittances in accord- ance with detailed regulations. Certain remittances of a personal na ture are subject to annual quotas, but most are approved at the discretion of the State Bank. Remit- tances by Pakistani nationals to their families abroad require special authorization. Payments for invisibles connected with imports are generally given the same treatment as that accorded the underlying trade transaction. Transport insurance must, except w i th respect to certain aid shipments, be taken out with insurance companies in Pakistan. The remittance of dividends declared out of current profits is allowed freely to foreign shareholders where the investment was made with the Government's approval. Profits of branches of foreign companies may be remitted freely to their head offices. The same applies to head office expenses charged to a branch's profit and loss account and accepted for tax purposes by the Pakir s tani income tax authorities. On an administrative basis, the State Bank approves an exchange allocation of US$500 a person a trip for private travel; this allocation can be taken up once every two years. Additional exchange for business travel, medical treatment, educa- tion, and sponsored cultural trips may be granted on an ind iv idual basis. There are also specific allowances for pilgrims' travel to Saudi Arabia and other Middle East- ern countries. 353 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency not exceeding the amoun ts they brought in and PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency notes. Residents leaving for Afghanistan may take out PRs 50 in Pakistan cur- rency notes and coins and any amount of Afghan cur- rency. Residents traveling to other foreign destinations may take out PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency and any amount in foreign currency notes and travelers checks granted by authorized banks under permissions issued by the State Bank. Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 or higher may not be taken out. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of specified commodities to any destination, and all exports to the Republic of China, Israel, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited.3 Exports of most other commodities are allowed freely. However, export licenses are required for some 24 listed items, as well as for certain types of sports goods and a few other items subject to minimum export prices, and for certain textile products intended for export to member countries of the EEC. The Cotton Export Corporation of Pakistan has a monopoly over exports of cotton; rice is exported through the Rice Export Corporation and cement through the State Cement Corporation. The State Bank exercises control over exchange receipts and requires a declaration by the exporter that, when payment in accordance with the prescribed method is received, he will surrender the exchange w i th in a certain period of time. A f ter making certain that the exporter's declaration meets all conditions, the author- ized dealer certifies the export form for shipment. Exporters are obliged to collect and surrender export proceeds within four months of shipment; the State Bank may, on the merits of each case, allow an exten- sion of this period. The surrender of Afghan currency accruing from exports to Afghanistan is not required. Industrial units established under the Pay-As-You- Earn Scheme are permitted to utilize up to 50 per cent of the f.o.b. value of exports for the servicing of sup- pliers' credit on imports of plant and machinery. Export duties are levied on a range of export items, including raw cotton, rice, wool, and hides and skins. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Afghan currency, which may be retained, incoming foreign exchange derived f rom invisi- bles must be surrendered within one month. Travelers may bring in PRs 20 in Pakistan currency notes a person and Rs 5 in coins that are legal tender in India; Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 and above may not be brought in. There is no limitation on the import of other currency notes and coins. 3 Prohibited exports include beef, mutton, grains, flour, da i ry prod- ucts, vegetables, poultry, blood meal, meat meal, corn gluten meal, sesame oil cake, certain citrus fruits (unless graded), and certain hides and skins. On Janua ry 21, 1976 exports of raw cotton were tem- porarily suspended. 354 Capital Investments in Pakistan by nonresidents are subject to approval. In order to encourage industrial develop- ment in Pak is tan, the Government follows a liberal policy toward fore ign entrepreneurs, who can, with the approval of the Government, start any industry in the private sector w i thout any conditions being laid down regarding the participation of local capital. It is, how- ever, expected that local rupee expenditure will ordinar- ily be met f rom local equity capital. Repa tr ia t ion facilities are as follows: (1) Foreign capital invested in approved industries established after September 1, 1954 may be repatriated at any time there- a f ter to the extent of the original investment, and current profits may be transferred without restriction, to the coun try of origin of the capital. (2) Profits that are reinvested in approved industrial projects with the approval of the Government may be treated as invest- ment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. (3) Appreciation of any capital investment under (1) and (2) may also be treated as investment for the pur- pose of subsequent repatriation. These repatriation fac i l i t ies do not apply to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange unless the purchase is an integral part of an approved investment project, or to capital invested in Pak is tan before September 1, 1954. Guarantees provide for just and fa ir compensation in the currency of the country of origin of the investment in the event of na t iona l iza t ion of any project. Foreign na t iona ls in Pakistan or abroad may register their investments in National Prize Bonds issued by the Government of Pakistan, and thus facilitate repatriation at any t ime of the principal and the prize winnings. Transfers of capital abroad by resident nationals are, in general, not permitted; the purchase of foreign securi- ties by resident Pakistanis requires approval by the State Bank and is seldom permitted. Detailed rules govern the transfer of capital by persons emigrating or retiring f rom Pak is tan, depending upon the nationality of the person concerned and the country or monetary area to which the t rans fer is to be made. Foreign nationals temporar i ly residing in Pakistan are treated as nonresi- dents for purposes of t rans fer of securities. General permission has been given in connection with the issue, sale, or t rans fer of Pakistani securities, excluding shares of public or private limited companies, in favor of nonresidents, provided the securities are registered at the Pakistani address of the purchaser and investment is made on the basis of nonrepatriation of capital and re tu rn. Pakistani securities held by nonresidents may be transferred to other nonresidents against payment abroad with the same facilities in respect of remittance of capital and earnings as those obtained by the trans- feror. A general permission has also been issued allow- ing foreign nationals temporarily resident in Pakistan to make investments in units of the National Investment Trust, subject to certain stipulations. ©International Monetary Fund. Proceeds accruing from the liquidation of nonresident capital assets that are not covered by repatriation arrangements must be credited to blocked accounts. Subject to approval by the State Bank, balances on blocked accounts may be invested in approved government securities payable in Pakistan rupees or placed on time deposit with banks. A general permission allows Pakistani nationals resi- dent abroad to acquire securities in Pakistan by remit- tance of foreign exchange or to the debit of their nonresident accounts in Pak is tan; dividends or interest thereon, as well as the proceeds upon sale, must be credited to nonresident accounts and cannot normally be transferred abroad. Pakistani nationals require the prior approval of the State Bank to sell movable or immovable assets held abroad, and the liquidation pro- ceeds must be repatriated to Pakistan through normal banking channels. Gold The export and import of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the State Bank. No such permission is granted, but there are no restrictions on the internal sale and purchase of nonmonetary gold. Changes during 1975 January 1. The goods to be exported from Pakistan and India under this agreement would be of Pakistani and Indian origin and for consumption in India and Pakistan, respectively; these goods could not be re-exported to third countries. Not for Redistribution PANAMA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Panamanian Balboa. The parity rate for the U.S. dollar is B 1.00 = US$1, and Panama does not avail itself of wider margins. U.S. currency notes and coins circu- late freely in Panama, and local currency is represented only by limited amounts of silver balboas and subsidiary coins, a commemorative 20-balboa silver coin, and two commemorative gold coins of B 100 and B 500. Exchange transactions by commercial banks are based mainly on New York market quotations. Panama has no exchange restrictions on foreign payments, with the exception of a prohibition on payments to Rhodesia other than those for pensions or for humanitarian, educational, medical, or informa t ional purposes. On November 26, 1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sec- tions 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regulation Office, a semiautonomous institution of the Panaman ian Governmen t. The Price Regulation Office is responsible for the implementation of restric- tions on imports of commodities that compete with national production and on certain exports. The Minis- try of Commerce and Industry determines the import quotas for commodities listed in trade agreements, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, jointly with the Price Regulation Office, those for certain agricultural commodities. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Quotas are imposed on imports of commodities competing with present or prospective domestic production; some of these are not being licensed. Import licensing also applies to imports of various foods tuffs. Other imports are free. Payments abroad may be made freely. A tax of 7 per cent on the f.o.b. value is levied, in addition to import duty, on private sector imports of all dutiable goods other than specified pharmaceutical products and foodstuffs, for which the rate is 2l/2 per cent and 3J/2 per cent, respectively; books are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, except those for human i tar ian, educational, medical, or informa t ional purposes. Authorization is required for exports of coffee in any form, coconuts, copra, and beef cattle, and for certain manufactured products in short supply. Merchan- dise on which export taxes are imposed is also subject to licensing. Export taxes are levied on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, and other minerals, sugar, bananas, coconuts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of cement, certain foods tuffs, firearms, and ammunition are prohibited. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except for most payments to Rhodesia. A travel tax of 4 per cent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets pur- chased for travelers starting their trip in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, except for most payments to Rhodesia. Several foreign- controlled banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresidents. Gold Panama has issued two commemorative gold coins with face values of B 100 and B 500, which are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely hold gold in any fo rm at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any fo rm with residents or nonresidents at home and abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers are subject to license if made by residents other than the monetary authorities; import licenses are issued freely by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry and export licenses are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Exports of unworked gold produced in Panama are subject to an export duty of 1 per cent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U.S. coins, which are exempt) to a duty of l/2 of 1 per cent. Not for Redistribution PAPUA NEW GUINEA1 (Position on January 1, 1976) Exchange Rate System The currency of Papua New Guinea is the Kina, which is officially maintained at parity with the Austra- lian dollar. The Bank of Papua New Guinea deals with local banks in Australian dollars, Japanese yen, and U.S. dollars only. On January 1, 1976, the Bank's fixed buying and selling rates for the Australian dollar were K 1.0010 and K 0.9990 per Australian dollar, and its buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were K 0.7948 and K 0.7961 per U.S. dollar. The corre- sponding rates for the public posted by the authorized dealers were K 1.0025 buying, and K 0.9975 selling, per Australian dollar, and K 0.7933 buying, and K 0.7977 selling, per U.S. dollar. The Bank of Papua New Guinea's exchange rate for the U.S. dollar is set daily on the basis of the middle rate quoted by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Papua New Guinea formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as from December 4, 1975. Administration of Control The Bank of Papua New Guinea administers exchange control by means of the Foreign Exchange Regulations, issued in November 1973. Overall policy is determined by the Government with the advice of the Bank of Papua New Guinea and the Department of Finance. The Bank delegates extensive powers to the trading banks operating in Papua New Guinea, which have been appointed authorized dealers in foreign exchange. Export licensing is administered by the Department of Foreign Relations and Trade. Prescription of Currency Contractual commitments to persons resident outside Papua New Guinea, which are expressed in a foreign currency, may only be met by payments in foreign currency.2 Export proceeds may be received in any for- eign currency or in Papua New Guinea currency from an overseas bank's account in Papua New Guinea. Nonresident Accounts The Bank of Papua New Guinea seeks to control all credits to nonresident bank accounts; funds credited to such accounts may be withdrawn without fur ther formal- ity. Only in exceptional circumstances is approval given for a nonresident bank account to be denominated in a foreign currency. Imports and Import Payments No restrictions are placed on payments for imports, except where goods imported from Rhodesia are con- 1 Papua New Guinea became a member of the International Mone- tary Fund on October 9, 1975. 2 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the kina. cerned. Authorized dealers have powers to approve the great majority of transactions without the necessity for completion of application forms or reference to the Bank of Papua New Guinea. Approval is given for pay- ment to be made under extended credit terms for items such as capital equipment. There are no import licensing requirements. Payments for Invisibles Approval is readily given for most payments for invisibles, provided that supporting documentation can be produced. The remittance overseas of life insurance premiums on new policies written af ter December 31, 1975 in the names of permanent residents is not permit- ted. No absolute limits are imposed on travel funds, although applications for exceptionally large amounts are referred to the Bank of Papua New Guinea for consideration. Travelers may not take or send out of Papua New Guinea domestic currency in excess of K 200 in notes and K 5 in coin; however, domestic coins issued for num isma t ic purposes may be taken out freely. Over- seas visitors are free to take out any currency which they brought in and had recorded on arrival. Exports and Export Proceeds Residents of Papua New Guinea may export goods w i thout exchange control formality (except to Rhodesia) on condition that they comply with the terms of the General Authority issued by the Bank of Papua New Guinea. The essential conditions of this Authority are that payment for goods exported is received within six months before or after the date of export and that the proceeds are sold to an authorized dealer in Papua New Guinea. Where exporters are not in a position to com- ply with the conditions of the General Authority, they must apply to the Bank for a Specific Authority. No authority is needed for certain excepted categories of goods; these include sundry items such as passengers' personal effects. Export licenses are required for all types of goods under the Exports (Control and Valua- tion) Act. Special provisions are in force for the export of prescribed goods (logs, pearls, tuna fish, and wood chips). Proceeds from Invisibles Approval is required only for the disposal of foreign currency proceeds other than by sale to an authorized dealer in Papua New Guinea. Overseas visitors may bring in any amount of currency for travel expenditure. Capital Outward transfers of overseas-owned capital are allowed without limit; advance commitments, however, 359 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAPUA NEW GUINEA are only given in exceptional circumstances. Persons who have been granted temporary residential status by an authorized dealer or the Bank of Papua New Guinea are permitted to repatriate their surplus earnings with- out limit. New investment outside Papua New Guinea by perma- nent residents and by companies and other organizations operating in Papua New Guinea is subject to certain limitations. Where an investment is for portfolio rea- sons, the amount which may be invested in a 12-month period is limited to K 10,000 for individuals, K 25,000 for private companies, and K 100,000 for public com- panies. Investment may only be in the fo rm of market- able company securities and real estate. The approval of the Bank of Papua New Guinea is needed for the acquisition and disposal of foreign securities by perma- nent residents.3 Where direct investment is involved, approval would norma l ly depend on the extent to which additional real benefits (such as exports) would accrue f rom the investment. Approval is needed for all new or increased foreign investment in Papua New Guinea, both f rom the Bank of Papua New Guinea under the Foreign Exchange Regulations and f rom the National Investment and Development Authority under legislation governing that Authority. In addition to investment in the form of loans and equity capital, approval is also necessary f rom the Bank for the acknowledgment of indebtedness so that a right to receive a payment is conferred on a nonresident. Gold Approval by the Bank of Papua New Guinea under the Central Banking (Go ld) Regulations is necessary for the sale, purchase, and export of gold. An exemp- tion to the Regulations allows native miners to export gold to Australia for refining without specific approval. The Regulations do not apply to gold used in the course of a person's profession, to Papua New Guinea currency, or to gold coins with a gold content of over K 50. A K 100 gold coin is legal tender but does not circulate; it may be taken out freely by travelers. Changes during 1975 April 19. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System On March 1, 1956, a new par value for the Para- guayan Gua rani was established by Paraguay with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Exchange transac- tions take place in a dual exchange market. Transactions in the official exchange market (mercado libre bancario) must be carried out through the Central Bank of Para- guay ( for all government transactions) or an authorized commercial bank; these transactions take place at a rate of 0 126 per US$1, subject to taxes and commis- sions. Transactions in the f luc tua t ing free market (mer- cado libre fluctuante de cambio) are conducted through licensed foreign exchange houses at a fluctuating rate which on December 31, 1975 was about 0 140 per US$1 buying, and 0 143 per US$1 selling. All purchases and sales of exchange by banks are subject to a tax of 1 Vi per cent, except transactions w i th foreign embassies and diplomats; transactions with meat packing plants; and transactions relating to investments in Paraguay that are covered by Law No. 216 of Novem- ber 9, 1970, as amended. In addition, banks charge a commission of 2 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange. A tax of 10 per cent is levied on outward remittances of profits and dividends, and a tax of 30 per cent on remittances of interest, royalties, rents, honorar- iums, commissions, and other income accru ing to non- residents f rom Paraguayan sources. There are no for- ward exchange facilities. The transactions settled in the official exchange ma rket are exports and imports (except unrecorded border t rade ), certain current invisibles, all government transac- tions, registered private capital transac t ions, and related profit remittances. All other transactions are channeled through the f luc tua t ing free market, unless settlements are effected under reciprocal credit agreements with LAFTA countries. The authorized banks, but not the exchange houses, are required to sell 30 per cent of their gross foreign exchange receipts in specified currencies * to the Cen- tral Bank. Administration of Control The Central Bank determines fore ign exchange policy and supervises the foreign exchange transactions car- ried out by commercial banks and authorized foreign exchange houses. Prescription of Currency Payments between Paraguay and Argen t ina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru must be made through accounts which the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other central banks concerned maintain with each other, w i th in the f ramewo rk of the LAFTA multi- lateral clearing system. There are no other prescription of cu r rency requirements. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited.2 Cer- tain other items require a license from the Ministry of Interior; these are ma in ly narcotics and arms and ammun i t ion. All other imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing. Imports of most commodities are subject to an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the f.o.b. va lue, which is retained for 120 days, or for nonexempt commodities imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay, 90 days. Advance deposits are not required fo r, inter alia, public sector imports, imports by foreign diplomats and by foreign staff of certain in te rna t ional organizations, petroleum and petro- leum derivatives, certain machinery and agricultural equ ipmen t, wheat, and newsprint f rom any source, imports f rom neighboring countries and Uruguay, and imports f rom other LAFTA countries of items included in the Paraguayan concession list (the National List). The Central Bank has au thor i ty to grant exemptions on a case-by-case basis. Surcharges, calculated on the c.i.f. value, are payable on most imports even if no foreign exchange payment takes place. An import surcharge of 36 per cent applies to most general imports from any source; however, for goods or ig ina t ing in LAFTA countries and included in the Paraguayan National List the rate ranges f rom 3 per cent to 30 per cent, and for certain other LAFTA goods (mainly Pharmaceuticals) in a special list the rate is 8 per cent. Fuel derived f rom petroleum is sub- ject to a surcharge of 15 per cent (10 per cent for neighboring countries and U ruguay ). There is an addi- t ional surcharge of 5 per cent on imports f rom all sources of telephone and telegraph equipment, television receivers, and radios and record players and their parts and accessories. Commodities that are exempt f rom sur- charge generally are also exempt from advance deposit. These surcharges are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of the documents for customs clearance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The fo l low ing are the principal exemptions f rom sur- charge: wheat; crude petroleum; equipment for petro- leum exploration and exploitation; agricultural tractors; imports for the Government; imports for religious, charitable, cultural, or educational purposes; imports by fore ign diplomats and certain international organiza- tions; Spanish agricultural and industrial machinery and imp lemen ts imported through the Spanish free zone in 1 Argentine pesos, Belgian f rancs, Braz i l ian cruzeiros, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 These include sugar, rice, flour, and certain other agricultural prod- ucts and food s tu f f s, certain petroleum products, cement, certain yarn and textiles, and certain wire and wire products. 361 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the National Wheat Program; books and periodicals; and imports for investments under Capital Investment Law No. 216/70. Imports of investment goods and of raw materials for export industries receive exemption on a case-by-case basis. In addition to the above surcharges, a tariff surcharge is levied on certain imports by virtue of Law No. 1334/67, which implemented Decree-Law No. 451 of March 31, 1967, and Law No. 10 of August 29, 1968. On goods that are not exempt, it is generally 12-24 per cent (8-16 per cent for certain goods subject to LAFTA con- cessions) and is levied on the c.i.f. value, which is cal- culated as follows: the f.o.b. value plus 10 per cent for imports from neighboring countries and Uruguay, and the true market value upon arrival in customs for imports from other countries. Exempt f rom this comple- men tary import du ty are public sector and d ip loma t ic imports; raw materials and equ ipment for the production of goods that are subject to internal consumption taxes; imports under Capital Investment Law No. 216/70; and all imported goods taxed under the Internal Consump- tion Tax Law. Imports are also subject to sales tax at 5 per cent or 10 per cent by virtue of Law No. 69/68. In addition to those mentioned above, the following charges are levied on either the c.i.f. value of imports or the true market value upon arrival in customs: a con- sular fee of 5 per cent, an import clearance fee of 1 per cent, and a customs surcharge of surcharge, and advance deposit concessions to proposed private foreign investments, provided that these are reg- istered; the terms may vary from case to case. Capital imported under Law No. 216/70 may be retransferred in installments of up to 20 per cent from the third year after the beginning of production, in the currency origi- nally imported. Gold Decree-Law No. 18 of 1952 provides that the Central Bank may determine the max imum amount of gold and foreign exchange that residents may hold; exempt is any amount acquired by the Central Bank or institutions authorized to deal in foreign exchange. In practice resi- dents may freely purchase, hold, an^ sell gold in any form, in Paraguay or abroad, and exchange houses may freely deal in gold coins, gold bars, and gold leaf w i th residents and nonresidents. Exports and imports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry require the prior approval of the Central Bank, for which nonbank residents and industrial users are eligible; payments for gold imports by industrial users must be made through authorized banks at the official exchange rate, and payments for imports by others must be made through exchange houses at the fluctuating free market rate.
