Not for Redistribution PERU (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System On December 18, 1946, a par value for the Peruvian Sol was established by Peru with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market with a single fixed exchange rate of S/. 45 per US$1, buying and selling. The exchange certificate market rate applies to all trade transactions and specified non trade trans- actions, including the principal capital movements, and the d ra ft market rate to services and most other nontrade transactions. The foreign exchange requ iremen ts of the public sector are met entirely through the certificate marke t. Export proceeds must be converted in to exchange certificates, which are valid for three days and are issued by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru in U.S. dollars only. These exchange certificates may be used, only through the intermediary of commercial banks, to pay for imports (f.o.b.) and for certain non trade transac- tions. Generally, no exchange certificates are issued against export proceeds surrendered by the public sector, nor are certificates used to cover foreign payments of the public sector, since normally the Central Reserve Bank buys and sells foreign exchange direct f rom and to government agencies at the certificate rate. When approved applications for certificates exceed the supply, the Central Reserve Bank sells foreign exchange at the certificate market rate without any delay. All foreign exchange receipts that are not required to be surrendered at the certificate rate must be sold in the d r a ft market, in which only the government-owned Banco de la Nacion and its authorized agents operate. Access to the d ra ft market is controlled and purchases of fore ign exchange are permitted only for specified paymen ts not eligible for exchange at the certificate rate. The banks are required to quote a s ing le rate for buy ing and selling certificates, but they may charge a commission of 1A of 1 per cent on sales of certificates (none on purchases of certificates); they may charge a commission of 1A of 1 per cent, buy ing and selling, on transactions in the d ra ft market. A s tamp tax of 1 per cent is payable on most outward remittances. Peru formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Administration of Control Export licenses are issued by the Directorate of For- eign Trade in the Ministry of Commerce. The Central Reserve Bank controls the use of certificates for import payments. It also authorizes the use of certificates for nontrade transactions; for profit remittances by branches of foreign companies, prior approval by the M in is t ry of Economy and Finance must be obtained in addition. 364 All imports of, and most payments for services by, the public sector require the approval of the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Public Sector and a reso- lution of the Ministry of Economy and Finance; a s im i lar Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector ( JUTREX) approves import paymen ts by the pri- vate sector on the basis of an annual forecast of imports that has been authorized by the competent sectoral ministries. Borrowing abroad by the public sector as well as borrowing abroad by the private sector with a government guarantee are subject to prior approval by Supreme Decree, upon favorable recommendation by the High Committee of the External Debt, the National Planning Institute, and the Permanent Commission on External Credit in the Ministry of Economy and Finance. The External Office for Foreign Investment in the Com- mercial Sector (Omsco) supervises foreign commercial investment in Peru, the use of foreign trademarks, pat- ents, and licenses, as well as the related royalty payments. Prescription of Currency In principle, all export proceeds must be received in convertible currencies;1 exchange certificates at present are only issued in U.S. dollars, but the Central Reserve Bank is empowered to issue certificates denominated in any convertible currency. Settlements in respect of trade transactions with Hungary and Poland must be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, which have been established under bilateral payments agreements. No other prescription of currency require- ments are in force. Payments between Peru and Argen- t ina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be made through accounts ma in ta ined with each other by the Central Reserve Bank of Peru and the other central banks concerned, w i th in the framework of the LAFTA mu l t i la teral c lear ing system. Imports and Import Payments 2 The import of a number of consumer goods that are considered nonessential is prohibited unless covered by concessions negotiated under the LAFTA and Andean Group agreements. Moreover, the import of a large number of manu fac tu res included in the Na t ional Reg- ister of Manu fac tu red Products requires the approval of the M in is try of Industry and Tourism and of the customs authorities, which is granted only in exceptional circumstances unless the goods originate in a country of the Andean Group. Most private sector impor ts require 1 The proceeds must be received in the currency in which the con- tract is expressed if it is one of the following currencies: Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Otherwise, export proceeds must be received in U.S. dollars. 2 Decree-Law No. 21390 of J anu a ry 9, 1976 provided for the intro- duction w i th in 90 days of a system of import licensing operated under the supervision of the Ministry of Commerce. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the prior authorization of the competent sectoral min- istry on the basis of an annual import forecast submitted by the importer. JUTREX allocates exchange (in annual allotments to the individual importers) in accordance with the annual import forecast approved by the sectoral ministries; imports of goods originating in countries of the Andean Group are exempt from this allocation sys- tem. The allocations are marked on individual import- er's cards (tarjetas de importador). Public sector agen- cies may not place import orders without the prior approval of the Commission on Public External Trans- actions and the Ministry of Economy and Finance. Certain agricultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by the Fish Meal Market- ing Agency (E PCHA P ), and crude petroleum and petro- leum derivatives only by PETROPERU, a government agency. Certain industrial raw materials and fertilizers may be imported only by the National Enterprise for Industrial Marketing (ENCI). Payments for the f.o.b. value of private sector imports, whether under documentary letters of credit or on a documentary collection basis, and for interest charges on foreign import credits, may be made at the certifi- cate exchange rate; however, payments for freight and import-related bank ing charges other than interest must be made at the d ra ft market rate. Transport insurance contracts for imported goods must be placed with national insurance companies unless a specific exemp- tion from this requirement is obtained f rom the Banco de la Nacion, in which case premium payments are made at the d ra ft market rate. The fu ll c.i.f. value of public sector imports may be paid with certificates. The use of certificates for import payments requires the prior authorization of the Central Reserve Bank, which provides the foreign exchange to the commercial banks against delivery of the certificates. The commer- cial banks must present evidence that the entire amount represented by the certificates will be used for the importation of merchandise. The relevant shipping docu- ments and the bill of lading, together with the commer- cial invoice and the remittance letter issued by the exporter, must be forwarded to a commercial bank and presented to the Central Reserve Bank for registration and validation. Submission of import contracts or other evidence supporting the transaction is required for advance import payments when the shipping documents are not avail- able; in addition, the intermediary bank must provide a guarantee equal to the sol value of the advance pay- ment. If the shipping documents are not presented within 30 days af ter the utilization of the foreign exchange, the Central Reserve Bank will collect the guarantee and refund this sum only when the required documents have been presented. M in imum credit terms have been prescribed for many imports. For imports of capital goods valued at over US$10,000 f.o.b., at least 80 per cent of the value must be financed PERU abroad through loans either from suppliers or other foreign creditors or from the Peruvian state develop- ment banks, to be repaid in accordance with minimum credit terms set by JUTREX. The state development banks may only provide such financing for national enterprises; these loans are repayable at the exchange rate prevailing at the time of repayment. The Central Reserve Bank may authorize the sale of exchange cer- tificates only for partial advance payments of up to 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value for imports of capital goods by the private sector (20 per cent of the c.i.f. value for public sector imports). These imports of capital goods must be covered by irrevocable docu- mentary credits and the intermediary bank must guar- antee re fund ing of the foreign currency if the import is not effected by the time the relevant documentary credit expires. For private sector imports of goods other than capital goods from countries outside the Andean Group, the m in imum external financing terms at the end of 1975 were as follows: (1) foodstuffs and pharmaceutical products were exempt; (2) a credit period of at least 90 days f rom the date of shipment was prescribed for certain intermediate and finished goods; (3) the corre- sponding m in imum period for all other goods was 120 days; and (4) import shipments valued at up to US$5,000 (c. & f.) were exempt, up to a total value of US$50,000 a year for each importer. Imports are subject to a surcharge tax of 10 per cent ad valorem. A maritime freight tax of 4 per cent of the ocean fre ight charges is levied on goods imported by sea other than certain agricultural and medical prod- ucts, books, and coins. Public sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Authorization is required in order to pay for invisibles w i th certificates or at the certificate rate. The transac- tions in invisibles that are eligible for the certificate market include government payments, profit remittances by branches of foreign companies operating in Peru, dividend remittances to foreign shareholders (provided that the original investment took place at the certificate r a t e ), and interest payments on those loans for which amortization may be transferred through the certificate marke t. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, require a resolution of the M in is t ry of Economy and Finance, a prior tax clear- ance, and the visa of the Central Reserve Bank. More- over, in compliance with the foreign investment regime approved by the countries of the Andean Group, new foreign investments must be authorized and registered w i th the competent agency. Access to the certificate market or the draft market for profit remittances is determined according to the market through which the inves tment is made. Remittances of profits on foreign capital invested in Peru are limited to 14 per cent a 365 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU year;3 foreign-owned enterprises may not pay royalties under new contracts to a foreign parent company or its affiliates; and the effective interest rate on a new loan f rom a foreign parent company or its foreign affiliate may not exceed by more than 3 per cent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is denominated. Exchange for payments that are not eligible for exchange certificates must be obtained in the d ra ft mar- ket, subject to the prior authorization of the Banco de la Nacion. For private sector payments in respect of a large number of current invisibles the sale of foreign exchange is authorized freely, either by the Banco de la Nacion or its agents, provided evidence is presented that genuine current payments are involved. These cate- gories include insurance premiums, the remuneration of technicians hired abroad, interest on loans for which amortization payments are permitted to be transferred through the draft market, rental income, pensions, and commissions. Payments for royalties, patents, and trade- marks require the prior approval of the contract by the competent agency. For certain other payments of the private sector basic allocations have been established up to which foreign exchange is sold freely through the d ra ft market by the Banco de la Nacion. These cate- gories include expenses abroad connected with tourist and business travel, study, and fam i ly maintenance. The basic limit up to which foreign exchange for tourist travel may be sold is the equ iva lent of S/. 1,500 a person a day for a max imum of 30 days in any one calendar year for travel to any country.4 The Banco de la Nacion fixes basic m ax imum amoun ts of foreign exchange which may be purchased annua l ly by each eligible company for business travel abroad by its offi- cials. There is a travel tax, which takes the form of a tax on a traveler's acquisition of goods and services abroad (including the cost of passages and fares) of 15 per cent for tourist travel and 20 per cent for business t rave l5 on amounts up to the daily limits specified above, and of 50 per cent on any amoun ts in excess of these limits; the m in imum amount payable is S/. 50 a day for each day spent abroad. Exempt are residents travel- ing on official business and foreign diplomats. Travel for medical trea tment or study abroad also is exempt. The tax is paid prior to depar ture on the basis of a sworn declaration specifying separately the amount of the fare, the value of anticipated services to be received, and da i ly expenses. Air and sea passages are in addition subject to a 15 per cent ad valorem tax (9 per cent for economy class f a r e s ). Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco Minero del Peru has a monopoly over the export of uncut precious stones and pearls, and MINEROPERU and the Banco Minero over exports of gold and silver. EPCHAP has a monopoly over exports of fish meal, fish oil, and cotton, and EPSEP over exports of fish for human consumption. All exports are subject to license to assure the necessary supply of export pro- ceeds to the certificate market. Traditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru; the latter must surrender the foreign exchange proceeds w i th in ten working days of paymen t. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight drafts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Exporters of non trad i t ional exports or local hand icraft articles are granted transferable tax credit certificates (certificados de reintegro tributario or CERTEX) equiva- lent to 15-30 per cent of the c. & f. va lue (of the f.o.b. value when the goods are shipped in foreign vessels).6 These certificates may be used by the exporter in pay- ment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. The Banco de la Nacion adm in is ters an export credit guarantee program and the Indus tr ial Bank provides or arranges export finance for non t rad i t ional exports. Tra- d i t ional exports are subject to a special tax of 10 per cent on any excess of the actual price over the reference price fixed by the M in is try of Commerce. Proceeds front Invisibles Most public sector entities other than the state banks must surrender the ir fu ll receipts at the certificate rate; the exceptions are earnings f rom services provided by the Peruvian Shipping Company (CPV) and the Peru- vian A ir l ine Company (AERO PERU ), which are eligible for the d ra ft ma rket rate. All other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the d ra ft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S/. 1,000 in Peruvian cur- rency, but the Central Reserve Bank grants exemptions in special circumstances. Capital All outward capital transfers require prior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital payments on private account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans 6 The rates were increased by 5 per cent in January 1976. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution contracted by the private sector, provided that the for- eign exchange proceeds of the loan have been sur- rendered to the Central Reserve Bank. Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate exchange may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public utility enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organi- zations, and for payment of debts guaranteed by the State. Payments in connection with all loans received before June 17, 1971 and not channeled through the certificate market must be transferred through the d ra ft market. The proceeds of all foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate mar- ket; amortization and service payments in respect of these loans are also settled through the certificate mar- ket. All exchange receipts that are not required to be sold in the certificate market must be sold in the d ra ft market. Only the Banco de la Nacion may receive funds origi- nating abroad for deposit to foreign currency accounts maintained in the name of nonresidents; these funds and the accrued interest thereon may be freely disposed of by the depositor and are exempt f rom income and inheritance taxes un t il December 31, 1978. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree- Law No. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of foreign capital, by Decree-Law No. 18999 of Octo- ber 19, 1971, and by Decree-Law No. 19232, Decree- Law No. 19307, Decree-Law No. 19971, and the legis- lation ruling the Peruvian exchange system. All foreign investments in Peru require the prior approval of the competent authorities with a view to channeling such investments to projects considered essential for the coun- try's development. If they wished to enjoy for their products the advantages deriving f rom the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at July 1, 1971 had to agree, by June 30, 1974, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to t rans fo rm them into mixed or national companies du r ing a maxi- mum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, mixed com- panies are defined as those in which na t ional investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. After June 30, 1974, the participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise had to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participa- tion must increase to at least 45 per cent af ter 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru after June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent participa- tion by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. Foreign investments in firms engaged in basic industries or in m in ing activi- PERU ties (including petroleum production) and in firms which export at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Common Market are exempt f rom the requirement of gradual transforma- tion into mixed companies; however, these enterprises do not benefit f rom the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement. All insurance and reinsurance companies that are not branches of foreign firms had to become national enterprises by June 30, 1974, and all insurance and reinsurance companies established in Peru after July 17, 1973, had to be completely owned by national investors. Investment in the m in ing sector is governed by the General Mining Law (Decree-Law No. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the Mining Code of May 12, 1950. Companies holding m in ing concessions may enter into m in ing contracts with the Government providing for special incentives and guarantees or may constitute mixed enterprises with government partici- pation of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of m in ing contracts, the Government may grant to mining concessionaires in i t ia t ing large-scale investment pro- grams tax incentives and guaranteed availability of foreign exchange for transfers of (1) recovery of in- vestment; (2) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prevailing rate for s im i lar loans in the financial ma rket f rom which the loans originate; (3) paymen ts for justified services; and (4) reasonable prof it remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. Mixed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special contract and, in add i t ion, special tax reductions. Gold The marketing of precious metals and their import and export are governed by Decree-Law No. 18882 of June 15, 1971 and Supreme Decree No. 065-71-EF of the same date. The export of gold and silver in the fo rm of agglomerated or native metals is the monopoly of MINEROPERU, while their export in the form of precious metals is the monopoly of the Banco Minero del Peru. All imports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and professional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco Minero del Peru, but only MINEROPERU is authorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. Residents traveling abroad may not take out jewelry valued at over S/. 50,000 unless it has been registered with the customs (S /. 15,000 for trips to bordering countries). 367 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU Changes during 1975 During the year, additional commodities were included in the National Register of Manufac tured Products. January 1. The new general customs law (Decree- Law No. 20165 of October 2, 1973) came into force. It incorporated the 10 per cent surcharge (Supreme Decree No. 202 of June 24, 1968) and the 2 per cent statistical tax which previously were levied separately (Decree-Law No. 20747 of October 1, 1974). January 1. Consular invoices ceased to be required for imports. New documentation requirements for commercial invoices came into force (Supreme Decree No. 020-74-MiNCOM of November 13, 1974, published on December 12, 1974). January 1. Imports from Chile, Colombia, and Venezuela of goods not on the exception list but included in the PID (punto inicial de desgravacion) list became subject to reduced import duties (Decree- Law No. 20616 of May 21, 1974). January 7. The travel tax, to the extent it was applicable to the basic amounts for a traveler's acquisi- tion of goods and services abroad, was increased from a flat 10 per cent to 15 per cent for tourist travel and to 20 per cent for business travel (Decree- Law No. 21061). January 21. Decree-Law No. 21083 made the mar- keting of domestic and imported rice a state monopoly. January 21. The standard rate of the tax on goods and services (payable on production, imports, and wholesale transactions) was increased to 17 per cent (Decree-Law No. 21070 of Janua ry 2 1 , 1 9 7 5 ). February 3. EPSA was put in charge of the market- ing of rice (Supreme Decree No. 1-75-AL). February 4. Decree-Law No. 21094 was issued, containing a new Organic Law for the Energy and Mining Sector. February 18. The open-ended customs duty con- cessions period for spare parts and components for the automotive industry (which had been introduced by Decree-Laws Nos. 19256, 19859, and 20536) was terminated with effect from January 1, 1976 (Decree- Law No. 21098). April 21. A new government agency, the Oficina de Inversion Extranjera del Sector Comercio (Omsco), was established to supervise foreign commercial invest- ment in Peru, as well as contracts regarding foreign trademarks, patents, licenses, and royalties. The agency was under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Commerce (Ministerial Resolution No. 304-75-CO/AJ). April 22. Decree-Law No. 21135 extended indefi- nitely the tax surcharge of 10 per cent on traditional exports which had been introduced by Decree-Law No. 20505 of January 15, 1974. July 23. New regulations were issued regarding the export and import of domestic currency in the region bordering on Ecuador (Supreme Resolution No. 98-75-EF/II). September 26. The exchange rates in the certifi- cate market and the draft market were unified at S/. 45 = US$1, buying and selling. Previously, the rate in the certificate market had been unchanged since September 1967 at S/. 58.70 (buying and selling), while the rate in the draft market had been stable since May 1970 at S/. 43.38 (buying) and S/. 43.50 (selling) per US$1. The dual exchange market was maintained. September 26. JUTREX revoked the requirement of a documentary letter of credit applicable since May 1974 to all private sector imports. October 28. Decree-Law No. 21297 reserved to the State the right to engage in the exploration, mining, or refining of radioactive minerals. November 17. A National Registry of Importers was created in the Directorate of Foreign Trade, replacing the previous Registry of Importers (Supreme Decree No. 011-75-CO/CE). November 21. Exports of fish meal and fish oil were suspended. They were resumed in April 1976. December 16. The State assumed the monopoly over imports of all alcoholic beverages and certain food- s tuffs; with effect from January 1, 1976, these imports were effected through ENCI and the Empresa de Servi- cios de Administration y Gerencia de la EPSA (AGEPSA ), respectively (Decree-Law No. 21353). December 17. The Banco de la Nation reduced the exchange allocation for expenditures abroad from S/. 1,500 a person a day, applicable to all countries, to S/. 1,200 a person a day for travel in the American continent and S/. 1,350 a person a day for travel else- where. The new allocations would apply in 1976. December 23. CERPER was charged w i th the control over the quality of products imported by EPCHAP and ENCI (Decree-Law No. 21361). 368 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.227864 gram of fine gold per Philippine Peso. All exchange transactions take place in a free market. The Bankers' Association establishes daily a "guiding rate"; on December 31, 1975 this rate was about P 7.50 per U.S. dollar. In spot transactions with their customers, commercial banks are required by the Association to observe certain margins. The maxi- mum and m in imum spot buying rates are l/2 of 1 per cent and 1 per cent below the guiding rate, respectively. The m in imum and maximum spot selling rates are 34 of 1 per cent and W* per cent above the gu id ing rate, respectively. The Central Bank of the Philippines, which is not governed by the Association's trading rules, makes its own purchases and sales of foreign exchange w i th in the above margins required by the Association. Neither the Central Bank nor the commercial banks quote cur- rencies other than the U.S. dollar. Interbank t r ad ing takes place at the Foreign Exchange Trading Center (FOREX ), where the Central Bank f rom t ime to t ime acts as a buyer or supplier. Administration of Control Exchange regulations are adm in is tered by the Central Bank, which issues circulars and memoranda to the authorized agent banks on the basis of policy decisions reached by the Monetary Board. Certain new foreign direct or portfolio investment in the Philippines requires the prior approval of the Board of Inves tmen ts (BO I ). Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements for outgoing payments, but all exchange proceeds f rom exports and invisibles must be obtained in Canadian dol- lars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japa- nese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U.S. dollars. Most payments and transfers to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Bank accounts denominated in pesos may be opened in the name of nonresidents, whether individual or cor- porate, without prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident accounts are permitted to be credited only with the proceeds from inward remittances of foreign exchange or convertible foreign currencies and with peso income f rom, or peso proceeds of, conversion of proper- ties (real or personal) located in the Philippines belong- ing to nonresidents. Nonresident accounts may be freely debited for peso withdrawals. However, withdrawals from nonresident accounts for transfer abroad are sub- ject to individual application with supporting evidence, and to established limits where applicable, such as in the case of emigrants. Both residents and nonresidents may under certain circumstances maintain foreign currency accounts with authorized agent banks in the Philippines (see section on Proceeds f rom Invisibles, be low). Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. Imports of certain commodities are prohibited on grounds of health, morals, and national security and those of certain others, mostly agr icu l tural commodities, for protective purposes. There are no other quantitative restrictions on imports (other than imports of go ld ); however, payment for imports of specified commodities is subject to prior approval of the Central Bank.1' 2 Such approval is granted on a case-by-case basis for commodities classified under three consumer goods cate- gories (unc lass if ied, semiunclassified, and nonessential consumer goods) or for completely knocked-down parts for automobile assembly plants. Payments for imports of certain other commodities (wheat, raw cotton, and leaf tobacco) are permitted only if they are financed through certain official credit arrangements. Any impor- ta t ion of plant, machinery, equipment, and spare parts under deferred payments arrangements with ma tu r i ty periods longer than 360 days is subject to prior approval by the Cen tral Bank. If payment terms are cash or w i th in 360 days, prior approval by the Central Bank is necessary for importation by any single importer of non- ag r icu l tu ral mach inery and equipment with an aggregate va lue in excess of US$50,000 within a calendar month, w i th the exception of ( 1) certified export-oriented firms, and (2) other importers who have obtained prescribed certification f rom the BOI. Imports from socialist or communist countries must be effected through NETRACOR, a government trad ing firm with the exception that most imports f rom the Peo- ple's Republic of China are handled by the Philippine In terna t ional Trading Corporation.3 As a method of payment, commodities may be imported against letters of credit, on a document against acceptance (D /A) basis, or under open account (O /A) arrangements. The use of the D /A and O /A procedures is l im i ted ma in ly to firms with a history of importing under these arrangemen ts prior to February 21, 1970; to producer firms established a f ter that date and expressly authorized by the Mone tary Board to import under these 1 Authorized agent banks have been instructed not to accept applica- tions for letters of credit or foreign exchange in respect of specified textile products that are subject to a moratorium. 2 Central Bank approval is required for payments for imports of cer- ta in syn the t ic fibers; certain synthetic yarns; all textile machinery and equipment; beef; ships and appurtenances thereto; and steel billets, ingots, hot-rolled coils and sheets, and other steel products listed under Commodity Group 681. 3 Early in 1976, the Central Bank informed agent banks of new procedures for import and export transactions with socialist and com- munist countries (Memorandum to Authorized Agent Banks No. 2 of Janua ry 5, 1976). 369 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES arrangements; to producer firms that are export oriented, are registered with the BOI, or are franchised utility concerns; and to such others as may be approved by the Central Bank. The use of these procedures by pro- ducer firms normally is restricted to commodities in the Essential Producer Goods category. Unless arrange- ments for such terms of credit are made, impor ts in excess of US$100 (US$500 for books and supplemen- tary readers) must be covered by letters of credit opened on or before the day of shipment. Imports financed by importers' own foreign exchange or not involving pay- men ts from the Philippines (so-called no-dollar impor ts) are allowed subject to prescribed conditions. Such per- missible no-dollar imports are exempt from the requ ire- ment of opening letters of credit. At the request of an authorized agent bank or other financial in s t i tu t ion, a firm may be "watch listed" by the Central Bank for arrears on its loan repayment comm i t- ments. A firm thus "watch listed" may not open import letters of credit without the approval of the Cen t ral Bank, which w i ll allow the open ing of letters of credit only a f ter a schedule for the repayment of overdue obligations has been agreed upon. Furthermore, it is the practice of certain authorized agent banks to require 100 per cent deposit against the opening of letters of credit for such firms, compared with 25 per cent or 50 per cent in normal cases.4 Imports into border regions by barter traders are gov- erned by Presidential Decree No. 93. Payments for Invisibles V ir tua l ly all payments to Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. In principle, all other payments are permitted, without prior approval of the Central Bank, provided that amoun ts of more than US$100 are sub- stantiated by documentary evidence regarding the pur- pose and the amount applied for. However, there are certain limits and regulations established by the Central Bank for purchases of foreign exchange for travel abroad by residents, remittances for educational expenses, ma in- tenance and expenses of dependents abroad of residents, remittances of profits, dividends, and interest, royalties, and film and other rentals (see be low ). Exchange for travel abroad is made available by authorized agent banks as follows: ( 1) US$25 a day, up to a max imum of US$750 a t r ip ( for exporters an add i t ional repre- sentation allowance of US$500) for each person for business or professional travel; (2) US$500 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Afr ica, North and South America, Australia, Europe, Japan, the Middle East, and New Zealand; and (3) US$200 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to Guam, Hong Kong, Okinawa, the Republic of China, or any other neighboring country. Foreign travel by Philippine citizens, however, is not normally permitted. * On various occasions du r ing 1975, the Bankers' Association granted specified industries either a tempo ra ry or a permanent exemption from the margin deposit requirements. 370 The fo l low ing l im i ts apply to exchange for educational expenses abroad: for studies in the Un i ted States, US$250 a mon th for living and other out-of-school expenses, plus the cost of tu i t ion, books, laboratory fees, and other school charges; for studies in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand, US$200 a mon th; and for studies in other areas, US$150 a month. Any schol- a rsh ip allowances are deducted f rom these amounts. Rem i t tances for educational expenses and student ma in- tenance abroad are allowed only to s tuden ts wo rk ing for a degree at du ly accredited colleges or universities. The fo l low ing l im i ts apply for remittances to depend- ents of residents: US$250 a mon th for each dependent l i v i ng in the Un i ted States; US$200 a mon th for each dependent l i v i ng in Aus tra l ia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand; and US$100 a mon th for each dependent l iv ing in other areas. The ma in tenance allowances for depend- ents are allowed only for close relatives under ce r ta in cond i t ions prescribed by the Central Bank. Rem i t tances of profits and dividends (net of taxes) acc ru ing to nonresidents out of net profits realized begin- n ing J anu a ry 1, 1973, are permitted in f u l l, provided that remittances are not financed f rom domestic credit resources. Profits earned and dividends declared before Janua ry 1, 1973 (wh ich had been un rem i t tab le for some t im e) may be remitted over a period of two years. Rem i t tances of royalties or ren ta ls on patents, trade- ma rk s, and copyrights are free ly permitted (net of taxes) for con trac ts registered w i th the Central Bank, provided that ( 1) the royalties do not exceed 5 per cent of the wholesale price of the commodity which is manu fac- tured locally under the royalty contract (2 per cent in the case of marketing service contracts), and (2) con- t rac ts do not exceed five-year terms and do not include restrictions on the export of the product. Remittances of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion- p ic ture films and rentals on television films are freely permitted, provided generally that the shares or rentals do not exceed 60 per cent of net proceeds f rom films. Foreign exchange w i th in the above limits may be purchased, w i thout prior approval of the Central Bank, for current paymen ts for invisibles administratively withheld prior to November 26, 1969. Applications for certain invisibles for which no basic allowance has been set are considered on their merits by the Central Bank. No person may take out or export from the Philip- pines foreign currency or any other foreign exchange except as authorized by the Central Bank. Residents may take out, as part of their travel allowance, up to US$100 in foreign banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any amount of foreign currency that they had previously brought in and declared, minus any amoun ts converted into pesos. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers require prior authorization f rom the Cen- tral Bank to take out more than P 500 in domestic notes and coins or checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos. Citizens of the Philippines and permanent resident aliens, when traveling abroad, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution must pay a travel tax of P 400 for first-class ship or airplane tickets or P 300 for any other ticket. Exempt are, among others, foreign diplomatic staff and Filipino Muslims making their first pilgrimage to Mecca. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia and South A f r ica are pro- hibited. Exports of certain strategic materials and items deemed essential for indus tr ia l iza t ion and economic development are also prohibited. Otherwise, exports are generally not restricted, but they are regulated to ensure that the fore ign exchange proceeds are surrendered to an authorized agent of the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks issue the necessary export permits upon registra- tion of the exporter's report of foreign sales (except export permits for gold, which are issued by the Central B ank ); reports of foreign sales for copra, coconut oil, and sugar-based commodities, however, are approved for registration only by the Central Bank. Registration of sales of sugar-based commodities requires prior clear- ance by the Depar tment of Trade. Authorized agent banks must sell to the Central Bank 10 per cent of their exchange receipts f rom export bills.5 As a general rule, no commodity may be exported unless it is covered by a d ra ft drawn in one of the prescribed currencies and unless collection of the pro- ceeds w i ll be unde r taken by an authorized agent b ank; however, payment by means of telegraphic t ran s fe r, check, or mail t ran s fer may be allowed. Payments for exports on a cash, collection, or consignment basis must be arranged through an authorized agent bank, which must specifically contract with the exporter to buy the exchange proceeds. No sh ipment of exports will be allowed by the customs unless a certificate is issued by a bank stating that payment has been received or arranged by the bank. Proceeds f rom exports must be received in the prescribed currencies w i th in 60 days f rom the date of shipment (or w i th in such period as may be established in special cases) and surrendered to the agent bank within 3 business days of receipt. An irrevocable letter of credit is required for all exports of scrap metals, copra, and coconut oil, and for all exports to Guam, Hong Kong, the Republic of China, Indonesia, and Japan. Exports of perishable commodities to Hong Kong require prepayment. Under an "export deduction" scheme, export-oriented industries are allowed, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, to use a part of their export proceeds for the repayment of the loans obtained for their imports of machinery, equ ipmen t, raw materials, and other requirements. An export tax is levied on the f.o.b. value of major exports. The rate is 6 per cent for copra and cen tr ifugal sugar; 4 per cent for gold, molasses, coconut oil, dessi- cated coconut, iron ore and concentrates, chromite ore and concentrates, copra meal or cake, unmanu fac tu red 5 With effect f rom March 30, 1976 this requ irement was revoked. PHILIPPINES abaca, unmanu fac tu red tobacco, canned pineapples, shrimps and prawns, bunker fuel oil, bananas, cement clinker, por t land cement, and petroleum pitch and residues; and 2 per cent for copper ore and copper concentrates. However, the export taxes on copper ore and copper concentrates and cement are suspended. Cer- ta in trad i t ional export commodities are subject to pre- m ium export duties; those on copper ore, copper concen- trates, and cement are suspended. The Philippine Exchange Company has a monopoly over the export of sugar. Export trade with socialist and commun ist countries authorized under Executive Order No. 384 is handled through NETRACOR, with the excep- tion that most exports to the People's Republic of China are hand led by the Philippine International Trading Corporation. Exports to the People's Republic of China require the prior approval of the Department of Trade. Exports f rom border regions by barter traders are governed by Presidential Decree No. 93. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles must be sold within three business days by the recipient to an authorized agent bank. Ph i l ipp ine nationals employed abroad are permit- ted to open U.S. dollar deposit accounts with the Central Bank or authorized agent banks, in which they may re ta in any U.S. dollars they remit to the Philippines. To be eligible for credit to such accounts at the Central Bank, earn ings must be transferred through Philippine diplomatic or consular establishments. Under a foreign currency deposit scheme, inward remittances by resi- dents or nonresidents of fore ign currencies for deposit in numbered foreign currency accounts are exempt from surrender requirements, provided that the remittances neither represent current earnings or income of residents nor payments by nonresidents pursuant to contractual obligations. Balances in such accounts are freely trans- ferab le abroad. Travelers may freely bring in any amount of foreign currency and up to P 500 in domestic notes and coins and checks, money orders, and other bills of exchange drawn in pesos, of which not more than P 50 may consist of Ph i l ipp ine coins. Capital All inward and outward capital movements, with the exception of certain bank ing operations and certain transactions related to financing of international trade (see be low), are subject to the prior and specific approval of the Central Bank. V ir tua l ly all payments and t rans fe rs to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. For the purpose of the approval of new inward foreign investments (in kind or in cash) as well as new foreign borrowings, preference is given to projects approved by the BOI, export-oriented industries, and other (nonexport-oriented) industries not utilizing domes- tic credit resources. The law guarantees full repatria- tion of cash investments made af ter March 15, 1973 in ( a) export-oriented industries that have been certified by 371 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES the Central Bank, (b) enterprises registered w i th the BOI, and (c) securities certified by the Central Bank and traded on the Manila and Makati stock exchanges. M in imum repatriation periods, however, are prescribed; thus, foreign investors must hold securities for at least 90 days before the proceeds become eligible for repatriation. Foreign direct cash investments made after March 15, 1973 and registered with the Central Bank are freely repatriable, except investments in domestic commercial banks, which if made after March 31, 1973, are freely repatriable and if made before that date are repatriable according to the schedule in (4) below. There are certain restrictions on sales of foreign exchange for the repatriation of foreign direct cash investments made before March 16, 1973 and noncash investments made after March 15, 1973, depending on the category of industry where the investment is made, as follows: ( 1) export-oriented industries certified by the Central Bank —repatriable in fu ll but no annual installment to exceed the applicant's share in the net foreign exchange earnings of the firm in the preceding year; (2) enterprises registered with the BOI, producing import substitutes or exports but not included in ( 1) above —repatriable in three equal annual installments starting one year after the liquidation of investment, but no annual ins ta l lment to be more than total net foreign exchange earnings in the preceding year; (3) enterprises registered with the BOI, not included in (2) above and not u t i l iz ing domestic credit resources —in four equal annu al install- ments starting one year after liquidation of investments; (4) rema in ing industries —repatriation according to the following schedule: US$0.25 million or less, five equal annual installments after liquidation; US$0.25-0.5 mil- lion, seven equal annual installments after liquidation; and over US$0.5 million, nine equal annual installments a f ter liquidation. During the period between the date of investments and repatriation, liquidation proceeds may be reinvested, subject to approval by the Central Bank, in foreign currency deposits under Circular No. 343, government securities, or shares of stock in export- oriented industries registered with the BOI or certified by the Central Bank. Without prior Central Bank approval, commercial banks may not receive credit from abroad other than credit arising from normal in terna t ional trade transac- tions. They may, however, freely accept f rom nonresi- dents of foreign nationality deposits in nine scheduled currencies (Canadian dollars, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. do l lars); such deposits are freely repatriable at the prevailing exchange rate and are exempt from the 35 per cent withholding tax. Nonbank residents may obtain suppliers' credits from abroad provided that repayment terms are within the limits prescribed by the Central Bank. The maturity may not be less than 5 years for amounts up to US$250,000 (with certain exceptions), not less than 8 years for 372 amounts between US$250,000 and US$500,000, and not less than 12 years for amoun ts greater than US$500,000. For export industries, amounts exceeding US$500,000 are approved if the credit has a maturity of at least 8 years, inclusive of a 3-year grace period on repayment of principal; and for amounts less than US$150,000, 3- or 4-year ma tur i t ies may be permitted depending on the amount of credit and the type of export industry. Interest rates may not be more than 1 Vi per cent above the prime rate of the lending country. Applications are not approved if the proposed project expands capacity in an indus t ry deemed to be overcrowded, or for firms which are in arrears with government financial institu- tions. Sales of foreign exchange for amortization of loans are permitted in accordance with the terms of loan contracts approved by the Central Bank. The same applies for loan contracts registered with the Central Bank prior to November 26, 1969. For those not fall- ing under these two categories, prior approval by the Central Bank is required for sales of foreign exchange for repayment of loans. The Management of External Debt and Investment Accounts Department in the Cen- tral Bank ma in ta ins a comprehensive record of credit taken up abroad by the public and private sectors. Emigrants may repatriate up to US$5,000, subject to ver if ica t ion by the Central Bank. The remaining liquid assets may be w i thdrawn in five years beginning one year from emigration. Except as otherwise specifically authorized, resident persons, firms, or corporations may not enter into any contract or transaction which may involve settlement in fore ign exchange, or involving any assets belonging to them expressed in foreign currencies or payable or deliverable abroad. This restriction also applies to con- trac ts or transactions involving assets within the Philip- pines belonging to a nonresident person, firm, or cor- poration, and to their exportation or importation. Detailed regulations are in force concerning transactions in securities between residents and nonresidents. Under the Investment Incentives Act of 1967, all investors in enterprises registered with the BOI are guaranteed the right to repatriate their investments, and to rem it earnings thereon and sums needed to meet pay- ments of principal and interest on foreign loans; they are also guaranteed freedom from expropriation and requisition. There are d i f fe rent arrangements for "pio- neer investments" and "preferred investments"; the fo rmer are granted certain incentives over and above those given to preferred investments. Normally, enterprises owned or controlled by for- eigners are permitted to operate only in "pioneer areas of investment ," and normally at least 60 per cent of the outstanding voting capital stock of registered enter- prises in "preferred areas of investment" (ma in ly invest- ments related to the exploitation of export-oriented natural resources and the manufacturing of import substitutes) must be owned by Philippine nationals. By virtue of the Laurel-Langley Agreement, U.S. citizens, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution corporations, and associations were given the same status for this purpose as Philippine citizens until July 1974. Under the Foreign Investment Law of 1968, new enterprises in which investment by non-Filipinos exceeds 30 per cent and which are not covered by the Investment Incentives Act must obtain prior au thor i ty f rom the BOI in order to engage in any economic activity in the Philip- pines. If purchases of shares of common stock by for- eign nationals would reduce Philippine ownership in a firm to less than 70 per cent, permission f rom the BOI must first be obtained. Gold Producers of gold may be eligible for assistance under the Gold Indus t ry Assistance Act (Repub l ic Act No. 3089, as amended by Republic Act No. 6364 of August 5, 1971 ), irrespective of whether this gold is a by-product or the principal or only product of their operations. However, gold producers who wish to take advantage of the floating exchange rate (the "guiding rate") in lieu of the subsidy must export their gold production. Exports of gold (as principal produc t) are subject to an export tax of 4 per cent. Pr imary gold producers may sell the ir production, in the form of refined standard bars, to authorized gold dealers of the Central Bank or retain it abroad for their own account for sale either to other authorized gold dealers or in the free market abroad. Purchases by authorized gold dealers f rom pr imary producers are based on current London market prices (as quoted in U.S. dollars, multiplied by the interbank gu id ing rate on the date of sa le ); sales by authorized gold dealers or primary producers in the free market abroad must be settled in "acceptable'' foreign currencies. Residents other than the monetary authorities, authorized gold dealers, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase gold abroad in any form other than jewelry. A gold coin w i th a face value of P 1,000 has been issued which is legal tender. This coin may be imported freely by travelers as well as resident physical or jur id i- cal persons. With this exception, imports and exports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not nor- mally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the mone tary authorities and indus tr ial users. Changes during 1975 January 1. The export tax on copper ore and copper concentrates was reduced f rom 6 per cent to 2 per cent (Executive Order No. 443 of December 26, 1974). January 3. Payments for imports of synthetic yarns and certain synthetic fibers became subject to prior approval by the Central Bank, irrespective of the method of payment (MAAB No. 1 ). Approval became depen- dent on the purchase f rom local producers of specified percentages of total purchases. January 24. Agreements or contracts relating to the rendering of nontrade services by residents to nonresi- PHILIPPINES dents henceforth had to be notified to the Central Bank w i th in five days af ter execution. The foreign currency proceeds were not eligible for deposit under Circular No. 343 (Circular Le t te r ). January 24. All foreign exchange received by agents or branches of foreign shipping or airline companies in the Philippines as advances from their head offices or principals for use in their operations had to be reported to the Central Bank w i th in five days from receipt (Circular Le t te r ). January 24. With exceptions for four specified banks, all authorities previously granted to banks to accept government deposits were withdrawn. As a corollary, no bank or nonbank financial intermediary could, without the prior approval of the Monetary Board, borrow funds f rom the Government or from government-owned or government-controlled corporations (Circular No. 446). February 4. The Central Bank made forward exchange cover available for imports of wheat. Such cover was granted for imports of fertilizer on March 7. February 6. The Central Bank announced that over- seas Filipinos re tu rn ing to the Philippines could avail themselves of the foreign currency deposit scheme under Circular No. 343 and re-export the foreign exchange deposited if they returned to their domicile overseas. February 21. The sale, transfer, or assignment of sugar by any planter, miller, central, or refinery to any other person or entity except the Philippine National Bank or the Philippine Exchange Company was declared illegal (Presidential Decree No. 659). March 21. Exports of copper ore and copper concen- tra tes were freed f rom export tax and premium export du ty (Execu t ive Order No. 450). March 21. Exports of cement were freed f rom export tax and prem ium export duty (Executive Order No. 451). March 21. Banks were prohibited f rom accepting for- eign currency deposits under Circular No. 343 when funded by foreign currency notes or coins offered by any person or firm in the Philippines, including Filipinos re tu rn ing f rom abroad (Circular Le t ter). April 21. The regulations governing remittances of profits and dividends and the repatriation of foreign capital were modified. Cash dividends and proceeds of sale of stock dividends accruing on foreign cash invest- ments in Philippine securities registered pursuant to Circular No. 365 could be reinvested in other Philippine securities listed on domestic stock exchanges and regis- tered under the provisions of that Circular. Pending the reinvestment or repatriation, the monies concerned had to be lodged either with the selling security dealer or in a suspense account w i th an agent bank, at the option of the fore ign investor (MAAB No. 29 ). Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Hate System The par value is 0.0309103 gram of fine gold per Portuguese Escudo. A central rate of Esc 25.50 = US$ 1 has been established, and Portugal avails itself of wider margins. Since March 19, 1973, however, no announced margins have been observed and all spot transactions between the escudo and foreign currencies take place at fluctuating rates. The parity for the Macao pataca is Esc 5.015 = P 1. On December 31, 1975 the authorized banks' buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were Esc 27.244 and Esc 27.472, respec- tively, per US$1. Neither the Bank of Portugal nor the commercial banks charge buying and selling commis- sions but there is a tax of 0.15 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange.1 For settlements with countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements,2 the U.S. dollar rate applies to transactions in "agreement dollars." Authorized banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal. They are also normally allowed to deal in foreign exchange with banks abroad at the rates prevailing in the Portuguese foreign exchange market, but they are not expected to solicit such trans- actions in foreign markets and may be required to jus t ify the amounts of their sales of escudos to non- residents. They are not allowed to buy and sell foreign exchange among themselves, or to enter into arbitrage operations in foreign markets. In dealing with their customers, the authorized banks buy and sell foreign exchange in convertible currencies for their own ac- count; their purchases and sales of bilateral agreement currencies are made for the account of the Bank of Portugal. Purchases and sales of unquo ted currencies can only be made through an authorized bank acting on a commission basis. Banks are required to obtain the prior approval of the Bank of Portugal to accept deposits in foreign currencies from residents or non- residents and to obtain short-term credits abroad. The banks may use their foreign exchange holdings for all authorized purposes, but the Ministry of Finance may set limits on their foreign exchange resources and in certain circumstances may require that foreign exchange assets be sold to the Bank of Portugal; since Decem- ber 31, 1971, the net foreign asset positions of the authorized banks have been subject to ceilings, and since May 31, 1972 their gross foreign exchange hold- ings have been subject to ceilingL. iThe currencies dealt with in the official exchange market and quoted by the Bank of Portugal are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwe- gian kroner, pounds sterling, South African rand, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 The only bilateral payments agreement is maintained with Israel. Settlements with Greece and Turkey, however, are also channeled through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. 376 Capital held abroad by residents in the form of for- eign exchange that is not subject to surrender require- ments may be transferred to other residents through authorized commercial banks at official rates of ex- change. Decree-Law No. 44699 of 1963 forbids direct transactions in foreign exchange between residents other than authorized banks. There is no forward exchange market, but authorized banks may enter into forward transactions with indi- vidual customers; the exchange rates may not be higher than the spot buying rate or lower than the spot selling rate of the same date, but the size of the commission is not prescribed. The commercial banks may cover open positions by entering into swap transactions with the Bank of Portugal. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portugal on behalf of the Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Trade control policy is formulated by the Directorate- General of Foreign Commerce in the Ministry of For- eign Trade. This Directorate-General also administers the trade controls; import and export licenses ("bulle- tins") are issued by its Foreign Trade Division, or by other executive departments duly authorized. All im- ports valued at over Esc 5 million and all exports valued at over Esc 2.5 million are subject to prior authorization by the Foreign Trade Control Committee; this screening is intended only to prevent overinvoicing and under- invoicing. Practically all foreign trade transactions are subject to registration with the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Prescription of Currency Transactions with countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements may be settled in any of the currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal (see footnote 1 ), or, for Portuguese exports, in escudos to the debit of a Demand Foreign Account in Escudos (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low). Trans- actions with Greece, Israel, and Turkey are settled through clearing accounts maintained in U.S. dollars. Payments to nonresidents may be made by crediting escudos to a nonresident account, subject to prior ap- proval by the Bank of Portugal. Nonresident Accounts The ma in categories of nonresident accounts are described below. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of per- sons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution arrangements: These accounts are divided into (1) "Time Foreign Accounts in Escudos," for which the opening, debiting, and crediting are subject to special advance authorization of the Bank of Portugal, and (2) "De- mand Foreign Accounts in Escudos," which may be opened, debited, and credited without prior authoriza- tion of the Bank of Portugal for (a) payments for transactions expressed in escudos and duly authorized in that currency, for imports and exports of goods, services, and capital between metropolitan Portugal and foreign countries,3 (b) purchases or sales of escudos against the foreign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal,4 (c) purchases or sales of foreign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal against escudos, and (d) transfers between these accounts. For all other debit and credit operations, authorization of the Bank of Portugal is required. The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the above accounts, requires the authorization of the Bank of Portugal and for amounts exceeding Esc 50 million with a ma tur i ty exceeding one year the approval of the Ministry of Finance is also required. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of per- sons resident or domiciled in countries w i th which Por- tugal has bilateral payments agreements or arrange- ments: These accounts are opened, debited, and credited according to instructions issued by the Bank of Portugal. Special accounts in escudos have been established to which Portuguese banknotes must be credited which have been presented by foreign correspondents and are in excess of the amounts that may be credited to De- mand Foreign Accounts in Escudos. These accounts may be debited only for payments in escudos to resi- dents, subject to the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. There are also provisions for resident and nonresident accounts in foreign currencies, but these accounts are of limited importance. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain products are prohibited, mainly for reasons of health, public order, and the prevention of commercial fraud. Any physical or juridical entity may be an importer; importers must have an import entitlement and must pay income taxes regularly. Prior registration (in the form of a "bulletin") is required for all imports valued at over Esc 25,000. Almost all imports from all sources are effected on the basis of "bulletins." For imports free of quantitative restriction, the bulletin serves a statistical purpose and enables the importer to obtain the necessary foreign exchange as specified in the bulletin. For imports sub- ject to restriction, the bulletin is equivalent to an import license (but for imports valued at over Esc 5 million 3 The Bank of Portugal generally authorizes such payments in escudos. * Sales of escudos are subject to the proviso that the commercial bank concerned may be required to in fo rm the Bank of Portugal of the nature of the transaction for which escudos are requ ired. Purchases of Portuguese banknotes are subject to special, restrictive rules. PORTUGAL prior authorization must be obtained from the Foreign Trade Control Committee). The validity of the bulletin is normally 180 days, but extensions are often granted. Baggage and imports of merchandise whose value does not exceed Esc 25,000 do not require a bulletin, pro- vided they are not expressly excluded f rom this exemp- tion. Payments for imports already cleared through customs require the approval of the Bank of Portugal when made after the validity of the bulletin. Payments beyond one year after customs clearance always require the approval of the Bank of Portugal. Goods not on the negative list may be imported freely from most countries that are members of the GATT. The negative list includes certain foodstuffs, other agricultural prod- ucts, certain na tural or manufactured raw materials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished products, including motor vehicles; the items on the list are subject to quantitative restrictions for protective reasons or under special regimes. A somewhat more extensive negative list applies to Japan. The GATT liberalization does not apply to Ghana and Nigeria; imports from these GATT members of goods liberal- ized if imported from other GATT countries are subject to individual authorization, which is granted on the merits of the case. Nonliberalized imports from countries that are GATT members are admitted either under global or bilateral quotas or under individual authorization. All imports from countries that are not members of the GATT are based on individual authori- zations; imports from some Eastern European countries are generally licensed in accordance with bilateral agreements. There are a few bilateral quotas for specified agricul- tural imports from certain EFTA countries. Imports of nonliberalized industrial products, except for certain protected steel products and automobiles, are free of quantitative restriction when originating in EFTA or EEC countries. Special legislation provides that auto- mobiles must be assembled in Portugal. Imports of passenger automobiles of EFTA origin are allowed up to 150 units a year for each producer, while those of non-EFTA origin are allowed up to 15 units a producer a year for those makes not assembled in Portugal and, for other makes, up to 2 per cent of the number of passenger automobiles of the same make that were assembled in Portugal in the preceding year. Imports of some makes of EEC origin are allowed up to 75 units a year for each producer. Imports of commercial vehi- cles for special purposes are free of restrictions. Imports of completely knocked-down vehicles from EFTA and EEC countries are free of restrictions, and allocations for imports from other GATT countries are available under special open licenses, subject to the use of certain m in imum percentages of domestic components. Many imports are subject to a temporary import surcharge of 20 per cent or 30 per cent of the customs value, irrespective of origin. 377 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL Payments for Invisibles Payments to foreign countries for current invisibles must be made through authorized banks and are gen- erally free of quantitative restrictions, but for most transactions ceilings are specified for amounts of foreign exchange that authorized banks may grant freely. For payments to countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements, the authorized banks may grant foreign exchange up to the equivalent of Esc 30,000 a transaction for most types of invisibles, including income on imported capital. For tourism and other private travel they may grant to persons 18 years of age or over the equivalent of Esc 20,000 a person a year (the equivalent of Esc 13,000 for persons between 12 and 18, and the equivalent of Esc 7,000 for children under 12). For payments to countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements, the author- ized banks may effect freely payments for other current invisibles listed in the respective payments agreements. Application must be made to the Bank of Portugal for exchange for payments of items not referred to above and for payments in excess of the above-mentioned limits. Travelers may not take out more than Esc 1,000 in domestic banknotes. Resident travelers may take out foreign currency up to the amount of their travel allow- ance, and nonresident travelers up to the equivalent of Esc 5,000; however, the latter may take out any larger amount for which proof of prior importation is sub- mitted, subject to deduction of the equivalent of Esc 700 for each day spent in Portugal. The export of higher amounts of domestic or foreign currency requires the prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal. Exports and Export Proceeds Prior registration is required for all exports valued at over Esc 25,000. Exports and re-exports are effected on the basis of "bulletins" (similar to the import bulle- t ins ). Exports valued at over Esc 2.5 million require prior authorization by the Foreign Trade Control Com- mittee. Export bulletins are issued freely, with few exceptions; the primary purpose of this procedure is to enforce the prescription of currency and surrender regu- lations. The export of a few domestically produced goods is restricted, mainly to assure adequate supplies to domestic industries and to avoid depletion of local resources. Baggage and exports and re-exports of mer- chandise whose value does not exceed Esc 25,000 do not require a bulletin, provided they are not expressly excluded from this exemption. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank, within the period stipulated in the export bulletin, the total amount of the export proceeds, in the foreign currency indicated in the bulletin. The Bank of Portu- gal may, however, authorize the deduction of commis- sion expenses abroad, and freight, insurance, or other charges pertaining to exports, from the total amount of the export proceeds subject to surrender. 378 Proceeds from Invisibles Portuguese residents may receive freely payments up to Esc 500,000 for invisibles from residents of countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements. Also, payments from residents of countries with which Portugal does have payments agreements may be received freely for invisibles listed in the pay- ments agreements. Receipts on account of all other invisibles require authorization by the Bank of Portugal, which is granted without restriction once the proposed operation proves to be real and licit. Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Nonresident travelers may bring in freely up to Esc 1,000 in domestic banknotes and any amount in foreign banknotes and coins for their travel expenses; imports of notes and coins by nonresidents for other purposes require authorization from the Bank of Portu- gal, and the re-export by nonresident travelers of foreign currency in excess of Esc 5,000 requires proof of prior importation of a larger amount and is subject to deduc- tion of the equivalent of Esc 700 for each day spent in Portugal. Returning residents may also bring in any amount up to Esc 1,000 in domestic banknotes and any amount in foreign banknotes and coins. Authorized banks are not permitted to receive or to pay domestic or foreign banknotes or coins for the settlement of ex- ternal transactions. Capital All capital movements between Portugal and foreign countries require prior approval by the Bank of Portu- gal; for transactions in excess of Esc 50 million whose ma tur i ty exceeds one year, the approval of the Minister of Finance is also required. Foreign investments in Portugal by residents of coun- tries that are members of or associated with the Orga- nization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD ), EFTA, IMF, or the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) are autho- rized freely if they involve activities that are of recog- nized interest for Portugal's development and provided that no speculative operation in real estate is involved. Certain activities, however, are reserved for enterprises having a majority of Portuguese capital (including de- fense, public utilities, oil refining, and fishing), and no new foreign investment is allowed in defense-related activities, banking and finance, the news media, and the electricity sector. Furthermore, Decree No. 393/70 specifies certain industries in which any domestic or foreign investment is subject to prior authorization. The transfer abroad of the full proceeds from the liquidation of foreign investment which originated in a bona fide inward capital movement from member countries of the OECD, EFTA, IMF, or IBRD is authorized without restriction. Foreign credits from OECD countries with a maturity of up to five years are liberalized when a Portuguese resident participates in the underlying commercial or ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution service transaction. The acceptance of other foreign credits is normally permitted. The repayment of foreign credits and loans that originated in a bona fide inward capital movement is always authorized. Investments in foreign countries by residents of Por- tugal are authorized only when the capital involved is not considered indispensable for the national economic development. In practice, authorization is granted only for small investments and for the improvement or en- largement of existing Portuguese investments. Residents of Portugal may reinvest in securities, within time limits fixed by the authorities, the proceeds of the sale of other securities in an OECD country. They may also transfer such proceeds to other residents, provided that the proceeds do not belong to a Portu- guese credit institution and that their owner is not under an obligation to surrender them to such an institution. Arbitrage operations in foreign securities carried out by residents of Portugal involving two other OECD coun- tries or between Portugal and an OECD country are authorized freely; but if a transfer of foreign exchange to or from Portugal is involved, prior authorization is required. Transfers by Portuguese nationals or by foreigners resident in Portugal who emigrate to any other OECD country are authorized automatically up to Esc 100,000 annually for a family and larger amounts may be granted on the merits of the case. Transfers by foreign nationals who have been resident in Portugal are authorized on the merits of the case when they return to their country of origin. Transfers on account of fam i ly loans, bequests, inheritances, and dowries to other OECD countries are usually authorized automatically up to Esc 500,000; for higher amounts, annual transfers up to Esc 500,000 are authorized. For bequests and inheritances, the legator or the deceased person must have been a resident of Portugal and the legatee or heir a resident of an OECD country at the time of death. Transfers to OECD countries in respect of life insur- ance policies due from Portuguese insurers are autho- rized in favor of the beneficiary when their value does not exceed Esc 500,000 for a capital sum, a reduced value, or an annuity certain, and Esc 50,000 for a surrender value. Capital movements and transfers of assets in excess of the limits mentioned, or not enumerated in the pre- ceding paragraphs, or involving countries other than those mentioned above, are authorized on the merits of each case. The net foreign asset positions of authorized banks must not exceed 5 per cent of their current liabilities in domestic currency. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold in any form in Portugal. The purchase or sale of coined or un- coined gold, when carried out between metropolitan PORTUGAL Portugal and foreign countries, is subject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal when- ever a resident of metropolitan Portugal takes part in the transaction or has an interest in it. The import, export, or re-export of coined or uncoined gold is also subject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Import authorizations for industrial gold are granted only to commercial banks and the Associa- tion of Industrial Users of Gold. Domestic sales of gold and of gold coins that are not legal tender are subject to a transaction tax of 20 per cent.5 There is a free market for gold in Macao, in which both residents of Macao and nonresidents who are not resident in Portugal may freely trade among themselves in bars, leaves, and coins; settlement must take place in patacas or U.S. dollars. In Macao, the Government sets overall limits for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry; authority to carry out such imports is delegated to a concessionary enterprise for a two-year period. Imports and exports of gold, unless made by or on behalf of the Macao monetary authorities, require licenses issued by the Commissioner for Economy. Changes during 1975 January 1.
