Not for Redistribution QATAR (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System l The par value is 0.186621 gram of fine gold per Qatar Riyal. The currency is pegged to the SDR and Qatar avails itself of wider margins. The Qatar Mone- tary Agency buys and sells sterling at no more than V2 of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate for sterling, which is determined on the basis of the sterling/SDR rate. The commercial banks' exchange rates for currencies other than sterling are based on Qatar's rates for sterling and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against sterling. Qatar formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, with effect from June 4, 1973. Administration of Control The Qatar Monetary Agency is the exchange control authority, but there is at present no exchange control legislation in Qatar. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy and Commerce. Prescription of Currency Qatar has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under cur- rent U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. No other prescription of currency require- ments are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by resi- dents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, and alcoholic beverages, firearms, ammu- nition, and certain drugs are subject to licensing for rea- sons of health, morals, or security. Otherwise, imports into Qatar are not restricted. There are no restrictions on payments for permitted imports. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Otherwise, all commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be 1With effect from January 15, 1976, Qatar maintained exchange rates for the Qatar riyal within marg ins somewhat wider than 2V4 per cent but not exceeding IV* per cent. repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely regardless of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments must not be made to or received from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Otherwise there are no limitations on payments for and proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents, although payments must not be made to or received from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. For- eign participation in certain industrial enterprises is prohibited unless Qatar nationals control at least 51 per cent of the shares. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of customs duty or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa, however, are prohibited. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Romanian Leu has been estab- lished with the Fund. The leu is officially defined as equivalent to 0.148112 gram of fine gold, yielding official rates as at December 31, 1975 of lei 4.97 per U.S. dol- lar and lei 6.67 per ruble. There is no exchange market. The National Bank of the Socialist Republic of Romania quotes official rates also for certain other currencies. Quotations for the 16 currencies defined as "freely con- vertible" l (except those for the U.S. dollar itself) and for the Finnish markka, the Greek drachma, the Spanish peseta, and the Yugoslav dinar are based on their rates against the U.S. dollar in the countries concerned; for the U.S. dollar and for inconvertible currencies, exchange rates are based either on the gold content against the leu or on the ratio between the currency concerned and the leu through the official rate against a third currency. For exchange rate purposes, payments for insurance and transportation connected with trade are considered as trade transactions. With the exception of capital transactions, nontrade transactions with countries other than the socialist countries listed in footnote 2 are car- ried out at the official rate plus a premium of 141.45 per cent, resulting in a rate of lei 12.00 per US$1; the sale of exchange at this rate to Romanian citizens for private use is subject to an additional service charge. Some trade transactions are subject to a price, equali- zation system. Excluded from this system are imports of machinery and equipment, complex equipment, assem- blies and sub-assemblies, and spare parts, the domestic delivery prices of which are determined by converting the foreign price into lei at a customs valuation coeffi- cient, to which customs duties are added. For consumer goods a similar calculation is made; their domestic prices are fixed, and any difference between these prices and those resulting from the calculation is reflected in the profits of the importing enterprise. For all other imports (basic raw materials and certain other less important production goods) and for all exports, the price equali- zation system applies. The equalization system is designed to eliminate the effect on the earnings of export- ers and importers of the differences between domestic prices and foreign prices converted into lei at a uniform settlement coefficient of lei 20 per US$1. For nontrade transactions with some socialist coun- tries 2 exchange rates are established by special agree- ments; for transactions with the U.S.S.R. this rate is lei 8.30 per ruble. An accounting rate of lei 20 per U.S. dollar is used for the payment and repayment of 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Luxembourg francs, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 Listed as Albania, Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, D.R. of Ger- many, Hungary, P.R. of China, Mongolia, D.P.R. of Korea, D.R. of Viet-Nam, Poland, and U.S.S.R. 382 foreign loans taken up or granted by the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, other official bodies, and Romanian enterprises. Administration of Control Foreign trade is a state monopoly. Import and export transactions are effected by authorized industrial cen- trals, producing enterprises, and foreign trade enter- prises. Foreign trade units have autonomy in selecting their foreign partners and operate on a trade criteria basis, taking into account prices, quality, delivery and payment conditions, etc. Import and export transactions are subject to authorizations granted by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and International Economic Cooperation. In the issuing of authorizations, both the provisions of existing trade agreements and criteria of economic effi- ciency are taken into account. Foreign currency pro- ceeds from exports are sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade; foreign currency required for import payments is purchased from that Bank. Exchange con- trol is administered by the National Bank and the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Prescription of Currency . Payments to and from countries with which Romania has bilateral payments agreements are made in curren- cies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.3 If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Permitted for- eign payments may not be made in lei, and the import and export in any form of Romanian notes and coins are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts with the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade or with the National Bank. Neither justification nor authorization is required to open such accounts, except for foreign economic organizations and agencies, which have to show evidence of permission to operate in Romania. These accounts are of three kinds: A-Accounts are maintained in convertible currency or in lei obtained for convertible currencies, gold, or other precious metals (except silver); B-Accounts are maintained in noncon- vertible currencies quoted by the National Bank, in clearing currency, or in lei received from the conversion 3 The countries with which bilateral payments arrangements were in force as of December 31, 1975 were listed as Albania, Bangladesh, Brazil, People's Republic of China, Colombia, Cuba, Cyprus, Ecuador, Egypt, Finland, Ghana, Greece, India, Iran, D.P.R. of Korea, Lebanon, Mali, and D.R. of Viet-Nam. (The bilateral payments arrangement with Algeria expired on December 31, 1975 and with effect from Janu- ary 1, 1976, settlements with that country were made in convertible currencies.) Settlements with Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, D.R. of Ger- many, Hunga ry, Mongolia, Poland, and the U.S.S.R. took place through the multilateral payments system within the International Bank for Economic Cooperation. Furthermore, certain settlements with Singa- pore also took place through special accounts. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of such currencies. Transactions in any individual B-Account may be effected in only one such currency. C-Accounts are maintained in lei received from legal sources. A-Accounts may be debited for payments abroad in any currency, for payments within the country, and for transfers to any other A, B, or C-Account. B-Accounts may be debited for all payments abroad in the curren- cies from which the funds were derived and for pay- ments within Romania. C-Accounts may be debited only for domestic transactions. The transactions permit- ted for the different accounts do not require any further authorization. Nonresidents may also keep accounts with the Savings and Consignment Bank. In addition, any bank may accept from nonresident customers time deposits in convertible foreign currencies, on which interest is paid at rates prevailing in international markets. Romanian citizens, including Romanians working abroad who transfer their savings to Romania, may open foreign currency accounts with the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade or the National Bank. The deposits may be used for payments at home or abroad, or for exchange into lei at the official rate plus premium (lei 12 per U.S. dollar). Receipts from abroad for special pur- poses for the benefit of Romanian citizens (such as the building of a house, the purchase of an automobile, the purchase of other goods or services whose prices are expressed in foreign currency, travel abroad, and educa- tion) are entirely paid out in foreign currency. In the case of certain other foreign exchange receipts from abroad, such as donations, assistance, or fam i ly mainte- nance, a proportion may be deposited in a foreign cur- rency account and the rest must be converted at the official rate plus premium. Imports and Exports The general policy targets for foreign trade are set at the central level, in accordance with the priority interests for the development of the national economy. Import and export plans are drawn up by the basic economic units, producing enterprises, and industrial centrals on the basis of current and long-term needs. After their elaboration, the plans are correlated and integrated into the single national plan, which is a synthesis of the effective production and export possibilities and of the needs for imported goods. The foreign trade plan specifies only a limited number of goods considered of particular importance for the national economy, especially raw materials. The major part of the plan is set forth as a lump sum, without being divided by importer or exporter countries but only distinguishing, according to the manner of settlement of exchange payments and receipts, between the clearing area and the convertible currency area. Import and export transactions are carried out on the basis of authorizations issued by the Ministry of For- eign Trade and International Economic Cooperation, for each commodity or group of commodities. The authori- ROMANIA zations are not restrictive or discriminatory and are issued, at the request of foreign trade units, for all types of goods, regardless of origin. The Ministry may take measures with a view to equilibrating the balance of payments, for the protection of the public health, for reasons of national defense and the security of the State, etc., in accordance with the provisions of the GATT. As a rule, annual import authorizations expressed in value terms are issued to individual importing enter- prises as a lump sum, or for a single kind of product. The authorization stipulates whether import payments are to be made in convertible currency or under bilateral payments agreements, and in the latter case the country is also specified. Export proceeds must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Invisibles All transactions in invisibles not connected with for- eign trade transactions require general or individual authorization given either by the Ministry of Finance or the competent ministry. For most categories of pay- ments in respect of invisibles, foreign exchange is made available automatically once the transaction has been authorized. For travel outside socialist countries an exchange allocation is provided up to the equivalent of US$70 a trip for each adult person for one trip a year. In addition, tourist agencies may organize group or individual trips payable in lei in amounts the equivalent of which may exceed the maximum allocations of for- eign exchange. Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, and the foreign currency required for payments in respect of such transactions is bought from the same bank. Receipts in foreign currencies from travelers are converted at lei 12.00 per US$1. Travelers with perma- nent residence in nonsocialist countries, Cuba, or Yugo- slavia must convert at least US$10 a person a day (or the equivalent in other "acceptable" currencies) during their stay in Romania. Foreign diplomats and tourists may purchase certain domestically produced or imported consumer goods in COMTURIST shops, against pay- ment in currencies of nonsocialist countries. The import and export of Romanian notes and coins by travelers is prohibited. Capital All inward and outward transfers of foreign exchange must be authorized by the Ministry of Finance. Out- ward transfers of funds belonging to resident physical persons are not normally permitted. For certain estab- lished categories, such as inheritances, reciprocal agree- ments have been concluded with a number of countries providing for automatic authorization of transfers of specified amounts to and from Romania. The Foreign Trade Law (Law No. 1 of March 1971) provides for the possibility of the establishment of joint ventures in Romania and abroad by Romanian economic organizations; under this law and enabling Decrees 383 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA Nos. 424 and 425 of 1972, foreigners are also allowed to invest capital in jo int ventures in Romania, up to 49 per cent of the total capital of the company con- cerned. The law and the decrees guarantee the repatria- tion in foreign currency of the capital and the transfer in foreign currency of profits after taxes. By agreement the accounts of joint ventures may be kept in an agreed currency. Foreign physical and juridical persons may keep in bank accounts in Romania their legally owned foreign currency or lei funds; balances in foreign exchange accounts are transferable abroad. Romanian nationals working abroad may hold their foreign currency savings in accounts opened with Romanian banks and use these funds for payments in Romania or abroad (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). Gold Only the National Bank has authority to purchase or sell gold in any manner, at home or abroad. The Bank, in turn, authorizes certain juridical persons to hold gold, to use it, and to engage in gold transactions, in accord- ance with the law. The ownership by physical persons, for domestic and personal use, of jewelry and of artistic and cultural objects of gold is not restricted. Changes during 1975 January 1. Each manu fac tu r ing enterprise would be directly responsible for its own foreign trade activities, even where these were carried out through the industrial centrals or the specialized foreign trade enterprises. Not for Redistribution RWANDA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00888671 gram of fine gold per Rwanda Franc. The central rate is RF 112 = SDR 1, and Rwanda avails itself of wider margins. The National Bank of Rwanda ( the central b ank) has established a middle rate of RF 92.84 = US$1 and quotes indicative rates for certain other currencies.1 The National Bank levies a fee (droit de dossier) for the validation of import and export licenses as well as transfer authorizations; the fee is RF 350 for import and export licenses or 2 per cent of the amount approved for transfers other than import payments. Payments by the Government and public sector agencies are exempt. Administration of Control Control over foreign exchange transactions and for- eign trade is vested in the Na t ional Bank; authority to carry out some of these transactions is delegated to authorized banks. Exchange policy and foreign trade policy are, in principle, to be determined by the General Foreign Exchange and Licensing Committee, which comprises the Minister of Finance and Economy, the Governor of the Na t ional Bank, and five other members. Prescription of Currency Settlements with Zai're are made through special accounts. Otherwise, the following applies. The U.S. dollar may be used for all payments and receipts, w i th the exception that payments to Bu rund i, Kenya, Tan- zania, and Uganda must be made in the currency of the country concerned. The Belgian f ranc may be used for all transactions with any European country. Paymen ts from any country may be received in Belgian francs, deutsche mark, French francs, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars; in addi- tion, proceeds from exports to Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda may be received in the currency of the coun try concerned. All foreign payments, except in border trade, must be made by bank transfer. Exchange transactions with Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. Imports of a few types of goods, such as nar- cotics, are prohibited f rom all sources for reasons of public policy. All imports except baggage and house- hold effects of travelers and merchandise valued up to RF 50,000 (when settled in Rwanda f r an c s) require licenses if payment is to take place in foreign exchange; these are issued freely and serve statistical purposes only. Before orders are placed, applications for import licenses for all other goods must be submitted to the National 1 Burundi francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Kenya shillings, Netherlands guilders, pounds s te r l ing, Swiss f ranc s, Tanzania shillings, Uganda shillings, and zaires. Bank through an authorized bank on a form entitled Import License and Payments Authorization (Model I ). The approval of an import license application constitutes an authorization also to obtain foreign exchange. The Na t ional Bank grants global import licenses for certain essential commodities and for specified amounts to individual firms in order to ensure their continuous operation. Licenses are examined at the National Bank only to avoid capital exports through overinvoicing and to ensure that importers (unless exceptionally authorized to do so) do not have recourse to domestic bank credit. Except as stated above, there are no restrictions as to currency of payments or permitted origin or place of shipment, but control is exercised to ensure that pay- ments are made to the supplier country. Import licenses must be presented to the customs officials when the goods are cleared through customs. The number and date of expiration must be entered on the customs clear- ance fo rm, a copy of which is then sent to the National Bank by the customs authorities. In practice, certain goods are imported ma in ly or exclusively from the Peo- ple's Republic of China. In principle, payments for imports cannot be made prior to customs clearance and must be made within the validity period of the license; however, importers are authorized to pay by means of documentary credits upon shipment if their books are kept in accordance with the accounting rules of the Common Organization of A f r i- can and Maur i t ian States. All imports are subject to a license validation fee (droit de dossier), which is RF 350 a license for most goods and 1 per cent of the value c.i.f. Kigali of the license, with a m in imum of RF 350 and a maximum of RF 5,000, for specified luxury items (Group B). Payments for Invisibles The prior approval of the National Bank is required for all payments for invisibles. Foreign exchange is sold by the Na t ional Bank, through the authorized banks, for transport, insurance, and other expenses connected with imports and exports; for transfers of the salaries or wages —after income tax and social security contribu- tions and af ter deduction of 40 per cent of net income or RF 35,000 a month, whichever is higher —of foreign nationals employed in Rwanda under contract; for transfers of the net earned income of foreign nationals who are self-employed or are engaged in a profession or established as independent traders; and for salaries of foreigners traveling abroad on leave. Payments in respect of transport charges on imports and exports cannot be made un t il imported goods have been cleared through customs or after the exchange proceeds f rom exports have been surrendered. Net profits and divi- dends due to nonresidents may in principle be remitted abroad in fu l l, subject to the right of the National Bank 385 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution RWANDA to prescribe their transfer in installments. Nonresidents may not transfer their net income from rents, except upon their final departure. Residents may freely purchase tickets for travel abroad in Rwanda francs, with the exception that the prior approval of the National Bank may be required when certain travel by persons of foreign nationality is involved. Purchases of foreign exchange for travel pur- poses are authorized on an ad hoc basis. Remittances for payments for certain other invisibles may also be authorized on an ad hoc basis. Travelers may take out domestic banknotes up to RF 5,000. Residents require authorization by the National Bank to take out foreign banknotes. Nonresi- dent travelers may take out any amount in foreign bank- notes declared upon entry minus the amount of their expenditures in Rwanda. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. All exports, except trade samples, baggage and house- hold effects of travelers, and merchandise valued at less than RF 50,000, are subject to a prior declaration entitled Declaration of Collection of Foreign Exchange (Model E ). Declarations for all exports must be pre- sented to the National Bank through an authorized bank for certification. A declaration is valid for a period of three months, but extensions may be granted by the National Bank, which also reserves the right to deter- mine the conditions for certification. For exports to Bu rund i, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zaire, payment must be collected not later than 30 days after the goods have left the country; for exports to all other countries, this period is 120 days, except for minerals shipped abroad for refining, for which the period is 180 days. All exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered to an authorized bank within 8 days from their collection. Proceeds from Invisibles All receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the authorized banks within 8 days from their collection. The collection of claims resulting f rom services per- formed for nonresidents must take place within 30 days of the date on which the claim falls due. Travelers may bring in up to RF 5,000 in domestic banknotes and any amount in foreign banknotes. Capital All outward transfers of capital require the prior approval of the National Bank. Such approval is rarely given unless the transfer relates to a foreign investment in Rwanda that is covered by the Investment Law of May 4, 1964 or to the personal effects of a foreign national returning to his own country. Retransfer guar- antees, as well as an exchange rate guarantee, may be given by the National Bank in respect of short-term capi- tal inflows rema in ing in Rwanda for at least two months; such inflows result ma in ly from swap transactions between Rwandese banks and their foreign correspond- ents. Commercial banks are not permitted to import or export domestic banknotes. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Rwanda for numismatic purposes only. With this excep- tion, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold require licenses and are normally made only by the monetary authorities. Changes during 1975 January 1. Not for Redistribution SAUDI ARABIA (Position on December 37 ,1975) Exchange Rate System On August 11, 1973, Saudi Arabia established a par value of 0.207510 gram of fine gold per Saudi Ara- bian Riyal, corresponding at the time to SRls 4.28255 = SDR 1 or SRls 3.55001 = US$1. Saudi Arabia avails itself of wider margins. Since March 15, 1975 Saudi Arabia has maintained exchange rates for the riyal on the basis of the parity of SRls 4.28255 = SDR 1; since September 9, 1975 rates have been permitted w i th in margins somewhat wider than 21A per cent but not exceeding 11A per cent. On December 31, 1975, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency's middle rate for the U.S. dollar was SRls 3.53; it sold U.S. dol- lars to banks at SRls 3.535 per US$1 and bought from banks and the principal producer of petroleum at SRls 3.525 per US$1; these rates served as the basis for exchange quotations in the market, the banks being permitted to charge up to V* of 1 per cent above and below the Monetary Agency's buying and selling rates. The Monetary Agency also sells sterling to banks. All settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited; there are no other restrictions on foreign payments. Saudi Arabia formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as from March 22, 1961. Prescription of Currency The use of the currencies of Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa is prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited f rom all sources for reasons of health or security. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are not required, and no control is exercised over export proceeds. All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and the re-export of cer- tain imported items benefiting from government sub- sidy are prohibited. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that payments must not be made to, or received f rom, Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Travelers may freely import and export Saudi Arabian banknotes and coins. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents, but payments must not be made to, or received f rom, Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents, inc lud ing private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and without payment of any customs duty or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited. Not for Redistribution SENEGAL (Position on December 57, 7975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Senegal has been established with the Fund. The unit of its currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a commission of %o of 1 per mill for transfers to other countries of the West African Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per mill for transfers to countries outside the Union. Exchange rates for foreign cur- rencies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West Afr ican Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Sene- gal's exchange control measures do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Terri- tories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Cen- tral African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Togo, and Upper Vo l ta ). Hence, all payments to these coun- tries may be made freely. All other countries, except Senegal itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of Money and Credit in the Ministry of Finance and Economic A f fa i rs, which also supervises borrowing and lending abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Senegal, inward direct invest- ment, and all outward investments. Part of the approval authority in respect of exchange control has been dele- gated to authorized banks. The BCEAO is authorized to collect, either directly or through the intermediary of banks, other financial institutions, the Postal Adminis- tration, and notaries public, any in fo rma t ion necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs (Directorate of Foreign Trade), including those for 1The CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 388 gold. Import certificates for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself. Prescription of Currency Senegal is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Certain settlements with Guinea are made through bilateral accounts established under a payments agree- ment. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. The crediting to nonresident accounts of CFA banknotes, French bank- notes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account with the French Treasury is not permitted, except for BCEAO bank- notes mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Dakar by authorized banks' foreign correspondents; such bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts opened by the latter with authorized banks in Senegal. Imports and Import Payments Imports of Rhodesian and South A f r ican origin and /or provenance are prohibited f rom any source, and the import of certain other goods is prohibited from all countries except member states of the West African Customs Union. The import f rom any source of a number of other commodities is subject to individual licensing. Imports f rom countries in the French Franc Area other than Mali are generally free of license and quan t i ta t ive restriction; some goods, although free from import license, require prior authorization by the Minis- try of Finance and Economic A f fa i rs. Imports of vir- tually all goods f rom EEC countries (the six original member states) and imports of some goods f rom all former OEEC countries, the United States, and Canada are free of quantitative restrictions; such liberalized imports require only an import certificate made out by the importer himself. There is an annual program with global quotas for imports f rom all non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area. The import program is put into effect through individual licenses, which are required for most commodities. Licenses are issued only to authorized traders and to industrial and agri- cultural producers. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 25,000 (c.i.f. or delivered at the border). The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported (if no documentary credit has been opened, on presentation of the bill of lad ing ). Furthermore, payments for imports valued at CFAF 500,000 or less (but over CFAF 15,000) cannot be made prior to cus- toms clearance. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Pay- ments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Furthermore, autho- rized banks have been empowered to effect freely any payment abroad up to CFAF 15,000 on behalf of resi- dents. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the fo rm of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 150,000 a year for each person (CFAF 75,000 for children under ten ); any foreign exchange rema in ing after return to Senegal must be surrendered. Applications for additional amounts of for- eign exchange may also be approved. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of CFAF 7,500 a day, subject to a maximum of CFAF 150,000 a person a trip, but not more than the equivalent of CFAF 15,000 may be taken out in for- eign notes. The transfer of the full net salary of a foreigner working in Senegal is permitted upon presen- tation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period; however, for Maur i tan ian nationals working in Senegal the transferable portion is limited to 50 per cent or 80 per cent, depending on fam i ly status and residence, except for leave salaries, which are transfer- able in fu l l. Resident and nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out, in addition to any foreign exchange allocation, up to CFAF 15,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West Afr ican Mone- SENEGAL tary Union, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the amount declared by them on entry (minus the amount converted in Senegal plus any amount up to CFAF 50,000 reconverted by purchase of foreign banknotes), or if no declaration has been made, up to the equivalent of CFAF 50,000; other banknotes as stated above; and any means of payment, such as travelers checks, established abroad in their name. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. With a few exceptions (e.g., gold, diamonds, tunny ), exports to countries in the French Franc Area are free of license. Most exports to other countries require licenses, mainly in order to assure adequate sup- plies for the domestic needs of Senegal and to prevent certain re-exports. Proceeds f rom exports to foreign countries must normally be collected within 120 days of the arrival of the goods at their destination. They must be surrendered by sale on the exchange market not later than one month after collection when received in a non-Franc Area currency. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 50,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other coun- tries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries f rom foreign assets, must be collected, and surrendered, if received in foreign currency, within one month of the due date or the date of receipt. Resi- dent and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Opera- tions Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign banknotes must declare them to the customs upon entry and sell them to an authorized bank within eight days. Capital All settlements between Senegal and Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Capital movements between Senegal and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained 389 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SENEGAL over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver- tising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Sene- gal; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those over foreign securities, these control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West Afri- can Monetary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investment abroad by residents of Senegal requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Eco- nomic Affairs.2 Foreign direct investments in Senegal3 must be declared to the Minister of Finance and Eco- nomic Affa irs before such investments are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postpone- ment of the projects submitted to him. Both the making and the liquidating of direct and other investments, whether these are Senegalese investments abroad or foreign investments in Senegal, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Senegal requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs. Exempt from authorization, however, are operations in connec- tion with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Senegalese Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offer- ing, or sale in Senegal has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Eco- nomic Affairs. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indi- cated above; (2) loans contracted by authorized banks; (3) loans other than those mentioned above, subject to certain conditions, when the total amount outstanding 2 Including investments made through the intermediary of foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Senegal and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of com- panies in Senegal. 3 Including those made by companies in Senegal that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or sub- sidiaries in Senegal of foreign companies. 390 of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 40 million for any one borrower. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad requires prior authorization by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs. The Investment Code of June 12, 1972 (Law No. 72-43) provides various facilities and benefits for approved foreign investments in Senegal. Law No. 74-6 of April 22, 1974 provides special facilities for export industries established in the Industrial Free Trade Zone. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Senegal. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authori- zation by the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated arti- cles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a combined weight of 200 grams. By vir- tue of Ordinance No. 60-21 of October 1, 1960, brokers in precious metals require an authorization from the Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs to conduct their business. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Purchases abroad of nonmonetary gold are subject to a tax of 25 per cent. Commercial imports of gold jewelry require prior authorization (Decree No. 65-794 of Novem- ber 19, 1965). Furthermore, imports of ornaments require the prior advice of the Senegal Office for Handi- crafts (Office Senegalais de PArtisanat) and the Direc- torate of Mines and Geology (Notice to Importers of May 17, 1971). Changes during 1975 January 8. Decree No. 75-044 empowered the Min- ister of Finance and Economic Affairs to conclude .on behalf of the Government a loan agreement for US$8.5 million with the Iranian Government. February 8. The prohibition on settlements and trade with Portugal was terminated by Decrees Nos. 75-095, 75-096, and 75-097. June 3. Decrees Nos. 75-563 and 75-564 made imports of various types of bicycles, tractors, and auto- mobiles subject to prior import authorization, irrespec- tive of origin. July 10. France resumed its participation in the Euro- pean common margins arrangement. The parity between the CFA franc and the French franc remained un- changed. December 29. Senegal informed the GATT that it had ceased to invoke Article XXXV of the General Agreement in respect of Japan. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SIERRA LEONE (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Leone. With effect from June 27, 1972, however, the leone was allowed to float with sterling. The Bank of Sierra Leone deals in sterling only and stands ready in transactions with commercial banks to buy and sell leones in exchange for sterling at the rate of Le 1 = £ stg. 0.50, subject to a max imum commission of 1 per cent on either side. The authorized banks in Sierra Leone base their rates for other currencies on the cur- rent London market rates. On December 31, 1975, the banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.01675 and US$1.00675, respectively, per Le 1. Sierra Leone avails itself of wider margins. Administration of Control Exchange control policy is made by the Ministry of Finance. The day-to-day administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Authorized commercial banks are permitted to sell exchange for permitted imports and, in small amounts, for travel expenses. The Bank of Sierra Leone has power to direct payments into Blocked Accounts. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Prescription of Currency Sierra Leone has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Transactions with Sterling Area countries as well as non-Sterling Area countries are subject to exchange control. Sierra Leone's regulations define the Sterling Area so as to include Sierra Leone and to exclude South Africa. Settlements with other Sterling Area countries usually are made in sterling or other Sterling Area currencies. Certain settlements with the People's Republic of China must be channeled through clearing accounts established under the terms of a bilat- eral payments agreement.1 Authorized payments to countries outside the Sterling Area other than the Peo- ple's Republic of China and Rhodesia, including pay- ments for imports, may be made in leones to the credit of an External Account in Sierra Leone, in sterling to the credit of an External Account in the United King- dom, or in any other foreign currency2 except Rhode- sian currency. Receipts from exports to non-Sterling Area countries other than the People's Republic of China and Rhodesia may be obtained in sterling from an Exter- nal Account in the United Kingdom, in leones from an External Account in Sierra Leone, or in any specified 1A payments agreement concluded with Guinea in 1964 is inoperative. 8 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the leone. currency3 other than a currency of the Sterling Area. Receipts from exports to Sterling Area countries may be obtained in leones from a Sterling Area Account or in any currency of the Sterling Area other than leones. Settlements with Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in leones held with authorized banks in Sierra Leone by residents of countries outside Sierra Leone other than residents of Rhodesia may be desig- nated External Accounts. Residents of Sterling Area countries may ma in ta in Sterling Area Accounts denomi- nated in leones. Rhodesian Accounts are accounts with banks in Sierra Leone conducted in the name of persons resident in Rhodesia. In addition, there are Blocked Accounts, to which are credited amounts that may not be remitted abroad and that are due to nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. With minor exceptions, all commodities from any source require individual import licenses. Imports of rice can be made only by the Rice Corporation. Foreign exchange is granted for all permit- ted imports, but not for insurance on imported goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to nonresidents require approval, which for most current transactions is given freely. Remittances of earnings by foreign nationals are limited in principle to Le 8,000 or 40 per cent of net annual wages and salaries, whichever is lower, but the Bank of Sierra Leone may permit the transfer of higher amounts. Insurance on imported goods must be taken out with insurance companies incorporated in Sierra Leone. For travel abroad, residents are entitled to a basic exchange allowance of Le 500 a person a calendar year. Applications for larger amounts are considered on an individual basis. In addition to the basic exchange allow- ance, travelers may take out, regardless of destination, Le 20 in leone notes and the equivalent of Le 50 in foreign currency notes. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign currency banknotes, including sterling notes, declared by them when entering Sierra Leone. Exports and Export Proceeds Except for a few commodities sold to certain destina- tions, exports require individual export licenses. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. 3 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 391 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SIERRA LEONE The proceeds in specified currencies (see footnote 3) of exports other than diamonds to countries outside the Sterling Area must be transferred to Sierra Leone within a month of receipt and sold to an authorized bank in Sierra Leone within six months from the date of export, unless permission to do otherwise is obtained. By virtue of Government Notice No. 57 of November 14, 1974, the proceeds from exports of diamonds and all other minerals must be obtained in the currency of the import- ing country or in any specified currency, through the account of the Bank of Sierra Leone in the importing country. The buying and exporting of diamonds is car- ried out by five locally licensed firms and by several foreign companies. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 3) must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Subject to declaration upon entry, persons enter- ing Sierra Leone may br ing in any amount of foreign banknotes. The importation of domestic banknotes is limited to Le 20 per traveler. Capital Capital payments to nonresidents of Sierra Leone are subject to exchange control. Residents of Sierra Leone require permission from the Bank of Sierra Leone to purchase foreign currency securities or real estate situ- ated outside Sierra Leone. Investments by nonresidents other than residents of Rhodesia may be repatriated at any time, together with profits, provided that exchange control permission was obtained in i t ia l ly for the invest- ment. The Sierra Leone Exchange Control Act of 1954 imposes control on the issue and t rans fer of securities. The placing of an issue in Sierra Leone requires permis- sion if either the person acqu ir ing the securities or the person for whom he is nominee is resident outside Sierra Leone. Permission must also be obtained before a security registered in Sierra Leone may be transferred to a person resident outside Sierra Leone. Capital in respect of securities registered in Sierra Leone may not be transferred outside Sierra Leone without permission. Where permission has been given for securities regis- tered in Sierra Leone to be sold to persons resident out- side Sierra Leone, the company is usually required to obtain bank certification of the funds brought into Sierra Leone to ensure that permission will not be given later for taking out appreciably more than was brought in. The Development Ordinance of 1960 provides for income tax and customs duty concessions to foreign and domestic companies undertaking industrial or agricul- tural activities that are needed for the development of the country. Noncitizens are prohibited from owning or controlling certain types of business. By virtue of Public Notice No. 50 of October 11, 1974, residents of Sierra Leone must sell to an autho- rized dealer in Sierra Leone their holdings of gold and 392 specified currency. Exemption is made for authorized dealers, diplomats, and those exempt sterling assets held prior to June 24, 1972 for which exemption has been claimed and granted by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Exempted securities may be sold outside the Sterling Area and any income therefrom may be retained in the Sterling Area or reinvested in other Sterling Area securi- ties. Any certificate of security purchased with the pro- ceeds of the sale of securities exempted under this permission is exempt from deposit requirements. Any assets held outside the Sterling Area by any foreign national temporarily resident in Sierra Leone also are exempt from surrender and deposit requirements, pro- vided exemption has been claimed and granted by an authorized dealer or by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Sierra Leone for num isma t ic purposes. Also, residents and nonresidents may freely purchase, hold, sell, or export certain Sierra Leonean gold coins issued for commemorative purposes. With these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authorities, gold pro- ducers, and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad; residents have been directed to declare and make available to the Government all gold held in the form of bars or coins. Imports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require individual import licenses. Exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Chief Inspector of Mines; such licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and local gold producers. Travelers, however, do not require a license to take out personal jewelry if the value of the total gold and plati- num content does not exceed Le 200. Exports of unworked gold are not subject to export tax. Changes during 1975 January 1. The Exchange Control (Diamond and Other Mineral Export Payments) Order, 1974 (Govern- ment Notice No. 57) came into effect. It required the proceeds of the sale of diamonds or any other minerals mined in and exported from Sierra Leone to be received by the sellers in the currency of the importing country or any other specified currency through the account of the Bank of Sierra Leone in the importing country, notified to them by the Bank of Sierra Leone. Not for Redistribution SINGAPORE (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.290299 gram of fine gold per Singapore Dollar, and Singapore avails itself of wider margins. Since June 20, 1973, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate within announced mar- gins. The closing selling and buying rates in the Singa- port foreign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were S$2.4900 and S$2.4890 per US$1, respectively, for telegraphic transfers. The authorized banks are free to deal spot and for- ward in all currencies. Forward cover for periods in excess of six months in respect of import or export transactions requires the prior approval of the Mone- tary Au thor i ty of Singapore, as does all forward cover on transactions of residents in the Asian currency market. Singapore and Brunei currency notes and coins are freely interchangeable, at par and without charge, in the two countries concerned, at the commercial banks and with the monetary authorities. Singapore formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from November 9, 1968. Administration of Control The Monetary Authority of Singapore administers exchange control. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this purpose. The Trade Division of the Ministry of Finance administers import and export controls. Prescription of Currency Singapore has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Singapore has made no changes in the list of Scheduled Territories (covering Singapore and all other Sterling Area territories) which appears in the first schedule to the Singapore Exchange Control Act.1 All payments to and from the Scheduled Territories may be made in either a Scheduled Territory currency or a specified currency.2 Certain payments to Romania must be made through special accounts. Payments to other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia may be made in Singapore dollars or another currency of the Scheduled Territories through an Exter- nal Account, or in any non-Scheduled Territory currency effect from February 4, 1976 Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand were included in the Scheduled Territories. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 394 other than Rhodesian currency. Receipts from exports to other countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia must be obtained in either Singapore dollars or another currency of the Scheduled Territories through an External Account, or in any specified cur- rency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of residents of other Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as resident accounts. The accounts of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories are treated as nonresident accounts and, unless specially restricted, are designated External Accounts. External Accounts may be credited with the proceeds of any non- Scheduled Territory currency, other than Rhodesian currency, sold to a bank in Singapore, with transfers of Singapore dollars or sterling from other External Accounts, and with funds eligible for transfer to coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories. Balances on External Accounts may be transferred to any other account, whether resident or nonresident, and may be converted into any non-Scheduled Territory currency other than Rhodesian currency. Accounts of residents of Rhodesia are designated Rhodesian Accounts. All debits and credits to such accounts require prior approval. Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports are permitted freely under open general license or specific licenses, depending on the nature and origin of the goods. A few imports are controlled for health or security reasons. All imports originating in Rhodesia, South Africa, or any territory administered by either are prohibited. Specific licenses are required for (1) rice (excluding bran) and refined sugar, irrespective of origin; (2) textile fabrics, when originating in Japan; and (3) all goods originating in, wholly or mainly manufactured in, or consigned from Albania, the People's Republic of China, Cuba, Czecho- slovakia, the German Democratic Republic, the Mon^ golian People's Republic, and North Viet-Nam. License applications for goods under (3) must be submitted through the intermediary of Intraco Ltd., which levies a surcharge of 0.5 per cent on the c.i.f. value of imports from these countries. Permission to make payments for permitted imports is readily given, provided that the prescription of cur- rency regulations are observed. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of the Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Payments related to commercial transactions and personal payments of a current nature to other countries, except Rhodesia, are ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution also permitted freely. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for payments in respect of many categories of current invisibles, either w i thout limitation or up to established limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits, or for purposes for which no delegation of authority has been granted, are approved by the Monetary Au thor i ty of Singapore, provided that no unau thor ized capital outflow is involved. There are no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange made available for travel abroad; there is a basic foreign exchange allowance equ iva lent to S$ 10,000 a person a year for travel outside the Scheduled Terri- tories and amounts in excess of this figure are allowed on application. Remittances to nonresidents of divi- dends, interest, and agreed prof i ts on all bona fide invest- ments are subject to exchange control approval, which is given freely. Unless special permission is obtained, not more than S$ 1,000 in Singapore notes and the equivalent of S$2,000 in foreign currency notes and Scheduled Territory banknotes (other than those of Singapore, Malaysia, and B run e i) may be taken out of Singapore by travelers; there is no restriction on the amount of Singapore notes, Malaysian and Brunei cur- rency notes, and currency notes issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Malaya and British Borneo, that may be taken out of Singapore by travelers going direct to Brunei or Malaysia. Travelers v i s i t ing Singa- pore may take out any amount of fo re ign currency notes and Scheduled Territory banknotes (other than those of Singapore, Malaysia, and Brune i) that was declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of certain textiles to Belgium, Denmark, France, the Fed- eral Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the Un i ted Kingdom, and the United States are subject to quantitative restric- tion. Exports of scrap metal, rice, and a few other items are restricted. Other commodities do not require an export license. Exchange control approval is required only for exports exceeding S$20,000 in value to coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories; this requirement serves to ensure that the proceeds are obtained in accordance with the provisions of the Exchange Control Act and are sold to an authorized bank, normally w i th in six months of shipment. Export proceeds up to S$3 mil- lion for each recipient in specified currencies may, however, be retained and may be used to make com- mercial current payments and any other approved pay- ments to residents and nonresidents of Singapore. Proceeds from Invisibles The exchange control requirements governing exchange receipts f rom invisibles are, in general, the same as those for export proceeds, including the facility for the reten- tion and use of up to S$3 million in specified currencies for each recipient. Travelers coming direct f rom Brunei SINGAPORE or Malaysia may bring in any amount in Singapore notes, Malaysian and Brunei currency notes, and cur- rency notes issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Malaya and British Borneo, and other travel- ers may bring in such currency notes up to the equiva- lent of S$ 1,000; otherwise, permission is required for the import of Singapore, Malaysian, and Brunei cur- rency notes. Permission is also required for the import of currency notes of India in excess of Rs 270 and of Indonesia in excess of Rp 3,000. No limitations are imposed on the import of currency notes of other countries. Capital 8 There are no restrictions on capital transfers to and f rom other countries in the Scheduled Territories. Capi- tal transfers f rom Singapore to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control approval. Inward transfers of capital f rom such countries (with the exception of borrowing in non-Scheduled Territory currencies) do not require approval and the subsequent utilization of nonresident-owned funds in Singapore for investment purposes also is exempt from individual exchange control approval; however, government approval is required for investment in most residential property and in any vacant land other than land already designated prior to September 11, 1973 for industrial or commercial use. Investment by residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia in Singapore stocks and bonds, whether quoted or not, is freely permitted in any currency, including Singapore dollars f rom an External Account. Proceeds from sales of Singapore securities held in Singapore and of other investments may be freely repatriated by residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories; the approval authority for such transfers has been delegated to authorized banks. Borrowing from local banks by nonresident-controlled companies is not restricted. Investments by Singapore residents in countries out- side the Scheduled Territories normally may be made on ly upon approval of the exchange control authorities; however, residents are permitted to invest without limit in certain prescribed external bonds, and up to certain prescribed limits in securities denominated in specified currencies or in deposits in specified currencies with authorized banks or with Asian Currency Units. The exchange allowance for cash gifts and personal loans by individuals is S$30,000 a remitter a calendar year. Singapore banks that have been licensed to operate an Asian Currency Unit, and thus to operate in the Asian dollar market, may freely accept deposits in specified currencies and Scheduled Territory currency f rom an External Account from nonresidents of Singa- pore; banks require individual exchange control approval for corresponding borrowing or lending transactions with residents of Singapore. All transactions must be 3 With effect f rom February 4, 1976, the remaining restrictions on capital outflows to non-Scheduled Territories were fu r ther relaxed. 395 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SINGAPORE conducted over accounts held in the Asian Currency Units of the banks concerned. Borrowing in the Asian dollar market by resident exporters to finance out- standing export bills is in practice unrestricted. The spot and forward foreign exchange positions of banks are supervised by the Monetary Au thor i ty. Gold There is a free gold market in Singapore, to which residents and nonresidents have free access; settlements between residents and nonresidents must take place in a Scheduled Territory currency to an External Account or in any foreign currency, wh i le receipts f rom nonresi- dents may be accepted in any currency or against debit to an External Account. Both resident and nonresident individuals and companies are permitted to import, hold, negotiate, and export gold freely; imports and exports require neither exchange control approval nor import or export licenses, and gold can be dealt with freely by any person in Singapore. A S$150 commemorative gold coin issued by the Board of Commissioners of Currency, Singapore, is legal tender; this coin is treated for exchange control purposes as gold rather than local currency and its export and import is dealt with in the same way as that of gold. The price of gold used for the m anu f a c tu re of orna- ments is fixed by the Singapore-Chinese Gold and Silver Merchants Association. On December 31, 1975, this price was about S$500 per tael for 24-karat gold and S$460 per tael for 22-karat gold. Changes during 1975 January 1.
