Not for Redistribution SOMALIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.118193 gram of fine gold per Somali Shilling, and Somalia avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Somalia carries out exchange transactions in some of the "convertible" cur- rencies * with authorized dealers at fixed rates, tak ing into consideration those in leading exchange markets in Europe; on December 31, 1975, the Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were So. Sh. 6.2327 and So. Sh. 6.3573, unchanged since 1973. The exchange market in Somalia comprises the Central Bank and the sole commercial bank, which operates as the authorized exchange dealer in respect of transactions in foreign currencies. There is a foreign exchange commission (including banking commission) of 0.7 per cent for all exchange transactions other than purchases and sales of banknotes. The authorized exchange dealer generally does not conduct forward exchange transactions on behalf of the public, although this is not prohibited. Administration of Control The Ministry of Industry and Commerce is the princi- pal government agency concerned with the implementa- tion and operation of trade and exchange controls. It has been given the authority to regulate and control all foreign economic transactions and to establish policy for the licensing of imports, exports, and exchange. The Central Bank is authorized to determine the rates at which foreign currencies are to be negotiated, to establish list of "convertible" currencies,1 and a to appoint authorized exchange dealers. The sole commercial bank has been appointed as authorized exchange dealer. The Central Bank may also implement the trade and exchange controls on behalf of the Ministry of Indus try and Com- merce. An Advisory Commission, consisting of nine members, representing various ministries, the Central Bank, the Customs Authority, and the police, advises the Ministry of Industry and Commerce on policy questions relating to the regulations and control of foreign eco- nomic transactions. The Na t ional and Local Licensing Committees, usually consisting of members representing the Ministry of Indus try and Commerce, the M in is try of Finance, the Central Bank, the Customs Authority, and the police, decide on applications for licenses for imports and exports and for transfers in respect of services. The Central Bank grants licenses for certain routine invisi- bles. Transfers in respect of capital are authorized by the National Licensing Committee in Mogadiscio, unless they are governed by the provisions of Law No. 10 of February 18, 1960 on foreign investments, as extended and amended by Decree-Law No. 3 of March 3, 1968 and Law No. 17 of June 15, 1968. 1 The "convertible" currencies are listed as D j ibou ti f rancs, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Prescription of Currency Settlements with the People's Republic of China and the U.S.S.R. are made through bilateral clearing accounts denominated in pounds sterling. Settlements with Egypt must be made mostly in convertible currencies; 50 per cent of payments for impor ts f rom Egypt and all pay- men ts for invisibles to Egypt other than those for Suez Canal dues are to be debited to Somalia's creditor bal- ance resulting f rom the terminated payments agreement with that country; other payments normally are chan- neled through special accounts denominated in sterling. Settlements w i th all other countries must be made in Somali shillings or in "convertible" currencies (see foot- note 1 ); however, residents are not permitted to make settlements w i th Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Somali shillings or in "con- vertible" currencies may be opened with the authorized exchange dealer by Somali nationals residing abroad and der iv ing income only f rom sources outside Somalia; for- eign nationals and foreign institutions enjoying diplo- matic status in Somalia; foreign persons customarily resident abroad and companies whose head office is abroad, provided that they do not derive income (includ- ing export proceeds) f rom sources within Somalia; and by other physical or jur id ical persons individually authorized by the Central Bank to ma in ta in a nonresi- dent account. Imports and Import Payments Imports of goods originating in or shipped f rom Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The impo rt of a few commodities from all sources is temporarily prohibited for balance of payments reasons.2 Ind iv idual licenses are required for all other commodi- ties. Some of these commodities may be imported only f rom specified sources.3 Certain other commodities are liberalized when or ig ina t ing in EEC countries. The state trad ing organization, the National Agency for Trade (En te Naz iona le per il Comercio or ENC ), is responsible, inter alia, for the import and /or distribution of certain commodities received under aid programs. It also is the sole agent for the importation of animal and vegetable oils and fa ts, corn, rice, wheat flour, coffee, tea, sugar, pasta, cement, and certain other commodities; some are not being imported at present (e.g., soaps and detergents, 2 Bu t ter, cheese, tomatoes, nonalcoholic beverages, ready-made cloth- ing, textiles and related materials, electrical appliances and parts, and small passenger automobiles. 3 The permitted origin varies from commodity to commodity; the specified sources of supply generally are Egypt and /or the U.S.S.R. Made-up articles and related products may be imported only when or ig ina t ing in A f r i c an or A rab countries, member countries of the EEC, People's Republic of China, German Democratic Republic, North Korea, or U.S.S.R. 397 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOMALIA rubber and plastic footwear, and bleached or unbleached cotton cloth). The Somali Petroleum Agency is the sole importer of fuel and fuel products, batteries, and rubber tubes and tires. The Pharmaceutical Agency is the only agency entitled to import medicines, while the Agency for Construction Materials is the sole importer of con- struction materials. Certain other commodities also are imported by state agencies only. If goods imported d i f fer in weight, quan t i ty, or value by more than 10 per cent from the specifications in the import license, a new import license must be obtained. All imports other than those made by the Government, diplomatic and consular agencies, and in terna t ional orga- nizations are subject to a statistical and administrative tax of 10 per cent. Payments for imports are authorized by the Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer on the basis of the import license and other documentation relating to the import transaction (bills, bills of lading, shipping notices, e tc .). Provided that the Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer is satisfied that the transac- tion meets the legal requirements, permission to make payment for imports is granted to the applicant not later than the third business day following the receipt of the application or on such other subsequent day as may be specified by the applicant. The Central Bank or the authorized exchange dealer may also permit advance payments for imports (i.e., payment for merchandise not actually passed through customs at the time of payment) provided that documentary evidence of actual shipment is produced. Advance payments for imports without documentary evidence of actual shipment are not per- mitted. Payments for imports from neighboring areas 4 are permitted only by letter of credit and by cash against documentation. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Payments for current invisibles are subject to licensing, mainly to prevent unauthorized capital movements; provided that balance of payments considerations permit, genuine requirements are met. Transfers of salaries, wages, gratuities, and allowances paid in Somalia to their foreign personnel by enterprises registered under the Foreign Investment Law are nor- mally allowed up to 50 per cent. The Central Bank may grant licenses for exchange for travel purposes up to specified limits. Applications for all other invisibles are considered on their merits by the Licensing Committees in Mogadiscio, Hargeisa, and Burao. For tourist travel by residents, there is an allowance of the equivalent of So. Sh. 1,000 a person a year, which is applicable to all countries, except Canada, Japan, and the United States; for these three countries, the allowance is So. Sh. 1,400 a person a year. Nonresident travelers may take out w i thout authoriza- tion any foreign exchange which they brought in and up 4 Aden, Djibouti, Mukalla, Ethiopia, and Kenya. 398 to So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins. Resident travelers may take out without authorization So. Sh. 200 in Somali notes and coins and up to the equivalent of So. Sh. 200 in foreign banknotes and coins. A currency declaration is required by all persons leaving the country. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. The export of a few commodities to any destination may be prohibited for reasons of public policy. An export license is required for all other commodities. Bananas are exported only by the Banana Marketing Board. The ENC is the sole agent for the exportation of incense, myrrh, gum arabic, and charcoal. The export of salt, dried fish, and hides and skins also is a public sector monopoly. All export proceeds must be repatriated, declared, and offered for sale to the Central Bank or to the authorized exchange dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Central Bank may exempt exporters from the surrender obligation in respect of their export pro- ceeds. Where no banks are operating, an advance pay- ment deposit of 50 per cent of the value of livestock exports and 15 per cent of the value of other exports is required. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated, declared, and offered for sale to the Central Bank or to the author- ized dealer within five business days after their receipt. The Central Bank may grant exemptions from the sur- render requirement. Nonresidents may bring in freely with them any amount in foreign exchange and up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins; they must make a currency declaration when entering the country. Resident travel- ers may bring in up to So. Sh. 200 in Somali banknotes and coins and are obliged, upon arrival, to declare and offer to surrender any foreign exchange or gold they bring in. Capital Payments to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Capital transactions are subject to licensing unless they are authorized by the Foreign Investment Law of February 1960 (as amended in March and June 1968). In accordance with the provi- sions of that law, foreign enterprises must be registered with the Ministry of Planning and Coordination. For "productive" enterprises (i.e., those that engage in irriga- tion, improvement of land, establishment of factories, construction of aqueducts, and testing, analyzing, and drilling activities in connection with oil and mineral exploration), profits may be transferred abroad freely up to a limit of 15 per cent per annum of the capital invested; the unused portion of this transfer right is cumulative for three years. Should profits in any one ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution year be less than 15 per cent, the transfer right for the succeeding three years is correspondingly increased. The capital itself may be transferred abroad beginning five years after the date of registration. Profits resulting from other foreign investments may be transferred abroad up to a limit of 10 per cent per annum of the capital invested, and the capital itself may be transferred abroad over a minimum period of three years, beginning seven years after the date of registration. The Ministry of Finance, upon the recommendation of other ministries concerned, may extend total or partial exemption to any enterprise f rom import and export taxes, excise duty, income tax, and municipal tax for a period not exceeding five years. For investments regis- tered prior to March 1968, the fiscal exemptions may be granted for up to ten years. Enterprises registered in or after March 1968 must, to the largest possible extent, employ residents; a program for the substitution of resi- dent employees for nonresidents is to be submitted, for the record, to the Committee on Foreign Investments. Gold Residents may hold and acquire in Somalia, for numismatic purposes only, gold coins that are not legal SOMALIA tender in any country. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require permissions issued by the Central Bank; such permissions are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold imported by jewelers must be melted down to a fineness of not more than 22 karats within one month. Imports of gold are exempt from customs duty when originating in EEC countries and are subject to a 10 per cent duty when of other origin. Changes during 1975 March. Subsequently, a new state agency was established to act as importer and distributor of these goods. 399 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per South A f r ican Rand. On June 24, 1974 South A f r ica began an exchange rate policy of independent managed floating, but since June 27, 1975 a policy has been followed of keeping the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar constant for longer periods at a time. As at Decem- ber 31, 1975 the South A f r ican Reserve Bank quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R 1. Exchange rates are based on the Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. The commercial banks' spot rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were US$1.1529 buying, and US$1.1471 selling, per R 1. Subject to certain l im i ta t ions, authorized dealers are per- mitted to conduct forward exchange operations among themselves and with overseas banks. The Reserve Bank provides forward cover in U.S. dollars only; such cover is given to authorized dealers at a charge of 1 per cent per annum, for import transactions and for foreign loans raised in their own names. South Afr ica fo rma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as of September 15, 1973. Exchange Control Territory For purposes of control over transactions in securities, residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland are regarded as nonresidents. Otherwise, there are virtually no exchange or trade restrictions between the Republic of South Africa (defined for exchange control purposes as including South West A f r i c a ), Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland, and these are regarded as form ing, with the Republic of South Afr ica, a single exchange control territory, the Rand Monetary Area. Administration of Control Import and export licenses are issued by the Director of Imports and Exports acting on behalf of the Secretary for Commerce. Exchange licensing is the responsibility of the Treasury, which has delegated this authority to the South A f r ican Reserve Bank; in tu rn, the Reserve Bank has delegated to the commercial banks much of its licensing power. Appropriate exchange for licensed imports is made available by the authorized dealers upon presentation of suitable documentary evidence. Prescription of Currency South Afr ica has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. All countries outside the Rand Monetary Area constitute 400 the Nonresident Area.1 Settlements within the Rand Monetary Area take place in rand only.2 Swazi bank- notes and coins are convertible into rand at par without restriction, but they are not legal tender in South Africa. Settlements w i th residents of the Nonresident Area, except Rhodesia, may be made in rand to and from a nonresident account and in any specified currency 3 and, for outgoing payments only, in any other foreign cur- rency.4 Settlements with Rhodesia may be made in rand to and f rom a local Rhodesian or other nonresident account, in Rhodesian currency and, for inward pay- ments only, in any specified currency. Nonresident Accounts The rand accounts of persons resident outside the Rand Monetary Area are divided into Rhodesian Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, and Blocked Accounts (but see December 4 entry under section on Changes during 1975, below). Rhodesian Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Rhodesia. They may be credited with all authorized payments by South Afr ican residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Afr ica of Rhodesian currency and of any specified cur- rency, and with payments from local Nonresident or Rhodesian Accounts. They may be debited for pay- ments for exports to Rhodesia and other payments due by Rhodesian residents to South Afr ican residents, for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Afr ica for short periods, for payments to other local Rhodesian Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Rhodesian currency. Nonresident Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies ( inc lud ing banks) resident, domiciled, or registered outside Rhodesia and the Rand Monetary Area. They may be credited with all authorized pay- ments by South African residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of specified currency, and with payments f rom other Nonresident 1 In the application of the Securities Control Notices, however, the Nonresident Area comprises all countries outside South Africa, and thus includes Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Correspondingly, there are two definitions of resident status for exchange control purposes. 2 In September 1974 Swaziland issued its own currency, the lilangeni (p lu ral ema langen i ), to replace the rand. Lilangeni banknotes are f ree ly convertible into rand, at par, at the Monetary Au thor i ty of Swaziland, but they are not legal tender in South Africa. Checks and other bills of exchange drawn by Swazi residents for payment in South A f r i c a, Botswana, and Lesotho must be denominated in rand. 3 Australian dollars, Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Fiji dollars, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Indian rupees, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kenya shillings, Malagasy f rancs, Malawi kwacha, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Pakistan rupees, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Seychelles rupees, Spanish pesetas, Sri Lanka rupees, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, Uganda shillings, U.S. dollars, zaires, and Zamb ian kwacha. 4 Foreign currency is any currency other than currency that is legal tender in South Afr ica. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Accounts in South Africa. They may be debited for payments to South Afr ican residents for any purpose; for payments to nonresidents for any purpose, i.e., by transfer to a local Nonresident or Rhodesian Account or for remittance to any country outside the Rand Monetary Area; for the cost of purchases of any foreign currency; and for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Afr ica for short periods. Blocked Accounts are held by nonresidents of South Africa and are subject to exchange control restrictions.5 They represent mainly the proceeds from sales of South African securities by a nonresident of South Africa to a resident. Such proceeds may not be transferred from Soufh Africa or to another Blocked Account in South Africa, but may be retained on deposit with an author- ized dealer, used within certain limits for the holder's living expenses while visiting South A f r ica, or reinvested in securities which are quoted locally; such securities may be exported and sold abroad. If invested in govern- ment, municipal, or public utility bonds, but not the national savings certificate series issued from October 1, 1974, the proceeds on redemption at maturity are freely transferable to the nonresident owner, provided that he had held the securities for a continuous period of at least five years to redemption. Blocked rand may also be used to subscribe to a special issue, made available by the Government to nonresidents of South Africa only, of five-year transferable bonds offered by tender on a discount basis and repayable at face value. The redemption proceeds are transferable in the foreign cur- rency of the monetary area in which the holder is resi- dent. In special cases, blocked rand may be used for direct investment in manu fac tu r ing enterprises. Emi- grants' assets that exceed the permissible transferable amount, and the proceeds of South Afr ican securities held by immigrants prior to their arrival in South Africa or acquired abroad within three years of their arrival, are also blocked, but favorable consideration is given to the release of such immigrants' funds, with the excep- tion of funds of persons who had been South A f r ican residents (see section on Capital, below). Imports and Import Payments All importers of goods requiring import licenses must be registered with the Director of Imports and Exports. Most licenses allow the importation of a range of com- modities, but they are, in general, to be used for goods as prescribed on the relevant import permit. Import licenses are valid for imports f rom any country. Imports free of license include ( 1) all goods imported f rom Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland and (2) all goods imported from Rhodesia, Malawi, and Zambia that were grown, produced, or manufactured in those countries. 5 Unlike the other types of nonresident rand accounts, Blocked Ac- counts can also be held by residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. SOUTH AFRICA The Import Control Regulations for 1976, as announced in December 1975, distinguish generally between the following broad categories of imports: (1) Goods which may be imported without an import permit. This free list contains 507 tariff headings or subheadings and corresponds to some 25.3 per cent of 1975 imports. ( 2) Goods which may be imported only under permit but subject to automatic licensing for bona fide mer- chants and manufacturers. These fall under an unspeci- fied number of tariff headings or subheadings and correspond to 60.0 per cent of 1975 imports. (3) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which global quotas are determined from time to time. These account for about 6.0 per cent of 1975 imports. (4) Goods which may be imported only under per- mit and for which specific permits authorizing the import of these goods individually are issued. They cover some 8.7 per cent of 1975 imports. Provided that licensing regulations are respected and upon presentation to his bank of the necessary consign- ment documents (proof of importation), an importer is automatically granted exchange to pay for the import. Payment prior to the date of shipment or dispatch are not normally allowed. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. All payments to nonresidents of the Rand Monetary Area for current invisibles require exchange licenses. Authority is, how- ever, delegated to the commercial banks to approve certain payments without limitation and others up to established limits. For current income payments, such as declared dividends, profits, royalties, etc., that accrue in South Africa, approval is given by the authorized banks without reference to the Reserve Bank, provided that the relative royalty agreement was approved by the Department of Industries and the Reserve Bank and the profits or dividends to be remitted by nonresident- owned branches and subsidiaries are based on profits earned since December 31, 1959 and their remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. Favor- able consideration is, however, given by the Reserve Bank to such transfers where the use of local credit facilities is not regarded as excessive. Income derived f rom securities acquired with blocked funds or other- wise held by nonresidents is freely transferable to the owner's country of residence. Limited amounts of exchange to pay for membership fees, family mainte- nance, etc., are authorized. The basic allowance for tourist travel in a year is R 2,000 for an adult and R 800 for a child under the age of 12. Separately, there is another annual basic exchange allocation of R 500 for an adult (R 200 for a child under 12) for travel to Malawi, Rhodesia, Za'ire, Zambia, and Portu- guese East and West Africa. Applications for larger 401 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. Residents leaving South Africa for destinations out- side the Rand Mone tary Area may take out not more than the equivalent of R 200 in banknotes. South Afr i- can Reserve Bank notes, however, may not exceed R 50 but are not regarded as being part of the basic travel allowance. Foreign visitors leaving South Afr ica within 12 months af ter arrival may take with them up to R 50 in Reserve Bank notes and any amount of foreign notes which they brought into the country or obtained from the disposal of ins trumen ts of exchange that they brought to and exchanged in South Afr ica. These limi- tations on the export of Reserve Bank notes do not apply in the case of Bantu re tu rn ing to neighboring countries, who are permitted to take w i th them reason- able amoun ts in the form of banknotes representing their earnings in South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic currency to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of commodities considered as being in rela- tively short supply, or for which domestic prices are substantially lower than those obtainable overseas, require licenses irrespective of destination (w i th the exception of exports to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swazi- l a n d ). Certain other goods are controlled for strategic reasons only, and permits are required for their export to all destinations but no import certificate is required where the goods are exported to the United Kingdom, any Commonwealth country, any British colony, pro- tectorate, or trust territory, or the United States. The re-export of imported goods to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area is controlled to prevent com- modity and exchange arbitrage. Unless otherwise permitted, all export proceeds must be remitted to South A f r ica and surrendered within six months from the date of shipment and 30 days f rom the date of collection. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered within 30 days f rom the date of their acquisition, unless exemp- tion is obtained. Upon entry f rom countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, residents and nonresidents may bring in R 50 in South African Reserve Bank notes. There are no limitations on the import of domestic cur- rency from Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. Capital* Inward capital transfers require exchange control approval; all inward loan transfers require specific approval,7 while inward transfers in respect of equity capital are freely permitted. Foreign exchange accruing to residents from capital transfers and transactions must be surrendered. Outward transfers of capital by resi- dents to destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area require the approval of the South Afr ican Reserve Bank and are usually not allowed; when falling under the Securities Control Notices, transfers to Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland also require prior approval. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident- controlled firms is subject to limitation. Transfers by residents for the purchase of South African (or other) shares on external stock exchanges are generally not permitted (except in amounts not exceeding R 2,000 for each shareholder, to allow South Africa residents to exercise rights arising from existing holdings of shares in foreign companies quoted only on foreign stock exchanges), although South African stockbrokers may engage in arbitrage transactions in securities, sub- ject to certain conditions designed to prevent any net outflow of exchange. Applications by South African residents to retain in, or transfer to, neighboring terri- tories (this term excludes Botswana, Lesotho, and Swazi- land) funds for bona fide long-term investment in specific development projects or for the expansion of existing projects that are owned or controlled by South Africans are considered by the South African Reserve Bank and the Treasury on their merits. For three years after their arrival in South Africa, immigrants (excluding former South African residents) may dispose of their foreign assets (including foreign cash f u n d s) held outside the Rand Monetary Area or otherwise invest them (including by purchase of South A f r ican securities abroad). The proceeds from the sale of all South African securities brought in by immigrants are blocked; the blocking is normally for at least three years, but the restriction may be removed freely (except for former South African residents) on amounts up to R 20,000 or, subject to Reserve Bank approval, on addi- tional amounts, to enable the immigrant to set up a home and to meet current living expenses. The proceeds of the sale of South African securities by nonresidents of South Africa to residents must be credited to Blocked Accounts (see section on Nonresi- dent Accounts, above). The following payments related to nonresident capital may be carried out by the author- ized banks without reference to the South African Reserve Bank: transfers to nonresidents of South Africa of the proceeds on maturity of government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certificates (except those issued on October 1, 1974), provided that they were registered in the name of the nonresident 6 For purposes of the application of the Securities Control Notices, a nonresident is defined as a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside South A f r ica. For all other exchange control purposes, a nonresident is a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside the Rand Monetary Area. 7 Approval is generally given for borrowing abroad w i th a maturity of at least six months by domestic entrepreneurs, except for property development, speculation, or consumer credit. Authorized dealers gen- rally are permitted to raise funds abroad in their own names for the financing of South Afr ican foreign trade and other approved purposes. 402 ©International Monetary Fund. Emigrant families whose net assets do not exceed R 20,000 may have R 10,000 transferred outside South Africa as a settling-in allowance, and those with greater assets may have 50 per cent of their assets, up to R 30,000, transferred; any balance exceeding the per- missible transferable amount is blocked, and the value of any foreign assets is deducted from the applicable settling-in allowance. Emigrants may, however, utilize such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a fam i ly un it to subscribe to the five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Government on a tender basis (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The South Afr ican Reserve Bank approves transfers of repayments at ma tur i ty to nonresident holders of mortgage bonds registered in their names on or before June 16, 1961. Favorable consideration is given for the transfer by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries of open or approved loan account balances or undistrib- uted current profits, or for the t rans fer of any dividends by them, provided that the remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. The physical export f rom South Africa of nonresident-owned securities is permitted, except by emigrants in excess of their settling- in allowance. There are normally three ways in which holders of blocked rand ( inc lud ing holders resident in Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) can repatriate funds from South Africa: (1) by taking up special nonresident bonds issued by the Government (see above) —these mature in five years, when the redemption proceeds may be withdrawn at the official rate; ( 2) by holding certain government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certificates (except those issued on October 1, 1974) for at least five years to redemption, when the proceeds can be transferred abroad at the official rate; and (3) by exporting South Afr ican shares bought on the Johannesburg stock exchange, provided that they have been restrictively endorsed, and selling them outside South Africa at a price which may involve a premium or a discount on the South Afr ican quota- tion; on December 31, 1975, the corresponding dis- count on blocked rand was about 7 per cent (but see December 4 entry under section on Changes during 1975, below). SOUTH AFRICA Gold Residents of South Africa may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in South Africa for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents of South Africa other than the monetary authorities, authorized dealers, reg- istered gold producers, and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. All exports of gold require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized dealers in respect of exports of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler (subject to a written declaration to the effect that the jewelry will be brought back to South Africa on the traveler's re turn) and in respect of exports of gold jewelry by manufac tur ing jewelers (subject, except for exports to Malawi, Rhodesia, and Zambia, to a written declaration that the articles are in fully manufactured form and that the gold content of each does not exceed 75 per cent of the selling price to the ultimate con- signee). Furthermore, authorized dealers may without reference to the Reserve Bank allow residents to export for num isma t ic purposes currency coins, including gold coins, up to R 300 for each applicant during a calendar year. The gold mining industry must sell its output to the Reserve Bank, within one month of production, except for sales effected on the industry's behalf in the free market. The Mint from time to time strikes gold coins with- out a face value (Krugerrand) that are legal tender but do not circulate freely in South Africa as currency; these are made available in limited numbers to resident collectors, while the bulk is sold abroad. Imports of gold are confined mainly to coins for numismatic purposes and to certain types of jewelry. Changes during 1975 January 1. A further relaxation of import restrictions became effective. It provided for the transfer to the free list of 34 groups or classes of commodities that were subject to permit control, and for the transfer of 20 types of commodities in paragraph 4 of the import control measures, the importation of which was previ- ously strictly limited, to paragraph 2, which implied that these goods would be licensed to meet the full reason- able requirements of importers. January. Production capacity for Krugerrand was increased from 75,000 to 150,000 coins a week. May 2. The commission charged for forward pur- chases of foreign exchange for import payments was reduced from 3 per cent to 1 per cent, in order to encourage importers to make greater use of export credit available overseas. May 2. Further import permit allocations equivalent to 40 per cent of total permits issued in 1974 were granted for consumer goods, confectionery, and alco- holic beverages, bringing the total allocation for these three categories to 80 per cent. It was announced that the Reserve Bank was discontinuing the practice of mak ing small and frequent adjustments to its buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars. In fu tu re these rates would be kept con- stant for longer periods at a time and would only be adjusted upward or downward if considered essential in the event of any basic change in domestic or interna- tional economic circumstances. The new policy would be based on a middle rate of R 1 = US$1.40 w i th the same total spread of l/2 of 1 per cent as before. The Reserve Bank quoted public buy ing and selling rates of US$1.4035 and US$1.3965 per rand. The previous middle rate had been R 1 = US$1.47. August 11. Restrictions on private sector borrow ing abroad were eased and certain other exchange control modifications were announced: (1) Local en t rep reneu rs were permitted to borrow funds abroad for periods of not less than six months, except for property develop- ment, speculation, or consumer credit; previously, for- eign loans were only approved for "manu fac tu r ing and other productive" purposes. The relaxation would extend to foreign borrowings by exporters in an t ic ipa t ion of receivable payments. (2) Authorized dealers might apply to raise funds abroad in the ir own names for the f inanc ing of South A f r ican fo re ign trade and other approved purposes. (3) It had been decided in princi- ple that blocked rand would be made directly t ran s fe ra- ble between nonresidents; the details and effective date would be announced later. (4) Control over local bor- rowing by foreign-controlled South A f r ican firms would be extended to certain leasing arrangemen ts, fac to r ing (with recourse), and certain "lease backs." (5) The normal maximum period for which the Reserve Bank would extend forward exchange cover for imports was extended from 6 months to 12 months; applications for forward cover for longer periods would be considered for certain capital goods imports. (6) The requirement that forward exchange cover must be arranged w i th in seven days af ter the fore ign transaction was concluded was abolished. (7) Applications for forward cover by authorized dealers in respect of foreign loans raised in their own names would be favorab ly considered. (8) Authorized dealers might arrange foreign finance for imports, without reference to the Reserve Bank, for periods not exceeding 12 months, against 180 days previously. August 28. The third and final round of permit allo- cations for imports in 1975 was announced. The allo- cation was for 20 per cent of permits issued in 1974 for consumer goods, clothing, confectionery, and alco- holic beverages. This brought the total for 1975 to 100 per cent of 1974 allocations for these commodity groups, except clothing, which stood at 80 per cent. Also, the release from import control was announced of 20 groups of commodities still subject to import restrictions; they were gazetted on September 5. September 22. The Reserve Bank's middle rate for the U.S. dollar was reduced to R 1 = US$1.15 from R 1 = US$1.40. The Reserve Bank's buy ing and sell- ing rates were adjusted to R 1 = US$1.1529 and R 1 = US$1.1471, respectively. No change was made in the exchange rate policy introduced on June 27. December 4. It was announced that from January 1, 1976 the blocked rand system would be changed. "Blocked rand" ar is ing f rom investment by nonresidents would be redesignated "securities rand"; the latter term would denote the local sale and redemption proceeds of South A f r ican securities and other investments in South A f r ica, owned by nonresidents, excluding former resi- dents of South Africa. Emigrants' funds blocked in South A f r ica would continue to be referred to as blocked rand and would be subject to the same restric- tions as before. The Johannesburg stock exchange would be permitted to quote prices for securities rand, and its members would be permitted to buy and 'sell securities rand on behalf of nonresidents. Authorized dealers would be permitted to transfer securities rand balances from one securities rand account in their books to another, in their own books or in the books of another authorized dealer; the relevant exchange control requirements would be advised in due course. December 8. The import control policy for 1976 was announced. It would be maintained substantially along the lines which applied dur ing 1975. Importers would be granted an advance permit allocation of 40 per cent of the total permits issued to them in 1975 in respect of consumer goods, clothing, confectionery, and alcoholic beverages. This allocation was equivalent to the advance granted for 1975, and fur ther issues for the commodities in question would be reviewed in May 1976. The import control regulations for 1976 were gazetted on December 19. December 22. It was announced that the changeover f rom blocked rand to securities rand was being post- poned un t il February 2, 1976. (Trading in securities rand began on February 2, 1976; the opening quotation was US$0.97-0.98 per R 1. Purchases by nonresidents of nonquoted securities continued to be settled at the official exchange rate.) 404 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0126953 gram of fine gold per Spanish Peseta. Spain avails itself of wider margins. The official intervention limits for the U.S. dollar have been suspended since January 22, 1974. The official buying and selling rates of the Bank of Spain on Decem- ber 31, 1975 were Ptas 59.689 and Ptas 59.859 per US$1.1 Official buying and selling rates for specified cur- rencies2 are fixed daily by the Bank of Spain acting in consultation with the authorized banks. Purchases and sales of clearing currencies are centralized in the Bank of Spain, which publishes the rates at which it settles the transactions it carries out direct. These rates are the same as the prevailing rates for the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Spain also quotes buy ing and selling rates for banknotes in specified foreign currencies on a weekly basis. Authorized banks are allowed to operate in foreign markets for spot transactions and forward transactions related to commercial transactions for up to 360 days; forward transactions with customers are restricted to currencies adm i t ted to the Madrid foreign exchange market and to permitted import and export transactions with a ma tu r i ty up to 360 days. Exchange Control Territory The Peninsular Territories of the Spanish State, the Canary Islands, the Balearic Islands, Ceuta, and Melilla constitute a single exchange control territory. Administration of Control The guidelines on foreign exchange policy are fo rmu- lated by an interministerial commission. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of all administrative func t ions connected with exchange control. The Bank of Spain is in charge of the operative func t ions (basically, the handling of the external reserves). It is also responsible for the authorization of foreign currency loans to resi- dents for nontrade purposes. Trade controls are administered by the M in is try of Commerce. This Ministry also is in charge of the con- trols over Spanish investment abroad, private Spanish lending abroad, foreign financing of trade, and the registration of foreign investments in Spain. Contracts dealing with technology must be registered w i th the M in is try of Industry. 1 On Feb rua ry 9, 1976 the peseta was allowed to depreciate to Ptas 66.54 buy ing, and Ptas 66.60 selling, per US$1. 3 Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Finnish ma rkkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss f rancs, and U.S. dollars. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles other than those with bilateral payments agreement countries may be made in any specified cur- rency,2 but in practice they are usually made in the currency determined on the basis of the country of origin or destination. Settlements with bilateral pay- ments agreement coun tr ies3 are made through agree- ment accounts expressed in U.S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are six types of nonresident accounts: Foreign Accounts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Accounts), Foreign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accounts), External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Currencies, Bank Accounts in Pesetas w i th Andorra, and Emigrants' Accounts. A Accounts may freely be credited with (1) the countervalue in pesetas of convertible currencies sold on the Spanish foreign exchange marke t; (2) amounts transferred from other A Accounts; ( 3) amounts trans- ferred from B Accounts; and (4) any interest payable on the account concerned. These accounts may freely be debited for ( 1) any payment in pesetas in favor of Spanish jur id ical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain (including payments relating to foreign investment in Spain); and (2) trans- fers to other A Accounts. Debits for the purchase of foreign currency for remittance abroad are not permitted. B Accounts may freely be credited with (1) any peseta collections generated in Spain that under existing rules are transferable abroad under powers delegated to authorized banks; (2) amounts transferred from other B Accounts; and ( 3) any interest payable on the account concerned. The crediting of amounts originating from A Accounts is prohibited. B Accounts may be freely debited for ( 1) the countervalue in pesetas of foreign currency acquired on the Spanish foreign exchange mar- ket; (2) any payments in pesetas in favor of Spanish ju r id ical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain, including those relating to for- eign investment in Spain; ( 3) transfers to other B Accounts; and (4) transfers to A Accounts. All other entries on A or B Accounts require the prior authorization of the Ministry of Commerce. Private banks are required to make special noninterest- bearing deposits in cash at the Bank of Spain, in an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of the increases after October 18, 1971 in nonresident-held deposits in A and B Accounts (demand deposits, savings account deposits, 3 Colombia, Egypt, and Equatorial Guinea. 405 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN or time deposits at less than three months' no t ice), and in an amount equivalent to 50 per cent of the increases in such deposits when held for three months or more (100 per cent of any increase af ter February 7, 1973). Furthermore, banks are prohibited from paying interest on any nonresident-held peseta deposits in A or B Accounts, whether demand, time, or savings deposits. External Accounts in Internal Pesetas are designed to hold funds accruing in Spain to nonresidents that are not transferable abroad ("blocked pesetas"). Balances are freely negotiable between nonresidents holding such accounts; if the recipient of pesetas does not hold an account of this type, he needs prior approval to open one. These accounts may be credited freely with (1) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally acquired with pesetas f rom an External Account in Internal Pesetas; (2) the fu ll proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish shares and fixed-interest securities that have been acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas and have been held for less than three years consecutively by the same owner ;4 (3) with receipts f rom the National Lottery; (4) w i th any nontransferable wages, salaries, pensions, rents, or divi- dends accruing to the account holder; (5) with interest received on balances held in these accounts; and (6) w i th transfers f rom any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. They may be debited freely for (1) payments of any amount of personal expenses in Spain of the account holder and his close relatives (managers' per- sonal expenses if the account is opened in the name of a ju r id ical pe r son ); (2) the purchase of shares quoted on the stock exchange and of Spanish fixed-interest securities; (3) the purchase for the use of the account holder (provided that the account holder is a nonresi- dent physical person) of u rban and rural properties that do not represent investment for commercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes (applicable to rural properties only if the account holder is of Spanish n a t ion a l i ty ); (4) the purchase of National Lottery tickets; and (5) transfers to any other External Accounts in In te rnal Pesetas. All other entries on these accounts require prior authorization and the accounts may not be overdrawn. Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Curren- cies may be held by nonresident foreign nationals, nonresident Spanish na t iona ls, and nonresident firms or banks; resident foreign nationals may ma in ta in such accounts only if opened before Janua ry 1, 1968. The deposits may be either sight or time deposits. The accounts may be credited with convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market and with any amount of interest. They may be debited freely for reconversion into the currency initially deposited, for the purchase of other convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market, and for conversion into pesetas, inc lud ing the transfer to an A Account. Over- 4 The proceeds of such securities that have been held for at least three years consecutively are transferable abroad. 406 drafts are prohibited except for mail credits in favor of foreign banks. Emigrants' Accounts—Since October 29, 1970, com- mercial banks have been authorized to open savings accounts in convertible pesetas for Spaniards working abroad. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Most imports are admitted under the following arrangements: (1) free imports, (2) global quotas, (3) state trading, and (4) individual licensing, also referred to as the ''bilateral import regime." All imports require either an import license or an "import declaration" issued by the Directorate-General of Tariff Policy and Imports. Pro- vided that import prices are not considered abnormal, import declarations are issued freely for a large number of goods (mostly foodstuffs not under state trading, raw materials, capital goods, and spare parts, but also some consumer goods) included in an import free list that applies to most countries with which Spain has no bilateral payments agreements; the free list also applies to specified imports from Iran and Japan.5 All other imports require licenses. There are global quotas for specified imports from countries to which the free list applies, but licenses are usually granted for larger amounts.6 With certain excep- tions, the global quota regime also applies to goods of Japanese origin. Licenses for imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are issued freely. Imports of raw cotton, cer- ta in other agricultural products, some raw materials, petroleum products, and tobacco are state traded; some goods formally listed as being subject to state trading, such as feedgrains, may in fact be freely imported by private traders. Imports of certain agricultural products that are free of quantitative restriction and previously were state traded are subject to variable import levies. Import subsidies are paid on certain foodstuffs and specified other essential commodities. Exchange in the appropriate currency to pay for authorized imports is granted freely. Except for capital goods, suppliers' credit for imports is not normally permitted to exceed 90 days. All import transactions must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank, and the import payment must be made through the intermediary of the bank of domi- ciliation; exempt from domiciliation are transactions whose value is less than Ptas 500,000 provided that pay- ment is to be made within one year. Not for Redistribution are subject to individual authorization, for the purpose of checking capital transactions. Payments up to Ptas 5,000 for any purpose may be made freely. For a large proportion of invisibles, the banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the request is supported by appropriate documents. For certain services, transfers may be made freely up to a pre- established amoun t; for transfers which exceed that amount licenses are required which are granted at the discretion of the Government. Holders of Spanish securities (excluding securities issued by private companies and acquired through direct subscription) may freely transfer abroad accrued inter- est, dividends, and proceeds from the disposal of subscription rights; the securities must have been pur- chased with convertible pesetas, with pesetas resulting from the sale of foreign exchange quoted in the Spanish foreign exchange market, or with pesetas released from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Profits and divi- dends on direct investments are also transferable abroad without restriction. Rents on nonresident-owned real estate are transferable, provided the purchase price has been paid in fu ll and the owner has no outstanding tax liabilities applicable to the property concerned. A gen- eral license permits the reinsurance abroad of risks insured in Spain with Spanish firms or w i th foreign insurance companies operating in Spain. Insurance con- tracts abroad may not be concluded, except where they concern exports and imports of goods. There is a basic tourist exchange allowance of Ptas 50,000 a person a year; however, amoun ts in excess of this l im it are approved freely for bona fide tourist expenses. The authorized banks are also permitted to sell the equivalent of Ptas 2,000 a day for business trips, up to the equivalent of Ptas 100,000 a person for each trip. For larger amounts, the banks must apply for approval, which may be granted. Travelers may take with them Ptas 3,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain (Ptas 10,000 for persons going to Ando r ra ). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports are subject to prior licensing by the Directorate-General of Exportation. All export proceeds must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Certain agricultural exports are subject to an export tax. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange proceeds from invisibles must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Travelers may bring in a maximum of Ptas 50,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Capital Foreign capital participation in Spanish industries of up to 50 per cent of the capital of the enterprise is exempt from authorization, while investment that exceeds 50 per cent requires the authorization of the SPAIN Council of Ministers; for participation in public service companies in general, the former ratio is 25 per cent. Special ratios and regulations apply for a number of specific activities.7 Foreign investment in Spanish compa- nies manu fac tu r ing capital goods that are listed in the Appendix List of the Customs Code requires registration only; within 30 days the registration may be deemed authorization if no notification to the contrary has been received. Foreign investment is not permitted in Spanish enterprises whose activity is directly connected with na t ional defense, while investment in firms dealing with public in fo rma t ion and in certain public services is sub- ject to specific regulations. Foreign investment for the purpose of modernizing, expanding, and establishing Spanish enterprises may be effected by transferr ing currencies that are negotiable in the Madrid exchange market, by using convertible pesetas, by bringing in capital goods, by reinvesting profits or capital transferable under the Foreign Invest- ment Law, or by providing know-how, patents, or licenses. All contracts dealing with technology require prior registration with the M in is t ry of Industry. Proceeds, including capital appreciation, from the liquidation of foreign direct investments made for the purpose of establishing, modernizing, and expanding Spanish enterprises may be transferred freely. Purchases by nonresidents of shares in most Spanish companies are permitted freely up to the percentages applicable to direct investment. This applies to shares acquired by Spaniards resident abroad, as well as by resident or nonresident foreigners, either with convert- ible pesetas or with pesetas resulting from the conversion of foreign currencies negotiable in the Spanish exchange market. Proceeds, including capital gains, from the liquidation of such shares may be transferred abroad at any t ime, or used for fur ther purchases of shares.8 Purchases by nonresidents of bonds and other fixed- income securities representing debts of either Spanish companies or the Spanish Government and its agencies are unrestricted when financed as indicated in this para- graph, and the fu ll sales proceeds are transferable. Investment in Spanish real estate by nonresidents is, w i th in certain limits,9 freely permitted if financed with pesetas derived from convertible currencies or from bal- 7 The foreign content of investment by Spanish companies with for- eign participation (inversion de cascada) is determined in the following manne r: (1) if foreign participation exceeds 50 per cent, the invest- ment is considered 100 per cent foreign; (2) if foreign participation is over 25 per cent but equal to or less than 50 per cent, the investment is considered foreign to the extent of such participation; nevertheless, if foreign investors enjoy a position of dominance, the investment is considered 100 per cent foreign; and (3) if foreign participation is 25 per cent or less or if there is Spanish Government participation, the investment is considered as domestic. 8 However, if the purchase was made with internal pesetas, the owner of the shares must hold them for three years, after which he may transfer the liquidation proceeds abroad. 9 Purchases of real estate by nonresident physical persons of foreign nationality are freely permitted by a general authorization as follows, if financed with funds imported from abroad: (1) one plot not exceed- ing 5,000 square meters for one single-family dwelling for personal use, (2) the land needed for the construction of an apartment build- ing, and (3) up to three apartments in a single apartment building. There are separate regulations for the purchase of business premises. 407 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN ances in nonresident peseta accounts (A or B Accounts). The Ministry of Commerce has empowered authorized banks to provide the investor with a document certifying that he owns such pesetas; this is the only requirement for official registration of the change in ownership. Cer- tain investments in real estate may also be financed from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Irrespective of the method of financing, rural properties purchased may not exceed 4 hectares of irrigated land or 20 hectares of unirrigated land. When Spanish real estate is sold to a resident, the fu ll sales proceeds are transferable if the initial purchase was financed with convertible foreign currency or with pesetas from an External Account in Convertible Pesetas, an A Account, or a B Account. If the initial purchase was financed w i th pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas, no part of the sales proceeds is transferable. Outward capital transfers by residents require approval. Requests by firms to invest abroad in the same line of business are granted rather liberally, provided that the investment contributes to the expansion of Spanish exports; this includes participation in foreign enterprises. No formal authorization is required for such investments when undertaken by Spanish firms which have been granted an individual "export card" and have net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 million, provided that the firm's total foreign investments do not exceed 40 per cent of its assets in Spain. Other direct investments are subject to more severe restrictions. Portfolio investments by all residents and purchases of real estate abroad by private persons are severely restricted. However, regis- tered investment funds w i th assets of at least Ptas 1 bil- lion are permitted to place up to 10 per cent of their assets in foreign securities that are officially quoted on specified stock exchanges abroad. Approval of requests by nonbank resident firms to grant loans to nonresidents is based on criteria similar to those applied to residents' requests to make direct investments abroad. Suppliers' credits from Spanish resi- dents to nonresidents require authorization by the Minis- try of Commerce; such authorization accompanies the export license. There has been no experience with the issuing of bonds in the Spanish capital market by nonresidents, nor with short-term credits granted by Spanish banks to nonresidents other than certain export credit granted direct to foreign importers. Credits to nonresidents for transactions with Spain may, however, be authorized by the Ministry of Commerce. Also, the authorized banks may extend various types of credit to nonresidents, pro- vided that this credit is financed with funds deposited in Spain in nonresident convertible currency accounts; some forms of such credit do not require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce. Local bank credit at medium term or long term to Spanish firms with foreign participation in excess of 25 per cent is subject to spe- cial directives, but domestic bank credit for up to 18 months may be granted, irrespective of the degree of 408 foreign participation, on the same conditions as to wholly Spanish-owned firms. For transfers abroad of bona fide inheritances and dowries, authorizations are granted liberally. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Spain for num isma t ic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized indus t r ial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By law, only the Bank of Spain is allowed to import or export gold; industrial requirements are met by imports effected by the Bank of Spain. There is a global quota for imports of gold from member countries of the EEC. Changes during 1975 January 7. With one general exception, however, investments made prior to February 1, 1975 were exempt from declaration; their liquidation, nevertheless, was subject to declaration. January 31. The rules governing External Accounts in Internal Pesetas were modified. (1) The kind of assets in which balances held by foreign companies (excluding their establishments in Spain) and nonresi- dent physical persons (whether of Spanish or foreign ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution nationality) could be invested was extended to include private and government fixed-interest securities. As previously, earnings on eligible assets were freely trans- ferable. (2) The principal invested in these assets (including any capital gains) was made transferable, provided that the investment had been maintained in the same securities, without interruption, for at least three consecutive years; otherwise, the sales proceeds had to be credited to an External Account in Internal Pesetas. (3) The use of pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas for the purchase of rural properties for personal use was l im i ted to nonresident physical persons of Spanish nationality. In addition, un iform treatment was henceforth accorded to balances in External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, with the elimination of the distinction between those released prior to June 1, 1972 and those released on or after that date (Resolution No. 2134 of Janu- ary 23, 1975 of the Directorate-General for External Transactions). February 14. Commodities under 65 tariff headings were deliberalized by transfer f rom the import free list to the global quota list. The global quotas were announced in a Resolution of February 27. March 21. For travel to Andorra, the amount of Spanish banknotes that travelers may take out was increased from Ptas 3,000 to Ptas 10,000 a person. April 10. An Order of March 5 of the Ministry of Finance came into force which allowed Spanish compa- nies with foreign participation to obtain domestic credit for up to 18 months on the same conditions as wholly Spanish-owned firms. As regards medium-term and long-term credit, companies w i th foreign participation not exceeding 25 per cent were authorized to obtain credits of over 18 months without restriction, while companies with foreign participation of more than 25 per cent could obtain domestic credit up to 50 per cent of paid-up capital and reserves, if they could at the same time obtain external credit (in a proportion to the total credit at least equal to the percentage of the foreign participation in the company). These firms had two months to submit details of their capital and of any investments held in other Span- ish companies. May 29.
