Holders of investments so financed were entitled to all rights of transfer abroad to which foreign investors were entitled. June 21. Decree No. 1361/1975 of June 20 came into effect. It revoked the temporary import duty reduc- tions introduced by Decrees Nos. 1426/1973 and 1467/1973 of June 1973. July 4. The Directorate-General of Exports issued a resolution concerning the "global export regime," modi- fy ing the provisions of the relevant resolution of August 12, 1974, which was revoked. The new resolu- tion specified the goods that could be exported to any country (except payments agreement countries) under global export licenses, as well as the permissible export credit periods. July 24. Decree No. 2185/1975 modified the regula- tions concerning temporary imports, including those for re-export. August 7. The export du ty on olive oil was abolished. August 27. A resolution of July 30 of the Directorate- General for External Transactions was gazetted, which regulated purchases of real estate by nonresident physi- cal persons of foreign nationality. Such persons could freely, w i th funds imported f rom abroad, purchase ( 1) plots of land not exceeding 5,000 square meters for the construction of one single-family dwelling for the owner's personal use; (2) land for the construction of apartment buildings, provided that no member of the apartment building commun i ty owned more than three apartments in the building for which the site was pur- chased; and (3) for business purposes, up to three com- mercial premises w i th a max imum total area of 200 square meters. The relevant resolution of December 20, 1974 was revoked. September 25. Exports of specified fresh f ru i ts and vegetables became subject to export levies at rates not exceeding the difference between domestic and foreign prices. September 29. The Bank of Spain suspended its deal- ings in Mexican pesos and Portuguese escudps. Dealings in escudos were resumed on February 13, 1976. December 31. An Order of the Ministry of Finance provided for certain changes in the regime established under an Order of July 9, 1974 for the granting of credit to finance the working capital of export firms. The new regulations came into force on January 1, 1976. 409 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.149297 gram of fine gold per Sri Lanka Rupee. The Sri Lanka rupee is pegged to ster- ling at the rate of SL Rs 15.60 = £ stg. 1. The official exchange rate is applicable to receipts from major exports and to payments for "A category" imports (rice, wheat flour, fertilizers, Western Pharmaceuticals, and certain other imports classified as essentials), as well as some invisibles. Another effective rate of SL Rs 25.74 = <£ stg. 1 arises from transactions in Foreign Exchange Entitle- ment Certificates (henceforth called certificates), which exporters of nontraditional exports (i.e., exports other than black tea, rubber, and major coconut products) and most other earners or recipients of foreign exchange are entitled to receive upon surrender of foreign exchange earned. Nonresident travelers, when converting foreign exchange into Sri Lanka rupees at the official rate, may also receive either corresponding certificates or their cash value in rupees. The certificates are denominated in Sri Lanka rupees and are issued with a face value equivalent at the official rate to the foreign exchange surrendered; they are not transferable and must be surrendered to authorized dealers within 30 days of the date of issue for encashment at a price of SL Rs 65 per SL Rs 100 in certificates. Additional certificates are sold by commercial banks on behalf of the Central Bank of Ceylon upon demand and at the same price; such certifi- cates also are not transferable. Certificates with a face value corresponding at the official rate to the amount of foreign exchange required must be surrendered when purchasing foreign exchange for payments in respect of most imports and most invisibles. The commercial banks deal in certificates for up to four months forward, at SL Rs 66 selling, and SL Rs 64 buying, per SL Rs 100 certificate; transactions are permitted only when relating to anticipated genuine payments and receipts in foreign exchange to which the certificate requirements or privi- leges are applicable. The Central Bank deals in U.S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees only. While its spot rates for sterling and the Indian rupee are fixed, the Central Bank determines exchange parities for some 20 other foreign currencies, including the U.S. dollar, from time to time on the basis of London market rates for those currencies. Rates for other foreign currencies are determined by commercial banks, also on the basis of London market rates. The Central Bank stands ready to provide forward cover to commercial banks in U.S. dollars, sterling, and Indian rupees, buying and selling. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Exchange Control of the Central Bank of Ceylon as 410 agent of the Government. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is drawn up annually by the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs. This Ministry is responsible for the exchange allocations for government departments and public corporations. Within a block allocation to private sector importers, licenses for the industrial sector are issued by the Actual Users Division of the Ministry of Industries and Scientific Affairs. Otherwise, import and export licensing is han- dled by the Controller of Imports and Exports. All remittances of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka must be made through commercial banks authorized to carry out operations in foreign currencies in accordance with the exchange control procedures prescribed by the Control- ler of Exchange. Remittances may also be made through post offices, under permits issued by the Controller of Exchange. Prescription of Currency Sri Lanka has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Payments to countries that prior to June 23, 1972 were Scheduled Territories may continue to be made in the currencies of such countries, and receipts from such countries continue to be acceptable in the currencies of such countries, with the exception that export proceeds normally must be received in prescribed currencies (see below). Settlements with countries with which Sri Lanka has bilateral payments agreements * and with Egypt must be made through the relevant special accounts. Payments in respect of trade with Pakistan also are effected through special accounts. Payments to, and receipts from, mem- ber countries of the Asian Clearing Union other than Pakistan (i.e., Bangladesh, India, Iran, and Nepal) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) must be effected in Asian monetary units through the Asian Clearing Union; for settlements with Pakistan, this is applicable to invisibles only. Payments to all other coun- tries except Rhodesia may be made by crediting sterling or Sri Lanka rupees to a sterling External Account or an External Rupee Account, or in the currency of the creditor country. Furthermore, payments for imports not originating in countries with which bilateral pay- ments agreements are in force (nor in Rhodesia) may be made in any foreign currency, i.e., any currency other than the Sri Lanka rupee. Receipts f rom all other coun- 1 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, German Democratic Repub- lic, North Korea, Syrian Arab Republic, and U.S.S.R. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution tries except Rhodesia may be accepted in Sri Lanka rupees from an approved account or in any prescribed currency.2 Transactions involving deviations from the general procedures require the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Special procedures apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident Accounts may be held in Sri Lanka by banks, corporations, or persons residing abroad. Trans- fers of balances in these accounts to sterling External Accounts or External Rupee Accounts require approval by the Controller of Exchange. Blocked Accounts are used for holding funds that may not be transferred abroad and that are owned by nonresidents, repatriates, and emigrants. Such funds, unless they originate from payments for imports, may be used in Sri Lanka for certain investments, subject to the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Pro- ceeds from the liquidation of such investments must be credited to Blocked Accounts. Also retained in Blocked Accounts is a proportion of local currency earnings, derived from the exhibition of foreign-owned films, if the takings exceed the amount specified in the import license; such retained funds may be used by the owner for certain specified purposes, including the making of films in Sri Lanka. Special Accounts may be maintained in Sri Lanka by nationals of Sri Lanka working abroad. Credits to the accounts are limited to the proceeds of remittances from abroad (inclusive of the value of the certificates to which the remittances entitle the holder) but the accounts may be freely debited for payments within Sri Lanka. Balances in such accounts are exempt from wealth tax, and income arising from investments made out of such balances with the approval of the Controller of Exchange is exempt from income tax; the value of such investments is also exempt from wealth tax. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for imports by the Food Commissioner's Department and certain minor imports (such as trade samples, gifts of up to SL Rs 750, and books up to certain specified amounts for each consignment), all imports require individual licenses. All trade imports are subject to quota restrictions. They are divided into two groups—the A category and the B category. Imports in the A category broadly comprise basic necessities, Western Pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, books and periodicals, and two-wheeled trac- tors. The B category includes all remaining imports. The value and composition of imports are established 2 Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. SRI LANKA by an annual import program. Imports of many non- essential items or goods similar to locally produced items are either not permitted or considerably restricted. The right to import is restricted to government de- partments, government-sponsored corporations, and registered importers, although private individuals are allowed to import certain commodities for their own use, subject to special authorization. Imports of speci- fied commodities 3 are restricted to government or state corporations, the Cooperative Wholesale Establishment, or the Lanka Salu Sala Ltd.; these commodities are referred to as "reserved items." In order to allocate foreign exchange, applicants for import licenses are divided into three groups: (1) actual users of industrial raw materials, machinery, etc., (2) those who import other goods for their own use and not for resale, and (3) established importers who import goods for trading purposes. Public sector imports shipped or transshipped from places served by vessels of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation must be carried in vessels owned or chartered by the Corporation, whenever such shipping space is available. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these for certain imports, including items otherwise not permitted, subject to approval by the Controller of Imports and Exports and, in some cases, the Controller of Exchange. An authorized dealer may approve an application to remit foreign exchange or to credit a nonresident ac- count when the applicant furnishes or undertakes to furn ish evidence of importation and the cost of the goods together with a valid importer's copy and an exchange control copy of the import license. Payment for imports in the B category requires, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange involved, surrender of certificates with a face value equal to the rupee payment; imports in the A category do not require the surrender of certificates. Import licenses for certain imports (primarily food products, industrial raw mate- rials, and machinery) may be subject to a minimum deferred payment term. Letters of credit against such licenses may be opened provided that drafts are drawn payable either not earlier than 6 months after shipment or 12 months or later after shipment, in accordance with the terms of the import license. Payments for certain imports under trade credits of 90, 180, or 365 days' duration are exempt from the requirement of surrender of certificates. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control permission and, with certain exceptions, require sur- 3These include mainly rice, wheat, flour (except corn flour), unre- fined sugar, refined sugar, Maldive fish, dried fish, cumin seed, masoor dhal, dried chilies, coriander, pulses, yeast and baking powder, garlic, fennel seed, mathe seed, turmeric, dates, sultanas and raisins, cement, fish meal, corn, caustic soda, cotton yarn, newsprint and other paper products, petroleum products, and textiles and manufactures of textile materials. 411 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA render of certificates corresponding to the full amount of the foreign payment. Exempt from surrender of certifi- cates are ( 1) expenditures for certain approved courses of study abroad; (2) remittances abroad by non- nationals for fam i ly maintenance, up to certain limits; (3) provident fund contributions and life insurance premiums which commenced prior to the introduction on May 6, 1968 of the certificate scheme; (4) pensions and the final remittance, on retirement, of pension and provident funds, contributions to which commenced prior to May 6, 1968; (5) expenditures of foreign embassies, official international organizations, and for- eign diplomatic personnel; and (6) other expenditures abroad specifically exempted f rom the certificate sur- render requirement by the Controller of Exchange. The remittance of life insurance premiums on policies in foreign currencies purchased by nonnationals residing temporarily in Sri Lanka is permitted, and such policies are considered as part of the assets available to them on retirement. Foreign exchange for personal travel abroad is only granted for emigration, the taking up of employment abroad, and furloughs of nonnationals. Business travel is generally limited to travel for the promotion of exports and of tourism, and exchange up to a maximum of <£ stg. 15 a day for persons of the rank of chairman or director of a firm or corporation and of <£ stg. 10 a day for other executives for a maximum period of 30 days is allowed in such cases. Exchange for educational expenses is allocated only for certain courses of study that w i ll be of positive value to the country and that are not available in Sri Lanka; allocations are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance, acting on the personal recommendation of the Minister of Education. For study in educational institutions in "Asian group" countries,4 exchange up to a maximum of SL Rs 250 a month for undergraduate studies or up to SL Rs 450 a month for postgraduate studies is allowed, as well as SL Rs 250 a year for books plus actual fees. For study in the United Kingdom, foreign exchange is made available at <£ stg. 45 a month for undergraduate studies, and at <£ stg. 60 a month for postgraduate studies, plus actual fees, and £ stg. 25 a year for the cost of books. Following the devaluation of the pound sterling in November 1967, students in countries whose currencies were not devalued were allowed supplementary remit- tances to enable them to receive the same amount as previously in the currency concerned. For study in such countries (other than the United States and Canada ), the maximum allowable is <£ stg. 53 a month for under- graduate studies and <£ stg. 70 a month for post- graduate studies; the maximum for the United States 4 The "Asian group" is listed as Aden, Afghanistan, the East African region, Brunei, Bu rma, Egypt, Hong Kong, India, Indochina, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Malaysia, Pak is tan, Persian Gulf Sheikdoms, Saudi Arabia, Syrian Arab Republic, Thailand, and Turkey. 412 and Canada is US$225 a month and US$240 a month for undergraduate and postgraduate studies, respectively (in addition to an annual book allowance and actual fees). For travel (and other expenses) for medical reasons, exchange is authorized if a certificate is produced from a medical specialist in Sri Lanka and supported by the Director of Health Services that equally effective treat- ment cannot be obtained in Sri Lanka; the amount authorized will depend on the estimated cost, as cer- tified by the specialist. Indian and Pakistani nationals are permitted to remit for fam i ly maintenance a max imum of SL Rs 750 a month or one third of their gross monthly income, whichever is less. Other foreign nationals are permitted to remit <£ stg. 85 a month for a wife, <£ stg. 105 for a boy in a senior school, <£ stg. 100 for a girl in a senior school, <£ stg. 75 for a child in a jun ior school, and <£ stg. 25 for other children, up to a maximum of two thirds of the gross monthly income when dependents are direct ones. For other dependents, this ceiling is one third of the gross monthly income. When the amount claimed on this basis exceeds one third of the gross monthly income, the excess will be treated as an anticipatory transfer to be set off against the amount the repatriate is entitled to remit upon departure. Tem- porary residents on short-term contracts are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their gross monthly income. Nationals of Sri Lanka are not granted exchange for fam i ly remittances. Commissions up to 5 per cent of the c.i.f. value are allowed on export orders secured through agents abroad. No remittances for insurance on exports are permitted; these must be covered with the Insurance Corporation of Sri Lanka. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts may use these funds for travel expenditures and other current invisibles, subject to approval by the Controller of Exchange. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign exchange declared to the customs at the time of entry; they may not take out Sri Lanka currency notes and coins. Resi- dents may take out foreign currency notes and coins not exceeding the equivalent of SL Rs 50 a person (SL Rs 25 for children under 12) once in 12 months, provided that they have been granted exchange for travel. Subject to the approval of the Controller of Exchange, residents may also export domestic currency notes of a value not exceeding SL Rs 50 a person (SL Rs 25 for children under 12). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Permits issued by the Controller of Exchange are required for all commercial exports, and exports to countries with which Sri Lanka ma in ta ins bilateral payments agreements are subject to the approval of the Director of Commerce. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Furthermore, most exports require an export license issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports; licenses for tea are issued by the Commissioner of Tea Exports and those for coconut products by the Coconut Market- ing Board. Rubber exports to the People's Republic of China, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are under state trading. The State Gem Corporation has the exclusive right to export gems and exports of private exporters are made with the permission of the Cor- poration; it also handles exports in the names of gem miners who wish to export gems through the Corpora- tion. Re-exports of nonmonetary gold, silver, and dia- monds are allowed only in special circumstances. The Controller of Exchange issues the permit for a commercial export when he is satisfied that payment representing fair value for the goods has been or will be received in Sri Lanka by approved methods of payment and, usually, within six months from the date of ship- ment. Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered. There are special arrangements, how- ever, for gems and nontraditional exports. Exporters may maintain accounts, designated Convertible Rupee Accounts, with authorized dealers in Sri Lanka. These may be credited with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. Sri Lanka rupee value (inclusive of certificates) of the net export proceeds of gems, with 5 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates where ap- plicable) of nontraditional exports, and with 20 per cent of the f.o.b. value in Sri Lanka rupees (inclusive of certificates) of net export proceeds of original and individual works of art by individuals. Debits to the accounts are permitted for imports, travel and study abroad, other payments which are not of a capital nature, and transfers to other Convertible Rupee Accounts. Exporters of all goods other than black tea in bulk and in packets, rubber (excluding sponge rubber), coconut oil, copra, desiccated coconut, and fresh coco- nuts are entitled to receive certificates with a face value in Sri Lanka rupees equal to the f.o.b. value of exports, upon surrender to an authorized bank of the foreign exchange actually earned. Exporters can use these cer- tificates as supporting documents when buying foreign exchange for payment of imports, or for other payments abroad, which require the surrender of certificates. Cer- tificates have to be surrendered to the monetary authori- ties or to an authorized bank within 30 days of issue. The holders can use them when making foreign ex- change payments within seven months from the date of issue; at the end of the seven-month period, the validity of the certificate lapses. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Receipts under the following headings entitle the recipient to obtain certificates with a face value equivalent to the value of the foreign exchange surrendered to an authorized bank: (1) travel receipts; SRI LANKA (2) insurance receipts; (3) investment income; (4) pri- vate transfers and donations; (5) small savings remitted to Sri Lanka by workers abroad;5 and (6) miscellaneous other inward remittances as determined, on a case-by- case basis, by the Chief Accountant of the Central Bank. Nonresident travelers are eligible to receive certificates corresponding to the amount of foreign exchange con- verted with authorized dealers; alternatively, the latter may pay the traveler, in addition to the rupee equivalent of the foreign exchange sold, the cash value of the certificate. Part of the Sri Lanka rupee equivalent of certain proceeds from invisibles may be credited to Convertible Rupee Accounts; this proportion is 5 per cent of gross foreign exchange earnings from tourism, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings by individuals from the sale of their original and individual works of art to tourists in Sri Lanka and from the publication abroad of scien- tific and literary works, 20 per cent of foreign exchange earnings from professional and consultancy services performed abroad by individuals, and 5 per cent of the proceeds from such services performed by firms, com- panies, etc. A traveler entering Sri Lanka must declare his hold- ings, including currency notes and coins. The amount of foreign funds that may be carried into Sri Lanka in the form of travel credit instruments is not restricted. The import of Sri Lanka, Indian, and Pakistan currency is not permitted; however, Sri Lanka notes in denomina- tions of SL Rs 10 or less may be imported up to SL Rs 50, provided that evidence of prior export of such notes by the same traveler is produced. Other currency notes and coins may be taken in without restriction. Capital Investments of foreign capital are permitted in pro- jects which are specifically approved by the Govern- ment, or, where the capital is drawn from a Blocked Account in Sri Lanka, in certain investments in Sri Lanka that have been approved by the Controller of Exchange, including shares of public companies incor- porated in Sri Lanka; capital transfers for direct invest- ment in Sri Lanka are entitled to receive certificates upon conversion of the foreign exchange into rupees. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments in approved projects other than investments made from Blocked Accounts may be repatriated, along with capital appreciation; transfers require the surrender of certificates. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments not approved by the Government may not be transferred abroad, but they may be reinvested with 5 Since December 17, 1971 Sri Lanka nationals employed abroad and not availing themselves of the Special Accounts scheme for small sav- ings introduced on February 6, 1971 may be required to remit to Sri Lanka a specified percentage of their annual earnings, if these exceed specified amounts. Compliance may be required for annual passport renewal. The funds remitted are entitled to certificates upon conversion but may not be used for imports or payments abroad. 413 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA the approval of the Controller of Exchange; the current income thereon may be remitted abroad. New foreign investments in Sri Lanka that are con- sidered and approved by the Foreign Investment Ad- visory Committee of the Ministry of Planning and Economic Affairs are also granted special facilities in respect of remittances and taxation. Investments abroad by residents are not normally permitted. Resident-owned securities on which the principal, in- terest, or dividends are payable (either contractually or at the option of the holder) in any foreign currency must be declared to the Controller of Exchange, and the sale or transfer of such securities is allowed only with the permission of the Controller of Exchange. Emigrants are allowed to purchase foreign exchange up to the equivalent of <£ stg. 100 and the cost of passage, subject to reimbursement within three years. They may also export their personal and household effects up to SL Rs 5,000, and their personal jewelry up to SL Rs 7,500. Emigrants over 60 years of age are also permitted remittances of pensions or other in- come accruing in Sri Lanka up to <£ stg. 25 a month. Otherwise, emigrants are not permitted capital remit- tances except on grounds of dire hardship, nor gener- ally, remittances of income (including pensions) accru- ing in Sri Lanka. However, certain remittances of income may be approved to persons over 55 who emi- grated before June 26, 1973, and pension payments to persons pensioned by the Government of Sri Lanka who emigrated before 1964 have been continued with- out interruption. Repatriates leaving Sri Lanka for residence in the country of their permanent domicile are permitted, at the time of their departure, to transfer assets represent- ing their retirement funds and a reasonable amount of savings as determined by the Government f rom time to time. For persons who have been in business in Sri Lanka, the capital they originally brought into the country plus a reasonable amount of savings are allowed to be transferred, subject to certain limits. The transfer of personal assets and of income thereon requires the surrender of certificates; exempt are ( 1) balances on provident and pension funds held abroad and repre- senting contributions in respect of contractual obliga- tions entered into before May 6, 1968, (2) provident and pension funds held in rupees in Sri Lanka, and (3) the value of insurance policies held abroad and taken out before May 6, 1968. Special provisions, governed by an agreement between Sri Lanka and India, apply to Indian families returning to India. Gold Imports and exports of gold in any form require licenses issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports with the approval of the Central Bank. Such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports 414 by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. The People's Bank is the sole importer of gold; it has not imported any nonmonetary gold since July 1972. It sells gold in small quantities to licensed craftsmen and jewelers and also to hospitals. Commercial imports of jewelry and of other articles containing gold are severely restricted. No credits to Convertible Rupee Accounts are allowed for the gold or silver content of commercial exports of jewelry. Changes during 1975 January 7. Other fore ign personnel work ing in the Sudan under certain contracts, as well as foreign nationals residing in the Sudan, may ma in ta in resident current or savings accounts in Sudanese pounds. Blocked Accounts are ma in ta ined by fo rmer residents; earnings accruing to these accounts may be used within the Sudan by the account holder for his personal expenses up to limits established in each case by the exchange control authorities. Except for the crediting of interest, all debits and credits to Blocked Accounts requ ire approval. Imports and Import Payments Certain imports are prohibited for protective reasons and others are not being licensed. Imports f rom Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica also are prohibited. Per- mitted impor ts generally are licensed or accepted for reg is tra t ion in accordance with allocations under the foreign exchange budget. Impor ts of certain consumer goods and commercial trucks are eligible for importa- t ion on a barter basis. Certain imports are permitted only when acceptable fore ign financing is obtained. Sugar and wheat are imported by a state agency only. For goods that require ind iv idual licensing, import licenses must be obtained f rom the M in is try of Finance and Na t ional Economy and validated ( f r a n k e d) by the Exchange Control Department of the central bank. "Nil" licenses, which also require f rank ing, are issued for certain imports financed with foreign exchange held abroad by residents and by Sudanese expatriates or offi- cials stationed abroad. Import insurance normally must be taken out w i th local companies. Most private sector imports are subject to an advance deposit of 2 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable before validation and a sur- charge of 5 per cent is levied on the c.i.f. value of all imports; capital goods, heavy trucks, tires and tubes, and medicines are exempt from advance deposits. Goods otherwise subject to the advance deposit requirements are exempt when financed with suppliers' credit of at least two years' ma tu r i ty, provided that the amount of the transaction is at least LSd 500,000. If a letter of credit is opened, the authorized bank usually requires a cash margin of 10 per cent to 30 per cent. In prac- tice, for many goods whose impor ta t ion the banks are not allowed to finance, a 100 per cent margin deposit must be made. A s tamp du ty of LSd 5 is levied on the application form for each remittance in respect of pri- vate sector imports. Most imports are subject to a devel- opment tax of 2 per cent ad valorem. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control approval. Remittances are permitted for family mainte- nance (up to LSd 500 a person a yea r ), educational ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution expenses (up to LSd 1,200 a student a year for Western Europe, in addition to tu i t ion fees; study in the United States is exempt f rom this ce i l ing ), and for certain other purposes. Allowances for tourist travel to countries other than Egypt are authorized by the commercial banks up to a max imum of LSd 60 every other year for each adult traveling to Western Europe and the United States, and LSd 40 every other year for travel to other areas. Allowances for nonbusiness travel to Egypt, how- ever, are the equivalent of LSd 50 an adult, and LSd 30 a child, a year, and are also authorized by the commer- cial banks. Exchange for travel must be purchased at an effective exchange rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50. Sudanese nationals resident abroad who remit foreign exchange to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 — US$2.50 may at the same rate obtain foreign exchange equivalent to 75 per cent of the amount con- verted in any one year and use this exchange to make personal remittances abroad. Sudanese Government offi- cials (other than seconded s t a f f) and students receiving educational allowances at the official rate are not entitled to avail themselves of this arrangement. Salaried foreign nationals not permanen t ly resident in the Sudan, except Egyptian nationals, are permitted to remit their bona fide current savings to any country other than Israel, Rhodesia, or South A f r ica, Shipping charges, insurance premiums, profits, interest, and divi- dends earned by nonresidents may be remitted freely upon presentation of the required documents. The remittance of income accruing from blocked assets in the Sudan (including income from Blocked Accounts) is prohibited, except for earnings f rom investments in government securities made before 1970. The exporta- tion of Sudanese currency is prohibited. Stamp duties are payable on the application forms for virtually all payments for invisibles. The duty is LSd 5 on appli- cations for remittances of profits and dividends, for other transfers, and for foreign exchange for business travel, LSd 2 on applications for foreign exchange for tourism, and from LSd 1 to LSd 0.25 on applications for remittances for other purposes; government remit- tances and those by diplomats are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. With the exception of cotton and gum arabic, all exports require a license. Exporters must submit an export form to an authorized bank. Autho- rized banks may approve these forms only if payment is in the form of cash against documents or against sight letters of credit; exports on credit require the approval of the Bank of Sudan. All commodities are subject to m in imum export prices. The proceeds of exports must be repatriated and surrendered through an authorized bank. When the terms of payment are cash against documents or sight letter of credit, proceeds must be surrendered on delivery of the shipping documents; in other cases a surrender date is usually specified. Some SUDAN major export commodities are exported solely by public sector entities. At the end of 1975, the export of some commodities (including meat and du r ra) was prohibited for supply reasons, and the export of certain others was permitted only when the proceeds were to be received in convertible currencies. Certain minor exports may be sold on a barter basis. Most exports are subject to a development tax of 2 per cent ad valorem. Proceeds from Invisibles Sudanese nationals resident abroad other than gov- ernment officials or students may remit foreign exchange in convertible currencies to the Sudan for conversion at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50, and receive an incen- tive bonus of 60 per cent per annum which is paid on amounts so transferred to the Sudan and kept in a spe- cial account for at least six mon ths ;3 75 per cent of the remittances so received may be repatriated at the end of the six-month period but in that case the bonus is forfe i ted and the remittance becomes subject to the pre- vailing exchange tax. Receipts from abroad in respect of invisibles must be surrendered to authorized banks and are subject to the general prescription of currency requirements. Travelers entering the Sudan may bring in any amount in notes and coins of other countries permitted by their regulations to be taken out of those countries. However, the importation of Sudanese cur- rency is forbidden. Capital Under the Development and Promotion of Industrial Investment Act, 1972, which superseded the Organiza- tion and Promotion of Industrial Investment Act of 1967, incoming foreign capital for industrial investment may be registered and thus may receive, among other advantages, a guarantee for repatriation of the original capital and profits thereon. Emigrants of Sudanese nationality may on departure transfer up to the equiva- lent of LSd 1,500 to their new country. Upon emigra- tion from the Sudan, resident foreigners may transfer up to the equivalent of LSd 2,500. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in the Sudan for num isma t ic purposes. Subject to certain conditions, residents may also purchase, hold, and sell in the Sudan domestically produced gold. With these exceptions, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other thari jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Bank of Sudan; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the mone- tary authorities and industrial users. Some newly mined gold is exported for processing and then reimported. 3 This bonus is payable only once, irrespective of the length of time by which the deposit period might exceed six months. 417 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SUDAN Changes during 1975 January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1974 of the bilateral payments agreement with Czecho- slovakia, settlements with that country were placed on a convertible currency basis. January 9. The 1974 regulation was amended which had canceled all export licenses for meat and livestock for which letters of credit had not been opened prior to December 17, 1974. Letters of credit could still be opened until January 31, but existing contracts could not be modified. February 1. Exports of durra and millet were pro- hibited. February 18. The bilateral payments agreement with Poland expired. March. A new marketing policy designed to encour- age exports was adopted. In addition to price conces- sions, it made provision for deferred payments for exports. A flexible pricing policy would be followed for cotton exports, which now could also be sold on deferred payment terms. March 31. The bilateral payments agreement with the German Democratic Republic expired. Settlements were placed on a convertible currency basis. April 5. The Ministry of Finance and National Econ- omy announced that it would consider applications for imports to be financed with foreign credit facilities, if the terms and conditions of finance were reasonable and there was actual need for the commodities involved. April 5. Applications for "nil" licenses for commer- cial imports henceforth would be considered only from Sudanese expatriates working abroad; in certain cases applications for imports for personal use would also be considered. Among those eligible to apply were gov- ernment officials abroad, Sudanese diplomats, and Suda- nese on secondment abroad. Other Sudanese could apply provided they presented documents concerning the source of finance. April 8. Exports of dom nuts, mother of pearl and trochus shells, henna, and crude animal materials could be licensed on a fu ll barter basis. In addition, melon seeds and gourd seeds, honey, beeswax, and fruits could be exported on a partial barter basis, with 50 per cent of the proceeds to be obtained in convertible currencies. At the same time, specified consumer goods and other items became eligible for importation on a barter basis; these were spices; sandalwood and mahlab, perfumes, and cosmetics; television sets, radios, and tape recorders; commercial trucks; certain undergarments and ready- made clothing; toys; and groceries. April 26. The ban on payments to, and trade with, Portugal was lifted. May 2. Export proceeds of gum arabic became eli- gible for the 15 per cent exchange subsidy. As a result, cotton remained the only export not settled at the rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50. July 17. Licensing of imports from India for settle- ment under the bilateral payments agreement was sus- pended. The suspension was subsequently lifted. 418 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SURINAM* (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.457587 gram of fine gold per Surinam Guilder. Surinam has established a central rate of Sur. f. 1.78876 = US$1, and avails itself of wider margins. The fixed official rates for the U.S. dollar are Sur. f. 1.77 buying, and Sur. f. 1.80 selling, per US$1. There are also fixed official buy ing and selling rates of Sur. f. 1.75 and Sur. f. 1.80 for U.S. banknotes. The rates for other foreign currencies1 are set daily by the Central Bank of Surinam on the basis of the market quotations for the U.S. dollar and those currencies in Amsterdam and the fixed buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in Surinam, net of any commissions. There is no exchange market in Surinam. Administration of Control In principle, all foreign exchange dealings are subject to license, as are dealings between residents and nonresi- dents in domestic currency and other domestic assets. The authority to grant exchange licenses is vested in the Foreign Exchange Board, which has delegated much of this authority and issues licenses mainly for capital transactions and certain invisibles. The Board has autho- rized the Director of Economic A f fa i rs (or, on his behalf, the Head of the Import, Export, and Foreign Exchange Division of the M in is try of Economic A f fa i r s) to issue import and export licenses, and has empowered the Central Bank of Surinam to provide foreign exchange for import payments (subject to presentation of an import l icense); the latter authority is exercised through the commercial banks, which have all been appointed as authorized banks by the Foreign Exchange Board. The authorized banks are empowered to provide foreign exchange for specified current payments without requir- ing an exchange license. They may also accept free of license those inward transfers of foreign exchange that do not result from borrowing abroad; the taking up of foreign loans is subject to Foreign Exchange Board approval. Except in the circumstances specified above, the authorized banks are not permitted to sell foreign exchange without requiring the submission of an exchange license by the remitter. Prescription of Currency Settlements in Surinam guilders between Surinam and foreign countries other than the Netherlands Antilles are not permitted; they must, in general, be made in convertible currencies2 although payments to and f rom * Surinam is not a member of the International Monetary Fund. 1 All currencies other than the Surinam guilder are considered for- eign currencies. 2 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Barbados dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, East Carib- bean dollars, French francs, Guyana dollars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Trinidad and Tobago dollars, and U.S. dollars. the Netherlands Antilles may also be made in Nether- lands Antilles guilders or Surinam guilders. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks, may freely open accounts in U.S. dollars with domestic banks; no overdrafts are permitted. Nonresidents other than banks may freely open accounts in Surinam guilders with domestic banks; certain debits and credits are covered by a general license, while all others are subject to a specific license. These accounts must not be overdrawn, and debits for certain specified purposes must not exceed a total of Sur. f. 3,000 a month. Authorized banks have also been granted a general license permitting them to open nonresident accounts in Surinam guilders in the name of nonresident banks; these accounts also must not be overdrawn. Nonresident guilders or foreign cur- rency accounts may not be credited with Surinam bank- notes mailed from abroad or with the foreign currency equivalent. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all imports.3 Some items, such as specified explosives and narcotics, are prohibited for reasons of public policy or health. Imports of a few other commodities are prohibited from non- EEC sources for protective reasons and are subject to quota when originating in EEC countries; they include coffee (roasted and unroas ted), sugar, powdered milk, butter (in packs of 500 grams or less), most worked and unworked wood, and certain metal furn i ture. The import of prohibited goods may be allowed when there is a need for them, provided that they cannot be obtained in Surinam. Another group of commodities are subject to quota, irrespective of origin; these include matches, prefabricated wooden houses, certain women's wear, certain footwear, and certain wooden or cane furniture. Special conditions are attached to the import of copra, rice, butter (in packs of over 500 grams), wheat flour (in packs of over 1,000 grams), veneer, and fu rn i tu re that is on neither the prohibited nor the restricted list; the import of these commodities also is restricted for protective reasons but the issuance of licenses is subject to administrative decision rather than to quota. A government agency, the Surinam Central Import Service, acts as the sole importer of certain staple foodstuffs. All other imports are licensed freely from any source. The import license serves as a payment license, exchange being made available upon presenta- tion of the license. Most licenses have a validity of six 3 However, two specified mining companies do not need licenses for their own import requirements. The commercial banks and the General Post Office have authority to provide foreign exchange up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month on account of certain services (bank charges, legal fees, membership dues, copy and patent rights, and so f o r t h ); up to Sur. f. 150 an item a month for advertising expenses and payments for books; up to Sur. f. 300 a year from each remitter in respect of gifts, subject to a limit of Sur. f. 300 a year on any beneficiary's receipt of gifts from Surinamese residents; and up to Sur. f. 200-300 a month for the support of each member of the remitter's own fam i ly in the Netherlands Antilles or the Netherlands, subject to a l im it of Sur. f. 600-900 a month for a f am i ly un it ( fam i ly remittances up to the same amoun ts to other countries require a license, which is gran ted upon application). The basic exchange allowance to residents for travel is Sur. f. 750-2,500 a person for each tr ip (50 per cent of these amounts for children under 14), depending on the destination;4 the authorized bank must enter on the travel ticket the amount of foreign exchange sold and the date, the purchase of travel exchange not being per- mitted until three days before departure. Travelers may take out Sur. f. 100 in Surinam currency. The export by resident travelers of foreign banknotes ( inc lud ing Netherlands currency) is limited to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident travelers may freely pur- chase and take out foreign currency up to the equivalent of Sur. f. 250. Nonresident travelers may also freely take out any foreign banknotes they brought in, pro- vided that amounts in excess of Sur. f. 5,000 were declared upon entry. Payments due as interest on loans and as net income from other investments, and payments of moderate amounts for amortization of loans or depreciation of direct investments, may be made if an application sup- ported by an auditor's report is duly presented to the Foreign Exchange Board for verification. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports require export licenses, which for most com- modities are issued freely, provided that the exporter undertakes to surrender the foreign currency proceeds to an authorized bank within six months of shipment. Export licenses for cattle and pigs, fresh beef and pork, and planting materials are granted only af ter favorable advice of the Director of Agriculture, Animal Hus- bandry, and Fisheries. The export of baboonwood is restricted and that of rice is subject to special regula- 4 Sur. f. 1,500 for the Caribbean area and Central and South America except Guyana, French Guyana, and Venezuela; Sur. f. 750 for Guyana and French Guyana; Sur. f. 2,500 for the United States, Canada, and Venezuela; and Sur. f. 2,000 for the rest of the world. 420 tions. Certain exporting companies have received spe- cial permission from the Foreign Exchange Board to maintain current accounts in foreign currency with their parent companies abroad and to use these for specified payments and receipts (including export proceeds). Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to an authorized bank. Travelers may bring in foreign currency without limit, and up to Sur. f. 100 in domestic currency; resident travelers must surrender any foreign currency in excess of the equivalent of Sur. f. 500. Capital A decision of September 21, 1960 of the Foreign Exchange Board provides for the transfer abroad of capital proceeds f rom the sale to residents or the liqui- dation of fu l ly or partly foreign-owned companies or other fo rms of enterprise. The decision covers invest- ments made by nonresidents with foreign capital after July 31, 1953. It also provides for the annual transfer of profits and for the transfer at any time of the foreign exchange (including loans) imported by the nonresident entrepreneur for the company's use. Profits must be transferred within a period of three years; otherwise, they are considered to have become part of the firm's work ing capital or to have been lent to the firm, and may only be transferred in annual quotas of 20 per cent. An Investment Law passed on February 3, 1960 pro- vides for additional incentives to private investment in Surinam. The Foreign Exchange Board grants licenses on appli- cation for transfers abroad from a deceased's estate, up to a max imum of Sur. f. 25,000. For estates of more than Sur. f. 25,000, fur ther annual transfers are per- mitted so as to spread them over a period not exceeding ten years. The Board allows emigrants (heads of fam- i ly) to transfer in foreign exchange the equivalent of Sur. f. 5,000 in a lump sum, and subsequently Sur. f. 5,000 a year. The head of a repatriating family is permitted to transfer the equivalent of Sur. f. 10,000 plus 10 per cent of his total taxable earnings in Surinam accrued during his period of residence; if his Surinamese assets exceed the sum thus calculated, the excess may be transferred at a rate of Sur. f. 10,000 a year, or at a higher rate when this is necessary to ensure that the entire balance is released within ten years. Subject to certain requirements, residents may pur- chase or sell in specified countries5 Surinamese corpo- rate shares that have been designated as negotiable by the Foreign Exchange Board. Transfers for investment in Netherlands or other foreign securities or real estate by residents are not permitted, although exceptions may 5 Belgium, Canada, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Netherlands Antilles, United Kingdom, and Un i ted States. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution be made for direct investments abroad when it is con- sidered that Surinamese interests will benefit. All borrow- ing from nonresidents by nonbank residents requires prior approval by the Foreign Exchange Board. The foreign transactions of authorized banks are restricted, in principle, to those undertaken for the account of their customers, and banks are required, in principle, to surrender to the Central Bank any excess of foreign currency purchased over foreign currency sold, but the Central Bank permits them to place part of their liquid funds abroad and they have received a general license to place abroad at short term U.S. dollars corresponding to balances in nonresident U.S. dollar accounts. Gold Producers of gold may sell only to authorized gold buyers. Locally produced gold must be surrendered to the Foreign Exchange Board by sale to the Central Bank at Sur. f. 2,110 a kilogram fine for bars of at least 10 kilograms or at Sur. f. 180 a gram for unworked gold with an average smelting loss of 6 per cent and an average gold content of 94%ooo.6 Authorized gold buyers are permitted, however, to sell nuggets at freely agreed prices to the public for industrial and artistic purposes; dealings between residents in gold bars and other forms of unworked gold, with the exception of nuggets, are prohibited. As local production does not meet demand for industrial purposes, the Central Bank imports some gold, which it sells to authorized gold buyers. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Surinam 6 These amounts are to be adjusted in accordance with the revision of the official U.S. dollar price per troy ounce. By the end of 1975 this had not yet been done. SURINAM for numismatic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Residents other than the mone- tary authorities, producers of gold, and authorized indus- trial and dental users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than nuggets, jewelry, or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange licenses 7 issued by the Foreign Exchange Board; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, producers of gold, and indus- trial users. Residents arriving from abroad, however, may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration, and provided that they surrender it to the Central Bank within 20 days. Nonresident travelers also may freely bring in gold, subject to declaration; they may re-export the declared amount freely. Imports of gold coins are duty free and those of unworked gold are subject to a duty of Sur. f. 0.0375 a gram, irrespective of origin. The general tariff for gold ornaments is 60 per cent ad valorem, but those of EEC origin are subject to duty at 50 per cent ad valorem. Imports of all forms of gold are subject to a statistical fee of 1.5 per cent and a licensing fee of 0.5 per cent. Not for Redistribution SWAZILAND (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange and Trade System Swaziland's currency is the Lilangeni (plural ema- langeni), which is at par with the South African rand; Swaziland also uses the rand as its currency, and both currencies are legal tender. No par value has been established for the lilangeni but a central rate of E 1.00 = R 1.00 has been established, and Swaziland avails itself of wider margins. The South African Reserve Bank on December 31, 1975 quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the South African Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against the rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. Swaziland has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a. country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Swaziland also forms part of the Rand Monetary Area which is a single exchange control terri- tory comprising Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland, and, on a de facto basis, Botswana.1 For purposes of exchange control over transactions in securities or gold, residents of a member country of the Rand Monetary Area are not regarded as residents of another member country. The Ministry of Finance and Economic Plan- ning controls all external currency transactions; trans- actions with residents of Rhodesia, or involving Rho- desian currency, are prohibited. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary Area, and in principle these are uncon- trolled. In relation to countries outside the Rand Mone- tary Area, Swaziland applies exchange controls that are generally similar to those of South Africa, although Swaziland's treatment of certain capital transfers to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area may be more liberal. Payments to nonresidents for current transac- tions, while subject to control, are not normally restricted, but applications for most outward transfers of capital are considered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Authority to approve some types of current payments is delegated to authorized dealers up to established limits; this is true, for example, of the basic exchange allowance for tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calen- dar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring coun- tries. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Holders of blocked emalangeni may purchase five-year 1 Botswana is not a party to the Rand Monetary Area Agreement of December 5, 1974 and, upon the issue of its own currency, is to be treated for exchange control purposes in the same manner as all other countries outside the Rand Monetary Area. 422 nonresident bonds, the maturity proceeds of which are transferable, five years after purchase, to the currency area of which the holder is a resident. Swaziland is a member of a customs union with Botswana, Lesotho, and South Africa, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any coun- try of the customs union. Imports from South Africa do not require licenses and include an unknown quantity of goods originating outside the customs union. Insofar as Swaziland imports goods direct from countries out- side the customs union, such imports are usually licensed in conformity with South Africa's import regulations. Import licenses are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment. Certain exports are subject to licensing, ma in ly for revenues and similar reasons, but most exports are in the first instance shipped free of license to or through South Africa. Changes during 1975 January 24. Swaziland issued the Exchange Control Regulations, 1975. These Regulations, made under the Exchange Control Order, 1974 (promulgated on Decem- ber 30, 1974), together with that Order, replaced the Exchange Control Act, No. 98 of 1949, as amended in 1950 and 1959. There was no change in exchange control policy; under the Monetary Authority of Swazi- land Order, 1974, the Monetary Authority would con- tinue to act as agent for the Government in the admin- istration of exchange controls in accordance with such regulations, instructions, and directives as the Minister of Finance and Economic Planning might issue from time to time. February 5. Swaziland communicated to the Fund a central rate of E 1.00 = R 1.00 and availed itself of wider margins. March 24. Swaziland introduced its own Manual of Exchange Control Rulings for use by authorized dealers. It took into account the terms of the Rand Monetary Area Agreement of December 5, 1974. May 16. The issuance of legal tender gold coins with face values of E 50 and E 100 was gazetted. June 10. Circular No. 6 regulated the position of persons temporarily employed in Swaziland. June 27. It was announced that the Reserve Bank was discontinuing the practice of making small and fre- quent adjustments to its buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars. In fu tu re these rates would be kept con- stant for longer periods at a time and would only be adjusted upward or downward if considered essential in the event of any basic change in domestic or interna- tional economic circumstances. The new policy would be based on a middle rate of R 1 = US$1.40 with the same total spread of l/2 of 1 per cent as before. Not for Redistribution SWEDEN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.171783 gram of fine gold per Swe- dish Krona. A central rate of SKr 4.56 = US$1 has been established, and Sweden avails itself of wider mar- gins. Margins of 21A per cent are maintained for spot rates in the official exchange market between the Swe- dish krona and the Belgian f ranc, the Danish krone, the deutsche ma rk, the French f ranc, the Luxembourg franc, the Netherlands guilder, and the Norwegian krone. No announced margins are ma in ta ined for other currencies. On December 31, 1975 the buy ing and selling rates of the authorized banks for the U.S. dollar were SKr 4.3950 and SKr 4.41, respectively, per US$1. Authorized banks may buy f rom and sell to other authorized banks any foreign currency on a spot basis against other foreign currency or Swedish kroner. Also, they may purchase, spot, f rom foreign banks and other nonresidents foreign currencies against any foreign cur- rency or Swedish kronor credited to a Regular Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low). They may sell to foreign banks and other nonresidents foreign currencies spot against any other foreign currency or Swedish kronor debited to a Regular Account. The acquisition by foreign banks or bank ing firms of kronor on Regular Accounts is subject to limitation. Authorized banks may conclude with residents other than banks fo rwa rd exchange transactions covering cur- rent payments and authorized payments for periods not exceeding ( 1) 24 months in respect of receipts for exports, freight, and charter services; (2) 24 months in respect of payments for imports, fre igh t, and charter services; and ( 3) 6 months in respect of other receipts and payments. Forward exchange transactions covering payments under ( 1) above may be allowed for periods exceeding 24 months a f ter special permission f rom the Sveriges Riksbank is obtained. Authorized banks may under certain conditions conclude forward transactions for a period not exceeding 12 months with foreign banks. Such transactions between banks may, however, be for periods exceeding 12 months if made in cover of forward transactions with residents. Forward mar- ket rates are left to the interplay of market forces. Sweden formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Some members (and their a l te rna tes) are ap- pointed by the Government, and all other members (and the ir alter- nates) by the Board of Directors of the Sveriges Riksbank. 424 Directors of the Riksbank. Authorized banks and some other authorized agencies implement the exchange con- trol regulations. All current payments are exempt from exchange con- trol, provided that they are made through the inter- mediary of an authorized bank in accordance with the currency prescriptions issued by the Riksbank. The authorized banks have been granted general licenses giving them power to approve various payments that are subject to exchange control. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Board of Trade, except those for foodstuffs, which are issued by the National Agricultural Marketing Board, and those for gold and gold alloys, which are issued by the Riksbank. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from foreign countries may be made in any foreign currency or in Swedish kronor through any Regular Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be low). Nonresident Accounts There are two main types of nonresident accounts held in Swedish kronor with authorized banks in Swe- den: Regular Accounts and Restricted Accounts. Other nonresident accounts are Foreign Exchange Accounts and Kronor Accounts for Nonresidents Domiciled in Sweden. Regular Accounts may be held by residents of all countries. These accounts may be credited with trans- fers f rom other Regular Accounts, with authorized pay- ments to foreign countries by residents of Sweden, and with sales of any foreign currency. They may be debited for transfers to any other Regular Account and for authorized payments to residents of Sweden, and they may be exchanged into any foreign currency. The crediting of Regular Accounts with proceeds from sales of foreign currencies or with transfers from other Regu- lar Accounts may not result in the creation of abnor- mal balances. Regular Accounts do not normally bear interest. Restricted Accounts are held mainly by persons who had been residents of Sweden but became nonresidents af ter emigrating. The accounts may be credited with interest accrued to, and earnings from, assets in Swe- den, proceeds f rom sales of assets in Sweden owned by the account holders, and funds transferred from abroad. Balances in Restricted Accounts may be used for pay- ments in Sweden for maintenance expenses of the account holder and his family; minor merchandise pur- chases; taxes and other official charges; expenses related to the administration and maintenance of the account holder's assets in Sweden; purchases of Swedish bonds ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution denominated solely in Swedish kroner and of real estate; and gifts to, and the support of, persons domiciled in Sweden. Foreign Exchange Accounts2 are held in foreign cur- rencies. Such accounts may be credited with authorized payments in foreign currencies due to the account holder and with accrued interest. Balances on such accounts may be used for making authorized payments in foreign currencies to a resident. A Foreign Exchange Account may also be credited with transfers f rom abroad of foreign currencies, or transfers from Regular Accounts or f rom other Foreign Exchange Accounts. A Foreign Exchange Account may be debited for transfers to any nonresident account. Balances on Foreign Exchange Accounts may be sold to an authorized bank against any other foreign currency or Swedish kroner. Kronor Accounts for Nonresidents Domiciled in Swe- den may be maintained by banks and may be credited with payments in Sweden in favor of an account holder and with accrued interest; they may be used for with- drawals in kronor in Sweden. Imports and Import Payments 8 All imports are prohibited when originating in or shipped f rom Rhodesia. With the main exception of a few agricultural and fishery products, practically all goods are free from quantitative restriction and import licensing when imported f rom countries other than ( 1) Japan and (2) Albania, Bulgaria, the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, the German Demo- cratic Republic, Hungary, North Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, the U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. Most imports from countries in the second group are also liberalized. Some imports f rom Japan require licenses. Imports f rom the Republic of China of certain textiles are subject to specific licensing arrangements. Imports f rom certain countries (Hong Kong, India, the Republic of Korea, Macao, Malaysia, Malta, Pakistan, and Singapore) of specified textile products are regu- lated through bilateral consultations. In addition, imports from all sources of certain footwear are subject to global quota. Technically, the exceptions to the liberalization regime are governed by "negative" lists. Imports not covered by the liberalization measures require individual licenses, some of which are granted in accordance with bilateral trade arrangements. Payments for imports, including normal advance payments, may, as current payments, be made without permission through authorized banks and without the formality of presenting an import license. Such accounts may be credited with authorized receipts in foreign currencies and with interest and debited for author- ized payments in foreign currencies. SWEDEN Payments for Invisibles, below) are not met, an exchange control permit is required. Importers are permitted to utilize foreign commercial credits, provided that these do not exceed what is regarded as customary in the trade. Payments for Invisibles The exchange control regulations define and list those categories of payments abroad which are considered as current payments. Persons domiciled in Sweden may make such payments without restriction in favor of per- sons domiciled abroad. The payments must be made through authorized banks in order to ensure that capital payments are not made in the guise of current payments. Payments not exceeding the equivalent of SKr 100 that are made abroad for any purpose do not have to be verified by authorized banks; however, if they constitute partial payments of a capital nature, the approval of the Riksbank is required. Life insurance premiums in excess of SKr 1,000 a person a calendar year require the approval of the Riksbank; such approval is normally given freely in respect of both existing and new insur- ance policies. For tourism, recreational travel, or study abroad, resi- dents may acquire and take out freely up to SKr 6,000 a trip in Swedish and foreign banknotes and coins and other means of payment; applications for additional amounts must be submitted to the Riksbank and are given liberal treatment. Authorized banks and other authorized agencies may allocate to residents, without restriction, exchange for business travel abroad. Nonresidents leaving Sweden may export freely Swe- dish and foreign banknotes and other means of payment which they brought into, or duly acquired in, the coun- try. No traveler may, however, without specific permis- sion take out of Sweden more than SKr 6,000 in Swe- dish banknotes and coins. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports except ships, scrap metals, and arms are exempt f rom license if payment is to be received in conformity with the general regulations (see section on Prescription of Currency, above); however, all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Proceeds from exports of goods do not have to be surrendered; they may be kept in a foreign currency account with a Swedish authorized bank and used by the holder to make authorized pay- ments abroad, or they may be sold to an authorized bank against Swedish kronor. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles are subject to the same treat- ment as those f rom exports (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, above). Each person entering Sweden may bring in up to SKr 6,000 in Swedish banknotes and coins and unlim- ited amounts of other means of payment. 425 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SWEDEN Capital Direct investment abroad by Swedish residents requires individual authorization, which normally is granted only if the investment is considered to promote exports or otherwise to be favorable f rom a balance of payments point of view. Authorization may be con- ditional on foreign financing with an average ma tu r i ty of at least five years. Financing abroad is, however, as a rule not required for investments in sales companies and other companies which give rise to exports from Sweden, investments involving relatively small amounts, or investments in countries that are the main recipients of Swedish development assistance. Residents may, on application, transfer capital abroad to purchase, for recreational purposes, real estate valued at no more than SKr 50,000 for each fam i ly, sub- ject to certain limitations regarding the cost of a lot and the time allowed for building on it; amoun ts up to SKr 75,000 may be approved where a recreational need is clearly established. A Swedish resident when emigrating is permitted to transfer up to SKr 100,000, subject to verification by the Riksbank; after one calendar year (beyond the year of emigration), he will normally be permitted to trans- fer the remainder of his assets. When Swedish residents emigrate to engage abroad in activities of limited dura- tion, applications for transfers in excess of the initial SKr 100,000 are considered in a restrictive manner. Transfers on account of inheritances that are due to nonresidents are permitted. Authorized banks may freely approve payments abroad in respect of various categories of remittances, including those in respect of gifts and support payments up to SKr 2,000 for each transfer. Residents are permitted to accept capital receipts f rom abroad on account of life, pension, and annu i ty contracts; contractual amortization of their investments; the sale of foreign securities, real estate abroad, and personal property held by them abroad; and gifts and inheritances. Residents may accept other kinds of capi- tal receipts from abroad only upon approval f rom the Riksbank. Residents who wish to receive loans or credits other than normal suppliers' credit f rom nonresidents must receive authorization to do so; each case is considered on its merits. Borrowing abroad for periods of at least five years to finance industrial investments in Sweden that are considered to be favorable from a balance of payments point of view is normally permitted. The Riksbank also permits exporters to cover their normal suppliers' credits through foreign borrowing. Suppliers' credit granted by Swedish shipyards may be refinanced abroad even if it serves to finance sales of ships to Swedish shipowners. Swedish importers can also be granted permission to take up credit abroad to finance contemplated imports. Borrowing by way of suppliers' credit is not controlled, and other borrowing to finance 426 imports is approved where the borrowing itself and the repayment terms are in conformity with commercial practice in the trade concerned. In this context, author- ized banks are upon application permitted to extend to the foreign counterpart of a Swedish exporter or importer credit intended to finance certain specified import and export transactions, and to refinance such credit through a corresponding foreign borrowing. Per- mission for the financing of the export and import trans- actions mentioned above requires that the credits con- form to normal commercial practice. Residents are not normally permitted to extend financial loans to non- residents. Under certain conditions, authorized banks may be granted permission to borrow abroad at long term for purposes of on-lending to residents who have received permission to borrow abroad. Foreign-owned companies in Sweden usually are per- mitted to borrow at long term from the parent compa- nies. Generally, the repayment of foreign credits at any date other than that specified in the contract requires a new authorization f rom the Riksbank; such authorizations are granted restrictively. Permission is needed for the issuance of bonds and shares in Sweden by nonresidents; bond issues in favor of other Scandi- navian countries and the International Bank for Recon- struction and Development have been admitted when the state of the Swedish capital market and the balance of payments were considered to allow them. Foreign direct investments in Sweden require authori- zation, which normally is given, provided that not more than 50 per cent of each individual investment (minor investments excepted) is financed with domestic credit. The transfer of the liquidation proceeds of such invest- ments, including appreciation, requires authorization, which is always given. Investment by nonresidents in Swedish real estate requires approval according to regu- lations other than exchange control regulations. Residents do not need authorization to sell portfolio holdings of foreign securities to nonresidents. The pur- chase of listed, as well as unlisted, foreign securities by residents f rom nonresidents, requires authorization. As a rule, such authorization is not granted. However, authorized banks and stockbrokers may by virtue of a general license purchase from nonresidents, on behalf of residents, listed foreign securities and listed Swedish securities denominated in foreign currencies with the proceeds from sales to nonresidents of Swedish-held securities denominated in foreign currencies, provided that the purchase does not include certificates or shares issued by investment companies or investment funds (mutual funds) and is made within six months of the corresponding sale. Residents may without authori- zation buy foreign securities and Swedish securities denominated in foreign currencies from other residents. Subject to individual license, the repurchase abroad is permitted of listed Swedish securities expressed in Swedish kroner, provided that an affidavit can be pro- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution duced showing either (1) that at no time since Janu- ary 1, 1959 have the securities been owned by a person domiciled in Sweden, or (2) that the securities have been acquired with the permission of the Swedish exchange authorities from a person domiciled in Sweden. The authorized banks and stockbrokers may, by virtue of a general license, handle purchases by nonresidents of listed Swedish securities expressed in Swedish kronor when payment is to be made in the form of other simi- lar securities (switches), provided that (1) the foreign seller and buyer is the same person in each case; (2) the afore-mentioned affidavit requirements are met; (3) for- eign holdings of bonds are not exchanged for shares; (4) not more than two weeks pass between the date of the purchase from and the date of the sale to the foreign party. The export of securities owned by nonresidents other than Swedish emigrants is not restricted. Ceilings are placed on the net foreign exchange hold- ings of each authorized bank and the types of assets have been listed which the banks may hold within their foreign exchange limits. The ceilings for commercial banks have been fixed so as to enable them to carry out their foreign business. Banks may grant only normal overdrafts to nonresidents. They may incur foreign exchange liabilities, but may not maintain a net liability in any one currency. This, together with the permission to pay interest on foreign exchange deposits held by nonresidents, enables the banks to borrow foreign cur- rency from nonresidents for on-lending (but not in the form of kronor) to foreign banks. Swedish banks may not borrow abroad freely in order to sell the proceeds against Swedish kronor in the market, but under certain conditions they may be granted permission to borrow abroad to relend in Sweden (see above). Nonresidents' holdings of kronor in Regular Accounts must not be "abnormal," and, with minor exceptions, they cannot earn interest. Gold Gold in any form may be held, purchased, and sold within Sweden. Imports and exports of gold and gold alloys require licenses issued by the Riksbank; the types of gold affected are unmanufactured gold, most types of semimanufactured gold, and gold coins (except coins imported by or on behalf of collectors or collections). Import licenses are normally granted to jewelers, dental laboratories, and users of gold for industrial and scien- tific purposes, as well as to persons and firms importing for resale to these categories of users. As a general rule, no licenses are issued for the import of gold to be held on private account. Commercial imports and exports of articles contain- SWEDEN ing gold, such as jewelry, may be made freely without a license. The same applies to imports and exports of gold coins of numismatic value and intended for col- lectors or collections. Changes during 1975 January 1.
