Not for Redistribution SWITZERLAND ' (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The gold content of the Swiss Franc as established by Decree of the Federal Council on May 9, 1971 is 47/216 (= 0.21759) gram of fine gold. The "central rate" for the U.S. dollar fixed on December 20, 1971 was Sw F 3.84 = US$1. The gold parity of the Swiss franc has not been altered accordingly. On January 23, 1973, the Swiss National Bank suspended until further notice its intervention in the exchange market and no announced margins have since been maintained in the market for any currency, although from time to time intervention may occur to maintain orderly market conditions. The market rate for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 was Sw F 2.6200 per US$1. Exchange is controlled in respect of transactions with four countries with which Switzerland has bilateral agreements or in respect of which Switzerland has enacted autonomous regulations. Bilateral agreements cover certain specific payments with three countries— Cuba, Egypt, and Turkey; Switzerland also controls its payments with the German Democratic Republic, including East Berlin. Official rates are applied to transactions covered by some of these arrangements. This domain of regulated settlements is known as the sector of controlled payments. All settlements outside this sector (including those with all other countries), as well as certain settlements involving Egyptian pounds which represent compensation for nationalization of Swiss property in Egypt, may be made freely at free market rates. Foreign banknotes are negotiated freely in Switzerland at rates determined by the interplay of supply and demand. Exchange Control Territory For all purposes of import, export, and the application of controlled payments, the Principality of Liechtenstein is included in the Swiss customs territory for the dura- tion of the treaty of March 29, 1923 between Switzer- land and the Principality of Liechtenstein concerning the union of the Principality of Liechtenstein with the Swiss customs territory. For purposes of capital con- trol, physical or juridical persons (including banks) domiciled in the Principality of Liechtenstein are gen- erally considered by Switzerland as residents, except in respect of the acquisition of Swiss real estate. For purposes of the Federal Law on Banks and Savings Institutions, however, Liechtenstein is considered a for- eign country. Administration of Control The authority to impose measures for the control of imports, exports, and payments is vested in the Swiss 1 Switzerland is not a member of the International Mone tary Fund. 428 Federal Council acting, as a rule, on the proposals of the Federal Department of Public Economy or the Federal Political Department. The Swiss National Bank is the executive authority in matters of currency, and the Swiss Compensation Office, together with the authorized banks, is entrusted with the operation of controlled payments. Prescription of Currency The currency and manner of settlement on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles in the sector of controlled payments are prescribed in accordance with the provisions of the relevant payments agreements and /or by the Swiss regulations. Settlements with coun- tries in this sector are made in Swiss francs; however, certain settlements with Egypt may be made in Egyptian pounds through special accounts maintained by the Swiss Compensation Office at the Central Bank of Egypt, and certain settlements with Cuba must be made in Swiss francs to the debit or credit of a special account at the Swiss National Bank. Outside the sector of con- trolled payments, certain settlements with Turkey are subject to special regulations. In all other cases, settle- ments are not subject to regulations involving prescrip- tion of currency. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts related to the sector of controlled payments may be grouped as follows: (1) accounts related to Cuba, which are centralized with the Swiss National Bank, and (2) the "decentralized" accounts, comprising those which may be held with the Swiss National Bank and with authorized banks in Switzer- land. The accounts of the second group are of two kinds: the accounts of the German Democratic Repub- lic, which are transferable only to other accounts of the same nationality, and the accounts of Egypt, which are subject to special treatment. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia require a license; licenses are not granted in excess of the average volume of imports for 1964, 1965, and 1966. With minor excep- tions, imports into Switzerland from other countries may be made freely. The only commodities subject to license irrespective of their origin are certain agricul- tural products and certain fuels. Import permits for goods still under license are, in general, granted freely, but global quotas are established for certain agricultural products. Imports of textiles from specified countries are subject to price surveillance or price certification. Settlements are made automatically for authorized imports from countries to which the Swiss control regu- lations are applicable, i.e., the sector of controlled pay- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ments. Payments for imports from all other countries may be made freely through the free market. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely; how- ever, payments to the German Democratic Republic (including East Berlin) are controlled.2 The export of Swiss and foreign banknotes is free. Exports and Export Proceeds The export (including re-export) of some goods is subject to export control through individual licenses. This export licensing system is operated in part with the assistance of appropriate trade organizations. Export proceeds received through the sector of controlled pay- ments are converted into Swiss currency in observance of the existing regulations. Other export proceeds are freely disposable. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles received through the sector of controlled payments are converted into Swiss francs in observance of the existing regulations. Proceeds received in convertible currencies are freely disposable. The import of Swiss and foreign banknotes is free. Capital Transfers of capital f rom countries in the sector of controlled payments require licenses if they are made through the sector of controlled payments; transfers of capital to such countries do not require licenses. Trans- fers of capital to other countries may be made freely, with the exception mainly that bank credits and other bank lending to nonresidents, when exceeding Sw F 10 million each and with a maturity of 12 months or more, require permission. This applies, inter alia, to foreign issues in Switzerland of bonds and to direct participa- tions by Swiss banks in Euro-bond issues. Furthermore, all proposed first placings of medium-term negotiable paper (notes, certificates of deposit, etc.) in amounts of Sw F 3 million or more must be submitted to the National Bank for examination. In addition, issues in Switzerland of foreign bonds denominated in Swiss francs are subject to ceilings. All capital exports denomi- nated in Swiss francs and licensed by the National Bank (bond issues, placings of notes, and other loans and credits, except export credit) must be converted into foreign currency at the National Bank. Issues by foreign issuers of debt instruments expressed in Swiss francs and having a maturity of less than 12 months are dis- couraged. The same applies to foreign bond issues denominated in Swiss francs in amounts below Sw F 10 million.3 2 Payments to Cuba are controlled only insofar as they relate to the Cuban-Swiss agreement on indemnification for nationalized property. 3 For the application of some regulations, namely, those based on the Law on Banks and Savings Institutions, which does not extend to banks in Liechtenstein, Liechtenstein is considered a foreign country. SWITZERLAND Inward capital transfers are restricted. Some of the relevant regulations make a distinction between alien nonresidents and nonresidents of Swiss nationality, the latter usually being exempt from prohibitions or approval requirements even when they have their permanent residence abroad. Physical or juridical persons having their domicile or registered office in Liechtenstein are considered nonresidents for purposes of the acquisition of Swiss real estate. The definition of the terms "for- eigner" and "foreign funds" is not the same under all types of capital control regulations. The physical impor- tation and exportation of Swiss and foreign securities are unrestricted. Borrowing from nonresidents, whether in domestic or foreign currency, by resident physical and juridical persons other than banks requires the prior approval of the National Bank, which is not normally granted; the principal exemptions from this licensing requirement are for borrowing corresponding to customary credit terms for current commercial transactions and for credits up to Sw F 1 million, if taken up in foreign currency, used entirely abroad, and not converted into Swiss francs. Banks are subject to reserve requirements against the growth and the level of external liabilities (liabilities both in Swiss francs and in foreign currencies); the reserve requirements are different for, on the one hand, deposits made between July 31, 1971 and October 31, 1974, and on the other hand, deposits made after the latter date. Since January 22, 1975 banks are not permitted to pay interest on Swiss franc deposits received from non- residents, savings accounts and similar accounts being subject to preferential treatment (see January 22 entry in the section on Changes during 1975, below). Banks must also charge a commission ("negative interest") of 10 per cent a calendar quarter, payable in advance, on all net increases after October 31, 1974 in nonresident- held Swiss f ranc deposits, irrespective of maturity; increases up to Sw F 100,000 are exempt from this commission. The banks have agreed to report daily all spot and forward transactions exceeding US$5 million. They are required to at least balance daily their overall foreign exchange position, as well as their position in each currency separately, short positions in foreign currency being prohibited.4 Banks' forward sales of Swiss francs to nonresidents with a maturity of ten days or less are limited to 50 per cent of their October 31, 1974 level; for maturities over ten days the limit is 70 per cent of that level.5 The National Bank is empowered to block in noninterest-bearing deposits, for an indefinite period of time, the Swiss franc counterpart of its spot pur- chases in the exchange market; these powers have not been invoked. 4 The reporting of dealers' positions was introduced on Janu- ary 30, 1976. 5 Reduced to 60 per cent at the end of January 1976. 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SWITZERLAND Purchases of real estate in Switzerland by or on behalf of persons or firms of foreign nationality who are domiciled abroad require approval by the canton where the property is situated. Such permission is also required for the acquisition of real estate by foreign physical persons who have been resident in Switzerland for less than five consecutive years. Gold Swiss gold coins are not legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form at home or abroad; domestic transactions are not subject to any sales or turnover tax. There is a free gold market in Zurich. Imports and exports of gold in any form by residents and nonresidents are unrestricted and free of license; however, the import of gold known or suspected to originate from South Viet-Nam or Cambodia is pro- hibited. No customs duties or other charges are levied on exports of gold. Imports of gold in certain forms are subject to customs duty (bars and certain coins are exempt) or sales tax (bars and coins are exempt). Import and export licenses are required for commercial imports and exports of certain articles containing gold; these are issued freely. Changes during 1975 January 1. January 9. The Federal Council, acting in agreement with the National Bank, issued liquidity and credit guidelines for 1975. The money supply (Mx) was to be increased by 6 per cent or about Sw F 3 billion, and the monetary base by about Sw F 1.5 billion. The ceiling on the growth of bank credit remained at 7 per cent but was operated more liberally. January 22. The National Bank raised the commis- sion charge ("negative interest") on all net increases after October 31, 1974 in nonresident-held Swiss franc deposits from 3 per cent a quarter to 10 per cent a quarter, effective immediately. Also, the existing prohi- bition on the payment of interest on foreign-held Swiss francs was extended to all nonresident-held Swiss franc deposits, irrespective of when the deposits had been made but subject to any existing contractual obligations, which could not be renewed. This ban on interest pay- ments did not apply to savings accounts or similar accounts, insofar as balances had not increased by more than Sw F 50,000 since October 31, 1974. At the same time, banks were obliged, with immediate effect, to at least balance their overall foreign currency positions daily and the National Bank was empowered to block in noninterest-bearing deposits, and for an indefinite period of time, the Swiss franc counterpart of its spot purchases on the exchange market. The exchange rate insurance facilities for exporters were improved. Additional types of risk could be covered, as well as nine additional currencies; previ- ously, only deutsche mark, French francs, Netherlands guilders, and U.S. dollars could be covered. Exchange rate losses of less than 3 per cent or less than Sw F 1,000 per order were not covered. The maximum guarantee would be 95 per cent of claims, subject to Parliamentary approval (see June 17, below). The new facilities came into effect on a trial basis for six months. June 17. Parliament approved an increase in the export risk guarantee from 85 per cent to 95 per cent of the amount of the export order. June 27. A commercial treaty with the German Democratic Republic was signed. Upon entry into force, settlements would be placed on a convertible currency basis; the clearing arrangements expired on Decem- ber 31, 1975. July 8. Not for Redistribution SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 37, 1975) Exchange Rate System On July 29, 1947, a par value for the Syrian Pound was established by the Syrian Arab Republic with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. In principle, there are two exchange rates, the official rate and the parallel rate, but since July 18, 1973 these have been unified. Since March 22, 1974 the exchange rates for the U.S. dollar have been LS 3.65 buying, and LS 3.70 selling, per US$1; exchange rates for other currencies are quoted on the basis of these rates for the U.S. dollar and the market rates for the currencies concerned in international centers. The Commercial Bank of Syria charges a commission of %o of 1 per cent on sales or purchases of foreign exchange. Administration of Control Policy with regard to imports and exports is deter- mined by the Government through the Ministry of Econ- omy and Foreign Trade. Under an agreement between the Central Bank of Syria and the Administrative Committee of the Exchange Office, all transactions of the Exchange Office are carried out through the Central Bank. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade, and exchange licenses for invisibles and capital transactions by the Exchange Office. Authorized commercial banks, travel agencies, hotels, and airline companies may deal in foreign exchange. The commercial banks may open letters of credit or accept bills for collection only with the prior approval of the Exchange Office. At present there is only one authorized bank, the Commercial Bank of Syria, which has been authorized by the Exchange Office to open letters of credit and accept bills for collection without prior approval, provided that certain conditions are fulfilled. Prescription of Currency The Exchange Office is empowered to prescribe the currencies to be obtained for exports. The current requirement is that proceeds of exports to all countries except those with which the Syrian Arab Republic has bilateral payments agreements1 be obtained in the cur- rency of the country to which the goods are exported if it is an "acceptable" currency,2 or in any other convert- ible currency, at the exporter's choice. Proceeds from exports to certain neighboring countries may be obtained 1 Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, German Democratic Repub- l ic ,-Nor th Korea, Sri Lanka, U.S.S.R., and North Viet-Nam. Settle- ments with Bulgaria and the German Democratic Republic were placed on a convertible currency basis with effect from Janua ry 1, 1976. 2 "Acceptable" currencies are those for which the Exchange Office quotes rates: Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Iraqi dinars, Italian lire, Jordan dinars, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Saudi Arabian riyals, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. in banknotes issued by the country concerned; these countries are Cyprus, Egypt, the Gulf states, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the Yemen Arab Republic, and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. Proceeds from exports to Egypt may be obtained in "acceptable" banknotes. Prescription of currency requirements are not applied to outgoing payments. All payments to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Syrian pounds may be held by nonresidents 3 and may be credited with the proceeds of foreign currencies sold to the authorized bank and with payments for goods. They may be debited to pay for Syrian exports to the country of the account holder or, with the prior approval of the Exchange Office, to other countries, and for expenses in the Syrian Arab Republic. Nonresidents and residents who have activi- ties abroad may also keep accounts in foreign currencies in the Syrian Arab Republic, but only if these accounts result f rom an inflow of capital; transfers abroad from these accounts are made freely. Temporary nonresident accounts may be opened in the name of nonresidents temporarily resident in the Syrian Arab Republic. Permitted credits include the local currency proceeds of foreign currency brought in at the parallel rate and amounts corresponding to import payments that are not transferred. Debits for local expenditures are com- pletely free, and debits for expenditures abroad also are permitted. Imports and Import Payments Imports of commodities originating in Israel, Rhode- sia, or South Africa are prohibited. Many basic com- modities (including green coffee, tea, rice, tobacco, salt, paper, iron and steel, and certain agricultural machin- ery) are imported only by state trading agencies (includ- ing the successor organizations to SIMEX) or, for their own account, by certain other official agencies. Imports are divided into two main categories: ( 1) imports prohibited by decree and specified in a Prohibited List, which comprises mostly goods that are produced domestically, including some textile products, and some less essential goods which are temporarily not admitted either for balance of payments reasons or for protective reasons; and (2) all other goods. Certain suspended imports may be acquired in payments agree- ment countries through compensation transactions involv- ing the export of Syrian industrial or mineral products. Virtually all imports must be made direct from the coun- 3 Residents are defined as including all physical persons of Syrian nationality, irrespective of domicile, and all persons who have been living in the Syrian Arab Republic for more than a year. 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC try of origin, without the intermediary of any firm con- ducting a business established outside the Syrian Arab Republic; the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade has the authority, however, to permit certain goods to be imported f rom countries other than the country of origin. Certain consumer goods that do not appear on a special list cannot be imported from the Federal Repub- lic of Germany or the United States unless it is shown that the price is lower and the quality higher than that of comparable products offered by other suppliers. All permitted imports, except those made by state trading agencies, require individual import licenses before the placing of orders. The state trading agencies may conclude import transactions and have the goods shipped before an import license is granted; the license must be obtained, however, before customs clearance. (Exempt from import license, by virtue of Order No. 338 of September 17, 1973, are certain commodities when imported by specified monopoly holders; these include coffee, tea, tobacco, sugar, salt, and rice, when imported by the TAFCO agency.) Certain imports (not on the Suspended or Prohibited List) from Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, and Saudi Arabia are exempt from license, in accordance with the Arab Common Market Agreement or the bilateral agreements of the Syrian Arab Republic with some of these countries. Syrian citizens, whether resident in the Syrian Arab Republic or abroad, are entitled to import specified raw materials, capital goods, consumer goods, and spare parts, provided that imports are paid for with their own foreign exchange held abroad; to obtain import licenses, which cannot exceed the value of LS 100,000 (except for capital goods), the importer must provide evidence of his foreign exchange holdings abroad on Decem- ber 31, 1970. Import licenses are granted freely to importers who have obtained foreign suppliers' credit of at least 365 days; settlement for goods licensed under such credit facilities may be made immediately if a documentary letter of credit is opened at the Commer- cial Bank of Syria and the importer covers the fu ll amount with his foreign exchange. Licenses to import specified consumer goods, raw materials, and semifin- ished goods, up to a value of LS 24,000 for a 12-month period, are freely granted to traders and industrialists whose activity is certified by the Chamber of Commerce or by the Chamber of Industry. Imports by parcel post of any goods that are not prohibited are permitted with- out a license, provided that each parcel is valued at LS 250 or less (LS 10,000 per year per importer for the public sector). There are limited import facilities for travelers arriving from abroad. There is a tax of 2 per cent on the issue of import licenses, except for government imports and imports of certain essential items, including raw materials, petro- leum, and petroleum products. In addition, there are the following taxes on imports which are collected by the customs: ( 1) a statistical tax of 4 per cent; (2) a consumption tax of 4 per cent for all imports for which 434 the tar iff rate is more than 1 per cent; (3) a defense tax of 10 per cent of the ta r i f f; (4) a school tax of 10 per cent of the consumption tax plus 2 per cent of the ta r i f f; (5) a harbor tax of 3 per cent of the tariff for goods transferred by ships through Syrian harbors (most commodities can be imported only through Syrian ha rbo rs ); and (6) an ocean tax of 2Ao of 1 per cent of the value of imports for all goods transferred by ship in any harbor, including those of neighboring countries. Payments for imports may be made at the parallel rate by letters of credit, time draf ts, or bills for collec- tion, or by crediting a nonresident account or a tempo- rary resident account. However, importers are not granted foreign exchange if they postpone the transfer un t il more than a week after the due date of the bill or d r a f t. The importer submits to the Commercial Bank of Syria the import license and the pro forma invoice. The Commercial Bank of Syria then opens the letters of credit or accepts the bills for collection. Approval by the Exchange Office is currently not required. Payments for Invisibles The insurance for imports under documentary credit must be effected locally. All payments for invisibles, except expenditures of Syrian officials abroad, must be made at the parallel rate. Both residents and nonresidents may freely take out fore ign banknotes. Residents traveling abroad may also take with them other foreign exchange purchased at the parallel rate as follows: for travel to Lebanon, the equivalent of LS 100 a trip; for travel to Jordan, LS 250 a t r ip; for travel to other Arab countries (except Algeria, the Libyan Arab Republic, Morocco, the Sudan, and Tun is ia) and to Cyprus and Turkey, LS 500 a trip; and for travel to other countries (including Algeria, the Libyan Arab Republic, Morocco, the Sudan, and Tun i s ia ), the equivalent of LS 1,250 a trip. For children between the ages of two and ten, the allowances are 50 per cent of these amounts. For travel to payments agree- ment countries 50 per cent of the travel allocation must be taken up through the clearing account concerned (30 per cent for travel on official business). On depar- ture, residents of Syrian nationality must pay an exit tax of LS 11.50 a person. Fixed allocations at the parallel rate also exist for other invisibles, as follows: 60 per cent of the salaries received by foreign technicians and experts employed in the Syrian Arab Republic; 50 per cent of the salaries of personnel of foreign diplomatic and international mis- sions in the Syrian Arab Republic; up to LS 3,000 a stockholder a year for dividends accruing to nonresi- dents from Syrian securities; and LS 250 a person a month for private donations and charities. In all cases, applications for additional amounts must be submitted for approval to the Exchange Office. Nonresidents leav- ing the country are permitted to take out LS 100 in Syrian currency, and residents LS 25. For additional amounts, the approval of the Exchange Office is required. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of wheat, cotton, cottonseed, barley, and their derivatives are nationalized and are made by the Cereals Office or the Cotton Authority. Exports of certain other commodities are also reserved for government agencies, state trading agencies, or specified companies. Exports of a few goods to any country and all exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Exports of the main export products and of all goods of foreign origin require licenses. For all other exports, licenses are not required. For most exports, however, a repatria- tion commitment must be executed in which the exporter undertakes to bring the proceeds to the Syrian Arab Republic and surrender them to the Commercial Bank of Syria within six months after the date of export. The proceeds of exports must be surrendered to the Commer- cial Bank of Syria at the parallel rate, with the excep- tion that the proceeds of cotton and petroleum exports must be surrendered to the Exchange Office at the offi- cial rate; as noted above, the two rates have been unified since 1973. Certain manufactured exports receive subsidies f rom the Fund for the Development of Exports of Industrial Products. Exports of cotton are subject to an export tax of (cid:2)l/2 per cent ad valorem. All exports of agricultural products (including cotton) are subject to an ad valorem agricultural tax of 10 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from pipeline royalties must be sold at the official rate and those from other invisibles at the parallel rate. Nonresidents entering the Syrian Arab Republic are permitted to bring in unlimited foreign exchange in any form. Foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents. Nonresi- dents are permitted to bring in not more than LS 100 in Syrian currency. Capital All inward and outward capital transfers take place at the parallel rate. Imports of private funds in the form of foreign exchange are free for private individuals, whether residents or nonresidents. The export of capital requires the approval of the Exchange Office, as does most borrowing abroad. Special facilities for investment of Arab capital in the Syrian Arab Republic are pro- vided by Legislative Decree No. 348 of December 29, SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC 1969. Other facilities permitting residents and nonresi- dents of any nationality to open foreign currency accounts in the Syrian Arab Republic with imported funds are based on Decree No. 779 of April 1, 1970 and Order No. 191 of April 23, 1970. Neither type of facility is applicable to funds received over clearing accounts or by diplomatic and UN missions and their s taffs. Order No. 265 of June 10, 1970 regulates the investment of funds of immigrants and of nationals of Arab States in the economic development of the Syrian Arab Republic. Immovable property in the Syrian Arab Republic may not without prior approval be acquired by nonresidents or foreign nationals other than resident Arab nationals. Gold Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold in the Syrian Arab Republic without restriction. The domestic negotiation of gold takes place at free market prices that are in line with free market prices abroad. Exports of gold are subject to export licensing, while imports are exempt from import licensing. Import payments require the approval of the Exchange Office, which is granted only for imports for industrial use or for re-export. Export proceeds are subject to surrender. Changes during 1975 During the year, there were virtually no changes in the exchange or trade control regulations other than those resulting from the termination of certain bilateral payments agreements. Restrictions on imports, how- ever, were fur ther relaxed on a de facto basis. The offi- cial buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar remained unchanged in 1975. January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1974 of the bilateral payments agreements with Poland and Romania, settlements with those countries were placed on a convertible currency basis. April. The abolition of import and export licensing requirements in trade with Jordan was agreed. In August, it was also agreed with Jordan to abolish border taxes. December 31. The bilateral payments agreements with Bulgaria and the German Democratic Repub- lic expired. With effect from January 1, 1976 settle- ments with these countries were placed on a convertible currency basis. 435 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TANZANIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System Nonresident Accounts The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Tanzania Shilling. A central rate of T Sh 9.66000 = SDR 1 has been established, and Tanzania avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Tanzania's rates for the U.S. dollar are based on the Fund's daily calcu- lation of the U.S. dollar/SDR rate. On December 31, 1975, the Bank of Tanzania's buying and selling rate for the U.S. dollar was T Sh 8.25 per US$1. The Bank of Tanzania deals with the Government and wkh autho- rized banks in Kenya and Uganda shillings (except Uganda banknotes) against Tanzania shillings at par. Administration of Control The Minister for Finance has delegated the adminis- tration of exchange control to the Bank of Tanzania. Authority for approving normal import payments, some payments in respect of current invisibles, and some capital payments is delegated by the Bank of Tanzania to the two authorized banks, the National Bank of Com- merce and the People's Bank of Zanzibar. On the ma in land, import control is administered by the Imports Controller in the Bank of Tanzania and export control by the Exports Controller in the Ministry of Commerce and Industries. The Bank of Tanzania acts as the registrar of exporters. The responsibility for issuing specific import and export licenses rests with the Controllers to whom applications must be submitted by the importer or exporter in Tanzania before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Import applica- tions for commodities the importation of which is con- fined to specified parastatal organizations must be sub- mitted through the respective parastatal organization. Zanzibar administers an independent system of foreign trade controls; all imports and the principal exports are made by the state trad ing agencies (B izan je and the Zanzibar State Trading Corporation). Prescription of Currency Tanzania has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Settlements between residents of Tanzania and nonresidents normally must be made either in con- vertible currencies or by debit or credit to External Accounts in Tanzania shillings. Certain proceeds must be received in specified currencies.1 Remittances to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Accounts in Tanzania shillings held by residents of foreign countries with authorized banks in Tanzania are, with exchange control approval, designated nonresident accounts and may be either External Accounts or unspe- cified nonresident accounts. They may be credited with authorized payments to residents of foreign countries by residents of Tanzania, with transfers from External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any for- eign currency (other than Rhodesian and South Afr ican cu r rency) to authorized dealers. They may be debited for payments to residents, for transfers to External Accounts in Tanzania, and for authorized purchases of foreign currencies f rom authorized dealers. Imports and Import Payments Some imports to the mainland from all sources are prohibited for reasons of health or security. Certain other imports are not being licensed. Imports originating in Kenya and Uganda are in principle unrestricted but some require specific licenses and others may only be imported by or on behalf of specified parastatal organi- zations. Certain goods listed in the Imports Control Notice, 1975 may be imported freely, irrespective of country of origin, while other goods listed require spe- cific licenses. A semiannual foreign exchange plan pro- vides for indicative foreign exchange allocations for goods subject to specific licenses. Most goods may nor- mally be imported only by or on behalf of specified parastatal organizations. All imports to the mainland f rom Zanzibar require a specific license when the goods originate outside Zanzibar. All imports from metropoli- tan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. All imports in to Zanzibar are made by government agencies. Transfer taxes are levied on a range of manufactured goods when imported from and originating in Kenya. For some of these commodities, the tax is applicable also when they are imported from and originate in Uganda. Most imports, irrespective of their origin, are subject to sales tax at rates ranging up to 50 per cent of the c.i.f. value plus import duty. Advance payments for imports are allowed in excep- tional circumstances only, exchange for import payments normally not being granted until after customs clearance. Most suppliers' credit requires the prior approval of the Bank of Tanzania. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified xThe specified currencies are listed as Aus tra l ian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Burmese kyats, Canad ian dollars, Cyprus pounds, Danish kroner, deutsche m a rk, French f ranc s, Icelandic k ronu r, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Jordan dinars, Kuwa i ti d ina rs, Libyan dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, Sri Lanka rupees, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and all other Sterling Area currencies other than Kenya shillings, Tan- zania shillings, and Uganda shillings. 436 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution categories of current payments up to established limits; amounts above these limits may be approved administra- tively by the Bank of Tanzania. Facilities exist whereby immigrant noncitizens work- ing in Tanzania under contract in salaried employment and with a firm commitment to leave Tanzania even- tually may throughout their period of employment remit abroad up to 33% per cent of their monthly salary uncommitted to cover f am i ly maintenance, savings, etc. Applications to remit in excess of 33% per cent of salary or in excess of T Sh 3,000 a month are considered on their merits by the Bank of Tanzania. Specified cate- gories of expatriate employees may remit the total amount of their salaries. Persons mak ing uncommitted remittances under these arrangements are not entitled to emigration facilities (see section on Capital, below). The basic exchange allocations for tdurist travel are suspended, but exceptions may be granted by the Bank of Tanzania on a case-by-case basis. Dividend remit- tances to nonresident shareholders and fam i ly remit- tances to relatives abroad also are suspended. Resident travelers are allowed to take out T Sh 100 in domestic currency. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, all Portuguese territories, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited. On the mainland, exports of products dealt with by state trading organiza- tions and of certain other products are subject to con- trols and, if there is a local shortage, may be restricted. Other goods may be exported without license. All princi- pal exports of Zanzibar are sold abroad by the Zanzibar State Trading Corporation. Re-exports from Zanzibar are prohibited. Exporters are required to be registered with the Bank of Tanzania, and must maintain an account with a local commercial bank. Export proceeds must be collected in convertible currencies within one to two months from the date of exportation and must be surrendered. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 1) must be sold to an authorized bank upon their collection. Travelers may freely bring in convertible foreign currency notes; a returning traveler may bring in up to T Sh 100 in Tanzania shilling notes he had exported on departure. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are subject to control by the Bank of Tanzania and are restricted; all capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Persons leaving Tanzania permanently who have been resident in Tanzania for four years immediately prior to the date of application and who have not been availing themselves of the facility of making uncommitted remit- TANZANIA tances of savings may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of T Sh 20,000 for each household. Any assets in excess of the initial emigration allowance of T Sh 20,000 are remittable in yearly installments of T Sh 20,000 each, after which any remaining amount will be considered for repatriation. Gifts to nonresidents require the prior approval of the Bank of Tanzania. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Tanzania, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is advisable to have the investment recognized by the Bank of Tanzania or to obtain a certificate of approved enterprise in terms of the Foreign Investment (Protec- t ion) Act, 1963. Foreign and domestic investment in specified types of production requires approval under the East A f r ican Licensing Ordinance. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresi- dents of Tanzan ian securities f rom residents on a recog- nized East A f r ican stock exchange, provided that pay- ment is received in an appropriate manner. The income f rom such securities is remittable, as are the proceeds on resale. Purchases of securities outside Tanzania by resi- dents are not permitted. All loans or overdrafts f rom residents to nonresidents or to foreign-controlled resident bodies require exchange control approval by the Bank of Tanzania. Gold A commemorative gold coin is legal tender but does not circulate w i th in Tanzania. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Tanzania for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constitut- ing the personal effects of a traveler are subject to indi- vidual licensing by the Bank of Tanzania. Import licenses for gold jewelry are issued by the Bank of Tanzania and are available to goldsmiths only. Licenses are not granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, industrial users, and producers of newly mined gold; imports are limited to an overall import quota. Changes during 1975 March 1. Imports of automotive spare parts were confined to the State Motor Corporation. April 2. Imports valued at less than T Sh 20,000 (previously T Sh 10,000) were exempted from preship- ment inspection. June 12. The importation by the private sector of raw materials which could be obtained locally was suspended. Foreign exchange authorizations for certain other private sector imports were given to firms only on condition that they would export a certain portion of their production. June 17. Not for Redistribution THAILAND (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0368331 gram of fine gold per Thai Baht, corresponding to B 20.00 = US$1, and Thailand avails itself of wider margins. There is an Exchange Equalization Fund which limits its operations to spot transactions in U.S. dollars with commercial banks. On December 31, 1975, the buying and selling rates of the Exchange Equalization Fund for spot exchange transactions with banks in U.S. dollars were B 20.375 buying, and B 20.425 selling, per US$1; on the same date, the authorized banks' rates for tele- graphic transfers were B 20.35 buying, and B 20.45 selling, per US$ 1. The authorized banks' rates for other currencies are based on their buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the New York and London rates for such currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Thailand on behalf of the Ministry of Finance; the Bank delegates responsibility for most transactions to authorized agents (i.e., authorized banks and authorized companies) and to authorized persons. All incoming exchange must be sold to an authorized agent. All out- going payments are subject to approval (given auto- matically for bona fide commercial transactions and other current paymen ts ); certain inward capital trans- fers may also be subject to approval, upon prescription by Ministerial Notification. Imports of gold require a license issued by the Ministry of Finance. Certain other imports and a few exports are subject to licensing by the Ministry of Commerce. Prescription of Currency There are no special requirements concerning the cur- rency to be used for settlements with foreign countries; payments are made largely in U.S. dollars or in sterling and related currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonresident accounts: Trans- ferable Accounts and Blocked Accounts. In principle, transfers of baht to and from nonresident accounts require approval; approval is not required, however, when the account is held for foreign diplomatic entities, international organizations stationed in Thailand, or Thai nationals temporarily abroad. Transferable Accounts may be credited freely with the proceeds from sales to authorized banks of foreign currency transferred from abroad, with amounts transferred from other Transfer- able Accounts, and with funds eligible for remittance abroad in foreign currency. Balances on Transferable Accounts are convertible into foreign currency at any time and may be debited freely for the purchase of foreign currencies for transfer abroad, for transfers to other Transferable Accounts, for payments in respect of exports, and for any other payments to residents. Funds that must be credited to Blocked Accounts in- clude proceeds of installment sales of books, rentals accruing in Thailand, freight in transit trade, proceeds from sales of assets of emigrating residents of Thai nationality, and funds that cannot be identified as eligi- ble for credit to a Transferable Account. Transfers of baht f rom Blocked Accounts for the purchase of foreign currency, except for certain current payments, are sub- ject to approval by the Bank of Thailand; approval is granted when no capital transfer on behalf of a Thai national is involved. Imports and Import Payments Most commodities may be imported freely, but import licenses are required for some commodities, and the import of certain other items is prohibited. All imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of tea leaf, tea dust, and coffee are subject to a requirement that the importer purchase a proportionate quantity of the same type of goods pro- duced in Thailand. Import licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia. Payments for imports may be approved by authorized banks upon submission of documents; the specific approval of the Bank of Thailand, which is given for all bona fide transactions, is required for advance payments in excess of US$1,400 and for opening revolving letters of credit or letters of credit with an expiry date exceed- ing nine months. Importers must obtain, in addition to the usual documents, a "certificate of payment" from an authorized agent before imported goods exceeding B 10,000 in value can be cleared through customs; military equipment imported by the Ministry of Defense and certain minor categories of imports are exempt from this requirement. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. Payments for invisibles require authorization, which is usually given by an authorized bank or otherwise by the Bank of Thailand; exchange is provided freely and promptly. Cargo insurance premiums due to foreign insurers may be remitted in foreign exchange; if they are paid in baht to an agent or a branch office of an insurance company registered abroad, they may be remitted as earned income after taxes. The transfer of profits and dividends is permitted freely by the Bank of Thailand. Apart from foreign travel, family maintenance abroad, and educa- tional expenses abroad, authorized agents are permitted 439 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution THAILAND to approve applications for exchange without supporting documents, provided that each payment does not exceed the equivalent of US$140. For foreign travel and family remittances, the amounts of exchange that an authorized agent may sell are subject to certain limits. For persons traveling abroad, authorized agents may approve exchange allowances not exceeding the equiva- lent of US$630, or US$40 a day for not more than 90 days, whichever is the greater; for business travel, additional foreign exchange not exceeding one half of the allowance may be obtained in certain cases for entertainment expenses. The amount of foreign exchange that an authorized bank may sell for fam i ly remittances is US$200 a mon th for each transferor for Europe and the United States and US$150 a month for each trans- feror for other countries. Amoun ts above these l im i ts are approved by the Bank of Thailand upon verification. No person may take out local currency exceeding B 500 (or B 1,000 for a fam i ly trave l ing on one passport) or foreign currency exceeding US$250 (US$500 for a f am i ly traveling on a single passport) without the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Transit passengers and tourists, however, may take out without prior authorization up to US$2,000 a person in foreign banknotes and coins, or such higher amount as they may have declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports or re-exports to Rhodesia require an indi- vidual license. Certain categories of exports are subject to licensing, irrespective of destination.1 All other com- modities may be exported freely, except to Rhodesia. The exporter is required to obtain a "certificate of exportation" f rom an authorized agent in order to clear the shipment through customs, as follows: for ship- ments of tin or rubber exceeding B 1,000 in value through any customs station and, with m inor excep- tions, for other goods exceeding B 10,000 in value through any customs station. This certificate is intended to assure repatriation of the export proceeds. Export proceeds must be collected and must be sold to an authorized agent w i th in 7 days of receipt; their surren- der must take place w i th in 15 days f rom the date of export if payment is made by letter of credit, 21 days if a sight bill is drawn for collection, or 15 days af ter the due date of a usance bill, but not later than 180 days after the date of export. Foreign tourists may freely take out precious stones and gold or p la t inum orna- ments up to any value but require a certificate of expor- tation to take out any other articles with a total value in excess of B 10,000. The export of most types of rice and rice products and of sugar is subject to export taxes referred to as export premiums. 1 These include gold, p la t inum, precious stones, live cattle and other specified animals, sorghum, corn, rice and rice products, all kinds of sugar, brass and copper in certain forms, iron scrap and most fo rms of iron other than pig iron and iron ore, and Deva and Buddha images and their parts. 440 Proceeds from Invisibles All receipts f rom invisibles must be sold to an author- ized agent. No person may bring into Thailand local currency exceeding B 500 without a permit, and a f am i ly traveling on the same passport may not bring in more than B 1,000 without a permit. Travelers may br ing in any amount in foreign notes and coins. Capital All outward transfers of capital, including premiums on l i fe insurance policies, by residents or nonresidents are subject to approval. Personal capital exports by residents are restricted. The Bank of Thailand approves the remittance of donations and. gifts of a reasonable amoun t. Foreign exchange f rom inward capital move- ments must be sold to an authorized agent and the pur- pose of the transfer must be declared. Foreign investments in Thailand can be accorded preferen t ial treatment under Notice No. 227 of the Na t ional Executive Council (issued October 21, 1972); this trea tment includes a guarantee of the transfer abroad of current net earnings and of capital repatria- tion. The repatriation of other capital is considered on the merits of each case; approval is normally granted if it can be shown that the funds originated abroad. Cer- ta in economic activities are reserved for Thai nationals. The contracting of suppliers' credits abroad requires Bank of Thailand approval. Such approval also is required for accepting foreign currency deposits, bor- rowing foreign currency, or assuming any form of indebtedness in foreign currency. All other private loans taken up abroad may be registered with the Bank to fac i l i ta te approval of outward remittances. The pub- lic sector requires the approval of the National Eco- nomic Development Board to negotiate external loans. Commercial banks must report daily to the Exchange Equalization Fund and to the Bank of Thailand both their foreign exchange transactions and their foreign exchange positions. Gold Residents may hold and negotiate domestically gold jewelry, gold coins, and unworked gold. Imports and exports of gold other than jewelry are subject to the following arrangements, unless they are effected by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. Commercial imports of gold in any fo rm are restricted and require a license issued by the Ministry of Finance. For gold bullion, the Ministry periodically fixes an authorized quantity of imports. A bidding system operates under which the importer offer ing the highest premium by tender is awarded a license as sole importer of the authorized quantity for a certain period. In addition to this pre- m ium, which accrues to the Government, the importer is required to pay to the Ministry of Finance a fee at the rate of US$1.75 per troy ounce of gold. The fee is payable in baht at the par value. In 1974 and 1975, ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution however, no license was awarded for the importation of gold bullion. Exports of gold bullion are prohibited, while those of gold ornaments, when not effected by foreign tourists and exceeding B 5,000 in value, require a certificate of exportation in addition to the export entry, for presentation to the customs, but bear no export duty or taxes. Foreign tourists may without a certificate of exportation take out gold ornaments up to any value. The conveyance of gold in transit is not restricted and is free of customs charges. Changes during 1975 January 23. The ban on private trade with the Peo- ple's Republic of China was lifted. February 19. Exports of most types of confectionery and sugar syrup became subject to license. March 5. Exports of petroleum gas became subject to license. March 25. Commercial banks were required to report daily to the Exchange Equalization Fund their foreign exchange transactions as well as their foreign exchange positions. March 31. Ministerial Regulation No. 17 was issued. It modified the regulations governing inward capital transfers by subjecting to prior central bank approval the acceptance of deposits in foreign currency, the bor- rowing of foreign currency, and any form of indebted- ness in foreign currency, upon prescription by Ministerial Notification. May 17. Exports of all types of yarn ceased to require a license. June 3. Export premiums on most types of rice were reduced. June 30. As a result of the enactment of the Action Trade with State-Trading Countries B.E. 2518, dated January 4, 1975, Notice No. 6 of the Competent Officer was issued to cancel the prescribed method of trade THAILAND payment with the People's Republic of China and Inner Mongolia. July 5. Imports of certain vinyl chloride monomers became subject to license. August 12. Imports of used motorcycles again became subject to license. August 12. Oils used in mixing paint ceased to require a license. September 25. Exports of coral became subject to license. October 1. Imports of coconut oil became subject to license and were prohibited. October 25. Exports of certain polyester fibers ceased to require a license. November 5. The amount of foreign currency that residents departing for travel abroad could take out without prior exchange control approval was increased from US$140 to US$250 a person ( f rom US$280 to US$500 for a family traveling on a single passport). The amount of foreign currency in banknotes and coins that transit passengers and tourists could take out without prior authorization was set at US$2,000 a per- son, unless a higher amount had upon entry been reported to customs in writing; previously, such travel- ers could take out any amount of foreign exchange with- out prior authorization. November 18. Trade with Laos was suspended. November 19. The Exchange Equalization Fund's spot buying rate for the U.S. dollar was changed from B 20.325 to B 20.375. The selling rate remained unchanged at B 20.425. As a result, the commercial banks' buying rate for the U.S. dollar was changed on November 20 from B 20.30 to B 20.35 per US$1. December 4. Export premiums on rice were further reduced; for some grades the reduction was 50 per cent. December 11. Trade with Cambodia was resumed. December 26. Exports of gunny bags and hessian cloth made of ju te yarn ceased to require a license. 441 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TOGO (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Togo has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transac- tions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de TAfrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a commis- sion of %o of 1 per mill on transfers from countries outside the West Afr ican Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per mill on transfers to countries outside the Union.2 Exchange rates for foreign curren- cies are based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Togo's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Upper Volta). Hence all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Togo itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle finan- cial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ministry of Finance and Economy, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Togo, inward direct investment and all outward investment, and the soliciting of funds in Togo for placement in foreign countries. Some of the approval authority in respect of exchange control has been delegated to authorized intermediaries. The BCEAO is authorized to collect, either directly or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal 1 The CFA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 Transfers between member countries of the Union are subject to the flat commission of CFAF 100 levied on settlements between offices of the BCEAO. 442 Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Foreign Trade Division in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry, except those for gold, which are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Economy. Prescription of Currency Togo is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settlements with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Oper- ations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspon- dent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. Certain settlements with Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. The crediting to nonresident accounts of CFA banknotes, French bank- notes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury is not permitted, except for credits to Foreign Accounts held by foreign correspondents of authorized banks, which may be credited with BCEAO banknotes mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Lome by those correspondents. Imports and Import Payments Most imports of Rhodesian origin and all imports of Portuguese or South African origin are prohibited. Imports f rom countries in the French Franc Area may be made freely, but require the prior authorization of the Foreign Trade Division in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry, when valued at CFAF 10,000 or more and destined for commercial purposes. Imports f rom all other countries require individual import licenses when valued at CFAF 10,000 or more. In principle, the licenses are to be granted in accordance with an import program which is to be established each year; as yet, however, an import program has not been established and almost all requests for import licenses from all sources are granted. There are no formal import free lists. The issuance of import licenses for printed piece goods of Japanese origin is conditional, in principle, on the purchase of a specified quantity of the local product; in practice, this requirement is no longer enforced. The Societe Nationale de Commerce (SONACOM) has an import monopoly for sugar, rice, flour, canned milk, soap, salt, corrugated iron, and iron rods. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. Import licenses entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, spot, but not earlier than one month before shipment if a docu- mentary credit is opened or one month before the pay- ment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Certain payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Pay- ments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted by a general authorization when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted by a general authorization. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a trip for any number of trips a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten); any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining after return to Togo must be surrendered within eight days of re-entry. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, subject to a maximum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. The transfer of the entire net salary of a foreigner working in Togo is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, residence permit, and work permit, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Residents may at any time and without indicating the purpose of the transfer make payments abroad, through an authorized bank, or up to CFAF 50,000 per transfer. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maximum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO bank- notes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by other Operations Account countries. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes but if going to a country that is not a member of the West African Mone- tary Union they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 250,000. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the amount declared by them on entry 3 or, if no declaration has been made, up to the equivalent 3 This amount is adjusted for (1) the amount of foreign currency sold for CFA francs; and (2) for any foreign currency acquired in Togo by (a) debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or a Foreign Account in Foreign Currency, (b) the conversion of foreign cur- rency travelers checks, etc., made out in the name of the traveler, and (c) any repurchases of foreign currency (permitted up to CFAF 175,000) with CFA francs resulting from the sale of foreign currency. TOGO of CFAF 175,000. Nonresident travelers may also freely take out any amount of letters of credit and travelers checks drawn up in their names abroad. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to all countries require licenses. Certain exports to Rhodesia and all exports to Portugal and South Africa are prohibited. The Office Togolais des Phosphates has a monopoly over the export of phos- phates and the Office des Produits Agricoles du Togo (OPAT) has a monopoly over the export of cacao, coffee, cotton, groundnuts, and certain other commodi- ties. The due date for payments for exports to foreign countries cannot be later than 180 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination and the proceeds must be surrendered within a month after the due date if the contract is invoiced in a currency other than that of France or of an Operations Account country; authorized diamond purchasing offices, however, may retain such foreign currency proceeds in foreign currency accounts with authorized banks in Togo. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services, and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets, must be collected and surrendered within one month of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any institute of issue maintaining an Oper- ations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Resi- dent travelers must within eight days sell to an autho- rized bank any foreign banknotes and foreign currency travelers checks they bring in in excess of CFAF 5,000. Capital Certain capital transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Capital movements between Togo and France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval by the Minister of Finance and Economy and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, over the issuing, advertis- ing, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Togo, and over the soliciting of funds in Togo for placing abroad; these controls relate to the transactions them- 443 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TOGO selves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those relating to foreign securities and the soliciting of funds in Togo, these control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member countries of the West African Mone- tary Union, and those other countries whose institute of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account. There also are special controls appli- cable to all countries other than Togo with respect to imports and exports of gold. All investments abroad by residents of Togo require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Econ- omy.4 Foreign direct investments in Togo5 must be declared to the Minister of Finance and Economy before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration dur ing which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The total or partial liquidation of any inward direct investment or any outward investment also requires prior declaration to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Togolese investments abroad or foreign invest- ments in Togo, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and Economy and to the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Togo requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Economy. Exempt from autho- rization, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Togolese Government and (2) shares that are similar to, or may be substituted for, securities whose issuing, advertising, or offering for sale in Togo has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance and Economy. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indi- cated above; (2) loans contracted by registered banks; (3) loans taken up either by industrial firms to finance works abroad or by approved international merchanting 4 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com- panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Togo and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Togo. 5 Including those made by companies in Togo that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or sub- sidiaries in Togo of foreign companies. houses to finance imports or exports; and (4) in cer- tain circumstances, any other loans, provided that the outstanding amount for any one borrower does not exceed CFAF 100 million. The repayment of any for- eign borrowing requires the prior authorization of the Minister; exempt from this requirement are loans consti- tu t ing a direct investment, loans taken up by authorized banks, and any loans exempted by the Minister. Lend- ing abroad is subject only to special authorization by the Directorate of Economy. Under the provisions of the general tax legislation, certain fiscal benefits are accorded to specified new investment (foreign and domestic) in both new and existing enterprises. Also, certain enterprises, in accor- dance with their importance to the economic develop- ment of Togo, may be granted by the Government, for a specified number of years, special privileges relating to the maintenance of existing taxes and the exemption from import duties on a large number of items. Such privileges are negotiated by the Government and the investor. An Investment Law (Law No. 65-10 of July 21, 1965, as amended by Ordinance No. 2 of January 10, 1973) applicable to both foreign and domestic capital lists the types of enterprises that may be designated as "priority enterprises," provided that the head office is in Togo. Such firms may sign a special found ing agreement by which they receive certain tax benefits. Firms that undertake to invest at least CFAF 20 million may receive a guarantee in respect of their taxation over a number of years. The law guarantees the right of free transfer abroad of capital invested in Togo and of all investment income therefrom. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Togo. Imports and exports of gold f rom or to any other country require prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance and Economy. Exempt f rom this requirement are (1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufactured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1975 July 10. France resumed its participation in the Euro- pean common margins arrangement; the parity between the CFA f ranc and the French franc remained unchanged. 444 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.444335 gram of fine gold per Trini- dad and Tobago Dollar, and Trinidad and Tobago avails itself of wider margins. However, a fixed relationship with sterling is maintained of TT$4.80 = <£ stg. 1. On December 31, 1975, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar quoted by the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago (inclusive of exchange charges) were TT$237.056 and TT$238.363, respectively, per US$100. The Central Bank quotes daily rates at which it stands ready to deal with the commercial banks in foreign cur- rencies as well as the rates at which the commercial banks must operate with the public in these currencies in transactions not exceeding TTSlOOjOOO.1 For transac- tions in excess of TT$ 100,000 the commercial banks are required to quote rates to the public not less favor- able than those fixed by the Central Bank for smaller transactions. Foreign exchange transactions through the Central Bank are for amounts of TT$25,000 and above and are subject to exchange charges up to a maximum of 1 per cent on inward and outward trans- fers; on December 31, 1975 the rates charged by the Central Bank to commercial banks were l/2 of 1 per cent on outward transfers and nil on inward transfers. Ster- ling exchange transactions through commercial banks are subject to varying exchange charges according to the amount and mode of transfer. Notes issued by the East Caribbean Currency Author- ity (East Caribbean dollars) and the Central Bank of Barbados are not legal tender in Trinidad and Tobago, but under an arrangement with the monetary authorities concerned the notes are purchased by the monetary authorities and are repatriated by them in return for reciprocity of treatment with respect to collections of Trinidad and Tobago dollars. Administration of Control The authority to administer exchange control is vested in the Central Bank, acting as agent of the Government. The Central Bank has delegated its exchange control authority with respect to import payments to certain officials of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce and with respect to payments up to specified amounts for certain current invisibles to authorized banks. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Trade and Commerce Division of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. The exchange control system provides for compulsory 1The currencies for which the Central Bank quotes daily rates are Canadian dollars, deutsche ma rk, French f rancs, Japanese yen, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars, in addition to Barbados dol- lars, Guyana dollars, Jamaica dollars, and East Caribbean dollars. surrender of foreign cu r rency2'3 and for control over both current and capital transactions. All overseas pay- ments and transfers require the approval of the exchange control authorities; payments to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Short-term credit transactions, such as the granting of credit, loan, or overdraft facilities by resident banks to nonresidents and local nonresident- controlled companies, are also subject to control. Prescription of Currency Trinidad and Tobago has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regula- tions continues to be regarded as a country of the Over- seas Sterling Area. In practice, settlements with resi- dents of other parts of the Sterling Area may be made only in sterling or other Sterling Area currencies. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia may be made in sterling to the credit of an External Account in any other part of the Sterling Area, or by crediting an External Account in Trinidad and Tobago dollars, or in any non-Sterling Area cur- rency. Payments from countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia must be received in sterling f rom an External Account in any other part of the Sterling Area, or by debiting an External Account in Trinidad and Tobago dollars, or in any specified cur- rency 4 other than Rhodesian currency. Special regula- tions apply to Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonresident accounts: External Accounts and Blocked Accounts. External Accounts may be opened by commercial banks for nonresidents of Trinidad and Tobago. These accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Trinidad and Tobago that have been approved by the exchange control authorities; with transfers from other External Accounts; and with proceeds from the sale of gold and foreign currencies to an authorized dealer. They may be debited for payments to residents of Trinidad and Tobago; for transfers to other External Accounts; and for purchases of foreign currencies.
