Not for Redistribution UGANDA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Uganda Shilling. A central rate of U Sh 9.66000 = SDR 1 has been established, and Uganda avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign currencies l other than deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars; its rates for the U.S. dollar are based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U.S. dollar/ SDR rate, and its rates for deutsche mark and pounds sterling are based on the previous day's New York rates against the U.S. dollar. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies 2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U.S. dollar in New York, except for Kenya shillings and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. Authorized banks may freely deal forward with customers in ster- ling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export con- tract and that the term of the forward contract does not exceed three months; contracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the M in is try of Commerce and Industry and the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade (UABT) under the External Trade Act (as amended) and by the Bank of Uganda. The Minister of Commerce and Industry has powers to prohibit imports and exports. Together with Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda is part of the East A f r ican currency area but exchange control is applied to both Kenya and Tanzania. Under Uganda's exchange control regulations, the three countries are referred to as the Scheduled Territories. Prescription of Currency Uganda has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. All payments to Kenya and Tanzania must be effected in the currencies of those countries through accounts held with each other by the central banks concerned. Payments to residents of countries in the Sterling Area other than Kenya, Tanzania, and South Africa may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of a Sterling Area Account in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area currency; receipts from such countries 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish and Faroese kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Span- ish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and all Sterling Area currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 460 may be obtained in Uganda shillings from a Sterling Area Account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Authorized payments, inc lud ing payments for imports, by residents of Uganda to residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas te r r i to r ies ), or Rhodesia may be made to an External Account in any Sterling Area country, in Uganda shillings to the credit of an External Account in Uganda, or in any other non-Sterling Area currency except Rhodesian currency that is appropriate to the coun t ry of residence of the payee. Receipts f rom countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), or Rhodesia may be obtained in Uganda shillings f rom an External Account, in any Sterling Area specified cur- rency from an External Account, or in any other speci- fied currency that is not a Sterling Area currency. Pay- ments to Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Certain settlements w i th Bu rund i, Rwanda, and Zaire are chan- neled through special accounts. Nonresident Accounts Sterling Area Accounts are held by residents of other Sterling Area countries except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be credited freely w i th all authorized pay- ments to such Sterling Area countries by Ugandan resi- dents, w i th transfers from other Sterling Area Accounts, w i th transfers from External Accounts, and w i th the pro- ceeds from sales to an authorized dealer in Uganda of any foreign currency or gold by residents of any other country in the Sterling Area except Kenya and Tanzania. They may be debited freely for payments for exports to other countries in the Sterling Area and other payments due by residents of other countries in the Sterling Area to Ugandan residents, for payments to residents of other countries in the Sterling Area for any purpose, for trans- fers to other Sterling Area Accounts in Uganda, for purchases of any Sterling Area currency, and for with- drawals by the account holder while he is temporarily resident in Uganda; provided that permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Sterling Area coun t ry has been obtained, Sterling Area Accounts may exceptionally be debited for transfers to External Accounts in Uganda or elsewhere in the Sterling Area, and for purchases in Uganda of any non-Sterling Area currency or gold. Accounts in Uganda sh i l l ings held by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), or Rhodesia with authorized banks are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Uganda, with transfers from other External ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any non- Sterling Area currency (other than Israel, Portuguese, or Rhodesian currency) and gold by nonresidents of the Sterling Area to authorized dealers; provided that the permission of the appropriate exchange control authori- ties in a Sterling Area country has been obtained, Exter- nal Accounts may also be credited with transfers from Sterling Area Accounts. They may be debited freely for payments to residents of the Sterling Area, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda or in any other Sterling Area country, and for purchases of non-Sterling Area currencies from authorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable beginning five years from the date of purchase. Subject to individ- ual permission, such balances may also be used for pay- ments to residents not related to export transactions. Transfers between Blocked Accounts in Uganda, and to Blocked Accounts in Kenya and Tanzania, require prior approval. All Blocked Accounts must be held with the Uganda Commercial Bank. Imports and Import Payments All permitted imports require approval by the UABT. Some imports from all sources are prohibited for rea- sons of public policy; imports prohibited for other reasons include passenger automobiles, cotton fabrics, blankets, electrical home refrigerators, transistor radios, and matches. Import license applications are screened by eight specified companies, which are supervised by the UABT. A Cabinet Committee under the Ministry of Finance periodically considers the recommendations of the UABT in light of the availability of foreign exchange as notified by the Bank of Uganda, and makes block allocations which are divided and distributed by the specified companies. Licenses for raw materials are issued in the name of the UABT for the account of the importer. The National Textile Board has a monopoly over the importation of most textiles; there also are state import monopolies for certain other commodities, includ- ing motor vehicles. Upon approval of the application, the importer must lodge a commission of 1 per cent of the amount of the license with the UABT. All imports f rom Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited and imports from Portuguese-controlled territories in Africa are not being licensed. Imports normally must be purchased direct from the country of origin. Some imports of manufactured goods from Kenya and Tan- zania are subject to transfer taxes. Import payments normally are made under letters of credit opened in the name of the UABT for the account of the importer; the latter generally must make full pay- ment to the authorized bank before the letter of credit is opened. Documentary evidence showing that the goods UGANDA have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities within six months from the date of payment. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to approval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 3,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in foreign bank- notes. The allowance is available for travel to any coun- try except Kenya and Tanzania, for which normally holiday facilities of up to U Sh 1,000 a person a year are available, and Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Salaried non- citizens recruited from outside East Africa may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their overseas leave. No foreign exchange is released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, nonnational missionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may during their stay in Uganda remit to their country of origin up to 33% per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the con- tract. Transfers of dividends and profits are subject to special regulations; thus, foreign-owned companies must retain in Uganda at least 20 per cent of the profits made in any business year, and they are not allowed to remit interim dividends. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by travel- ers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses and may be restricted to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. All exports to Israel, South Africa, the Portuguese- controlled territories in Africa, and Rhodesia are pro- hibited. The Uganda Tea Board has a monopoly over the export of tea, the Coffee Marketing Board over the export of coffee, and the Lint Marketing Board over the export of raw cotton. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot- note 2) must be collected within six months of exporta- tion and offered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee, cotton, copper, and hides and skins are subject to export duty. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is 461 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA prohibited, except that returning Ugandan residents may bring in U Sh 100 a person. Travelers may freely bring in foreign currency notes and foreign currency travelers checks. granted to a nonresident or to a body corporate resi- dent in Uganda which is by any means controlled, whether directly or indirectly, by persons resident out- side Uganda. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted and those to Israel, Portugal (and its overseas territories), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemptions from the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally transfer their assets up to the equivalent of U Sh 50,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premiums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remittance of savings. A fu r ther transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anni- versary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain approved securities or held on deposit with commercial banks in Uganda; such funds become transferable af ter five years. The income from such investments is transferable also during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; to secure guaranteed repatriation, how- ever, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Pro- tection) Act, 1964, which in normal circumstances is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in speci- fied types of production require approval under the East African Industrial Licensing Act and the Uganda Licens- ing Act, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and distributed by com- panies operating in Uganda are in principle transferable. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresi- dents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Uganda may not send, as a g i f t, to any country more than U Sh 100 a year without specific exchange control approval. With minor exceptions, prior exchange control approval is required for loans or overdraft facilities Gold A commemorative gold coin with a face value of U Sh 500 is legal tender but does not circulate. Resi- dents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the following from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets), gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued restrictively and only to goldsmiths. Changes during 1975 May 30. The issue of foreign currency notes to hold- ers of nonresident accounts required prior exchange control approval. June 12. Import duties were introduced or increased on a large number of items. Virtually all goods not already subject to duty became subject to a duty of 10 per cent ad valorem, the main exception being plant and machin- ery for processing and manufac tur ing industries. August 21. The regulations on nonresident accounts were amended. A minimum balance of U Sh 500 was required to open an account. Whenever any nonresi- dent account had not been operated for two years or more, it had to be closed. Banks were also reminded that all overdrafts on nonresident accounts required prior approval. October 27. The currency was repegged from the U.S. dollar to the SDR. The central rate was changed from U Sh 7.14286 = US$1 to U Sh 9.66000 = SDR 1. Uganda continued to avail itself of wider margins and the U.S. dollar continued to be the intervention cur- rency. The exchange rates for the currencies of Kenya and Tanzania remained unchanged. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES1 (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System On February 23, 1974, the United Arab Emirates established an initial par value of 0.186621 gram of fine gold per U.A.E. Dirham, corresponding at the time to Dh 1 = SDR 0.21 or US$1 = Dh 3.9720. The U.S. dollar parity has since been maintained unchanged. The United Arab Emirates avails itself of wider margins. The United Arab Emirates Currency Board establishes daily quotations for 18 currencies.2 The rate of exchange for the U.S. dollar against the dirham is fixed daily at the discretion of the Board within the limits of the wider margins. Rates for other currencies are fixed in relation to the U.S. dollar/dirham rate and the previous day's closing rates in New York. The Board deals with commercial banks, rulers of states, governments, and quasigovernment institutions. On December 31, 1975 the Board's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were Dh 3.9920 and Dh 3.9960, respectively, per US$1. The United Arab Emirates formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement on February 13, 1974. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emirates, and there are no registration requirements for inward or outward transfers. The United Arab Emirates has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Import and export licenses, where required, are issued by the authorities of the Emirate concerned. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and South Africa are pro- hibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by resi- dents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports of products manufactured by foreign com- panies blacklisted by the Arab League. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited from all sources for moral, health, or security reasons. Virtually all other commodi- ties may be freely imported without an individual import permit, but only licensed parties can enter the import trade and an importer can import only the commodity or commodities specified in his license. Certain commodi- ties (mainly rice, sugar, and flour) are imported by the state trading company, which, however, does not have an import monopoly in any commodity. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel and South Africa. Travelers may take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Virtually all commodities may be exported freely, with- out an export license, to any other destination. Each Emirate establishes its own export regulations. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or sur- rendered and may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts from current invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Transactions and settlements involving Israel or South Africa, however, are prohibited. Profits on foreign capi- tal invested in the United Arab Emirates may be remit- ted freely. Gold With the exception noted below, residents and nonresi- dents, including private persons, may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without an individual import or export permit, import and export gold in any form, but the import of gold for trade, like that of any other commod- ity, may only be undertaken by licensed parties. Transac- tions involving Israel, South Africa, or companies black- listed by the Arab League are prohibited. Gold bullion is exempt from import duty but jewelry is not. 1The seven federated states of the United Arab Emirates are Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, A jman, Umm al Qaiwan, Ras al-Khaimah, and Fujairah. 2 Bahrain dinars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, rials Omani, pounds sterling, Qatar riyals, Saudi Arabian riyals, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Pound Sterling. Since June 23, 1972, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the pound within announced margins, and therefore all transac- tions in the official exchange market, except those in currencies ma in ta in ing a fixed relationship with sterling, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The closing selling and buy ing rates in the foreign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1975 were US$2.0230 and US$2.0236 per <£!, respectively. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currency, except Rhodesian currency, subject to the observance of limits on open positions and the accumulation of spot foreign exchange. Forward rates may fluctuate under the inf lu- ence of market forces; transactions with resident cus- tomers may be entered into only for approved pur- poses, where there is an underlying commercial contract (or where an exporter is tendering for an over- seas export con trac t), and in the currency of the con- tract. There is also a market (referred to as the investment currency ma rke t) in which certain foreign currency proceeds,1 resulting ma in ly f rom the sale outside the Scheduled Territories (the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of Ire- land,2 and G ibra l tar) of foreign currency securities held for portfolio investment purposes,3 and of most personal residential property situated outside the Scheduled Terri- tories may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually attracting a premium over the official market; at the end of 1975, that premium was about 60 per cent calculated at the ruling U.S. dollar rate in the official exchange market, the middle closing rate on December 31 being <£! = US$1.2396. These funds are normally available for reinvestment in marketable foreign currency securities, for approved purchases of personal residential property in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, and, although little used for this purpose, for approved direct invest- ments in non-Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. Exchange Control Territory In general, the United Kingdom does not impose restrictions on exchange transactions or payments and receipts between residents of the United Kingdom and residents of the Scheduled Territories. Exchange control applies mainly to transactions with residents of coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories. For adminis- trative purposes, the non-Scheduled Territories are divided as follows: (1) the other member countries of the EEC, except the Republic of Ireland; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA), i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ireland and Gibraltar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories;4 (3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries, usually referred to as the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST ). Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is admin- istered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U.K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments requir- ing exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled by the Department of Trade. Prescription of Currency Receipts f rom Scheduled Territories may be obtained in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those from other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, must be in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), which must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Payments to Scheduled Territories may be made in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; payments to other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, may be made by crediting * The OSA thus comprises Australia, Bahamas, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Bermuda, Botswana, British Indian Ocean Territory, Solomon Islands, British Virgin Islands, Brunei, Cayman Islands, Cyprus, Falkland Islands and Dependencies, Fiji, The Gambia, Ghana, Gilbert Islands, Grenada, Guyana, Hong Kong, Iceland, India and Sikkim, Jamaica, Jordan, Kenya, Kuwait, Leeward Islands, Lesotho, Malawi, Malaysia, Maldive Islands, Malta, Mauritius and Dependency, N au ru, New Zealand, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Pitcairn Islands, Qatar, St. Helena and Dependencies, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Singapore, South Afr ica, South West Africa (Nam ib ia ), Sri Lanka, Swaziland, Tanzania, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Turks and Caicos Islands, Tuvalu (Ellice Islands), Uganda, United Arab Emirates, Western Samoa, Windward Islands, People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, and Zambia. 465 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM sterling to an External Account or in any foreign cur- rency except Rhodesian currency. For security reasons, settlements with Rhodesia are subject to special regulations generally prescribing the use of Rhodesian Accounts, Suspense Accounts, or, in certain circumstances, the Rhodesian Special Account with the Standard Bank, London. However, unless specifically included among the permitted debits to Rhodesian Accounts, all commercial payments, except those in respect of exports, due from persons resident in Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom must be received either in a foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or, with the specific permission of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account; authorized payments for exports f rom the United Kingdom to Rhodesia must be received in advance of shipment in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency, or, with the specific approval of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account. Persons normally resident in Rho- desia who are living temporarily in the United Kingdom as students or workers may open Temporary Resident Accounts in sterling with authorized banks in the United Kingdom; debits to such accounts are generally per- mitted only for living expenses within the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of resi- dents of the United Kingdom. Thus, for transfers between Scheduled Territories no U.K. exchange con- trol permission is required; for payments to other coun- tries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the author- ized banks are required to ensure that the payment has the approval of the exchange control authority in the territory concerned. External Accounts. With the exception of Rhodesian Accounts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see below), the sterling accounts of nonresidents with authorized banks in the United Kingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments by residents of Scheduled Territories, with transfers f rom other Exter- nal Accounts, with the proceeds from sales of gold or foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (includ- ing bankno tes), and with sterling banknotes mailed from outside the Scheduled Territories. External Accounts may be debited, subject to general or special permis- sion, for payments to residents of the Scheduled Terri- tories, for transfers to other External Accounts, for transfers to Rhodesian Accounts other than in payment for certain goods exported from Rhodesia, for payments in cash in the United Kingdom, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency (including banknotes) or gold. 466 Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers f rom External Accounts, provided that the bank has no reason to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (United Nations Sanctions) (No. 2) Order 1968; payments by residents of Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the terri- tory concerned; and payments by U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of for- eign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the discount or ma tu r i ty proceeds of U.K. treasury bills, (3) permitted imports from Rhodesia which have entered customs in the United Kingdom, (4) insur- ance and freight charges resulting f rom permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, (6) pensions and widows' annuities where associated with the deceased husband's employment, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or Malawi, (8) matur- ity proceeds of certain endowment insurance policies, and ( 9) expenditure in gathering news material. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; payments for living expenses in the United Kingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their fam i l ies; authorized purchases of U.K. sterling securi- ties to be held for the account holder; purchases in the United Kingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories for ( 1) interest on and repayment of out- standing personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, designs, trademarks, and royalties, (3) distributions f rom Rhodesian estates and trusts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U.K. residents for (a) expenses arising out of prop- erty in the United Kingdom owned on or before November 11, 1965, (b) taxes, (c) living expenses, educational fees, and incidental expenses, (d) insur- ance premiums and capital and annu i ty payments on personal policies taken out on or before November 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) gifts and maintenance not exceeding <£250 for any one payment, to individuals and religious, medical, educational, and charitable orga- nizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds provided the person was a member of the fund before November 11, 1965 or before taking up residence in Rhodesia after that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Payments in respect of educational and medical expenses in Rhodesia also are permitted. Transfers between Rhodesian Accounts and f rom Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts are not normally allowed. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rho- desian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Account, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be withheld unless the Bank of England directs otherwise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, except with specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U.K. tax payments and safe custody charges due on the monies in question, (2) used within specified limits for living expenses in the United Kingdom of residents of Rhodesia and certain other personal pay- ments, or (3) placed on deposit with banks or other financial institutions in the name of the U.K. resident by whom they are held. Permission is given for resi- dents of Rhodesia to use Suspense Account monies to purchase U.K. sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom and to purchase U.K. treasury bills and savings bonds and certificates. Per- mission is only given for them to purchase Rhodesian or foreign currency securities, however, when the funds for the purchase are derived from the immediate sale proceeds of other Rhodesian or foreign currency securi- ties, respectively. The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office staff in London and maintained with the Standard Bank, London. Pen- sions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia from residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and pensions due from Rhodesia to resi- dents of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and most parts of the OSA are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers from Rhodesian Accounts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Permission is not normally given for payments of any other nature to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Account. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of England, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet educational payments in the United Kingdom, the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for account of per- sons resident in Rhodesia. Imports and Import Payments For import licensing purposes countries outside the United Kingdom other than Rhodesia 5 are divided into eight groups: the Mediterranean Area,6 the Non- Community Area,7 the Non-CEFTA Area,8 the Dollar 5 All goods f rom Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are not normally granted. 6 The Mediterranean Area comprises Cyprus, Greece, Lebanon, Malta, Morocco, Spain, Tunisia, and Turkey. 7 The Non-Community Area comprises all countries other than EEC member states. 8 The Non-CEFTA Area comprises all countries other than EEC and non-Community EFTA member states. UNITED KINGDOM Area,9 Japan,10 Romania, the Eastern Area,11 and all other countries. Imports from countries other than Rhodesia are admitted under an Open General Import License with- out restriction, with the following exceptions as at the end of 1975:12 (1) from all other countries, seven com- modities or groups of commodities;13 (2) from the Dollar Area only, three commodities or groups of com- modities; (3) from Japan only, certain textiles; (4) from the Non-CEFTA Area only, one commodity; (5) f rom Romania only, two commodities; and (6) from the Eastern Area only, nine commodities or groups of com- modities. Most articles subject to specific import licensing can be imported in limited quantities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, i.e., without limit as to quantity or value. Imports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mutton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to m in imum import prices enforced through autonomously imposed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricultural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to EEC regulations. Once licensing requirements have been met to import from countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, whether under Open General Import License or some other form of license, U.K. residents may purchase foreign currency or credit sterling to an External Account to pay for the import, provided that evidence of customs entry is submitted or evidence that the goods have been dispatched to the United Kingdom or are to be dispatched immediately on receipt of pay- ment. Advance payments for imports are approved by the Bank of England where the payment is considered necessary or in accordance with the traditions of the trade and the continuance of the practice is considered to be essential. Current administrative practice is not to allow advance payments for consumer goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Payments to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require exchange control authorization, which (except for pay- ments to residents of Rhodes ia)14 is granted freely for all purposes other than sterling usance credits to finance trade directly between principals resident in non- Scheduled Territories outside the OSA, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding ,£1,000 or its equivalent. Authorized banks are permitted to approve applications for transfers on account of many categories of current invisibles with- out any limitation, and for other categories up to estab- lished limits. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for which no delegation of authority has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unauthorized capital out- flow is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against pay- ment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. For any type of travel outside the Scheduled Terri- tories (except to Rhodesia), U.K. residents can obtain on demand from banks and authorized travel agents foreign exchange up to the equivalent of .£300 a person a trip; for travel for business or professional reasons, an allowance of £40 a day up to a maximum of £2,000 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. Applications for additional amounts are approved by the Bank of Eng- land unless there is reason to suspect that the exchange is to be used for purposes other than genuine travel expenditure. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for without limit in the United Kingdom. Travel exchange purchased in the United Kingdom must normally be recorded in the traveler's passport. Under arrangements agreed with certain banks, per- sonal checks may be cashed abroad for travel purposes, up to £30 a check, if backed by check cards. Credit cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resi- dent travelers may take out up to £300 in foreign currency notes. Any unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency may be retained for a period of one 14 For security reasons, virtually all current payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result from permitted trade in goods. Consideration is, however, given to remittances on a limited basis to relieve hardship and to remittances of a continuing na tu re by charitable, religious, medical, and educational organizations for both current pur- poses or to meet capital expenditure in the educational and medical fields. Banks have authority to approve applications by U.K. residents who wish to open foreign currency accounts outside the Scheduled Territories for the receipt of travel funds for use during their stay abroad. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six months from the date of issue or for one month from the date of return to the United Kingdom, if later. In addition, resi- dent travelers may take with them up to £25 in U.K. and other Scheduled Territory banknotes, which may be exchanged or spent abroad only for travel expendi- ture; but those traveling direct to the Republic of Ire- land, the Channel Islands, or the Isle of Man may take out any amount. Visitors to the United Kingdom are, in addition, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in with them, other than notes in excess of £25 expressed in the currencies of the United Kingdom or the Republic of Ireland. Authorized banks are permitted to approve, within certain limits and subject to the submission of appro- priate documentary evidence of the amounts due, appli- cations to pay fees, accommodation charges, and all incidental expenses arising from the education of U.K. residents outside the Scheduled Territories. Special regulations apply to all travel to Rhodesia. For approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England will authorize the issue of foreign currency at a rate of up to £ 10 a day with a maximum of £300. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compassionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions (medical and educational supplies, food- stuffs where these are special medical preparations, newsfilm and photographs, and documentary and printed matter less than 100 years old) and for equip- ment for the essential replacement needs of the Rho- desian Railways and the Central African Power Corpo- ration. Virtually all exports to other destinations are free of export control and no exchange control forms are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate payment within six months of shipment; special exchange control permission to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six months without cover from the Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD). Receipts in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless the recipient has obtained specific permission to credit them to a retained cur- rency account (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for prior to shipment in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution by the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients of such currencies have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other banknotes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United Kingdom who receive foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency from certain capital account sources (mainly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities held for portfolio invest- ment purposes and the sale of personal residential prop- erty situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been given) for the purchase of marketable foreign currency securities, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Territories, or the making of approved direct invest- ments outside the Scheduled Territories; they may also sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purposes. If permission is not forth- coming, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ruling in the official market to an authorized bank in the United Kingdom. If permission is granted, however, the equivalent in foreign currency of 25 per cent of the proceeds must norma l ly be sold to an autho- rized bank for sterling at the official market rate of exchange.15'16 In certain circumstances, residents of the United Kingdom who have obtained exemption from their obligations under the Exchange Control Act in respect of assets denominated in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency may obtain permission for the sale proceeds of exempted securities to be sold for sterling in the investment currency market up to 75 per cent of the amount concerned.17 In certain circum- stances, exempted cash balances arising from the sale of property may also be sold as investment currency. There are no restrictions on capital transfers by resi- dents of the United Kingdom into the beneficial owner- ship of residents of other Scheduled Territories. All capital transfers by residents to countries outside the Scheduled Territories require approval. UNITED KINGDOM vidual resident of the United Kingdom may, from his own resources, make cash gifts or personal loans not exceeding a total of «£ 1,000, or the equivalent in foreign currency, during each calendar year to residents of the OSA, as well as a further £300 or the equivalent to residents of other countries outside the Scheduled Terri- tories except Rhodesia; additional amounts may be allowed under appropriate circumstances. The cash gifts allowance is noncumulative and is not transferable f rom one resident to another. A resident of the United Kingdom with dependents who are established residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia may make payments from his own resources not exceeding <£2,000 a year to support those dependents. Such payments, which may be gifts or loans, are outside the cash gift scheme and do not prejudice the normal cash gift allowances. For security reasons, no capital transfers are allowed to Rhodesia, whether in the form of direct investment or of the purchase of Rhodesian securities, or by any other means, except to relatives, or other Rhodesian residents where human i ta r ian reasons are given, to the extent of £75 du r ing any period of two years. For direct investments in non-Scheduled Territories, official exchange is normally made available only for certain projects directly concerned with promoting exports of goods and services where the prospective benefit to the U.K. balance of payments is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the investment within 18 mon ths and to continue thereafter; this benefit will norma l ly occur by way of additional export receipts, but may also arise from profits and other foreign cur- rency receipts that would not take place without the investment. For such projects ("super-criterion" proj- ec ts), official exchange may be made available up to $250,000 or 50 per cent of the total investment, which- ever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the invest- ment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an over- seas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. Direct investment other than for super-criterion proj- ects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fall directly upon the U.K. official foreign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the United Kingdom by way of benefits arising f rom the investments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of pay- ment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade forming an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. The permitted proportion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings after taxes, applied, if desired, on a global basis where more than one subsidiary is involved. The purchase outside the Scheduled Territories of marketable foreign currency securities for portfolio in- vestment must be financed either with investment cur- rency or with foreign currency borrowing. Such bor- rowing is freely permitted when under taken by or through U.K. professional security managers, and the resale of foreign currency securities acquired in this manner is exempt from the "25 per cent requirement" until the loan portfolio is liquidated and the profit repatriated. Purchases of marketable foreign currency securities with investment currency are freely permitted by virtue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized depositaries. Pur- chases f rom other residents may also be effected with sterling on The Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the prevailing investment currency p r em i um ). The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or an apartment for personal use in countries outside the Scheduled Territories requires specific approval and must be made either from another Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory currency, or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Ter- ritories with investment currency or borrowed foreign currency; payment for attendant expenses and improve- ments, but not maintenance, must also be made with investment currency. (As an exception to this rule, residents temporarily employed in the OSA or member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is normally limited to one prop- erty a fam i ly; purchases of investment currency are normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received pro- vided that the funds are held by an authorized depositary and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property within six months. The approval au thor i ty for amounts up to <£ 30,000 for a residential property has been delegated to authorized banks. All proceeds from the realization, redemption, or ma tur i ty of sterling capital assets ( inc lud ing direct in- vestments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories other than residents of Rhodesia are remit- table at the official market rate of exchange. Payments to nonresident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due from the estates of deceased residents; capital payments under life and other insur- ance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies are also authorized freely. 470 Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the intention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer their assets are, on their departure f rom the United Kingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, with the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Repatriates (non-Sched- uled Territory nationals or citizens, other than Rhode- sians, who having been resident in the United Kingdom re tu rn to take up residence in any country outside the Scheduled Territories) may normally transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the official market rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories and the OSA except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to transfer for a fam i ly unit up to £5,000 through the official foreign exchange market (£20,000 for older persons) and may export any foreign currency secu- rities they hold; the rema in ing declared assets in excess of £5,000 are restricted for a four-year period from the date of the departing person's redesignation as a nonresident. U.K. residents taking up residence and employment in member countries of the EEC, however, may, with specific approval, transfer sterling assets at the official market rate of exchange in excess of the £5,000 l im it where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. For emigration to the OSA, the basic settling-in allow- ance is £20,000 (with a similar concession for those tak ing up employment), also available at the official market rate of exchange, and holdings of foreign cur- rency securities are exportable. During the four-year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign currencies other than Rhode- sian currency through the investment currency market, may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on The Stock Exchange, the income therefrom being freely remittable through the official exchange market, or may be used, with general or specific permission, to meet certain expenses in the United Kingdom. After the four-year period any remaining assets are transfer- able in accordance with the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonresident; at present, the transfer at the official market rate of exchange is normally allowed. The participation of foreign capital as a direct invest- ment in the United Kingdom is subject to individual authorization, which is normally granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an ap- proved manner of payment (see section on Prescription of Currency, above) or by the import of goods and services; the foreign currency received must be sur- rendered at rates ruling in the official market unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases involving the take-over of existing companies that by their size or nature constitute a vital part of British industry are considered on their merits. Permissions given for direct investments in the United Kingdom by nonresidents are normally, unless ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution otherwise agreed with the Bank of England, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling f rom an Ex- ternal Account or in foreign currency (other than Rho- desian currency) and, where nonresidents (other than residents of the EEC and the OS A) have a controlling interest, on any subsequent finance being provided in foreign currency or External Account sterling at least in proportion to the nonresident interest in the equity of the company. The acquisition in any manner by any person not resident in the United Kingdom of 10 per cent or more of the ou ts tand ing shares of a company registered in the United Kingdom requires prior ex- change control approval. Nonresident firms and individuals must obtain per- mission f rom the Treasury in order to raise capital in the United Kingdom, and U.K. resident subsidiaries of nonresident companies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U.K. residents also need permission to lend to U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents. Such permission is normally given for sterling lending for the purpose of financing the company's day-to-day business, but is not normally given for any expansion of m anu f a c tu r ing capacity except for companies whose activities are re- garded as bringing special advantages to the U.K. econ- omy. There are three important exceptions to these principles: ( 1) Unlimited sterling finance in the United Kingdom is norma l ly allowed to U.K. companies in which any nonresidents have less than a controlling interest, except to companies which are purely vehicles for portfolio investment. (2) U.K. companies controlled by residents of the EEC or the OSA that are not purely vehicles for portfolio investment are no rma l ly allowed un l im i ted sterling finance for their operations anywhere in the United Kingdom. (3) U.K. companies controlled by residents of any non-EEC country outside both the Scheduled Territories and the OSA are upon application allowed similar facilities in respect of new expenditure in the areas of the United Kingdom which qualify for special government assistance (the assisted areas), while their requests in respect of new expenditure in other areas of the Un i ted Kingdom are considered on their merits. U.K. banks are prohibited f rom providing sterling loans or overdrafts to persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for the purpose of financing trade between non-Scheduled Territories, but sterling lending to residents of the OSA to finance trade with such non-Scheduled Territories is unrestricted. Borrowing by U.K. residents f rom nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to finance expenditure in the United Kingdom is subject to restrictions. Private sector U.K. residents other than authorized banks normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency f rom non- residents of the Scheduled Territories for conversion into sterling for use in the United Kingdom, or to finance current payments to nonresidents of the Scheduled Ter- ritories, unless the term of borrowing is at least two UNITED KINGDOM years; exporters, merchants, and certain commodity traders are, however, permitted to borrow foreign cur- rency for shorter periods f rom authorized banks or from nonresidents to finance their sales or, in some cases, stockholdings. Public sector bodies normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least five years. Autho- rized banks must not lend foreign currency to U.K. residents other than authorized banks for any other purpose w i thout prior reference to the Bank of England. U.K. companies normally are not permitted to borrow External Account sterling f rom nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories unless the term of the borrowing is at least two years. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositaries, transactions in securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the Un i ted K ingdom, except that transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on The Stock Exchange. Residents are norma l ly permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories, and, after 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange, to reinvest the balance of the exchange proceeds ( inves tment currency) in marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for certain approved direct investment or approved pur- chases of property for private use outside the Scheduled Territories. When foreign currency securities are sold by residents on The Stock Exchange for sterling, an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian cu r rency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers making a "book" in foreign cur- rency securities may on application be exempt from the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book" but not in respect of sales of securities held as investments. Investment currency held for a continu- ous period of 6 months normally ceases to be investment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the fo rm of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian cu r rency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an autho- rized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market. Investment currency may norma l ly be retained as investment currency for a maxi- mum of 12 months, af ter which period any amount rema in ing must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign ex- change market.18 18 Investment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term government bonds (w i th up to six months to run before final ma tur i ty) or in six-month treasury bills or other forms of recognized short-term money-market paper (including certificates of deposit) without incur- ring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on resale of the paper. 471 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, arrange day-to-day bor- rowing of foreign currency, whether from U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign cur- rency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not pre- vented by the U.K. regulations from buying and selling sterling securities in the United Kingdom; they may also buy and sell, subject to certain conditions, Rhodesian securities on The Stock Exchange, but they must obtain the permission of the U.K. authorities to buy and sell other securities in the United Kingdom. Permission is required for all transfers of securities in the United Kingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either transferor or transferee, but most transfers are covered by a general authority. In most cases, U.K. companies may issue sterling securities (including bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U.K. authorities. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on The Stock Exchange against payment in foreign currency or in sterling from an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported from the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on The Stock Exchange for settlement in foreign currency or, in cer- tain circumstances, for settlement in sterling excluding the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the United King- dom other than on The Stock Exchange, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Non- residents other than Rhodesian residents may sell ster- ling securities in the United Kingdom for sterling which may be held on External Account or, alternatively, may be transferred abroad at official market rates. Most transactions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England; subject to certain conditions, however, autho- rized banks may approve applications by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia to buy and sell sterling securi- ties on The Stock Exchange. Except in respect of U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is required), warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital payments on matured securities regis- tered in the names of nonresidents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These warrants may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. 472 Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in their foreign currency business. They may also switch such deposits into ster- ling on a covered basis. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold In the United Kingdom gold bullion and gold coins are subject to control. Exemption under the Exchange Control Act, 1947 exists for: (1) the buying, selling, lending, and borrowing of gold coins minted in or before 1837; (2) the buying and selling of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the United Kingdom, if the seller is a person resident in the United Kingdom and is not selling on behalf of a person resident outside the United Kingdom; and ( 3) the borrowing and lend- ing of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the United Kingdom, if both the borrower and the lender are persons resident in the United Kingdom. Transac- tions both in gold coins not exempted above and in gold bullion may only be undertaken with permission. Per- mission is normally given for the use of gold bullion for genuine industrial and professional purposes. The sale of gold bullion for the manufac ture of gold coins, gold medals, etc., is prohibited unless specially authorized. Gold sovereigns are legal tender but do not circulate in the United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United Kingdom or which, having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. Gold coins minted after 1837 or gold medals, medal- lions, tablets, or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions and manufactured af ter 1837 are subject to individual import licensing, and such licenses are nor- mally given only to authorized dealers in gold. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. The export of gold bullion and of post-1837 gold coins to Gibraltar and the Republic of Ireland is not normally permitted except with the approval of the local control authorities. Authority has been given to autho- rized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin purchased by any non- Scheduled Territory resident in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign currency. A license is required from the Department of Trade for the export of gold (and other) jewelry, etc., containing diamonds. The export of gold in manufac- tured form over 100 years old and valued at £4,000 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution and over also requires a license from the Department of Trade. Manufactures of gold other than medals, etc., manu- factured after 1837 may be imported without quantita- tive restriction under Open General Import License f rom all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among ( 1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories, and (3) residents of the OSA who are sellers of new production. The U.K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of 1A of 1 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter into forward transactions in gold w i thout prior permis- sion from the Bank of England. Banks may also finance purchases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange and accept gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or Ex- ternal Account sterling to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Changes during 1975 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative import regulations were made in accordance with EEC decisions and directives; most of these related to textiles, beef and veal, or electronic calculators. January 1. The third reduction of 20 per cent in import duties on goods originating in EEC member countries took place. January 1. Existing restraint arrangements for the import of all textiles from quota-controlled sources were continued for the first quarter of 1975. January 1. The licensing arrangements for the first half of 1975 for imports of cotton yarn originating in, or consigned to the United Kingdom from, Turkey or Greece came into effect; on July 1 they were extended to the end of the year. January 1. The restrictions on exports of ferrous scrap and of reusable and rerollable steel products to member states of the EEC were removed. Exports to other destinations remained subject to individual licensing. January 15. The Bank of England reminded banks that specific exchange control permission continued to be required for any sale of sterling securities which would result in a nonresident acquiring directly or indi- rectly 10 per cent or more of the voting rights in a U.K. company or increasing an existing holding beyond that level. January 21. Licenses ceased to be required for ex- ports of coal, coke, and solid fuels. January 22. Restrictions were imposed on the refi- nancing in sterling of bills for trade originally contracted and financed in foreign currency, except for trade to or from the Scheduled Territories. The rules concerning UNITED KINGDOM guarantees in favor of residents of the OSA were also tightened. January 29. Authorized banks were empowered to approve certain specified payments in respect of resi- dents of Rhodesia which had previously required appli- cation to the Bank of England, as follows: (1) from Rhodesian Accounts and Suspense Accounts in respect of expenses incurred outside the United Kingdom by residents of Rhodesia, e.g., educational and medical expenses, economy class air fares from the United Kingdom to Rhodesia, and living expenses of persons aged 65 or over; and (2) from Suspense Accounts to meet expenditure in the United Kingdom incurred by residents of Rhodesia in respect of the maintenance of property, educational, medical, or living expenses, insurance premiums, and charitable donations or gifts to residents of the Un i ted Kingdom. Authorized banks were also permitted to redesignate the accounts of persons who leave Rhodesia to take up residence in the Scheduled Territories. January 29. Authorized banks could approve appli- cations by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia to buy and sell on The Stock Exchange sterling securities issued in the United Kingdom, subject in the case of purchases to the securities being registered in the name of a U.K. authorized depositary or their U.K. nominees and the certificate of title being held by the U.K. authorized depositary concerned, and in the case of sales, subject to the proceeds being withheld in suspense. January 31. A new Industry Bill was published. Among other things, it would empower the Government to prevent the transfer of control in a U.K. manufactur- ing company to nonresidents if it considered that this would be contrary to U.K. interests. The bill received Royal Assent on November 12 and came into force on November 20. February 20. It was announced that the ECGD would be enabled to offer exporters of capital goods under fixed-price contracts partial insurance against cost esca- lation. Cover would be available for contracts with an ind iv idual value of £2 million or more and involving a manu fac tu r ing period of two years or more. The scheme, which would not be available for exports to member states of the EEC, came into operation imme- diately. In addition, exporters would be aided in obtain- ing performance bonds where these were required by overseas buyers. March 4. Exports of petroleum and petroleum prod- ucts ceased to require individual licenses. March 11. Agreement was reached on a revision of the terms on which the United Kingdom had acceded to the EEC. April 3. New and expanded surveillance arrange- ments for textile commodities came into effect. They covered most yarns and fabrics of all main textile fibers and the basic man-made fibers, consigned from all coun- tries other than member states of the EEC, which were 473 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM not already subject to licensing; individual import li- censes were issued without restriction as to quantity but subject to the provision of certain informa t ion. Existing surveillance arrangements were superseded but licensing arrangements for textiles subject to restraint were not affected. April 15. Value-added tax on many goods, whether locally produced or imported, was increased to 25 per cent. April 15-16. Gold coins, gold medals, etc., were brought under stricter control by a combination of tighter exchange controls and individual import licens- ing, as follows: (1) The Exchange Control (Gold Coins Exemption) Order, 1971 was revoked and was replaced by the Ex- change Control (Gold Coins Exemption) Order, 1975. The latter exempted all gold coins f rom the provisions of Sections 2 and 3 of the Exchange Control Act, 1947 but exempted f rom the provisions of Section 1 of the Act only the following: (a) the buying, selling, lending, and borrowing of gold coins minted in or before 1837; (b) the buying and selling of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the United Kingdom, if the seller is a person resident in the United Kingdom and is not selling on behalf of a person resident outside the United Kingdom; and (c) the borrowing and lending of any gold coins minted after 1837 and held in the United Kingdom, if both the borrower and the lender are per- sons resident in the United Kingdom. For purposes of this Order, the United Kingdom was defined as includ- ing the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands. (2) Gold coins minted after 1837 and gold medals, medallions, tablets, or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing inscriptions and manufactured after 1837 could no longer be imported into the United Kingdom under the Open General Import License. Applications from authorized dealers in gold for a license to import gold coins minted after 1837 and gold medals, etc., manu- factured after 1837 would normally be granted subject to certain conditions, but licenses would not otherwise be issued. (3) Restrictions were placed on sales of gold bullion and gold coins by authorized dealers in gold. These restrictions prohibited the sale, unless permitted by the Bank of England, of gold bullion for manufac tur ing gold coins, gold medals, and the like, and prevented gold coins minted after 1837 that might be purchased in the fu tu re by authorized dealers f rom persons resident out- side the United Kingdom, from being resold to U.K. residents, including other authorized dealers in gold. Authorized dealers in gold could sell post-1837 gold coins to residents of the United Kingdom only if such coins were held for the account of, or had been pur- chased from, residents of the United Kingdom (includ- ing other authorized dealers in go ld), or were from their own existing stocks acquired prior to April 16. In the case of sales of gold bullion and post-1837 gold 474 coins to residents of the Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom, authorized dealers required in addition the specific permission of the Bank of Eng- land; applications for permission normally had to be supported by evidence of approval by the local exchange control authorities. Sales of post-1837 gold coins by authorized dealers in gold to persons resident outside the Scheduled Territories were not restricted. In addition, the Bank of England ceased its sales of gold sovereigns to residents of the United Kingdom, with the exception of sales to authorized gold dealers for export outside the Scheduled Territories. The ma in effect of these measures was that residents of the United Kingdom (other than authorized dealers in gold possessing a license) could no longer import gold coins minted after 1837 or gold medals, etc., manu- factured after 1837; that any post-1837 gold coins that authorized dealers in gold might in the fu tu re purchase from persons resident outside the United Kingdom could not be resold to residents of the United Kingdom; and that the export of gold bullion and of post-1837 gold coins to Gibraltar and the Republic of Ireland was not normally permitted except with the approval of the local control authorities. The holding, buying and selling, and borrowing and lending (between residents of the United K ingdom) of post-1837 gold coins and gold medals, etc., that were already in the United Kingdom remained unrestricted. Control over the export of all gold coins, irrespective of the year of issue, and of gold medals, etc., was not changed, but exports to the Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom were brought under closer control. A short-lived premium over over- seas quotations arose for gold coins already in the United Kingdom. April 15. Following a change in administrative practice, the Bank of England henceforth was prepared to authorize the payment of interest on external sterling loans when the rate was not fixed for the term of the loan. For such loans from nonresidents required to be ma in ta ined for a m in imum period of two years, the interest rate could be either: ( 1) fixed for the term of the loan at not more than l/z of 1 per cent above the interbank lending rate in the Euro-dollar market appro- priate to the minimum repayment term specified by the Bank of England; or (2) variable, at not more than l/2 of 1 per cent above the interbank lending rate in the Euro-dollar market appropriate to the period up to the first date set in the loan agreement for rollover or review of interest, and thereafter varying on the same basis for each subsequent similar period.
