The conver t ib i l i ty of the U.S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets has been suspended and exchange rates are not m a in t a in ed w i th in any stipulated margin f rom parity. There are no restric- tions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions invo lv ing the au thor i- ties or nationals of Cambodia, the People's Republic of China, Cuba, Nor th Korea, No r th V ie t -Nam, and South Viet-Nam, and those imposed pu r suant to UN Security Council Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 on any transfer of f u n ds to, or on behalf of, or for the benefit of, any person in Rhodesia ( in c lud ing the authorities th e r eo f ), unless the f u n ds are in payment of imports of strategic and critical ma te r ia ls of Rho- desian origin.1 The United States fo rma l ly notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Department of the Treasury deals w i th license applications involving financial or commerc ial trans- actions directly or ind irec t ly w i th Cambod ia, Cuba, Nor th Korea, Rhodesia, Nor th V ie t -Nam, and South Viet-Nam or the ir nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, and the Rhodes ian Sanctions Regulations. It also deals with license app l ica t ions involving the blocked accounts in the Un i ted States of the above-named countries, as well as the People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, Es ton ia, the German Democratic Republic, Latvia, and L i thuan ia. The Bureau of Customs of the Department of the Treasury administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are adm in- istered by the Depar tment of Ag r icu l tu re through the issuance of import licenses. A global import quota on sugar is set by the Depar tment of Ag r icu l tu re. Allocations and licenses for imports of crude petro- leum and petroleum products are issued by the Depart- ment of the Interior. For items sub ject to export control other than crude petroleum and petroleum products the Depar tment of Commerce is, in general, the responsible authority. Imports and Import Payments The impo r ta t ion of merchandise, as well as payment therefor, is prohibited under Treasury regulations, unless licensed, if such merchandise is of Cambod ian, Cuban, Nor th Korean, Nor th Vietnamese, or South V ie tnamese origin, or, unless the goods are strategic and critical ma ter ia ls, if the merchand ise is of Rho- desian or ig in. Impo rt quotas are in effect for ( 1) cotton, certain cotton waste and products, most da i ry products, and peanu ts, pursuant to Section 22 of the Agricultural Ad ju s tm ent Act; and (2) cer ta in f ish and certain potatoes. A global import quota is in effect for sugar. With the exception of the import quotas for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, bu t ter oil, and sugar, the above quo tas are on a coun try-of-produc t ion basis.2 Impo r ts of crude oil and oil products are subject to an import en t i t lement program and to impo rt license fees. The Un i ted States is a pa r ty to the GATT Arrange- ment Rega rd ing I n t e r n a t i o n al Trade in Textiles and to 18 bilateral textile agreements negotiated under the A r rangemen t 's prov is ions. These agreements set the levels for the partners' exports of textiles and apparel to the Un i ted States. Imports of f resh, f rozen, or chilled beef, veal, and mu t ton are governed by 12 b i la teral agreemen ts as an alternative to the impos i t ion of manda to ry quo tas und er the Meat Import Act of 1964. Other paymen ts and transfers abroad may be made freely, with certain exceptions wh ich are perm i t ted on ly under license; these exceptions are paymen ts to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, No r th V ie t-Nam, and South V ie t-Nam. Exports of designated strategic materials and equipment to all other countries (except Canada) also require individual validated licenses. For many commodities, when exported to countries other than CMEA members, certain Arab states, Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, North Viet-Nam, or South Viet-Nam, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a full year's shipments. The licensing requirements applicable to Poland, Romania, and Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those appli- cable to other Eastern European countries. Exports of certain commodities to all destinations have from time to time been subject to controls for reasons of short supply; as at the end of 1975 such controls were appli- cable to crude petroleum and petroleum fuels. Export plans for wheat, corn, sorghum, soybeans, and soybean oil are subject to reporting requirements in order to avoid the need for controls. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are pro- hibited to and from Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rhodesia, North Viet-Nam, and South Viet-Nam. Individuals leaving or entering the country with more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, travelers checks, money orders, and /or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital 8 Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. In addition, inward and outward direct or portfolio invest- ment are generally free of any other form of approval requirements, although in certain instances compliance with specified banking regulations may be required; with a few exceptions for national security reasons or to protect vital national interests, the United States does not impose special restrictions on inward investment. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain transactions with or involving Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rhodesia, North Viet-Nam, and South Viet-Nam, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the country (as well as corresponding reporting requirements for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the mails). Federal Reserve member banks must meet reserve requirements of 4 per cent on net Euro-dollar borrow- 3 Early in 1975 it was announced that the Administration had con- ducted a thorough review of U.S. policy toward inward investment and concluded that no change in the open-door policy was necessary or warranted. 478 ings from their foreign branches; foreign-owned non- member banks and agencies and branches of foreign banks voluntarily maintain reserves against increases in their net borrowings f rom foreign sources above their May 1973 levels, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board. The foreign currency positions of banks, whether overall or with respect to individual currencies, are not subject to limitation. Gold U.S. citizens or residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm, at home or abroad, except for gold transactions involving Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rhodesia, North Viet-Nam, or South Viet-Nam. Commercial banks may deal in gold bullion and gold coins, with the same exceptions. U.S. gold coins remain legal tender at their face value. Treasury licensing for importers, exporters, producers, refiners, and processors of gold is no longer required. Producers of gold may sell their output in the free market. Gold may be freely imported, except from the countries mentioned above and except counterfeit gold coins. Commercial imports of gold jewelry are free of quantitative restriction but are subject to import duty at a rate of approximately 12 per cent. There is no duty on gold ore, bullion, or coins. All forms of gold must be declared at the point of entry into the United States. Changes during 1975 January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1974 of the U.S. Sugar Act (P.L. 92-138), imports of sugar ceased to be subject to country quotas. The Presi- dent retained the authority to establish a global quota subject to a reduced rate of duty. A global quota of 7 million short tons was set for 1975 (as announced on November 17, 1974); the tariff rate was not changed and remained at the lowest level provided for under the ta r i ff schedules. January 1. Quantitative restrictions on imports of sweetened chocolate, candy, and confectionery were abolished. January 1. The suspension of quota restrictions on meat imports, which had expired on December 31, 1974, was extended to December 31, 1975. January 1. The export controls over ferrous scrap were discontinued. January 3. The U.S. Trade Act of 1974 (P.L. 93-618) came into force. It granted the Administration author- ity to enter into broad-scale international trade nego- tiations, while offering safeguards to domestic indus- tries and workers hurt by import competition. The ma in provisions gave the President authority ( 1) to negotiate on tariff and nontariff barriers to trade during a five-year period; (2) to modify the levels of tariffs and quotas in order to deal with U.S. balance of pay- ments deficits or surpluses for up to 150 days without Congressional approval; ( 3) to grant emergency import ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution relief from increased imports under the "escape clause," as well as adjustment assistance, on the basis of liberal- ized criteria and procedures; (4) to provide speedier relief from "unfair and unjustifiable" trade practices; (5) subject to certain provisos, to extend most-favored- nation status to communist countries; and (6) to grant generalized tariff preferences to developing countries. The Trade Act also gave Congress the power to review and reject trade agreements (nontariff agreements). The U.S. Tariff Commission was renamed as the U.S. International Trade Commission. The Trade Act amended the An t idump ing Act and the Countervailing Duty Law and reinforced the standards for the administration by the Executive of Countervailing Duty Laws as they apply to the An t i -, dumping Act. In view of the newly imposed statutory time limitations, a simultaneous investigation of a back- log of complaints was undertaken. With respect to findings of injury to domestic industries, the criterion under the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 had been whether imports were in ma jor part the result of trade agreement concessions and were the ma jor cause of in ju ry; under the new Trade Act, no link to concessions is required and increased imports only have to be a subs tan t ial cause of serious injury. With respect to the generalized ta r i ff preferences (GSP), certain country exclusions were mandatory. Thus, the preferences could not be granted to any developing country which granted reverse preferences to any developed country which had a s ign if icant adverse effect on U.S. commerce, unless the developing country provided satisfactory assurances that it would eliminate the reverse preferences or their adverse effects on U.S. commerce before January 1, 1976. January 4. The President signed P.L. 93-646, which extended the Export-Import Bank's operating authority through June 30, 1978 and increased its commitment authority to US$25 billion. The law also modified the Bank's operational requirements and restricted its authority to finance sales to the U.S.S.R. January 6. The U.S. Government offered for sale, at public auction, approximately 2 million ounces of gold in 400-ounce bars. Bids from foreign governments or central banks were not admitted. Bids for 954,800 ounces were received, of which bids for 754,000 ounces were accepted at prices of US$153 an ounce or higher; the average price was US$165.67. January 14. The U.S.S.R. informed the United States that under the terms of the U.S. Trade Act of 1974 it could not bring the trade agreement of October 18, 1972 into force. February 1. By virtue of an Executive Order of January 23, a supplemental import fee of US$1 a barrel was introduced on imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products. February 13. A technical cooperation agreement was signed with Saudi Arabia. UNITED STATES February 24. Certain reporting requirements for non- bank firms were published and came into effect for reporting on March 31. They related to foreign cur- rency transactions by large U.S. enterprises and their foreign branches and majority-owned foreign subsidi- aries and were required by Title II of P.L. 93-110 (the Act amending the Par Value Modification Act) to provide additional data on the nature and source of flows of mobile capital. Banks and banking institu- tions in the United States had since November 30, 1974 been required to report weekly their positions, spot and forward, in specified foreign currencies, and to report mon th ly their assets, liabilities, and positions in speci- fied currencies. Nonbanking firms (including the U.S. branches and subsidiaries of foreign nonbanking firms) now were required to report to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, monthly and /or quarterly, their assets, liabilities, and spot and forward positions in the same currencies, including those of their foreign branches and majority-owned foreign partnerships and subsidiaries. The currencies to be reported were Belgian francs (commercial and financial), Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs (for foreign branches, partnerships, and subsidiaries also the positions in U.S. dollars). February 24. Responding to allegations that some national banks might have been offered large deposits and loans by some foreign investors subject to racial and religious conditions, the Comptroller of the Cur- rency notified national banks that such discrimina- tion was incompatible with the public service function of U.S. bank ing institutions and that the Comptroller's office would assure the adherence of national banks to a nond iscr im ina tory policy. February 27. The Export-Import Bank announced a liberalization of its lending and guarantee policies. The Bank was prepared to lend as much as 55 per cent of the export price, to guarantee as much as 85 per cent of an export transaction, and to go up to 90 per cent in combination. March. The Government announced that it would expect any foreign government contemplating a major direct investment in the United States to seek advance consultations w i th the U.S. Government. March 4. An economic cooperation agreement with Iran was signed. It provided for a trade target of about US$15 billion of reciprocal non-oil trade over the next five years. March 4. The Federal Reserve Board resubmitted to Congress proposed legislation to establish a national policy on foreign banks operating in the United States and a system of Federal regulation and supervision of those operations. The underlying principle was na- tional treatment or mutual nondiscrimination. Among other things, Federal Reserve membership of branches, agencies, and subsidiaries of a foreign bank would be 479 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES required where the parent foreign bank had world-wide bank assets greater than US$500 million. The proposed legislation would have empowered the Comptroller of the Currency to license new national branches of for- eign banks. It provided that the establishment in the United States of new bank ing offices of foreign banks would have to be approved by the Secretary of the Treasury. (By the end of 1975 this proposed legisla- tion had not been enacted.) March 6. The approval requirement under the voluntary system of October 7, 1974 for big export orders for grain and soybeans was discontinued; report- ing requirements were maintained. Under this system (applicable to wheat, corn, sorghum, soybeans, and soybean flour), exporters had initially been expected to obtain advance approval from the Department of Agriculture when (1) a sales contract would involve shipment of more than 50,000 tons of a particular commodity on a single day to any one country of destination, or cause cumulative sales of any commodity to a single destination to exceed 100,000 tons in a week; and (2) any change f rom export destinations previ- ously reported under existing contracts would affect more than 30,000 tons of one commod i ty on a single day or more than 100,000 tons in a week. These amounts had been doubled in February 1975. March 24. The President initiated the process for the implementation of the GSP scheme by submitting to the U.S. International Trade Commission for its consideration a list of more than 3,000 proposed eligible articles. The President also issued an Executive Order containing two lists of proposed beneficiary coun- tries (127 countries and territories designated as eligible and 24 countries not eligible for the present but being considered for possible designation). April 17. Trading in gold and silver commodity fu tures and transactions involving margin and leverage contracts in gold or silver bullion and bulk gold or silver coins became subject to the jurisdiction and regulation of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, an independent Federal agency established by P.L. 93-463 of October 23, 1974. May 7. By Executive Order No. 11858, the President established an interagency Committee on Foreign Invest- ment in the United States to monitor the impact of foreign investment (both direct and portfolio) in the United States, review major individual investments, and consider proposed new legislation or federal regula- tions. The Committee was to serve as a focal point w i th in the executive branch for ensuring that foreign investments in the United States were consistent with U.S. national interests. At the same time, in imple- mentation of another section of the Executive Order, an Office of Foreign Investment in the United States was created in the Department of Commerce to gather, consolidate, and analyze informa t ion collected by the various agencies of the U.S. Government on foreign investment flows into the United States, and to submit reports and recommendations to the Committee. May 7. New reporting requirements on foreign direct investments in the United States were adopted by the Department of Commerce, with effect from January 1, 1975. A foreign investor whose interest was 10 per cent or more of the ownership of a U.S. com- pany and whose investment was US$2 million or more was required to submit quarterly reports to the Depart- ment of Commerce as part of the latter's regular gather- ing of balance of payments informa t ion. Previously, the threshold figure for ownership interest was 25 per cent. May 16. Cambodia and South Viet-Nam were added to country group Z under the export control regula- tions; thus, the general export embargo policy was applicable, except for human i tar ian cases. May 22. The Federal Reserve Board issued an inter- pretation of its regulation M defining foreign institu- tions that are considered to be foreign banks. May 27. The Department of the Treasury, reiterat- ing the U.S. interest in ma in ta in ing a continuing volume of investment flows to the country, issued a summary of the laws and regulations applicable to foreign invest- ment in the United States. It stressed tha t, with a few exceptions to assure national security and to protect vital national interests, the United States did not impose special restrictions on foreign investment in the country. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES the EEC did not constitute subsidies in violation of U.S. laws. October 20. A five-year agreement on grain sales was signed with the U.S.S.R. The agreement committed the U.S.S.R. to purchase a minimum of 6 million metric tons of wheat and corn in any crop year beginning October 1, 1976; it permitted the U.S.S.R. to purchase an additional 2 million tons annually without govern- ment-to-government consultation; and it obliged the U.S. Government to facilitate U.S.S.R. purchases and not to exercise its authority to control shipments of these amounts unless the total U.S. grain supply (excluding rice) fell below 225 million metric tons (in which event the United States could reduce the amount which the U.S.S.R. might purchase to less than 6 million tons). The agreement also provided for consultation in advance of purchases in excess of 8 million tons of wheat and corn in any one crop year. An assurance was obtained that additional U.S.S.R. purchases of grain in the cur- rent crop year would not be in a volume which could disrupt the U.S. marke t; the United States noted that in its view this volume was 7 million metric tons. The agreement would come into force on October 1, 1976. October 20. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Upper Volta has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02. The BCEAO levies a commission of Mo of 1 per mill on transfers f rom coun- tries outside the West Afr ican Monetary Union and a commission of 2.50 per m i ll on transfers to countries outside the Union.2 Exchange rates for fore ign curren- cies are based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency con- cerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a com- mission on transfers to all countries outside the West Afr ican Monetary Union, part of which must be sur- rendered to the Treasury. With the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange control measures do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Depar tmen ts and Terri- tories, except the French Territory of the A fa rs and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Ben in, Cameroon, the Central A f r ican Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Ma l i, Niger, Senegal, and Togo). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta itself, are considered foreign countries, and in principle financial relations only w i th foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Accounts in the M in is try of Finance, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertis- ing, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta, inward direct investment and all outward invest- ment, and the soliciting of funds in Upper Volta for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control (except for imports and exports of gold, forward exchange cover, and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000) has been delegated to the BCEAO and, w i th in limits specified in the exchange control regulations, to authorized inter- 1 The CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common cu r rency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 Transfers between member countries of the Union are exempt. The commissions are not levied on transfers ordered by public treasur- ies and similar institutions or by the Postal Adm in is tra t ion of Upper Volta. 484 mediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, financial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public, any informa t ion necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange trans- actions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Administration, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce at the Ministry of Com- merce, Industrial Development, and Mines. Import cer- tificates for liberalized commodities and export attesta- tions (when settled in foreign currencies) are made out by the impor ter or exporter himself and are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the cur- rency of any Operations Account country. Certain set- tlements with Ghana are made through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Por- tugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account with the French Treasury is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports or ig ina t ing in or shipped from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Imports f rom countries in the French Franc Area may in prin- ciple be made freely, although exceptionally, special regulations may be issued. Imports shipped from and originating in EEC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import certificate (a t tes ta t ion ). Most imports f rom other countries are subject to licensing. Imports from non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are admitted in accord- ance with an annual import program, determined each ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this pro- gram, global quotas are established up to which import licenses are issued for specified commodities. Impor ts f rom Ghana are subject to special regulations. All import transac t ions re la t ing to fore ign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. The import licenses or import certificates (a t tes ta t ions) en t i t le impor ters to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documen tary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to France (as def ined above ), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are pe rm i t ted f ree ly; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approva l, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the au thor ized banks. A ll paymen ts to Por tuga l, Rhodes ia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Authorized banks and the Postal Adm in i s t r a t ion have been empowered to m ake paymen ts to fo re ign countries free ly, on beha lf of resi- dents, up to CFAF 50,000 a transfer. Payments for invisibles related to trade are pe rm i t ted free ly when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not requ ire au thor iza t ion. Transfers of income acc ru ing to nonresidents in the fo rm of p ro f i ts, d iv idends, and royal- ties are also permitted. Residents trave l ing for tou r i sm to coun tr ies other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the other Opera t ions Account coun tr ies of the French F ranc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equiva- lent to CFAF 175,000 a person a t r ip (CFAF 87,500 for ch i ldren under t en) for any number of trips a yea r; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remain- ing af ter re tu rn to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for t ravel abroad for business pur- poses is the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, w i th a max imum of CFAF 400,000 a t r ip. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a maxi- mum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by any ins t i tu te of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury. Resident travelers to other coun tr ies of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO bankno tes, but if going to a coun t ry that is not a mem- ber of the West A f r ican Mone tary Un ion, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out, in addition to any means of payment established in their name abroad, fore ign banknotes up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 or, subject to the submission of appro- priate documents (if it was e i ther declared upon entry or acquired by drawing on a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, e t c . ), any larger amoun t. They UPPER VOLTA may also take out any foreign means of payment other than bankno tes acquired in Upper Volta by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency, again subject to submission of documentation. Finally, they make take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by Operations Account countries. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agri- cultural products require a license f rom the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Exports to all other coun- tries are permitted freely but some also require a license. Cer ta in commod i t ies can be exported in special c ircums tances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regu la t ions. Export proceeds received in curren- cies other than those of France or another Operations Account c o u n t ry mu st be surrendered within two months of the da te on wh ich the payment falls due (the due date s t ipu la ted in the commercial contract, which must not, in principle, be later than 180 days after arrival of the goods at their des t ina t ion). All export transactions re la t ing to fo r e ign countries must be domiciled with an au thor ized bank when the ir value exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the exporter m u st sign a foreign exchange commit- m ent and subm it a customs ce r t i f ica t ion. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom t ran sac t ions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be re ta ined. All amoun ts due f rom residents of other coun- tries in respect of services and all income earned in those coun tr ies f rom foreign assets must be collected and surrendered w i th in two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings must not be received in or f r om Portugal, Rhodes ia, or South A f r ica. Resident and non re s ident travelers may b r ing in any amount of bank- notes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury, as well as any amount of fo re ign bankno tes and coins (except gold co ins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Res ident travelers mu st declare to the customs any for- eign means of payment in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they b r ing in and w i th in eight days af ter return sur- render these to an authorized bank. Capital All cap i tal movements between Upper Volta and Por tuga l, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Capital movemen ts between Upper Volta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange con tro l; capital transfers to all other countries 485 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are ma in ta ined over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver- tising, or offering for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta; these controls relate to the transactions them- selves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those over foreign securities in Upper Volta, the control measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, the other member coun- tries of the West Afr ican Monetary Un ion, and those other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are ma in ta ined also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institu- tions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate bu i ld ing opera- tions abroad; these special controls do apply also to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Upper Volta require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.3 Foreign direct investments in Upper Vo l ta4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months f rom receipt of the declaration dur ing which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The total or partial liquidation of either type of investment also is subject to prior declaration to the Minister. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enter- prise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are Quoted on a stock exchange. Since October 30, 1975, foreign firms operating in Upper Volta are obliged to "Voltaize" their capital within two years, up to at least 51 per cent in vital or priority sectors and up to at least 35 per cent in all others. The sale to residents of Upper Volta of securities of foreign companies operating in Upper Volta requires prior authorization by the Ministry of Finance, who establishes the sales value. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Upper Volta requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authori- 3 Including those made through the in termed iary of fore ign com- panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Upper Volta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of com- panies in Upper Volta. 4 Including those made by companies in Upper Volta that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper Volta of foreign companies. 486 zation, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper Volta Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Volta has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents f rom nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports f rom Upper Volta, or by international trad- ing houses previously approved by the Minister of Finance to finance international merchanting transac- tions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 100 million for any one borrower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are immediately surrendered by the sale of foreign currency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was sub- ject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the BCEAO, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Ordinance No. 70-0747 PRES/PL-TP of Decem- ber 31,1970, the Investment Code, provides preferential treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Two preferential categories (A and B) are established, in accordance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Cate- gory B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Gov- ernmen t, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Law No. 25761/AN set up an assistance fund for new industries. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any fo rm in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold f rom or to any other country require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance. Exempt from this requirement are ( 1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a com- bined weight of 500 grams. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System Prescription of Currency No par value or central rate has been established for Uruguay's currency, the New Peso. Exchange transac- tions take place in a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and a financial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports other than books (except when the exchange is purchased more than 180 days after the due date), exports other than books, freight and insurance on imports, and most pub- lic sector exchange operations are settled in the com- mercial market, where the exchange rates are fixed (although adjusted from time to t im e ), while all other exchange transactions take place in the financial mar- ket, in which the exchange rate fluctuates freely. On December 31, 1975 the buy ing and selling rates in the commercial market were NUr$2.70 and NUr$2.73 per US$1, respectively, and those in the financial market were NUr$2.77 and NUr$2.78 per US$1, respectively. The Central Bank of Uruguay supplies foreign exchange to the commercial banks for imports, and the proceeds f rom exports (valued at the officially assessed price or aforo where applicable) must be surrendered to the monetary authorities.1 Commercial banks operate on their own account in the financial market, but are not permitted to exceed their combined foreign currency positions in both markets as specified below, and must surrender any excess exchange holdings to the Central Bank, the relevant limit is the equivalent in U.S. dollars of the sum of the net U.S. dollar asset position on February 29, 1972 and the position in Argentine pesos and Brazilian cruzeiros on September 20, 1974. For- ward exchange transactions are prohibited. Various additional effective exchange rates arise f rom the following: (1) the application of exchange taxes (detracciones or retenciones) to the proceeds from cer- tain traditional exports; (2) the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates (reintegros) on proceeds from certain nontraditional exports; (3) a 40 per cent tax on certain profit remittances; and (4) the sale in the financial market of the excess of the actual f.o.b. value over the aforo or m in imum surrender value (sobreaforos) on wool exports. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through author- ized banks, banking houses, and the monetary authori- ties. The Bank of the Republic collects import sur- charges, export taxes, and consular charges and accepts export and import registrations. i rThe Central Bank was established on March 1, 1967, but some operations are still being carried out on its behalf by the Bank of the Republic. The term "monetary authorities" as used here refers to both banks taken together. 488 Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system; these coun- tries are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, and Venezuela. There is a separate arrangement for trade in specified goods with Argentina. Settlements with other countries in the commercial market are made in U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Most transactions in the financial market take place in U.S. dollars, Argentine pesos, or Brazilian cruzeiros. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, w i th in which period goods must be cleared through customs. An import declaration (denuncia) must be submitted to the Bank of the Repub- lic before the goods are unloaded. Imports of fully assembled automobiles are temporarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to an import surcharge (recargo). Goods are classified into nine categories; goods in one category bear no surcharge; goods in other categories are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 55, 75, 120, 150, or 200 per cent, payable at the time of regis- tration. Imports from LAFTA countries receive a fu ll or par t ial exemp t ion f rom these surcharges. Most imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required, and the above-mentioned import sur- charge, to an additional import duty of 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable upon customs clearance, and to another import surcharge (recargo tributario a la impor- tation) of 7 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable two days a f ter import registration. All imports are subject to consular charges payable in new pesos and calculated on the f.o.b. value at the commercial market rate. These charges are 3.5 per cent for private sector imports of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and tetra- ethyl lead; 0.25 per cent for imports of the same com- modities by the Administration Nacional de Combusti- bles, Alcohol y Portland (ANCAP) —the state oil, cement, and alcohol enterprise; 4 per cent for all other private sector imports; and 0.5 per cent for other imports by ANCAP. Import taxes and surcharges in most cases are calcu- lated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) established for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calculation is ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution based on an officially assessed price, which usually is expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram. Importers may purchase foreign exchange in the com- mercial market at any time from 5 days before to 180 days after the payment to the supplier falls due. Pur- chases at any later date must be made in the financial market. Purchases with an exchange rate guarantee (ventas futuras) require a peso deposit at the time of application; the exchange is provided on the due date and the applicable exchange rate is the commercial mar- ket rate on the date of application for the guarantee. The facility is available only for import transactions that are financed-abroad, and capital goods are ineligible. Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports are settled in the commercial market. Payments for all other invisibles may be made freely through the financial market. Cer- tain prof it remittances are subject to a tax of 40 per cent. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal traditional exports, except beef, are subject to taxes (detracciones or reten- ciones), which are withheld by the monetary authorities on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per un it of export commodity (as a percentage of the f.o.b. value for wool), but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso pro- ceeds of the export, except that for exports of wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value. The exchange proceeds of traditional exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in full to the monetary authorities, upon receipt. At the end of 1975 the prescribed maximum surrender period was generally not later than 30 days after shipment has been authorized (180 days for combed wool). Different periods were applicable to nontraditional exports and to traditional exports financed abroad. For certain exports, including wool and hides, mini- mum f.o.b. values (m in imum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram have been estab- lished for various grades and types. There are special arrangements for the advance surrender (anticipos and preanticipos) of the exchange proceeds from exports that are financed in foreign currency, either abroad or by domestic banks. Surrender before the export is registered (preanticipos) is permitted for wool, meat, cereals, oilseeds, and nontraditional exports; surrender after registration (anticipos) is limited to some tradi- tional exports. Subsidies in the form of tax credit cer- tificates (reintegros) of up to 50 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain nontraditional exports (80 per cent for new exports). Exports of cattle on the hoof (except when specially authorized), specified minerals (including iron, copper, URUGUAY zinc, aluminum, and nickel), and protein concentrates used for animal feed are prohibited. Exports of sheep- skin, wheat, sorghum, corn, and sunflower seeds are prohibited when production falls short of domestic con- sumption requirements. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds from invisibles may be held, utilized, or sold to the banking system. Department stores, hotels, and other tourist establishments are authorized to accept foreign currencies at the rate prevailing in the financial market; the proceeds must be sold through the banking system. There are no limitations on the import of for- eign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward and outward capital transfers by either resi- dents or nonresidents may be made freely through the financial market, with the exception of certain inward and outward transfers relating to investments registered under the Foreign Investment Law. However, certain borrowing abroad is controlled, and the amortization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under the Foreign Investment Law cannot normally be trans- ferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Exchange rate guarantees are in effect available on certain inward capital trans- fers, whether made by residents or nonresidents; these consist of swaps with the Central Bank. New foreign investments in Uruguay, as well as certain existing for- eign investments, are governed by a Foreign Investment Law (Law No. 14179 of March 28, 1974, as amended by Law No. 14244 of July 26, 1974, Decree No. 8087 974 of October 10, 1974, and Law No. 14371 of April 29, 1975). Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the transactions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, however, must either be financed from the buyer's own exchange holdings or settled through the financial market. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial market. Changes during 1975 During the period January-April 1975 the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were gradually depreciated from Ur$ 1,640 and Ur$ 1,656 to Ur$2,300 and Ur$2,330 per US$1; there were no changes in the commercial rate from April through September 28; from September 29 through December 31, the buying and selling rates were gradually depreciated from NUr$2.30 and NUr$2.33 to NUr$2.70 and NUr$2.73 per US$1. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bolivar. Exchange transac t ions take place at the following rates.1 The Central Bank of Venezuela purchases export proceeds f rom petroleum and iron ore at Bs 4.20 per US$1. Any proceeds f rom exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Central Bank must be purchased by it at Bs 4.285 per US$1. The Central Bank sells exchange to the Govern- ment and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.285 per US$1 2 and to the state agency, Petroleos de Venezuela (Petroven) a tB s. 4.20 per US$1. The commercial banks purchase fore ign exchange f rom the public at rates close to Bs 4.28 per US$1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.30 per US$1 for all transactions; foreign banks may only sell foreign exchange th at has not been obtained f rom the Central Bank. Some fore ign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buy ing and selling rates u sua l ly are slightly below Bs 4.30 per US$1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. The Central Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U.S. dollars at Bs 4.27 and resells at Bs 4.30 after 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the M in is try of Development or the M in is try of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the com- modity; for certain agr icu l tural products, the prior approval of the Agr icu l tural Ma rke t ing Corporation must be obtained before applications for export licenses are submitted to these ministries. Under the terms of an agreement between the Government and the Central Bank, the latter has the responsibility of ensuring that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human con- sumption and to certain exports of coffee and cacao. The Superintendency of Foreign Investments (SIEX) is charged with the supervision over foreign investment in Venezuela, over contracts for the importation of foreign technology and the use of foreign patents and trade- marks, and over borrowing abroad. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requ i remen ts are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argen t ina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, the Dom in ican Republic, 1 The exchange rates given (except those for the Central Bank's swap transactions) are those applicable to sight d ra f ts on New York. 2 The Central Bank does not sell fo re ign exchange to the public but does sell m inor amoun ts to its s ta ff and certain gove rnment off ic ia ls, at the rate of Bs 4.30 per US$1, for travel expenses. Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts ma in ta ined with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the coun- tries concerned. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fully assembled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, citrus fru i t, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigar- ette paper, na tural pearls, and matches. In addition, many other commodities require import licenses; quan t i ta t ive restrictions applicable irrespective of origin are ma in ta ined on some of these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South A f r ica. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quan t i ty import (contingentamiento). All other commodities are free from import licensing. Wheat for human consumption is imported by the Ag r icu l tu ral Ma rke t ing Corporation and receives a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f.o.b. value, calculated at Bs 4.30 per US$1. Imports f rom Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made f rom commercial banks or exchange houses. Transfers of profits and dividends are limited in prin- ciple to 14 per cent per annum of registered foreign capital. Resident and nonresident travelers must on depar ture pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, foreign tour- ists, Venezuelan and foreign diplomats, and personnel of in te rna t ional organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodi- ties. Export licenses for most commodities are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the Ministry of Agr icu l ture and Livestock. Exports of products con- ta in ing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangemen ts to ensure that the subsidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. Part of the proceeds from exports of petroleum and iron ore must be surrendered to the Central Bank at 493 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Bs 4.20 per US$1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need not) sell exchange proceeds to the Central Bank at Bs 4.285 per US$1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from fa l l ing below speci- fied m in imum amounts regardless of external prices for these products. Eligibility for this subsidy is maintained even if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements based on guaranteed m in imum prices may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. Non- traditional exports, as well as certain agricultural exports, are eligible for freely negotiable tax certificates, as an export incentive, provided that the value added nation- ally is at least 30 per cent. All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited, as are exports of petroleum and military equip- ment to the People's Republic of China and North Korea. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely dispos- able. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is reserved for the Central Bank. Capital All inward and outward capital transfers are per- mitted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, how- ever, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. Foreign capital imported for investment purposes and all foreign credits must be registered with SIEX. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law of December 30, 1970 (as amended on September 7, 1974 and on May 22, 1975) authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan .gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur- poses. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely 494 negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses f rom the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also from the Ministry of Development, while exports are licensed by the Ministry of Finance only. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Ministry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice imports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs du ty; all other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. All imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consular duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3*/2 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1975 January 1. The iron ore mining industry was national- ized. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA (Position on December 31,1975) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Western Samoa Tala has been established with the Fund. A central rate of WS$1 = US$1.67736 was established in 1973. The interven- tion currency is the U.S. dollar, and Western Samoa avails itself of wider margins. Since October 27, 1975 the exchange rate for the tala has been determined daily on the basis of the weighted basket of currencies used by New Zealand. On December 31, 1975 the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were WS$0.7574 and WS$0.7755, respectively, per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Finance operating as the exchange control authority; the Minister may delegate his approval authority to the Financial Secretary, who in tu rn may delegate part of his powers to authorized banks. All payments to non- residents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry, however, has dele- gated to the Bank of Western Samoa, the only autho- rized bank, authority to approve certain payments up to any amount and certain other payments up to speci- fied amounts. Prescription of Currency Western Samoa has ceased to be a Scheduled Terri- tory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Most settlements with Sterling Area ter- ritories take place in Sterling Area currencies, but there are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which pay- ments to or f rom nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from all sources for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported f rom any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual alloca- tion of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a semiannual basis, which may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited, except automobiles.1 The allocations are made by the Ministry of Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the 1 Rice, flour, sugar, milk products, and canned fish may be imported freely outside the allocation system. 496 latter automatically provides the foreign exchange required for import payments upon submission of docu- mentary evidence. Persons who are not licensed import- ers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for imports of higher value. The import of all motor vehicles requires an advance deposit of 50 per cent of the retail value. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas con- tractual obligations and insurance, are approved auto- matically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or within limits determined by the Ministry of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for all other invisibles require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Remittances in respect of study abroad are freely authorized. The Min- istry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pensions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons permanently resident overseas. Residents traveling to American Samoa, whether for business or private purposes, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$50 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$15 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other countries is equivalent to WS$10 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000. The Ministry of Finance grants supplementary alloca- tions when evidence of genuine need is provided. Resi- dent travelers may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance. Travelers may not take out any domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic short- ages. Copra exports are controlled by the Copra Board and banana exports by the Produce Marketing Division of the Ministry of Agriculture. Export proceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa within a reasonable time after shipment. Where exceptional cir- cumstances exist, the Ministry of Finance may waive this requirement for certain export items. Proceeds from Invisibles All receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Resident travelers must on return sell to the Bank all foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but no domestic banknotes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital All outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the M in is t ry of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by nonbank residents does require approval. The t rans fer of legacies f rom estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries permanen t ly residing overseas is approved up to a l im it of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of West- ern Samoa approves t rans fe rs of g i f ts to relatives and dependents, either for special f am i ly occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$200 a year for each fam- ily group. Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incen- tive Act No. 27/1965, as amended in 1969, makes pro- vision for the gran t ing of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the repa t r ia t ion of capital and profit remittances on fore ign capital are subject to approval by the M in is ter of Finance; such approval is norma l ly gran ted. Gold Residents may free ly purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or exports^ of gold in any form. WESTERN SAMOA Changes during 1975 January I. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established. All transac- tions take place in a free market at an exchange rate which in principle is a fluctuating one but since Febru- ary 1973 has remained unchanged. On December 31, 1975 the rate for the U.S. dollar was YR1 1 = US$0.22. Exchange rates for other currencies are fixed daily by the Central Bank on the basis of London cross rates against the U.S. dollar. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Economy who has the authority to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. The only commercial banks and authorized dealers are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development and seven branches of foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements.1 Settlements are usually made in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of a few commodities are reserved for the Government. All other imports require import licenses. These are issued freely for all commodities for which government agencies or firms with government participation do not have the exclusive right of importation; three firms have such rights, for cigarettes, petroleum products, and medical supplies, respectively. In addition to a license, the impor- tation of certain commodities requires the permission of certain government agencies. The importation of cer- tain textiles requires the approval of the Sanaa textile factory. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad also require an import license. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the local banks or the free market; a m in imum margin deposit of 20 per cent is prescribed against letters of credit. In addition to the applicable customs duty, imports are subject to a defense tax of 5 per cent and a statistical tax of 2 per cent. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles may be made freely. Travelers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. 1 There is an inoperative bilateral payments arrangement with Egypt. 498 Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical pur- poses only, all exports require registration forms, which are issued freely by banks; export licenses are not required. Exporters are not required to surrender the foreign exchange proceeds; these may be retained in for- eign currency accounts w i th domestic banks. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered but may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital No restrictions are imposed on inward or outward capital transfers. Both domestic and foreign investment are regulated by Law No. 18 of 1975. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Republic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits after taxes or of their capital. Gold Two commemorative gold coins of YRls 20 and YRls 30 have been issued, which do not circulate in the Yemen Arab Republic. By virtue of Ministerial Decree No. 21/1973 residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an import, export, or exchange license. Changes during 1975 June 22. Decree No. 26 of the Ministry of Informa- tion lifted the ban on imports of television sets. August 20. Law No. 23 of 1975 was enacted, which formally eliminated certain trade control and exchange control regulations which had not been enforced for some time. The authority to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports was transferred from the Central Bank to the Minister of Economy (with effect from November 15). The law also exempted the import and export of domestic and foreign currency by travelers from prior Central Bank approval. It came into force immediately and superseded the Exchange Control Law, Law No. 16 of 1964. August 20. A new Investment Law, Law No. 18 of 1975, was enacted. It was applicable to investment by Yemenis as well as foreign nationals and superseded Law No. 13 of 1970. October 16. The granting of licenses for imports from Japan was suspended. The suspension was terminated in early 1976. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni Dinar, which is issued by the Bank of Yemen ( the central bank) and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold. No par value for the Yemeni d inar has been established with the Fund. Since February 1973, the central rate has been YD 1 = US$2.89523 or US$1 = YD 0.345395. On December 31, 1975, the Na t ional Bank of Yemen's buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Yemen's General Department for Exchange Control through the Foreign Exchange Com- mittee, which has delegated certain powers to the Direc- tor of Exchange Control, a member of the Committee. The Ministry of Economy and Indus try issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be car- ried out through the in termed iary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Exchange Con tro l); at present the only commercial bank and authorized dealer is the National Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the authorized dealer, and for payments by the oil refinery, all payments for imports ( inc lud ing those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Two public corporations are engaged in foreign trade (see section on Imports and Import Payments, be low). The oil refinery is treated as a resi- dent entity but in its operations generally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the inter- mediary of authorized dealers in accordance with pre- scription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United King- dom. All payments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohib- ited. Export proceeds and certain receipts f rom invisi- bles must be received in prescribed currencies l and 1 Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche m a rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwa i ti dinars, Lebanese pounds, Nether- lands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss f rancs, and U.S. dollars. surrendered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held by certain persons not resident in the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. External Accounts in Yemeni dinars may be credited with proceeds f rom convertible foreign cur- rency transferred f rom abroad, with bank interest pay- able on such accounts, and with balances f rom other External Accounts. Transfers f rom abroad must be in the fo rm of bank draf ts; the accounts cannot be credited with payments in the fo rm of foreign banknotes (unless they have been declared to the customs on en t ry ), or w i th locally raised or locally earned funds (except in certain cases specified by the l aw ). External Accounts may be debited for any payments to residents, for trans- fers to other External Accounts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Transfers abroad f rom Nonresident Accounts in Yemeni dinars require the prior approval of the Exchange Control Department. The Foreign Exchange Committee may direct any pay- ment to a nonresident to a Blocked Account. Except with the Committee's prior approval, Blocked Accounts may be debited only for purchases of specified securities. Subject to certain conditions, Yemeni nationals work- ing abroad may establish nonresident accounts in for- eign currencies; balances in these accounts earn interest and are convertible into foreign currency on demand. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the oil refinery require individual licenses. Most overland merchanting trade with the Yemen Arab Republic is also exempt from the licensing requirements. Imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annually. In addition, importers may import any kind of goods with their own exchange; such imports are freely licensed. Payments for imports on a c. & f. basis against letters of credit or documentary d ra f ts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control; most other fo rms of payment for imports require approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. A Board of Trade is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The National Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cigarettes. The National Import Company Ltd. imports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law No. 37 of 1969. The National Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requirements, and most requirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN into and exports from the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls (except in respect of transactions between these zones and the rest of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The basic exchange allowance for tourism, which residents may take up without applying for exchange control approval, is the equivalent of YD 125 a person a trip in travelers checks, drafts, and foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of this amount for children under ten) .2 Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the applica- tion. Foreign employees of approved enterprises and the oil refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent of their total earnings (net of taxes). All insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not per- mitted. Travelers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic banknotes and up to the equivalent of YD 125 in travelers checks, foreign banknotes, or other foreign means of payment. Furthermore, nonresidents may take out any foreign exchange declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports, including petroleum products, are exempt from licenses. All exports to Israel and Rho- desia are prohibited. Except for exports to the Yemen Arab Republic specified by the Foreign Exchange Com- mittee, export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. The proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen Arab Republic may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or received from an External Account) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. However, Yemeni nationals working abroad are allowed to establish non- resident foreign currency accounts. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes but not more than YD 5 in domestic currency. 2 The equivalent of YD 75 for Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kuwait, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Yemen Arab Republic, and the Gulf States. Travelers to the Yemen Arab Republic may alternatively take out up to YRls 1,000 in Yemen rials. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. Expatriates are normally permitted upon departure to remit their liquid funds to their country of permanent residence. Foreign investments that have been approved under the Law for the Organization of Industry and the Pro- motion of Industrial Investment (Law No. 23 of May 14, 1971) may be granted exemptions from import duty and various other tax facilities. All remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remittances abroad by foreign firms under Law No. 23 also are subject to the Exchange Control Law (Law No. 16) and in any one year should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or a foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after entry. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm concerned has been established may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed gold- smiths may purchase, hold, and sell other unworked gold and gold coins and ornaments. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numis- matic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the Ministry of Economy and Industry (General Department for For- eign Trade); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Travelers may bring in or take out reasonable amounts of gold, in the form of ornaments only (not exceeding YD 100 in value for departing travelers). Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs control, but if incoming nonresident travelers wish to sell any gold coins or bullion, they must sell them to an author- ized dealer.
