Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0433330 gram of fine gold per Yugoslav Dinar. Since July 12, 1973 the authorities have not ma in ta ined the exchange rate of the d inar w i th in announced marg ins and therefore all transac- tions, except for receipts and payments effected under the procedures set forth for certain countries with which Yugoslavia has bilateral payments agreements, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the foreign exchange market in Belgrade on December 31, 1975 were Din 17.9720 and Din 18.0260 per US$1, respectively. The currencies dealt in are Australian dollars, Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Finnish markkaa, French francs, Iraqi dinars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti d inars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds ster- ling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these ma t ters, the Fed- eral Executive Council prescribes the general provisions in respect of foreign trade and exchange transactions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by v ir tue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regula- tions, makes decisions governing commercial transac- tions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing balanced trade with payments agreement countries. The Federal Secre- tariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange transactions. This Secretariat and the National Bank of Yugoslavia adm in is ter the exchange controls. The Na t ional Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and f rom foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a m in imum credit fund of Din 500 million and deposits of at least Din 1,000 million, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugoslavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations (includ- ing the gran t ing of gua ran tees ). Limited authorized banks, which must have a m in imum credit fund amoun t- ing to Din 100 million and deposits of at least Din 200 million, may conduct fore ign exchange opera- tions in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fu l ly authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices may only deal in foreign bankno tes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks, hotels, and specifically authorized tourist agencies. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (bo th producing and trading unde r tak ings) registered for this purpose. Registration is effected automatically, provided that certain condi- tions, inc lud ing the provision of m in imum working capital for trade enterprises, are fu lf i l led. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organiza- tions which export and /or import on their own behalf. Prescription of Currency Payments to and f rom countries w i th which Yugo- slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set for th in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requ ir ing settlements through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U.S. dollars with A fghan is tan, A lban ia, Algeria,1 Brazil, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Ghana, Greece, Hun- gary, Mongolia, and the U.S.S.R.; and (2) in pounds sterling w i th Nor th Viet-Nam. Certain settlements with Bangladesh, Colombia, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. A degree of mu l t i la tera l iza t ion of payments is provided under the bilateral payments agreements w i th A fghan i s tan, Ghana, and Hungary. For purposes of import and export licensing and the operation of nonresident accounts, Ghana and Hungary are considered to belong to the convertible area. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts denom ina ted in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. For- eigners resident outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies in Yugoslavia. For- eign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with authorized banks accounts expressed in fore ign currencies or dinars. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident ju r id ical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited.2 Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con- vertible currency. Transfers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kep t; outward transfers in other convertible currencies 1 Settlements w i th Algeria took place in convertible currencies with effect f r om Janua ry 1, 1976. 2 Accounts may be denominated in any of the following currencies: Au s t r ian schillings, Belgian f rancs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Finnish ma rkkaa, French f rancs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian k rone r, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish k rono r, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. Other con- vertible currencies must be converted into one or more of the forego ing currencies. 501 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA are subject to the account-holding bank being prepared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be opened only for certain foreign juridical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugo- slavia or for retransfer to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Foreign juridical and physical persons may freely open nonresident accounts in convertible dinars with authorized banks. Such accounts can be credited freely with amounts whose transfer in convertible currency has been authorized and they may be debited freely for permitted payments in Yugoslavia and for transfer abroad in the convertible currency of the account hold- er's country of domicile. Nonresident juridical and physical persons may also open other dinar accounts with authorized banks. These other accounts may be credited with dinars required in Yugoslavia in accordance with the existing regulations. Balances are, in principle, nontransferable and may be spent in Yugoslavia only for noncommercial payments by the account holder or by members of his close family, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign juridical person. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or from work performed in Yugoslavia by foreigners, from pen- sions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony payments, transfers may be effected in accordance with the existing regulations. Resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange accounts or foreign exchange savings deposits in con- vertible currencies with any authorized bank. These accounts are kept in the currency deposited, are interest bearing, and interest is paid in the foreign currency deposited. Foreign exchange accounts may be retained for an indefinite period of time and may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the account holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferable to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, below). Yugoslav emigrants residing abroad and former emigrants return- ing to Yugoslavia may also open foreign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be maintained by resident nationals. In the case of the currencies of certain Eastern European coun- tries 3 and Mongolia, the accounts are denominated in dollars of account, and for North Viet-Nam in pounds sterling of account; for other bilateral currencies the accounts are kept in the currency deposited. In general, balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugo- slavia or for retransfers to the bilateral country to which the account is related. 3 Albania, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, and U.S.S.R. 502 Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco- nomic organizations registered as participating in for- eign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial pro- ducers are registered. The import of certain basic food- stuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oils, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. For most commodities import licenses are not re- quired. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in five categories, largely in accordance with the manner in which exchange is made available: LB—liberalized goods; DL—goods liberalized under special license; GDK—goods imported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK—goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quotas are fixed by quantity and DK if they are fixed in d ina rs ); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. Goods in the LB category are mainly raw materials, foodstuffs, and spare parts, but they also include some consumer goods. Protective equipment for workers and all other goods not specifically included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. Exchange for payments for LB imports from the convertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of liberalized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. DL goods comprise certain consumer items, for which special licenses are required for statistical and recording purposes. The Secretariat for Foreign Trade is obliged to issue the license within 20 days from the date of application. Once the license is obtained the importer may freely acquire foreign exchange for the import payment in the same manner as for LB goods. The GDK list comprises raw materials, other repro- duction materials, most capital equipment, and most of those consumer goods not liberalized under the LB and DL regimes. Such imports can be made under several different procedures. Those for nonconsumer goods are as follows: Each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be financed from specific exchange allocations; a con- siderable portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Pro- ceeds, below), funds originating in depreciation allow- ances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The specific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large investment projects, including public ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Economic organizations may acquire for- eign exchange at a predetermined proportion of their annual depreciation allowance, a ratio that varies according to the economic sector involved. For con- sumer goods, t rad ing enterprises agree w i th in the Eco- nomic Chambers on the distribution of GDK quotas among themselves; if the enterprises are unable to agree among themselves on a GDK allocation, the Federal Secretariat for Market and Prices will allocate this quota among them. Imports under commod i ty quotas (list RK or list DK), ma in ly selected agr icu l tural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also machine tools and certain plastics, are subject to quotas estab- lished for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quan t i t ies ( R K) or in d ina rs (DK ). There are separate quotas in each case for imports f rom convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organizations.4 Exchange is provided automatically for payments for impor ts of goods subject to the RK and DK regime, but only up to a predetermined quan t i ty or amount for each item. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammun i t ion, op ium, motor vehicles, tractors, railroad ro l l ing stock, a i rc ra f t, fer t i l izers, na tu ral gas, and b i tumen. Import licenses are required only for list D commodities. These licenses au toma t ica l ly en t i t le an en terpr ise to purchase the requ is i te fore ign exchange. There is also a special list of goods whose import by enterprises requires ad hoc permission by the Secre- ta r iat for Foreign Trade, irrespective of any other requirement described above.5 At the end of 1975, the list comprised 413 items corresponding to 30.3 per cent of 1974 imports. For certain goods there is an additional requ iremen t, irrespective of those set out above, of a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1975 these goods were 61 LB items, 5 RK items, 2 DK items, and 1 D item. For all items concerned, the Secretariat may prescribe direct impor ta t ion f rom the coun try of or ig in; these items include a wide range of tropical foodstuffs and f ru i t s, raw ma ter ia ls, fa ts, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Self-employed Yugoslav nationals may freely and at any time import machinery for small farms or equipment for hand ic ra ft production, up to Din 80,000 a shipment. Also, Yugoslavs re tu rn ing f rom work abroad and non- residents residing in Yugoslavia for more than three mon ths may import goods up to Din 80,000 intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided such goods were paid for from the savings f rom their foreign earnings; such savings may be held abroad or in foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals work ing abroad may import automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, provided that impo r ta t ion is effected through a registered enter- prise and payment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav and foreign nationals are exempt f rom this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the fo l low ing circumstances: when they return for per- manent residence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is inhe r i ted; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance ind emn i ty received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad con t inuous ly and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens returning from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of the ir household. However, if the value of the goods exceeds Din 5,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the customs duties are paid. Compensation transac t ions are only authorized in exceptional circumstances. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 3 per cent equalization tax ("contingency tax") 6 are payable on all commodities not exempt from customs duty. In addition, an import surcharge of 10 per cent of the c.i.f. va lue at the border has to be paid for all du t iab le commodities, with the exception that the sur- charge is levied at a reduced rate of 5 per cen t7 for capital equ ipment for the development of basic primary product industries, for some reproduction materials, and for certain essential items such as butter, wheat flour, hides, and raw cotton. Many agricultural com- modities are subject to variable import levies. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans- actions, including transportation, are fully liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Pay- ments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia main- tains bilateral payments arrangements, then such pay- ments may be made only if the agreement in question provides for this to be done on a reciprocal basis. Authorized banks may sell foreign currency up to the equivalent of Din 1,000 for remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The National Bank may authorize the sale of any amount of foreign exchange for the foregoing and for unspecified purposes when justified in light of the circumstances. Purchases of services abroad, as well as spare parts, fuel, etc., by Yugoslav enterprises involved in international freight and passenger transportation are liberalized. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. However, travel agencies may sell orga- nized tours abroad against payment in dinars up to an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of their individual retention quotas. The National Bank may also authorize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. Payments for other in- visibles may be made from the remitter's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and sociopolitical organizations, from specific annual allocations). Not more than Din 1,000 in domestic currency, in denominations of Din 100 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange without declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market (including petroleum and petroleum derivatives and certain livestock) and certain other materials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade ("ac- cordance"). Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported within a certain period (global approva l). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an undertaking to import from such countries or to export to other countries. In accordance with bilateral arrangements, Yugoslavia restrains exports of certain commodities to specified countries. 504 Proceeds from exports must be repatriated within 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The surrender of these proceeds is not required. The full export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter maintains with an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the rele- vant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged in setting up trade fairs, and by film enter- prises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefinitely or used for certain payments abroad, but cannot earn interest. The permitted reten- tion rate is 20 per cent for all export earnings from goods and services, with the exception that a rate of 45 per cent applies to tourist organizations and a rate of 100 per cent applies to foreign exchange earnings of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad and to Yugoslav enterprises operating under long-term cooperation agree- ments with foreign companies. (Enterprises with long- term cooperation agreements may in any case import up to the value of their production which is a result of that cooperation.) In some instances (services rendered to foreign tourists and sales of newly mined gold to the National B a n k ), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota pur- poses. Producing enterprises selling specified consumer goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 20 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 90 days from the date on which the claim is payable. The performance of construction and engineering services in payments agreement countries is subject to an "accordance" issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. Receipts from services are eligible for retention quotas; the quota for hotels and tourist agen- cies is 45 per cent. Exchange proceeds may be used for payments abroad connected with the activities of the economic organization concerned, including payments for purchases of equipment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to economic organizations other than those with which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, while em- ©International Monetary Fund. Foreign firms are permitted to establish representational offices in Yugoslavia. Foreign ju r id ical and physical persons are perm i t ted to purchase bonds issued by Yugoslav enter- prises, sociopolitical commun i t ies, and other sociolegal persons. The investment income earned abroad by Yugoslav economic organizations must be repatriated w i th in 90 days; however, when repatriated the profits are governed by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, with the exception of inher- itances, to surrender all foreign exchange held or accru- ing abroad on capital account. Gold The National Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to customs declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been purchased in Yugoslavia. Residents who are private persons may hold gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the National Bank or to any authorized bank, and they may freely hold, purchase, impor t, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been registered as trad ing in gold may import gold jewelry under the GDK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Authorized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the rate of Din 17 per U.S. dollar to a price of US$42.22 an ounce) are re- garded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the pro- ducers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic eco- nomic organizations using gold for their normal activi- ties may purchase gold f rom domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each such organization individually. Changes during 1975 January 1. Following the expiration on December 31, 1974 of the bilateral payments agreements with Bul- garia, Poland, and Roman ia, settlements w i th these countries were placed on a convertible currency basis. January 10. Foreign f inanc ial credits for the purchase of equipment intended for investment in jo int enter- prises in developing countries became exempt f rom the deposit requirement. January 31. The bilateral payments agreement with Iraq expired. February 15. Foreign f inanc ial credits for the pur- chase of equipment for use in connection with projects of the International Bank for Reconstruction and De- velopment outside Yugoslavia became exempt from the deposit requirement. February 15. Modifications were introduced in the regulations concerning the holding of nonresident accounts. 506 February 21. The import surcharge was reduced to 2 per cent for a number of goods imported for the use of the Yugoslav Railways. February 28. Petroleum, natural gas, and coke were transferred f rom the LB import regime to the D import regime. Petroleum and petroleum products were also transferred from the LB export regime to the D export regime. March 7. Import duties on equipment imported under long-term production cooperation agreements were reduced by 40 per cent for the remainder of 1975. March 28. Oilseeds and vegetable oils were trans- ferred f rom the LB to the D export regime. March 28. Quotas for imports dur ing 1975 of coffee, corn, rice, and sugar were fixed. April 5. Foreign financial credits for the import of equipment for priority industrial sectors (as defined in the Resolution on Social and Economic Policy for 1975) were freed f rom the deposit requirement. April 11. Some 130 goods corresponding to about 2.3 per cent of 1974 imports were transferred from the LB to the D impo rt regime un t il December 31. On Janua ry 1, 1976, they reverted to their original classifi- cation. Engine oil was transferred f rom the DL to the D import regime. April 30. The import surcharge was increased from 6 per cent to 10 per cent; the special lower rate was increased f rom 2 per cent to 5 per cent. May 31. A decision of the Federal Executive Council was gazetted providing that organizations which contract impo r ts must submit documents showing that they have "assured foreign exchange for the payment of contracted imports." It was understood that "assured foreign ex- change" included export earnings in 1975. June 7. All interest on resident foreign exchange accounts was authorized to be paid in foreign exchange; previously, interest was payable partially in dinars. June 13. Some 31 items were removed from the DL import regime; 3 were placed under the LB regime and 2 under the RK, 13 under the DK, and 13 under the D regimes. June 21. The import of some 413 items amounting to 30.3 per cent of 1974 imports was made subject to the ad hoc approval of the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade under the special accordance procedure; imports of goods under the provisions of long-term production cooperation agreements with foreign companies were exempt. The requ irement of a special accordance was term ina ted on December 31. June 26. The advance import deposit requirements introduced in August 1974 were abolished. July 5. A law came into force which empowered the Na t ional Bank to issue bonds on foreign markets, up to US$50 m i l l ion, for purposes of strengthening the na- t ional exchange reserves. July 19. The Australian dollar was added to the Na t ional Bank's list of "currencies significant for main- taining l iqu id i ty for international payments." ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Zaire. A central rate of Z 1 = US$2 has been established,1 and Zaire avails itself of wider marg ins. The interven- tion currency is the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Zai're (the central b a n k) quotes an official rate of exchange for the Belgian f ranc based on the rate for the zaire quoted on the official exchange market in Brussels. The buy ing and selling rates for other quoted currencies, except the U.S. dollar, the French franc, and the CFA franc, also are based on official market rates in Brussels. For the U.S. dollar, the Bank of Zaire quotes a fixed rate of Z 1 = US$2, buying and selling. Quotations for the French f ranc and the CFA f ranc are based on daily quotations for the zaire in the official exchange market in Paris. Forward exchange transactions are prohibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zaire has regulatory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to authorize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to permit the impor ta t ion, exportation, and t rans it of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments f rom nonresidents must be received in listed convertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Zaire.2 Special authorization for the acceptance of other currency may only be given in respect of currencies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. However, certain settlements w i th Bu rund i, Rwanda, and Uganda are made through special accounts established under arrangements concluded by the Bank of Zaire with the central banks of the countries concerned. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Accounts in Zaires, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zaires. Nonresident Accounts in Zaires may only be debited with the approval of the Bank of Zai're. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and in terna t ional organizations established in Zaire, may be debited freely but may be credited only with the proceeds of sales of foreign currency and with payments made by the Government. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be cred- ited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; they !With effect from March 12, 1976 the central ra te was changed to Z 1 = SDR 1. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canad ian dollars, CFA francs, Danish k rone r, deutsche ma rk, French francs, I ta l ian lire, Ne the r lands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 508 may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Resident and Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident Zairian nationals require special authorization from the central bank to open these accounts w i th authorized banks; nonresident for- eigners may open them freely. Convertible Accounts in Zaires may be credited in accordance with Circular No. 131 3 and debited freely for conversion into foreign currency or for any pay- ments in domestic currency. Such accounts may be held by both residents and nonresidents but must not be credited with payments for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammun i t ion, narcotics, and jukeboxes. The importation of certain automobiles is prohibited for economic rea- sons. Import licenses submitted to the Bank of Zai're for prior approval are required for most commodities other than certain priority items (ma in ly foodstuffs, Pharmaceuticals, and intermediate goods). For most goods subject to license the importer must obtain either a discount of 6 per cent from the exporter's list price or a credit of at least 180 days after shipment. Those imports which are not subject to import license approved by the Bank of Zaire are subject to import declarations, which do not require the approval of the central bank. The central bank has issued a general import and pay- ments license which for such goods guarantees the availability of foreign exchange4 when payments fall due, provided that the importer files an import declara- tion with his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that invoice price and quality have been verified and found acceptable by the foreign cor- respondents of the Office Zairois de Controle. Such verification is also required for all other imports. Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made out at authorized banks, which forward the applications to the central bank af ter certification. Af ter approval of the applica- tion by the central bank, which is given in the form of a visa, the import license application is returned to the in termed iary authorized bank for validation. Import licenses validated by the authorized banks remain valid for customs clearance for six months starting from the first day of the month following that in which validation by the commercial bank takes place. Foreign exchange is in principle made available for all licensed imports, the validated license constituting at the same time an 3 Conversion of foreign cu r rency at the official rate, transfer from another Convertible Account in Zaires, or authorized payments by residents to nonresidents. 4 This guaran tee has been temporar i ly suspended. ©International Monetary Fund. For certain p r io r i ty impor ts covered by trade credits of 60 days or more the Bank of Zaire is prepared to gua ran tee the provision of fore ign exchange when the payment fa l ls due. The counterpart of the value of goods impor ted under the Belgian food aid p rog ram, the U.S. impo rt support program, and the ag r icu l tu ral aid program must be deposited w i th in 120 to 180 days a f ter their shipment. All imports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem and a turnover tax of 9 per cent. In addi- tion, most impor ts, irrespective of o r ig in, are subject to a tempo ra ry impo rt surcharge of either 5 per cent or 20 per cent ad va lorem on the c . i .f. value. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports not covered by general license require ind iv idual declarations. Banks are no rma l ly authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters unde r- take to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration ZAIRE must specify the na ture of the merchandise to be exported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally valid for three months; within this period, the proceeds must be received and surrendered. Most exports of minerals are subject to special regulations to take into account the t ime required for processing abroad. For mineral products exported by the Generate des Carrieres et M ines du Zaire (GECAM INE S ), a provisional payment of a variable portion of the shipment's estimated value has to be received and surrendered within 8 days after sh ipmen t. For diamond exports, two thirds of the value established at a p re l im ina ry examination in Zaire must be surrendered before the shipment is dispatched. Export proceeds f rom coffee must be surrendered w i th in 45 days a f ter sh ipmen t. Receipts f rom other agricultural exports must generally be repatriated w i th in three months of va l ida t ion. The exportation of coffee is a monopoly of the Na t ional Coffee Office. M in imum export prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, and certain other commodities. All exports are sub ject to a statistical tax of 1 per cent ad va lorem, and all commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange receipts f rom invisibles must be sur- rendered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is proh ib i ted. Nonresident travelers may bring in any am o u nt in fo re ign means of payment and may take out on depa r tu re the amount declared on entry, less the e q u i v a l e nt of Z 20 a calendar day spent in Zaire. Capital The repa t r ia t ion of new fore ign capital brought in und er the provisions of the Investment Code (Ordi- nance-Law No. 69-032 of June 26, 1969 as amended by Law No. 74-004 of 1974) is guaranteed, as is the trans- fer of p ro f i ts and dividends on such capital. With minor exceptions, other t rans fe rs abroad of capital owned by residents or nonres iden ts are not permitted. Gratuitous t ran s fe rs of real estate are subject to approval by execu- t ive o rd inance. The fore ign currency assets of the au tho r ized banks are not permitted to exceed their short- te rm l iab i l i t ies in fo re ign currencies. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, pro- ducers of gold, and indus t r ial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any fo rm other than jewe l ry, at home or abroad. The import and export of gold in any fo rm, except jewelry constituting the per- sonal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the central bank. Producers are not required to sell their production to the central bank. All newly produced gold is exported, w i th the exception of small quantities used domestically for the manu fac tu re of jewelry. 509 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE Changes during 1975 January 1. All construction firms and firms producing construction materials were placed under government control, as were large enterprises in the fields of d is tr ibu- tion and public transpor t; fore ign enterprises subject to the provisions of the Investment Code were exempted f rom the measure. Foreign banks would not be allowed to open branches outside Kinshasa. January 5. It was announced that Zairian citizens were required to t ran s fer to the State any immovable property or securities they held abroad. January 6. Central Bank Circular No. 147 provided that imports could not be shipped to Zai're w i thout prior attestation by the Office Zairois de Controle; the attesta- tion now became necessary also to open a documen tary credit in favor of the shipper. January 10. With effect f rom Janua ry 8, Circular No. 148 added a large number of commodities to the list of goods subject to import licensing (List A ), mostly textiles, garmen ts, and footwear. January 28. Circular No. 149 provided that all physi- cal persons of Za i r ian na t iona l i ty and all ju r id ical per- sons constituted according to Za ir ian law were required to repa tr ia te by September 30, 1975 any bank balances they held abroad that were denom ina ted in foreign cur- rencies. Such persons could open Repatriation Accounts with authorized banks in Zai're. These were anonymous numbered accounts denominated in fore ign currencies. They could only be credited with repatriated bank bal- ances; they could be debited free ly only for the payment of amoun ts due in zaires to residents or for the sale to an authorized bank of foreign currency balances held on these accounts. January 29. The existing open license system for imports, under which licenses w i th the visa of the Bank of Zaire were required only for items in List A, was replaced with a negative list system. Henceforth, all commodities were subject to licenses approved by the Bank of Zai're, except for a small number of specified items (ma in ly essential foods tu f fs, Pharmaceuticals, and intermediate goods). For many goods, licenses were not norma l ly issued. Documentary sight credits payable upon shipment for commodities subject to license were to be limited in 1975 to 10 per cent of their 1974 level. For other imports of goods subject to license (imports pay- able upon a r r iva l ), the importer was required to obtain either a trade credit of at least 180 days f rom the date of shipment, or a discount of 6 per cent f rom the current list price for the commodity ( for in termed ia te goods subject to license, however, the previous requirement of a 90-day credit or a 3 per cent d iscount was re ta ined ). (Letter No. 6821.) January 29. Transfers of rents and t rans fe rs for expenses of purchasing or representative offices abroad were suspended. Transfers of profits and dividends, which had been suspended de facto since Novem- ber 1973, were forma l ly suspended, w i th the exception 510 that fore ign shareholders employed in a local enterprise (associes actifs) were permitted to remit profits in 12 mon th ly ins ta l lmen ts following the completion of the enterprise's fiscal year. The restrictions on transfers of ren ts, profits, and dividends did not apply to firms for which guarantees existed under the Investment Code or under bilateral intergovernmental agreements (Letter No. 6821 ). February 12. Exemption f rom import licensing was extended to a number of additional priority products (Letter No. 7794). March. An indicative foreign exchange budget was introduced. March 24. Imports of foods tu f fs and Pharmaceuticals or ig ina t ing in or shipped f rom Belgium were made sub- ject to specific licensing. In principle such imports were to be limited to 15 per cent of their 1974 level. June 20. The impor ta t ion of certain foodstuffs and pharmaceu t ical products was reserved exclusively to specified local companies. July 31. For certain priority imports covered by trade credits of 60 days or more, the central bank was pre- pared to guaran tee the provision of the necessary foreign exchange when the payment fell due (Letter No. 7250). Subsequently, additional items became eligible for this guarantee. July 31. Salary transfers abroad on behalf of expatri- ates work ing in Zai're were limited, at both the individ- ual and the global level, to the amoun ts transferred in 1974. No new expatriates could be hired except for the setting up of new enterprises or to replace departing employees; central bank approval was required for each ind iv idual hired. No enterprises could increase individ- ual expatriate salaries. Insurance premiums, vacation allowances, and social security premiums of expatriates had to be deposited in special accounts, from which transfers abroad could be permitted in due course at the discretion of the central bank. Shipping insurance on imports payable upon shipment had to be taken out with SON AS; as before, insurance in foreign currency was only allowed for imports payable after arrival (Letter No. 7250). August 18. The President announced that Zai're would begin to accept payment in Afr ican currencies for its exports. September 1. The importation of pharmaceutical products was reserved for a government agency. September 27. Agreement was reached with Belgium on the creation of a Belgian-Zai'rian jo int committee to examine bilateral relations. October 22. The 1973 ban on exports of timber was lifted. November 25. The President announced a "new eco- nomic policy." The activities of the private sector and the mixed economy sector would be accentuated. December 30. A decision in principle was announced to re turn certain nationalized enterprises to the former owners. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA (Position on December 31, 1975) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.14592 grams of fine gold per Zamb ian Kwacha, and Zamb ia avails itself of w ider ma rg ins. The effective pa r i ty re la t ionsh ip for the U.S. do l la r, the in te rven t ion currency, is K 1 = US$1.55556 or US$1 =K 0.642856. The Bank of Zambia m a in t a ins fixed buy ing and se l l ing rates for the U.S. do l lar. Since Feb rua ry 15, 1973, these rates have been Mo of 1 per cent below pa r i ty for b u y i ng (US$1 = K 0.64246) and V-i of 1 per cent above pa r i ty for selling (US$1 = K 0 .64447). The Bank of Zamb ia deals on ly w i th au thor ized commerc ial banks in Zamb ia. The au thor ized banks no rma l ly charge an add i t ional }£ of 1 per cent plus any cable costs when dea l ing w i th customers. The Bank of Zamb ia bases its rates for sterling on the cu r rent rates for the U.S. dollar in the London marke t; it nor- ma l ly deals only in U.S. dollars and s te r l ing. Au thor ized banks are f ree to deal w i th customers in o ther cu r ren- cies, and base their rates on the Bank of Zambia's rates for the U.S. dollar and the current London ma rket rates for the currencies concerned. Administration of Control Exchange control is adm in i s te red by the Bank of Zamb ia under powers delegated to it by the M in i s ter of Finance. Much of the au tho r i ty for app rov ing no rmal current paymen ts is in tu rn delegated to commerc ial banks au thor ized to deal in fo re ign exchange. The con- trol of trade is the respons ib i l i ty of the M in is ter of Com- merce, who also issues impo rt and export licenses. Over- all impo rt policy is made by a comm i t tee on which the M in is try of Commerce, the M in i s t ry of F inance, and the Bank of Zambia are represented. Prescription of Currency Zamb ia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U .K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U.K. exchange control regu la t ions con- t inues to be regarded as a coun try of the Overseas Ster- l ing Area. Au thor ized paymen ts, in c lud ing paymen ts for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries other th an Rhodesia may be made in Zamb ian currency to the credit of an External Accoun t, or in any fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Paymen ts f rom residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zamb ian currency f rom an External Account, or in any fo re ign currency freely exchangeable for U.S. dollars or sterling. Special regula- tions apply to settlements w i th Rhodesia. All permitted payments to residents of Rhodesia mu st be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zamb ian currency to an External Account —Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhodesian Account in the United K ingdom, in U.S. dollars, or in Canad ian dollars. Proceeds f rom exports to Rhodesia must be received in U.S. or Canad ian dollars. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian currency held w i th authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited w i th authorized payments f rom residents of Zamb ia, w i th t rans fe rs f rom other External Accounts, and w i th the proceeds f rom sales of any fore ign currency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments for any pur- pose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of any foreign cu r rency other than Rhodesian currency f rom author- ized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zamb ian currency held with au tho r ized banks by residents of any coun try other than Zamb ia are credited w i th non transferab le capital sums in Zamb ian currency and w i th any unrem i t tab le portion of rents which have accrued to nonresidents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. No rma l ly, approval is given for the inves tment of balances on blocked accounts in Zamb ian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on blocked account balances is freely trans- fe rab le to the account holder's coun try of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, which is also blocked. Imports and Import Payments V i r tu a l ly all imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import f rom all countries of certain specified com- modities for health, safety, or moral reasons. Personal and household effects, samples, diplomatic shipments, and means of transpor ta t ion entering Zambia temporarily do not require ind iv idual import licenses, nor do any other goods for personal use and consumption, provided that the person impo r t ing them does not import more than K 50 worth of such goods in any period of 90 days. The two ma jor m in ing companies and the M in is try of Health are granted "blanket licenses" for bona fide requ iremen ts. The Controller of Customs is authorized to adm it emergency goods imported w i thout prior refer- ence to the Ministry of Commerce. All other imports requ ire individual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports w i th in a qua r te r ly exchange allocation established by the Minis- try of Commerce in consultation with the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. All imports under ind iv idual licensing are first divided into SITC 1 three- 1 S tanda rd In te rna t ional Trade Classification. 511 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA digit groups and further subdivided into end-use group- ings. Exchange allocations are specified for each of these categories. Normally, raw ma ter ia ls, in termed ia te goods for further processing in Zambia, Pharmaceuticals, and fuel and electricity are licensed liberally; alcoholic bev- erages, tobacco, durable consumer goods, and other consumer goods are licensed restrictively. No licenses are being issued for specified luxury consumer goods or for items that are produced locally. The Ministry of Commerce has designated certain import agencies as authorized to allocate foreign exchange among individ- ual applicants. These agencies include the National Import and Export Corporation and Zambia Railways. In principle, foreign exchange for import payments is automatically made available once an import license has been obtained, subject to presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. Prior approval by the Bank of Zambia, however, is necessary for payments to Rhodesia and South Africa in excess of K 20,000; payments for imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are not normally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Most imported goods are subject on customs clear- ance to sales tax, at a rate of 25 per cent, calculated on the sum of 120 per cent of the customs value plus the applicable import duty. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as business travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authori- ties, except when payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to Rhodesia or South Afr ica are involved. Special reduced allocations apply to payments for invis- ibles to Rhodesia, and authorized dealers are not per- mitted to make foreign exchange available for travel to Rhodesia. For other countries, exchange is granted as follows. The basic exchange allowance for business travel is K 40 a day for up to 15 days a person a calen- dar year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as education and medical treat- ment. Applications for amoun ts exceeding the limits may in certain circumstances be granted by the exchange control authorities if they are satisfied that exceptional treatment is justified. No exchange is granted for tourist travel. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of payments for advertising, management, accounting, administrative, engineering, and consulting services rendered to residents by nonresidents are subject to individual approval by the Bank of Zambia, which generally grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable, that they relate to exist- ing contracts, and that these services cannot be provided domestically.2 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and 2 Services rendered by a parent company abroad to its branch or wholly owned subsidiary in Zambia are not generally approved. 512 branches of companies whose head offices are situated outside Zambia may be transferred abroad up to 10 per cent of the nonresident share of the equity capital or 30 per cent of net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies, whichever is smaller.3 For- eign companies operating in Zambia may remit declared profits and dividends once a year after the end of the accounting year. The remittance of depreciation allow- ances is not permitted. Remittances of rents to nonresi- dents are restricted to 50 per cent of net annual rental income. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract basis and recruited after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit to their country of domicile a third of their annual earnings. Foreign nationals recruited before December 4, 1971 and still employed on a contract entered into prior to that date are allowed to remit to their country of domicile one half of their annual earn- ings. Foreign na t iona ls availing themselves of these arrangements are not entitled to the regular allowances for travel, education, maintenance, etc.; only one third of their leave pay is transferab le. To fac i l i ta te payments of small amounts, individuals are freely permitted to rem it abroad up to K 10 a mon th for purposes normally approved by the exchange control authorities (including f am i ly m a in t en an c e ). Travelers may not take out Zambian currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports valued at over K 50 require a license; minerals, however, are exported under general agree- ments w i th the m in ing companies. The export of certain metals is reserved, in principle, for an official agency, the Metal Marketing Corporation. Most exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain commodities are sub- ject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, certain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and ju te bags. For most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely, and some goods are covered by an open general license. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of ship- ment; the foreign exchange proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Local borrow ing by companies controlled e i ther d i rec t ly or indirectly f rom outside Zambia is restricted to a d eb t / equ i ty ra t io of 1 to 2. However, the Bank of Zambia permits borrowings in excess of this l im it for ce r ta in p r io r i ty sectors of the economy, provided the borrowings secure higher emp loyment oppo r tun i t ies and /or savings of foreign exchange. In genera l, res iden ts are not pe rm i t ted to t ran s fer capital abroad and, w i th ce r ta in exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an au thor ized bank any fore ign exchange wh ich accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Z amb i an secur i t ies quo ted on recognized stock exchanges ab road, prov ided that the secu r i t ies so acqu i red are registered in the names of specified nom inees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repa- triated. All income earned f rom these investments must be repa t r ia ted. Em ig ran ts are g ran ted exchange as fo l lows: ( 1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on depar ture, and subsequent annu al t rans fe rs of K 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on depar ture, together w i th K 250 for each child, up to a m ax imum of K 5,000 for a f am i ly un i t. Thereaf ter, annual t ran s fe rs of K 3,000, together w i th K 250 for each ch i ld, up to a max imum of K 4,000 for a f am i ly un it are permitted. (3) Unmarr ied persons under 50 are allowed K 2,000 on depa r tu re, and subsequent a n n u al transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emigration a l lowance, em ig ran ts may rem it gra tu i t ies, compensa- t ion paymen ts, and te rm inal bene f i ts up to a max imum of K 8,000 on departure, and up to K 5,000 as annual t ran s fe r s. In add i t ion, there are special fac i l i t ies for expa tr ia te fa rme r s. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zambia for num isma t ic purposes. W i th th is exception, residents other than the mone tary au thor i t ies and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other th an jewe lry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any fo rm o ther th an ZAMBIA jewe lry require exchange control approval as well as impo rt or export licenses issued by the Minister of Com- merce; such licenses are not norma l ly granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary au tho r i t ies and indus t r ial users. Gold-bearing slime is exported by copper companies as a by-product for r e f i n i ng and sale abroad. Foreign exchange for imports of gold may on ly be provided w i th the permission of the Bank of Zamb ia. Changes during 1975 January 2. The external financing of consumer goods and unc lass if ied goods w i th a repayment period of up to 180 days was generally permitted. External financing for cap i tal goods for the agricultural, industrial, trans- port, and construction sectors could be arranged with the specific approval of the Bank of Zambia. January 16. All unu t i l ized import licenses issued since Janua ry 1, 1974 were withdrawn for re-examina- t ion and reva l ida t ion. The cen tral bank began endors ing import licenses. New licenses were issued restrictively. January 31. Import duties on alcoholic beverages, soft d r ink s, cigarettes, gasoline, and diesel fuel were increased; those on motor vehicles were reduced. January 31. Expatriate fa rme rs not remitting abroad under a personal remittance quota were allowed to trans- fer abroad 10 per cent of the aud i ted net profits af ter t a x a t i on per a n n um. On September 22, it was provided that expatriate farmers could have another 10 per cent of aud i ted net profits a f t er taxa t ion held to their credit every year, and that the entire accumulated amount could be rem i t ted on em ig ra t ion f rom Zamb ia, together w i th the no rmal em ig ra t ion allowance. April 1. The customs surcharge of 10 per cent ad valorem was revoked. April 1. Imports became subject to a sales tax of 25 per cent payable on customs clearance and calculated on the customs va lue of the goods plus 20 per cent of the customs va lue plus the applicable import duty. April 14. The capitalization of free reserves was stopped. Only funds qua l i fy ing under the dividend fo rmu la could be capitalized. June 30. The President announced that imports in 1975 would not be allowed to exceed US$800 million. Impo rt licenses would no longer be issued for luxury goods. July 1. The rem i t tance of rent for any premises in terms of Section 3 7 ( 4) was suspended. July 7. The M in is ter of Commerce announced that the impo rt of goods produced locally would no longer be permitted. The goods concerned were specified on October 2. They included radios, television sets, and finished clothing. August 18. All Rhodesian blocked balances were paid over to the Bank of Zambia. September 16. The tourist travel allowance was with- drawn. However, expatriates wo rk ing on a contract basis could use the ir rem i t tab le funds for holiday travel. The 513 ©International Monetary Fund. Permission to remit profits and divi- dends was restricted to 10 per cent (previously 30 per cent) of paid-up capital, and provided that this 10 per cent did not exceed 30 per cent (previously 50 per cen t) of the net profit accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies. September 16. The export and import of Zambian currency, previously permitted up to K 10 a traveler, was prohibited. September 16. The restriction l im i t ing the issue of travelers checks to 50 per cent at the point of embarka- tion was withdrawn. Travelers checks could be provided up to the fu ll amount of any allocation of travel exchange. September 16. Hotels and travel agents were prohib- ited f rom buy ing or selling travelers checks and foreign currency notes. September 16. The Bank of Zambia would no longer consider exchange applications for purchases, take- overs, and participation agreements of any kind. All purchases, takeovers, and participation agreements already in force had to be resubmitted to the Bank for review, and no remittance abroad of funds in respect of dividends, consultancy, and management service agreements becoming due under the arrangements already in force would be allowed without specific and prior exchange control approval. September 19. Remittances of leave pay by expa- triates wo rk ing on a contract basis henceforth were included in their personal remittance quota and were reduced to one th i rd of the sum paid. Similar treatment was extended to commuted payments fo rm ing part of the en t i t lemen t. September 22. Authorized dealers were prohibited f rom rem i t t ing funds on account of travel agents or air- line companies in respect of package tours arranged by them for residents. October 2. The M in is ter of Commerce announced that import restrictions would be intensified. Priority would be given to m in ing equipment, medical supplies, raw ma te r ia ls for indus t ry, and general consumer goods. Among the prohibited items were watches, record play- ers, and cosmetics. In add i t ion, importers would not be allowed to bring in goods which were a monopoly of the Na t ional Import and Export Corporation or other specified agencies. October 2. Under the four th quarter import quotas, only one model of ten listed makes of passenger cars could be imported. October 7.
